article name: Network of Motives to Run for the White House; Donald Trump wouldn't be the first businessman to run for political office when he was initially not serious about winning, but rather more interested in increasing his wealth and promoting his brand.
article text: Regarding Holman Jenkins's "The Donald, and His Wallet, Are Untested " (Business World, Feb. 27): Donald Trump wouldn't be the first businessman to run for political office though he was initially not serious about winning, but rather more interested in increasing his wealth and promoting his brand.My father recalled vividly how W. Lee "Pappy" O'Daniel ran for governor of Texas in 1938, initially just to advertise for his Hillbilly Flour Company. Accompanied by Bob Wills and the Light Crust Doughboys, Pappy O'Daniel handed out hot biscuits on the campaign trail. The biscuits were so well received during the Great Depression that, according to my father, Pappy at some point realized that he actually had a good chance of winning in a crowded field. His populist campaign was effective enough to get him elected governor twice. There are enough parallels between O'Daniel and Mr. Trump to make Mr. Jenkins's analysis especially convincing to me.Gregory O. GinnAustin, TexasThe other night I watched the 1976 movie "Network." Although it is 40 years old, it struck me how the situation for the little guy hasn't improved. Newscaster Howard Beale (the Peter Finch character) tapped into the hopelessness of the obscure.Here we are in 2016 and our Howard Beale is Donald Trump. I doubt this will end well for conservatives.Steve SlaterWaterford, Mich.

article name: President Obama Created Donald Trump; After the cool, weak and endlessly nuanced Obama, no wonder voters are going for a strong, blunt leader.
article text: President Obama doesn't get enough credit for his accomplishments. I know this because he often tells us it is so. I happen to agree that he doesn't get enough credit. No, not for slowing the rise of the oceans or healing the planet, as he immodestly claimed he would, even before taking office. He has succeeded handsomely, though, in living up to his vow to be a transformative president, like Ronald Reagan, and not an incremental one in the Bill Clinton mold. Mr. Obama has accomplished many changes--they just aren't the ones we were waiting for.Mr. Obama has alienated allies like Israel while encouraging adversaries like Iran and Cuba. He has fostered Americans' record-breaking dependence on government programs and record-low participation in the workforce. He has expanded the power, size and expense of the federal government in unprecedented ways, all at the expense of Americans' freedom, standard of living and economic well-being.But the president truly doesn't get enough credit for creating one of the most polarizing forces in American politics today. No, not Hillary--that is more Bill's doing. Let's be honest: There would be no Donald Trump, dominating the political scene today if it were not for President Obama.I believe that voters tend to act in open-seat presidential elections to correct for the perceived deficiencies of the incumbent. In 1980, after four years of President Carter's telling us to turn up the thermostat and wear a cardigan, while the Soviets invaded Afghanistan and the Iranians invaded the U.S. Embassy, the fed-up American people elected a cowboy to the White House who made it clear that the evil empire's days were numbered.After eight years of President Reagan's supply-side economics and broadsides against welfare queens, we got a kinder, gentler President H.W. Bush. After four years of international diplomacy without the "vision thing," we got a loquacious Arkansas governor promising to invent a third way forward focused on the economy at home. After eight years of Clintonian empathy and skirt-chasing, we got a plain-spoken President George W. Bush, who promised to restore integrity to the Oval Office. After Hurricane Katrina and post-Hussein Iraq, we got the professorial President Barack Obama, who seemed to many to promise competence.After seven years of the cool, weak and endlessly nuanced "no drama Obama," voters are looking for a strong leader who speaks in short, declarative sentences. Middle-class incomes are stagnant, and radical Islam is on the march across the Middle East. No wonder voters are responding to someone who promises to make America great again. You can draw a straight line between a president who dismisses domestic terrorist attacks as incidents of workplace violence and a candidate who wants to ban Muslims from entering the country.Mr. Obama likes to bemoan the increasing partisan divides across the country, as if he were merely a passive observer at best and a victim at worst. Uncharacteristically, the president is being too modest. He has created the very rancor he now rails against. Imagine how different things would be if Mr. Obama had pursued a stimulus bill that included targeted tax cuts and infrastructure spending balanced with gradual entitlement reforms--instead of a stimulus that merely dusted off congressional Democrats' wish list of pork-barrel projects and ideological experiments.Imagine if Mr. Obama had actually worked with Republicans in an open process to bring down health-care costs--instead of pushing through, on a partisan vote, the largest expansion of government-welfare programs in a generation. Or if he had listened to the message that voters sent in the first midterm election by putting Republicans in charge of Congress--instead of petulantly relying on executive orders, and using an eraser and whiteout on the Constitution, to shove the Environmental Protection Agency and other federal agencies deeper into Americans' lives.Over the past seven years America could have been transformed in an inspiring way if its education system had been opened up, if its energy policy had been liberated, if the entire approach to governing had been overhauled. President Obama chose the opposite approach, favoring a closed education system that fails millions of children and an energy policy that chains the economy to his green agenda.President Obama loves to construct straw men so he can contrast his heroic self against them. But Donald Trump needs no characterization; he is capable of being absurd on his own, no outside help required. Without President Obama, there is no Donald Trump. Mr. Trump often diagnoses the ills Mr. Obama has caused, but his prescriptions are just as often wrong. America deserves better.Mr. Jindal is the former governor of Louisiana.Credit: By Bobby Jindal

article name: Front-Runners' Wins in Virginia on Super Tuesday Point a Way Forward; Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton show they can forge needed voter coalitions in diverse swing state
article text: Of all their primary victories Tuesday, the wins by Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton in Virginia did the most to show they can forge the voter coalitions needed to win their party's presidential nominations.Racially diverse, with big, urban centers and a large share of college graduates, Virginia stood as a proving ground for candidates in both parties as the nomination races move in coming weeks to other large, diverse states, including Ohio and Florida.The parties' two front-runners won the state in different ways: Mrs. Clinton expanded the coalition she had built in earlier contests; Mr. Trump, while showing growing support among some voter groups, won in large part due to greater intensity among voter groups who were already part of his natural base.Coming in the largest presidential swing state to vote so far, the two paths to victory give clues to the coalitions each candidate might try to form as a party nominee.Mr. Trump has built a dominating position in the presidential race by carrying lower-income voters and those without a four-year college degree. In Virginia, he won those groups with larger margins than he had in prior contests, preliminary exit poll results reported by various media show.Mr. Trump carried a remarkable 52% of voters with household income under $50,000, a far larger share than in his victories in the New Hampshire and South Carolina primaries. He won 44% of voters without a college degree--a larger share than in three of the four contests before Super Tuesday. Those voter groups remain the pillars of his candidacy.At the same time, Mr. Trump was able to deprive Sen. Marco Rubio, his top rival in the state, of big margins among his own natural base, including college graduates and voters with the highest incomes. Mr. Rubio won those groups--but not by the vote totals needed to overcome the bounding support Mr. Trump enjoyed among his own core groups. With almost all precincts reporting, Mr. Trump edged Mr. Rubio in the state, 35% to 32%.Mr. Trump's coalition took on different contours that suggest growing acceptance by some parts of the party and hesitancy among others after weeks of a coarsening nomination battle. Mr. Trump's share of self-described moderate voters in Virginia was lower by far than in any prior contest. He carried only 23% of that group, exit polls reported by media showed, compared to about one-third of voters in three prior contests and 55% in the Nevada caucuses.At the same time, he won a larger share of evangelical Christians than in any prior contest but one.Mrs. Clinton, in contrast to Mr. Trump, expanded the coalition she had built in prior contests.She carried 58% of white voters, preliminary exit poll results showed, compared to 54% in last weekend's South Carolina primary. Mrs. Clinton had lost white voters to Sen. Bernie Sanders in the course of winning the Nevada caucuses. With almost all precincts reporting, Mrs. Clinton won Virginia with 64% to Mr. Sanders's 35%.At the same time, Mrs. Clinton reduced Mr. Sanders's margins among younger voters, and he carried only 52% of voters younger than age 45, exit polls showed. That was a far smaller share than the 74% Mr. Sanders won during his landslide victory last month in New Hampshire.Mr. Sanders won only 36% of voters without a four-year college degree, a group he had carried in some prior contests.Mr. Trump's working-class coalition held together in many other states. In Arkansas, he won Republican voters with household income under $50,000 while losing higher-income voters to Sen. Ted Cruz. Similarly, he won Arkansas Republicans who don't have a college degree, while losing college graduates to Messrs. Cruz and Rubio.Mr. Trump also lost among Republicans with a college degree in Vermont, while winning those without a degree.Voters who went to the polls Tuesday also reflected the nation's widening partisan divide: Republicans in many states leaned more conservative than in their last competitive primaries, while Democrats were more liberal.In Tennessee, for example, 83% of GOP voters rated themselves as conservative, compared with 73% who said so in 2012.By contrast, the Democratic voter pool in Virginia was more liberal than during the party's last contested primary, in 2008. Some 68% of Virginia Democrats who voted on Tuesday called themselves liberal, the preliminary exit poll results showed, compared with 50% in 2008. The share of self-described moderates fell nine percentage points to 29%.Write to Dante Chinni at Dante.Chinni@wsj.comCredit: By Aaron Zitner and Dante Chinni

article name: The Trump-Obama Corporate Tax Reform Fail; They both want a minimum tax on the foreign earnings of U.S. companies. That's no 'inversion' cure.
article text: Removing the incentive for American companies to move their headquarters abroad is a widely recognized goal. To do so, the U.S. will need to join the rest of the G-7 countries and tax business income only once, in the country where it was earned. Notably, this principle--called territoriality--is included in the bipartisan framework for international tax reform developed by Sens. Rob Portman (R., Ohio) and Charles Schumer (D., N.Y.) in 2015.Unfortunately, recent reform proposals have a serious flaw: a "minimum tax" on foreign business income. This flaw is in President Obama's fiscal 2017 budget, and Republican presidential front-runner, Donald Trump, has broached a similar idea on the campaign trail.Currently, the U.S. taxes the world-wide income of its corporations at one of the highest rates in the world, but defers that tax until the profits are repatriated. The result is the worst of all worlds--a high federal statutory rate (35%) that encourages aggressive transfer pricing, a significant restriction on capital allocation that keeps cash offshore, very little revenue for the Treasury, and the loss of U.S. headquarters to countries with territorial tax systems.Major financing and investment patterns now reflect these distortions. A series of significant merger announcements are driven by the desire to get out from under the U.S. tax regime and to use offshore cash. The large debt offerings in our capital markets are efforts by companies to fund share repurchases and dividends because repatriation of their offshore cash would trigger punitive U.S. taxes.Tax reform is supposed to end these distortions, but a global minimum tax on foreign business earnings would undermine reform. The Obama administration's budget, for example, would end the deferral of taxes on unrepatriated cash and lower the statutory tax rate on corporate income to 28% (still higher than most other industrial nations). A U.S. company would still be able, as it can today, to take a credit on the taxes it already paid to another country. But if the taxes a U.S. company paid to another country were less than 19%, it would be slapped with an additional federal tax. The minimum-tax is dressed up by rhetoric that it will protect jobs at home and ensure that companies pay a "fair share."Mr. Trump has recommended a world-wide system without deferral and a much lower rate of 15%. As such, American firms earning profits abroad would still face home-country taxation and the Byzantine system of foreign tax credits that creates numerous tax planning opportunities.The flaw in both proposals? Corporate tax rates are declining around the world, amid continuing competition for firm headquarters and intellectual property. Ireland taxes most corporate profits at 12.5%. A global minimum tax means U.S. companies earning income abroad would still be subject to adverse U.S. taxes--precisely the distortion that tax reform is supposed to end. Meanwhile, the disincentives to be a U.S.-headquartered multinational firm will persist.Japan in 2009 and the United Kingdom in 2010 shifted to a territorial tax regime and lowered their statutory corporate rates. The U.K. did so to stop companies from moving their headquarters abroad; Japan was primarily interested in encouraging its multinationals to reinvest foreign earnings at home. Neither country adopted a minimum tax when it switched to territoriality. And neither country experienced the predicted dire consequences--such as dramatic tax revenue losses or job losses from outbound investment--of a switch to territoriality without a minimum tax.In fact, no significant country with a territorial tax regime has a minimum tax on its companies' foreign earnings. In part, this decision reflects the considerable complexity that such a minimum tax would create, a complexity that will only serve the industry of tax planners.Ultimately, the proposal for a minimum tax is driven by unfounded fears that American multinational firms pose a risk to the American worker by not showing loyalty to America. This coarse intuition is both naive and wrong. It is naive to assume that U.S. policy makers can exert market power to limit the logic of global opportunities and imperatives. More important, it is mistaken to demonize the foreign operations of American multinationals as working contrary to the interests of American workers.Instead the evidence, including research by C. Fritz Foley, James R. Hines and myself, suggests that U.S. companies succeeding globally expand at home--contradicting the zero-sum intuition. Demonizing multinational firms plays to populist impulses today. But ensuring that the U.S. is a great home for global companies and a great place for them to invest is actually the best prescription for rising median wages.Opportunities for corporate tax reform are infrequent. Including a global minimum tax would therefore be something the U.S. would have to live with for decades--during which corporate tax rates will fall around the world and the minimum tax, as well as its distortions, would grow in importance.Mr. Desai is a professor of finance at Harvard Business School and a professor of law at Harvard Law School.Credit: By Mihir A. Desai

article name: New Hampshire Primary Voters Pick Donald Trump, Bernie Sanders
article text: Voters in the Granite State cast their ballots in the nation's second presidential-nominating contestRepublican presidential candidate Donald Trump waves to his supporters at his primary night party in Manchester, N.H. The billionaire businessman was declared the winner of the Republican primary shortly after the polls closed.Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders gestures during a primary night rally in Concord, N.H. The Vermont senator won by a wide margin in the New Hampshire primary over former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.Michael Powlowsky of Hudson, N.H., cheers as a television screen shows early poll numbers favoring Mr. Trump.Supporters of Mr. Sanders cheer in Concord as CNN projects the Vermont senator won the primary.Ohio Gov. John Kasich arrives to a cheering crowd in Concord after his second-place finish in the state's Republican presidential primary.Michael Skocky of Cambridge, Mass., poses as he waits for Sen. Marco Rubio (R., Fla.) to arrive at his presidential primary night rally in Manchester.Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton speaks as former President Bill Clinton applauds at her New Hampshire presidential primary campaign rally in Hooksett, N.H.A man votes at a polling station in Manchester.Sen. Ted Cruz (R., Texas) speaks to supporters in Hollis, N.H. After a strong showing in Iowa, the Republican presidential candidate edged ahead of former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush for a third-place finish in New Hampshire.Supporters of Mrs. Clinton hold signs spelling out her name at her primary rally in Hooksett.Mr. Bush speaks during a rally in Manchester after a disappointing finish in the New Hampshire Republican presidential primary.Voters leave after casting their ballots in Chichester, N.H.Mr. Rubio greets his supporters at his primary election night party in Manchester. After a strong third-place showing in the Iowa caucuses, Mr. Rubio was hoping to prove his presidential staying power by pulling away from the pack in New Hampshire and moving closer to Donald Trump at the polls. Instead, he was in fifth place late Tuesday, with 81% of the precincts reporting.Voters fill out ballots at a polling station in Bedford, N.H.New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie addresses the crowd at his primary election night party in Nashua, N.H. Mr. Christie has canceled his South Carolina appearances and will return home to New Jersey to weigh his next campaign move.Supporters and demonstrators stand outside a polling place in Bedford.Republican presidential candidate and businesswoman Carly Fiorina appeals for support at Chez Vachon in Manchester.A voter casts a ballot in Hart's Location. The community of Hart's Location is one of three tiny New Hampshire towns--Millsfield and Dixville are the others--that cast the state's first votes of the primary, as the clock struck midnight.Tanner Tillotson applauds the results of the nine votes cast shortly after midnight in the U.S. presidential primary proceedings at the Hale House at the Balsams Resort in Dixville.A ward clerk opens absentee ballots at a polling station in Manchester.[Interactive content available online]

article name: Donald Trump Has Lowered Level of Political Discourse; That sucking sound you hear is Donald Trump's drawing former Gov. Mitt Romney and the others down to his level.
article text: That sucking sound you hear is Donald Trump's drawing former Gov. Mitt Romney and the others down to his level ("Romney Fuels GOP Fight ," page one, March 4). Chronological age no longer determines adulthood.Jim Van GilderRockport, TexasAs a former Mitt and Jeb supporter, I have a warning for the establishment: Respect the process. It's a big mistake not to respect the will of the people. The Republic has survived coarse dialogue before (see 19th century), but the Republican Party cannot survive if its leaders don't respect the votes of its members. If they were smart, they'd sit down with Mr. Trump and exchange their support for certain rules of engagement, such as free trade, a good foreign policy briefing and education in the laws of our country. But they shouldn't surmise that they're smarter than the voters. That's why voters are angry.Peter BroerBratenahl, Ohio

article name: The Case for Trump; An argument that he would represent 'conservative norms,' plus it's time for testimony on Hillary's emails.
article text: "The Justice Department is widely reported to have offered criminal immunity to Bryan Pagliano, the techie who set up Hillary Clinton's private email operation . Now that he has that get-out-of-jeopardy-free card, Mr. Pagliano also ought to be able to tell Congress and the public what he knows," writes the Journal editorial board . "Congress has a unique interest in this testimony. The FBI is presumably not investigating whether Mrs. Clinton or her aides deliberately attempted to evade federal record-keeping or freedom-of-information laws because those statutes don't include criminal enforcement. Yet the country has a right to know if itstop officials engaged in an organized effort to evade disclosure laws. "Potomac Watch PodcastAfter Michigan is Trump unstoppable?"So much for the nuclear deal producing a new era of Iranian accommodation to the world," says a Journal editorial . On Wednesday Iran test-fired two ballistic missiles with a reported range of 1,250 miles. The editorial notes that a message printed along the length of one missile said "in Hebrew as well as Farsi, lest anything be lost in translation--that 'Israel must be wiped off the face of the earth.'" Israel is 600 miles from the Iranian border .Bernie Sanders's 50% to 48% Michigan triumph is "one of the more remarkable upsets since the dawn of political polling," notes the editorial board . "The Vermont socialist campaigned hard against trade and the economic status quo, and according to exit polls he beat Mrs. Clinton 56% to 40% among voters 'very worried' about the economy. " Mr. Sanders beat her by 4 to 1 among people who wanted an "honest and trustworthy" nominee . And there's more bad news for Mrs. Clinton in the latest NBC/Wall Street Journal poll, as 56% of registered voters say they couldn't vote for Mrs. Clinton . "Some 51% of voters view Mrs. Clinton negatively, by far the highest share since her husband ran in 1992," adds the editorial .But there's a chance Mrs. Clinton will be running this fall against an opponent who is even more unpopular. Karl Rove notes that for all Donald Trump's talk about polling, he's the one Republican contender who consistently loses to Mrs. Clinton in hypothetical head-to-head match-ups.Morning Editorial ReportClick here to receive WSJ Opinion headlines and commentary via email.Perhaps it's simply a case of Trumphobia. Edward Luttwak writes , "Unlike the fear of Islam, which is a rational response to Islamist violence across the world, the fear of Donald Trump really is a phobia . There is a precedent for this: the panicked Reaganphobia that preceded the 1980 election." Mr. Luttwak argues that "Mr. Trump's lack of good manners may be disconcerting, but as president his foreign policies are unlikely to deviate from standard conservative norms."Most Hispanic voters view the economy and jobs as the top issue in this year's elections, and Hector Baretto says that a good way to reach these voters is to talk about improving the climate for small business. "Business startups in this country used to outpace business closures by about 100,000 businesses a year. Starting in 2008, the opposite became true: The number of businesses opening each year plummeted, and business closures now outpace business openings," writes Mr. Baretto .Also today, Andy Kessler describes how Vlad "The Impaler" Putin went "long and wrong on energy" with a disastrous currency bet .Credit: By James Freeman

article name: Democrats Settle in for Long Presidential Contest; Clinton's delegate lead grows even as Sanders wins Michigan; Trump aims for quick end to Republican race
article text: MIAMI--Sen. Bernie Sanders's upset win in Michigan this week left Democrats bracing for a long and costly primary fight and another round of split decisions in five contests next week.The first post-Michigan showdown between front-runner Hillary Clinton and Mr. Sanders came at the eighth Democratic debate here Wednesday evening, aimed at a Latino audience, where they challenged each other's records on immigration, education and jobs.Mrs. Clinton had to defend the government's handling of the 2014 influx of Central American children at the southern border, while Mr. Sanders was under fire for his opposition to a 2007 bill to rewrite immigration laws.While Florida is friendlier territory for Mrs. Clinton, the Vermont senator hopes to build on his narrow victory in Michigan, riding his populist economic and trade themes into neighboring industrial states Ohio and Illinois, which hold primaries Tuesday.Still, while Mr. Sanders has both money and momentum, Hillary Clinton has math on her side. The former secretary of state extended her commanding delegate lead Tuesday after minimizing her Michigan loss while trouncing her Democratic rival in Mississippi. She now has 1,221 delegates, more than half the number needed to secure the nomination; Mr. Sanders has 571.As Democrats settle in for a long haul reminiscent of the 2008 primary, the Republican contest could be nearing its conclusion if Donald Trump prevails next week in Ohio and Florida, two winner-take-all contests that could give the businessman an insurmountable delegate lead.The prospect of a protracted battle for the Democratic nomination and sooner-than-expected end to the GOP contest underscores the unpredictability of this election cycle. At the start of the year, most political experts were predicting reverse paths to the party's presidential nominations, with Clinton expected to dominate her race while a crowded field of Republicans slugged it out."It's a big win," Tad Devine, a senior strategist for the Sanders campaign, said of the Michigan victory that slowed Mrs. Clinton's momentum. "It's going to give a lot of people who weren't sure that Bernie could really prevail in this process a lot of hope that he will."On Tuesday, Democratic primary voters will cast ballots in North Carolina, Florida, Illinois, Missouri and Ohio.Mr. Sanders's aides are taking a realistic approach that aims to maximize his delegate haul in states he has his best chances of winning. That means, for instance, that Florida may be beyond their reach since independents can't participate, said Mr. Devine.Broad support from those unaffiliated voters helped Mr. Sanders win Michigan, while Mrs. Clinton won among registered Democrats. Also, the state allows early voting, meaning many Florida Democrats cast ballots before Mr. Sanders picked up new momentum with victory this week.Illinois and Ohio present better opportunities; both have more flexible rules regarding independent-voter participation in party primaries. In addition, Mr. Sanders's opposition to trade agreements is likely to resonate in those states.Michigan was the first big, industrialized northern state to weigh in on the primary. Its median household income of $49,000 and percentage of people who are 25 and older with a bachelor's degree, 26%, are in line with those in Ohio and Illinois. The states also have deep roots and history in blue-collar manufacturing.Though Mr. Sanders's message proved potent, Clinton advisers said they don't plan a major course change. They will work to highlight Mrs. Clinton's views on trade and her plans to create better-paying jobs."We're going to have to work even harder to amplify Secretary Clinton's economic argument," said Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook.The bigger concern for the Clinton campaign is the extension of a nomination race that they remain convinced she will ultimately win because of her lead in the delegate count.A long contest costs a lot of money, and she will continue to have to guard against Mr. Sanders's attempts to press her to embrace his more liberal positions, which the Clinton campaign worries would hurt her in the general election."From the beginning, we have approached this nomination contest as a battle for delegates," Mr. Mook said. "So, while Sen. Sanders has placed big bets on pulling out wins in certain individual states, we have sought to compete everywhere in every state with the goal of amassing the most delegates possible."Much like the Democratic presidential campaign in 2008, this race now could stretch into the early summer. In that campaign, Mrs. Clinton won 23 contests before eventually conceding to then-Sen. Barack Obama.Bill Burton, a Democratic strategist and former Obama aide, said Mrs. Clinton's Michigan speed bump reminded him of Mrs. Clinton's come-from-behind victory in New Hampshire in 2008 that caught the Obama campaign by surprise.At the time, top Obama advisers remained focused on methodically executing a plan focused on amassing delegates. He said Mrs. Clinton's campaign was wise to do the same this year.Dan Pfeiffer, a senior aide on the Obama 2008 campaign, said there are similarities between the situation Mrs. Clinton finds herself in now and that of Mr. Obama in 2008, but her delegate lead is larger than his was at a similar point in the race."The math made it virtually impossible for Clinton to catch Obama at this point in '08 and the same is true now. Everything that happens from this point on is interesting, but it is not particularly instructive," he said.Democratic strategist Mark Mellman said that, as in 2008, this Democratic race will be close and hard fought, but "it's not going be as close and it's not going to be as hard fought."Though the delegate math looks daunting for Mr. Sanders, his campaign advisers say he can close the gap. For one, the superdelegates, who are party officials and elected leaders, now backing Mrs. Clinton may switch allegiances if she loses their states."If you want to be the nominee of your party you not only have to win early you have to win often," Mr. Devine said. "You cannot go on a losing streak and expect that all the people, especially the superdelegates who've come to you in droves, are going to stay with you in droves."Dante Chinni contributed to this article.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: No Wonder Trump Does So Well With the Poor
article text: Your analysis of voting patterns on Super Tuesday is illuminating ("Voting in Poor, Rich Cities Offers Clues to Race Ahead," page one, March 3). Here's another possible reason why Donald Trump dominated in economically challenged cities, while Hillary Clinton's bedrock of support was in relatively high-income areas: Federal regulations disproportionately harm low-income households. Regardless of what benefits regulations may deliver, compliance with them imposes costs on producers. Contrary to popular myth, those costs aren't simply paid by the company owners. Instead, some of the costs are passed along in the form of higher prices.As I noted in recent congressional testimony, the fact that regulations cause prices to increase -- a regulatory premium, so to speak -- isn't news. But the fact that this premium contributes to poverty is. Recent research demonstrates the regressive nature of the regulatory premium. The big-ticket items on a low-income household's budget -- housing, electricity, telephone services -- are also some of the most heavily regulated goods, and therefore bear a high regulatory premium. Conversely, high-income households spend a smaller percentage of budgets on highly regulated goods, resulting in a relatively low regulatory premium.Perhaps Mr. Trump's voters aren't simply voting for him but instead are voting against a federal regulatory system that consistently produces results that hurt, rather than help, the economically challenged.Patrick McLaughlin, Ph.D.George Mason UniversityArlington, Va.

article name: Trump's America; There's nothing irrational about Donald Trump's appeal to the white working class, writes Charles Murray: they have every reason to be angry
article text: If you are dismayed by Trumpism, don't kid yourself that it will fade away if Donald Trump fails to win the Republican nomination. Trumpism is an expression of the legitimate anger that many Americans feel about the course that the country has taken, and its appearance was predictable. It is the endgame of a process that has been going on for a half-century: America's divestment of its historic national identity.For the eminent political scientist Samuel Huntington, writing in his last book, "Who Are We?" (2004), two components of that national identity stand out. One is our Anglo-Protestant heritage, which has inevitably faded in an America that is now home to many cultural and religious traditions. The other is the very idea of America, something unique to us. As the historian Richard Hofstadter once said, "It has been our fate as a nation not to have ideologies but to be one."What does this ideology--Huntington called it the "American creed"--consist of? Its three core values may be summarized as egalitarianism, liberty and individualism. From these flow other familiar aspects of the national creed that observers have long identified: equality before the law, equality of opportunity, freedom of speech and association, self-reliance, limited government, free-market economics, decentralized and devolved political authority.Related Reading* Election 2016: The Life of the Party (Jan. 29, 2016)* A Century of Political Spin (Jan 8, 2016)* The Middle-Class Squeeze (Sept. 25, 2015)* Donald Trump's New Version of an Old Political Fantasy (Aug. 14, 2015)As recently as 1960, the creed was our national consensus. Running that year for the Democratic nomination, candidates like John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson and Hubert Humphrey genuinely embraced the creed, differing from Republicans only in how its elements should be realized.Today, the creed has lost its authority and its substance. What happened? Many of the dynamics of the reversal can be found in developments across the whole of American society: in the emergence of a new upper class and a new lower class, and in the plight of the working class caught in between.In my 2012 book "Coming Apart," I discussed these new classes at length. The new upper class consists of the people who shape the country's economy, politics and culture. The new lower class consists of people who have dropped out of some of the most basic institutions of American civic culture, especially work and marriage. Both of these new classes have repudiated the American creed in practice, whatever lip service they may still pay to it. Trumpism is the voice of a beleaguered working class telling us that it too is falling away.Historically, one of the most widely acknowledged aspects of American exceptionalism was our lack of class consciousness. Even Marx and Engels recognized it. This was egalitarianism American style. Yes, America had rich people and poor people, but that didn't mean that the rich were better than anyone else.Successful Americans stubbornly refused to accept the mantle of an upper class, typically presenting themselves to their fellow countrymen as regular guys. And they usually were, in the sense that most of them had grown up in modest circumstances, or even in poverty, and carried the habits and standards of their youths into their successful later lives.America also retained a high degree of social and cultural heterogeneity in its communities. Tocqueville wrote of America in the 1830s as a place where "the more opulent citizens take great care not to stand aloof from the people." That continued well into the 20th century, even in America's elite neighborhoods. In the 1960 census, the median income along Philadelphia's Main Line was just $90,000 in today's dollars. In Boston's Brookline, it was $75,000; on New York's Upper East Side, just $60,000. At a typical dinner party in those neighborhoods, many guests would have had no more than a high-school diploma.In the years since, the new upper class has evolved a distinctive culture. For a half-century, America's elite universities have drawn the most talented people from all over the country, socialized them and often married them off to each other. Brains have become radically more valuable in the marketplace. In 2016, a dinner party in those same elite neighborhoods consists almost wholly of people with college degrees, even advanced degrees. They are much more uniformly affluent. The current median family incomes for the Main Line, Brookline and the Upper East Side are about $150,000, $151,000 and $203,000, respectively.And the conversation at that dinner party is likely to be completely unlike the conversations at get-togethers in mainstream America. The members of the new upper class are seldom attracted to the films, TV shows and music that are most popular in mainstream America. They have a distinctive culture in the food they eat, the way they take care of their health, their child-rearing practices, the vacations they take, the books they read, the websites they visit and their taste in beer. You name it, the new upper class has its own way of doing it.Another characteristic of the new upper class--and something new under the American sun--is their easy acceptance of being members of an upper class and their condescension toward ordinary Americans. Try using "redneck" in a conversation with your highly educated friends and see if it triggers any of the nervousness that accompanies other ethnic slurs. Refer to "flyover country" and consider the implications when no one asks, "What does that mean?" Or I can send you to chat with a friend in Washington, D.C., who bought a weekend place in West Virginia. He will tell you about the contempt for his new neighbors that he has encountered in the elite precincts of the nation's capital.For its part, mainstream America is fully aware of this condescension and contempt and is understandably irritated by it. American egalitarianism is on its last legs.While the new upper class was seceding from the mainstream, a new lower class was emerging from within the white working class, and it has played a key role in creating the environment in which Trumpism has flourished.Work and marriage have been central to American civic culture since the founding, and this held true for the white working class into the 1960s. Almost all of the adult men were working or looking for work, and almost all of them were married.Then things started to change. For white working-class men in their 30s and 40s--what should be the prime decades for working and raising a family--participation in the labor force dropped from 96% in 1968 to 79% in 2015. Over that same period, the portion of these men who were married dropped from 86% to 52%. (The numbers for nonwhite working-class males show declines as well, though not as steep and not as continuous.)These are stunning changes, and they are visible across the country. In today's average white working-class neighborhood, about one out of five men in the prime of life isn't even looking for work; they are living off girlfriends, siblings or parents, on disability, or else subsisting on off-the-books or criminal income. Almost half aren't married, with all the collateral social problems that go with large numbers of unattached males.In these communities, about half the children are born to unmarried women, with all the problems that go with growing up without fathers, especially for boys. Drugs also have become a major problem, in small towns as well as in urban areas.Consider how these trends have affected life in working-class communities for everyone, including those who are still playing by the old rules. They find themselves working and raising their families in neighborhoods where the old civic culture is gone--neighborhoods that are no longer friendly or pleasant or even safe.These major changes in American class structure were taking place alongside another sea change: large-scale ideological defection from the principles of liberty and individualism, two of the pillars of the American creed. This came about in large measure because of the civil rights and feminist movements, both of which began as classic invocations of the creed, rightly demanding that America make good on its ideals for blacks and women.But the success of both movements soon produced policies that directly contradicted the creed. Affirmative action demanded that people be treated as groups. Equality of outcome trumped equality before the law. Group-based policies continued to multiply, with ever more policies embracing ever more groups.By the beginning of the 1980s, Democratic elites overwhelmingly subscribed to an ideology in open conflict with liberty and individualism as traditionally understood. This consolidated the Democratic Party's longtime popularity with ethnic minorities, single women and low-income women, but it alienated another key Democratic constituency: the white working class.White working-class males were the archetypal "Reagan Democrats" in the early 1980s and are often described as the core of support for Mr. Trump. But the grievances of this group are often misunderstood. It is a mistake to suggest that they are lashing out irrationally against people who don't look like themselves. There are certainly elements of racism and xenophobia in Trumpism, as I myself have discovered on Twitter and Facebook after writing critically about Mr. Trump.But the central truth of Trumpism as a phenomenon is that the entire American working class has legitimate reasons to be angry at the ruling class. During the past half-century of economic growth, virtually none of the rewards have gone to the working class. The economists can supply caveats and refinements to that statement, but the bottom line is stark: The real family income of people in the bottom half of the income distribution hasn't increased since the late 1960s.During the same half-century, American corporations exported millions of manufacturing jobs, which were among the best-paying working-class jobs. They were and are predominantly men's jobs. In both 1968 and 2015, 70% of manufacturing jobs were held by males.During the same half-century, the federal government allowed the immigration, legal and illegal, of tens of millions of competitors for the remaining working-class jobs. Apart from agriculture, many of those jobs involve the construction trades or crafts. They too were and are predominantly men's jobs: 77% in 1968 and 84% in 2015.Economists still argue about the net effect of these events on the American job market. But for someone living in a town where the big company has shut the factory and moved the jobs to China, or for a roofer who has watched a contractor hire illegal immigrants because they are cheaper, anger and frustration are rational.Add to this the fact that white working-class men are looked down upon by the elites and get little validation in their own communities for being good providers, fathers and spouses--and that life in their communities is falling apart. To top it off, the party they have voted for in recent decades, the Republicans, hasn't done a damn thing to help them. Who wouldn't be angry?There is nothing conservative about how they want to fix things. They want a now indifferent government to act on their behalf, big time. If Bernie Sanders were passionate about immigration, the rest of his ideology would have a lot more in common with Trumpism than conservatism does.As a political matter, it is not a problem that Mr. Sanders doesn't share the traditional American meanings of liberty and individualism. Neither does Mr. Trump. Neither, any longer, do many in the white working class. They have joined the other defectors from the American creed.Who continues to embrace this creed in its entirety? Large portions of the middle class and upper middle class (especially those who run small businesses), many people in the corporate and financial worlds and much of the senior leadership of the Republican Party. They remain principled upholders of the ideals of egalitarianism, liberty and individualism.And let's not forget moderate Democrats, the spiritual legatees of the New Deal. They may advocate social democracy, but they are also unhappy about policies that treat Americans as members of groups and staunch in their support of freedom of speech, individual moral responsibility and the kind of egalitarianism that Tocqueville was talking about. They still exist in large numbers, though mostly in the political closet.But these are fragments of the population, not the national consensus that bound the U.S. together for the first 175 years of the nation's existence. And just as support for the American creed has shrunk, so has its correspondence to daily life. Our vaunted liberty is now constrained by thousands of petty restrictions that touch almost anything we want to do, individualism is routinely ignored in favor of group rights, and we have acquired an arrogant upper class. Operationally as well as ideologically, the American creed is shattered.Our national identity is not altogether lost. Americans still have a vivid, distinctive national character in the eyes of the world. Historically, America has done a far better job than any other country of socializing people of many different ethnicities into displaying our national character. We will still be identifiably American for some time to come.There's irony in that. Much of the passion of Trumpism is directed against the threat to America's national identity from an influx of immigrants. But the immigrants I actually encounter, of all ethnicities, typically come across as classically American--cheerful, hardworking, optimistic, ambitious. Keeping our national character seems to be the least of our problems.Still, even that character is ultimately rooted in the American creed. When faith in that secular religion is held only by fragments of the American people, we will soon be just another nation--a very powerful one, a very rich one, still called the United States of America. But we will have detached ourselves from the bedrock that has made us unique in the history of the world.Mr. Murray is the W.H. Brady Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. His many books include "By the People: Rebuilding Liberty Without Permission" and "Coming Apart: The State of White America, 1960-2010."Credit: By Charles Murray

article name: What to Expect if Republican Convention Is Contested; Losses in both Ohio and Florida could upend Donald Trump's march toward nomination
article text: CINCINNATI--If Ohio Gov. John Kasich or Florida Sen. Marco Rubio triumph in the winner-take-all primaries in their home states Tuesday, the odds are the Republican National Committee delegates will face a contested convention when they gather in Cleveland in July.At this point, only front-runner Donald Trump has a clear shot at winning the 1,237 delegates required to clinch the GOP nomination from the contests in states and territories. But losses in both Ohio and Florida could upend his march to the nomination.With most of the remaining states allocating delegates proportionally, Messrs. Rubio and Kasich are holding out hope they could prevail at a convention at which no candidate enters with a majority. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz maintains he could win the nomination outright, but his path to doing so is steep, and he and Mr. Trump could face a hostile environment among the party faithful at the convention.So if the party's nominee isn't clear by July, the most likely scenario is a contested Republican convention, something that hasn't happened since before the invention of color television. Here's a primer on how it could happen and how it would work.What would cause a contested convention?If no candidate wins 1,237 delegates during the primaries, caucuses and conventions in the states and territories, choosing a nominee would default to the convention delegates. Most of them are bound by their state results on the first ballot when the RNC meets in July in Cleveland, but after that rules allow almost all of them to vote for the candidate of their choice on subsequent ballots.Whether won through primaries and caucuses or during a floor fight in Cleveland, Republicans require their nominee to have at least 1,237 delegates, a majority of those elected to the convention. A plurality isn't enough, though if one candidate has a significant lead but isn't quite to 1,237, there may be significant pressure to coalesce behind him.How are delegates to the Republican National Convention selected?In most states, delegates are elected at state party conventions through a process that begins with local gatherings by precinct, county or some other smaller jurisdiction. But each state has its own process. In Illinois, voters in Tuesday's primary will pick delegates directly on their ballots. The candidate who triumphs in Ohio's winner-take-all contest will submit his own slate of delegates for approval by the Secretary of State's office.What is the obligation of convention delegates to support a specific candidate?After 2012, when Ron Paul wrested some delegates away from Mitt Romney in states the former Massachusetts governor won, the RNC asked states to bind delegates to candidates for at least one ballot, provided their candidate remains in the race.But again, the rules vary by state. If no candidate is elected on the first ballot, most states allow their delegates to become free agents, but some have extra requirements.Georgia and Maryland bind their delegates to their candidate through two ballots, unless the candidate receives less than 35% support on the first ballot. Kansas binds its delegates until a candidate formally releases them. Florida's winner-take-all delegates are bound through three ballots at the convention.And in Pennsylvania, the 14 at-large delegates are bound for one ballot, but the state's 54 congressional district delegates are elected directly on the primary ballot and are free agents even during the convention's first ballot.Many states also allow their delegates to make their own choice if the candidate backed by primary voters ends his or her campaign or releases the delegates. Usually this makes delegates free agents, but not always.South Carolina's delegates, all 50 of whom are now bound to Donald Trump, would automatically go to the state's second-place finisher, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, if Mr. Trump isn't nominated on the first ballot.There's a lot of talk about Democratic superdelegates. Do Republicans have those too?No. Democratic superdelegates are party leaders and state and former elected officials who are free to back the candidate of their choosing. In 2008, some of those party insiders initially backed Hillary Clinton and, after the long-fought primary, switched to then-Sen. Barack Obama, prompting a big intraparty skirmish that Mrs. Clinton lost.The Republicans have nothing comparable to those delegates. For most states, GOP delegates are elected in two buckets: at-large statewide and by congressional district, plus three for the RNC members from each state and territory.What is the threshold for a Republican candidate to be nominated for president?In 2012, RNC members, prodded by the Romney campaign, instituted a rule requiring any candidate to have won a majority of delegates in eight states to be nominated for president. The standard was meant to block Mr. Paul from creating mischief at the convention that year.This rule remains on the books but like almost every RNC rule, it is subject for review by the party's Rules Committee, which is scheduled to meet the week before the July convention in Cleveland. When it meets, the Rules Committee will determine eligibility requirements for its candidates, among a host of other bylaws that will govern the convention.The Rules Committee, which will be selected from delegates elected by the states and territories, will decide whether to limit potential candidates at the convention to those who mounted presidential campaigns or open it up by providing an avenue for Mr. Romney or House Speaker Paul Ryan to be considered for the nomination.The latter scenario could lead to bedlam in Cleveland, particularly if momentum builds for a potential consensus candidate like Mr. Ryan or Mr. Romney, both of whom have disavowed any interest in running.What's the precedent for Republicans requiring multiple ballots to choose a nominee? How could that happen this time?The last time Republicans entered their convention without a surefire nominee was 1976. That year, President Gerald Ford, who moved into the Oval Office after President Richard Nixon was forced to resign, prevailed over Ronald Reagan on the first ballot in Kansas City, Mo. That quick resolution may not be in the cards for 2016. And the last time it took multiple ballots was in 1948, when New York Gov. Thomas E. Dewey won the nomination on the third ballot in Philadelphia.Write to Reid J. Epstein at Reid.Epstein@wsj.comCredit: By Reid J. Epstein

article name: No Wonder Trump Does So Well With the Poor; Recent research demonstrates the regressive nature of the regulatory premium.
article text: Your analysis of voting patterns on Super Tuesday is illuminating ("Voting in Poor, Rich Cities Offers Clues to Race Ahead ," page one, March 3).
