article text: GREENVILLE, S.C. -- About three dozen Donald Trump volunteers packed a downtown office here Sunday afternoon, using iPads, computers and landlines to contact voters and read detailed scripts praising the candidate.Other supporters fanned out across the region's neighborhoods, rich and poor, holding iPhones with addresses pinned on a map that is linked to a campaign database.Mr. Trump has been criticized in other states for a flawed ground game, and he said his voter-turnout effort fell short in Iowa. In South Carolina, his aides set up shop months ago, trying to buttress a campaign built on star power with more traditional methods.As in prior early-voting states, Mr. Trump leads in public surveys. In one recent poll, conducted Feb. 10-12 by CBS News/YouGov, Mr. Trump's support stood at 42%, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz was at 20% and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio had 15%. The challenge is to get those backers to vote in Saturday's primary."We made 70,000 calls yesterday across the state," James Epley, the campaign's director for upstate South Carolina, said Sunday. "We chuckle when people say we don't have a ground game. Underestimate us at your peril."Still, many question some aspects of the campaign. The Trump voter lists are still less precise than other campaigns.His biggest support is from working whites without college degrees. Yet on Sunday, a group of volunteers fanned out in a wealthy neighborhood in downtown Spartanburg, about 30 miles from Greenville.Most residents they reached said they were supporting other candidates. "I'm not going to vote for Donald Trump," said Mark VanGeison, who answered the door and said he wasn't interested. More than two dozen voters said they had heard much more from other major candidates by mail, email and phone. Few reported being contacted by the Trump campaign.GOP legislators said they have had lunch, coffee or at least a phone call with many candidates, but few have spoken to Mr. Trump. Evangelical ministers said the same."For a while I thought the most buzz was for Trump, but I'm not so sure anymore," said GOP state Rep. Ralph Kennedy, who said he is undecided.The billionaire businessman's aides dismiss criticism of their approach, saying most traditional campaign spending in Iowa and New Hampshire was a waste, with some candidates shelling out thousands of dollars per vote only to place deep in the pack.Mr. Trump's South Carolina co-chairman, Ed McMullen, a veteran of a GOP think tank, said the centerpiece of Mr. Trump's strategy is his rallies, which average 7,000 to 10,000 people. The campaign asks supporters to sign up online for tickets and uses their contact information to follow up with calls and emails. It also uses demographic modeling to identify likely supporters, he said. Mr. McMullen said no other campaign is "doing the kind of depth we're doing," and other GOP models reliant on publicly available voter files have proven ineffective."Obama taught us a lot," said Mr. McMullen, citing President Barack Obama's data-driven 2008 campaign. "Republicans in the 2012 cycle with [Mitt] Romney saw a system blow up on Election Day. You wouldn't believe the ineptitude. A lot of people made a lot of money, for nothing."On Sunday, most volunteers at the Greenville call center said they had never worked for a campaign. Many came from out of state and stayed at a local Econo Lodge.Fuller Parker, a 20 year-old college student, recently drove an RV decorated with Mr. Trump's likeness across South Carolina, parking at Wal-Mart stores to attract voters."Driving the RV is far better than door knocking, Mr. Parker said. "They just flock to you when you're driving it."Yet the execution of the turnout operation can be spotty. Outside a livestock arena in Clemson last Tuesday, Mr. Parker and other volunteers left a sign-up table for supporters unattended as thousands streamed by, many without pausing to jot their names down.South Carolina Lt. Gov. Henry McMaster, Mr. Trump's most prominent backer in the state, says stumping at the local Lizard's Thicket Southern-cooking restaurant would be a waste of time. "The difference is, most candidates have to go to the people," Mr. McMaster said. "With Donald Trump, the people come to him."Credit: By Josh Dawsey and Valerie Bauerlein

article name: Donald Trump's MoveOn.org Moment
article text: By now it's a cliche that Donald Trump can say anything he wants, and his supporters don't care. They love him for his attitude and bluster, which has become a proxy for their rage against the political machine. Maybe that will be true again after Saturday night's debate in South Carolina, but someone has to point out how the GOP presidential frontrunner has adopted the political left's worldview on fundamental questions -- including blatant distortions of fact.Take his full-throated endorsement of the conspiracy theory that the George W. Bush Administration deliberately lied to get the U.S. into the Iraq war. "You call it whatever you want. I wanna tell you. They lied," Mr. Trump replied to a question by CBS moderator John Dickerson. "They said there were weapons of mass destruction. There were none. And they knew there were none. There were no weapons of mass destruction."Despite years of investigation and countless memoirs, there is no evidence for this claim. None. The CIA director at the time, George Tenet, famously called evidence of WMD in Iraq a "slam dunk." Other intelligence services, including the British, also believed Saddam Hussein had such programs. After the first Gulf War in 1991 the CIA had been surprised to learn that Saddam had far more WMD capability than it had thought. So it wasn't crazy to suspect that Saddam would attempt to rebuild it after he had expelled United Nations arms inspectors in the late 1990s.President Bush empowered a commission, led by former Democratic Sen. Chuck Robb and federal Judge Laurence Silberman, to dig into the WMD question with access to intelligence and officials across the government. The panel included Patricia Wald, a former chief judge of the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals appointed by Jimmy Carter, and Richard Levin, president of Yale University at the time.Their report of more than 600 pages concludes that it was the CIA's "own independent judgments -- flawed though they were -- that led them to conclude Iraq had active WMD programs." The report adds that "the Commission found no evidence of political pressure" to alter intelligence findings: "Analysts universally asserted that in no instance did political pressure cause them to skew or alter their analytical judgments."It's fair if the New York businessman wants to tout his opposition to the Iraq war way back when, though he'd soon learn in the Oval Office that Presidents must often make decisions based on imperfect intelligence. Failing to act can be as dangerous as ordering military action, as we learned from Bill Clinton's passivity toward al Qaeda in the late 1990s and President Obama's paralysis on Syria since 2011.But peddling false conspiracy theories ought to be disqualifying behavior in a presidential candidate because it corrodes public trust in democracy. Mr. Trump is claiming that government officials lied so they could send Americans to their deaths, and for what? So Mr. Bush could nearly lose an election over the war in 2004, and Republicans could lose Congress and the White House because of it in 2006 and 2008?MoveOn.org and others on the left have spread these lies for years because they have an unrestrained will to power and they really do believe the United States is the main source of trouble in the world. But this is not a worldview that conservative leaders have adopted, at least until now.We have enough respect for voters to appreciate that they support Mr. Trump for rational reasons. And we'd like to see him start to act more presidential in case he does become the GOP nominee. But his willingness to indulge the most crackpot left-wing conspiracy theory shows the tremendous risk Republicans would be taking if they make him their standard-bearer.

article name: Photos: Donald Trump Wins the Nevada Republican Caucuses
article text: Nevada Republicans picked Trump as their overall favorite Tuesday, adding to Trump's momentum heading into Super Tuesday.Republican U.S. presidential candidate Donald Trump gives a thumbs up as he addresses supporters after being declared by the television networks as the winner in the Nevada Republican caucuses at his caucus night rally in Las Vegas.Republican U.S. presidential candidate Marco Rubio gives a thumbs up at a campaign rally held on the night of the Nevada Republican caucus as he campaigns at Lacks Enterprises in Grand Rapids, Mich.Texas Sen. Ted Cruz greets Republican caucusers waiting in a long line Tuesday night at Edward C. Reed High School in Sparks, Nev. 'We will see what the voters of Nevada decide,' Mr. Cruz said after a reporter asked whether he would consider second place a win.Republicans wait in line at a caucus Tuesday at the Churchill County Fairgrounds in Fallon, Nev.A voter reviews his ballot Tuesday at Durango High School in Las Vegas during the Nevada Republican caucuses.Voters line up and sign in Tuesday at a Republican caucus at Durango High School in Las Vegas. Ahead of the caucuses, party officials in Nevada and Washington, D.C., feared a repeat of the 2012 debacle in which it took days to count just 33,000 ballots.Caucusgoers wait in line to enter a caucus location in Las Vegas on Tuesday.Supporters of Donald Trump and Marco Rubio wait for the doors to open Tuesday for the Nevada Republican presidential caucus at Western High School in Las Vegas.Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson speaks to reporters Tuesday during a campaign stop in Las Vegas.Ohio Gov. John Kasich, center, leaves a town hall campaign event Tuesday with Tim Tripepi, left, director of advance for Mr. Kasich's presidential campaign, at Kennesaw State University in Kennesaw, Ga. Mr. Kasich chose to forgo traveling to Nevada in favor of campaigning this week in states holding nominating contests March 1.Supporters of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump hold signs Tuesday at the entrance to the Silverton Las Vegas hotel and casino, where Sen. Marco Rubio held a campaign event.[Interactive content available online]

article name: Trump Leads on Eve of S.C. Vote
article text: GREENVILLE, S.C. -- After a raucous week of campaigning, Donald Trump remains atop polls in the Republican primary field here as voting begins Saturday in the state that brags that it picks presidents.In South Carolina, Mr. Trump is the top pick of 28% of likely Republican primary voters, according to a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll. But that is down eight percentage points from a January survey, and his 16-point lead in the earlier poll has narrowed to five points over Texas Sen. Ted Cruz's 23%. Florida Sen. Marco Rubio was third, at 15%, and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush followed close behind, at 13%.The crowded contest for second place may mean the primary here won't significantly winnow the field before the Feb. 23 GOP caucuses in Nevada, or even by March 1, when a swath of mostly Southern states will weigh in."I think this thing goes to Florida," said South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham, a Bush supporter who was referring to that state's March 15 primary. "I don't see South Carolina as being a knockout punch for anybody."While all the candidates promised to soldier on, a broad Trump victory here would cement his status as the Republican-to-beat for the nomination and likely trigger cries from party heavyweights to rally around one alternative.At several events on the South Carolina coast this week, the billionaire businessman asked voters to help him win "a mandate" that would propel him easily through the Republican National Convention to become the party's nominee.Meanwhile, the reasons for concern among party insiders about the prospect of a Trump nomination were on full display in the final week of campaigning.Mr. Trump engaged in a highly unusual dispute with Pope Francis over the issue of immigration; he blamed former President George W. Bush for failing to prevent the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001; and on Friday, he urged a boycott of Apple products until the company unlocks a California terrorist's cellphone."If Trump wins this one, I'm going to have to register as an independent," said Laura Duduit, 56 years old, a Rubio supporter who considers herself a staunch Republican. "That scares me to death."All of the candidates, except Ohio Gov. John Kasich, worked the Palmetto State on Friday making last-minute pitches.Mr. Kasich has adopted a Northern strategy aimed at winning the nomination, and he will watch the South Carolina results from Massachusetts, a rare non-Southern state voting on March 1. Mr. Kasich and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson were tied in the Marist poll for last at 9%."You like Bushes? We got a pile of Bushes," joked Mr. Graham before introducing a half-dozen members of the famous clan, including former first lady Barbara Bush.Meanwhile, Mr. Bush's Cuban-American rival, Mr. Rubio, was campaigning alongside South Carolina's first Indian-American governor, Nikki Haley, and its first African-American senator, Tim Scott. "A Benetton commercial," said Mrs. Haley, referring to the clothing brand known for showcasing diversity.The contrast between the dynastic family reunion and the diverse trio of under-50 politicians reflects the challenges facing Mr. Bush's struggling campaign, which may face calls to exit from the primaries if he performs poorly.The imagery at the Rubio events showed that South Carolina has the potential to revitalize the candidacy of Mr. Rubio after a poor showing in a New Hampshire debate and its Feb. 9 primary.But the hurdles for the entire field could get tougher if Mr. Trump scores a big enough win to claim all 50 of the state's delegates, and he is well positioned to do that.South Carolina awards 29 delegates to the statewide winner and another three to the winner of each of its seven congressional districts. Mr. Trump's statewide lead also translates to specific districts, according to polls of the field. If those results hold, the front-runner may deny other Republicans from claiming a single delegate in the first-in-the-South primary state."Until the party figures out who his one opponent is, he's going to keep grinding forward, because his base is unshakeable," said former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, who won the South Carolina primary in 2012.As the other candidates fight for their slices of supporters, Mr. Trump is the one candidate who has assembled a broader coalition of primary voters who feel abandoned by elected officials and disenfranchised by the political process.He draws his strongest support from likely South Carolina primary voters who haven't participated in past contests and those who didn't attend college, according to polls. And his supporters are more devoted to the political newcomer than any of his rivals.The Trump coalition includes infrequent voters, such as Crystal Ellenburg, of Gaffney, S.C., who attended her first political rally on Thursday night when Mr. Trump addressed thousands in the small city. "I love him," she said. "He's just so honest."Some 71% of his backers "strongly" support him, according to the Marist survey. Alice Hendershot, 67, said she hangs up when other campaigns call to attack the New York businessman. "There's no way I would go for any of those people," she said.Ian McMillan, 36, of Myrtle Beach, turned out to a Trump rally on Friday to support the Republican because he likes Mr. Trump's blunt style and because the truck driver sees the former reality TV celebrity as a better representative of "the silent majority.""I just feel that there's a lot of people in the country that feel like we have a censor on us, and we basically want our leaders to speak for us because we feel undervalued, because our leaders we currently have don't speak for us," he said.Still, the share of Republicans who say they would consider supporting Mr. Trump fell to 56% from 65% in January, according to a national Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll of 400 likely Republican primary voters conducted from Feb. 14-16.The same survey showed Mr. Trump losing to Mr. Cruz in a three-way race in which all the other candidates drop out, and lagging behind both Mr. Cruz and Mr. Rubio if the contest boiled down to a head-to-head match-up, according to the Journal survey.---Josh Dawsey and Felicia Schwartz contributed to this article.Credit: By Patrick O'Connor and Beth Reinhard

article name: Election 2016: Trump Leaves Trade Mark
article text: WASHINGTON -- Donald Trump is making a lasting mark on the Republican Party's stance on free trade, even if he doesn't win the presidential nomination, say backers and foes of trade deals.The billionaire businessman is hardening Republican opposition to trade pacts, and challenging the party orthodoxy on other mainstay issues like deficit reduction."The wariness is already there among Republicans" when it comes to trade, said Dartmouth economic historian Douglas Irwin. "It becomes accentuated when someone like Trump puts it front and center."The billionaire businessman's strong showing in Iowa, victory in the New Hampshire primary and front-runner status in Saturday's South Carolina race also send the message that his trade position is a winning one with GOP voters.Economists liken Mr. Trump to another populist tycoon who ran for president on a protectionist platform, computer pioneer Ross Perot, who helped legitimize opposition to free-trade deals among Democratic lawmakers.Mr. Perot opposed the North American Free Trade Agreement during the 1992 presidential campaign, where he ran as an independent, and during the subsequent fight over ratification of the deal under newly elected President Bill Clinton in 1993.While Nafta passed by an 34-vote margin in the House, the attention Mr. Perot garnered -- and the business imprimatur he gave to the opposition -- had an enduring impact on Democrats, whose support for free-trade measures was weakening then and has continued to wane.Pat Buchanan, who used his opposition to Nafta and other trade deals to fuel his Republican challenge to President George H.W. Bush during that 1992 presidential campaign season, said the aversion to such agreements has grown."Now, Republicans have been made aware that these deals can be politically costly and there is a downside to voting for them," Mr. Buchanan said in a recent interview.Tony Fratto, a former George W. Bush White House spokesman, said Mr. Trump's influence has helped open a divide on economic issues between the party's pro-business wing and the presidential candidates.Sen. Ted Cruz reversed his position favoring fast track authority to conclude trade deals and now opposes the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership negotiated under President Obama. Sen. Marco Rubio voted for fast track but now says he hasn't decided how to vote on TPP. Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and Ohio Gov. John Kasich still support TPP.The candidates also aren't addressing another Republican establishment standard -- deficit reduction.While all the candidates have proposed plans to slash taxes, which would add heavily to deficits, none have detailed how they would pay for them. According to an analysis by the Tax Foundation, a business-backed research group, Mr. Trump's proposal would have the largest cost -- somewhere between $10 trillion and $11 trillion over 10 years.In a statement, Mr. Trump said his plan to cut taxes, particularly a proposal to cut corporate taxes by about half to 15%, would boost growth by encouraging U.S. companies to repatriate profits now held overseas and by spurring foreign-owned companies to invest more in the U.S.Next on the trade agenda is the TPP, which includes Japan, Vietnam and Australia. Mr. Trump has called TPP a "horrible deal." He says that it will give China -- which isn't a party to the negotiations -- a "back door" way to join the agreement later.U.S. trade negotiators have tried to entice China to make changes in its economy, including reducing subsidies and opening service sectors to foreign competition, by telling Beijing such actions could allow China to join TPP later on.Mr. Trump's strong support among GOP voters and his bitter pronouncements against free-trade deals are adding to the problems trade deals now face in Congress.Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has said he won't bring up TPP for a vote before the November election, despite the Obama administration's lobbying for such a measure.Credit: By Bob Davis

article name: Trump's Tax Return Dodge
article text: Donald Trump didn't become the favorite for the Republican presidential nominee without having political talent -- not least his ability to unleash a torrent of verbiage that ducks a question. If he loses in the end, the guy should start up Trump Political School.Consider the businessman's response Sunday to a question about when he would release his tax returns, as he has already promised to do. George Stephanopoulos of ABC's "This Week" quoted our Saturday editorial calling on Mr. Trump to release his returns "so Republicans can know what they're voting for."Mr. Stephanopoulos: "Will you release them by Super Tuesday? Don't Republican voters have a right to know?"Mr. Trump erupted in that now-familiar and calculated way in which he pretends he is the victim of a great injustice:"Well, first, no, I won't. No, no, no, I won't. I'm working on it. We're working on, they're massive. You saw pictures of me. But let me tell you about The Wall Street Journal. I have no respect whatsoever for The Wall Street Journal. I don't think they know what they're doing."They have taken me on so much it's so ridiculous. Every day, editorials, bad editorials, and they had a poll come out, which was so wrong. I said they should fire their pollster and they should fire their editorial staff because I think these are people that don't know what they're doing."I don't even want to read it very much anymore. They're so wrong."So Mr. Trump shouldn't have to release his tax returns because he says The Wall Street Journal doesn't like him. The truth is we cover him like any other politician, and we defended him against the pope and Ted Cruz. This is the second time he's called on us to be fired, which are moments we'll always treasure. The first time he also threatened to sue us if we didn't apologize for noting his lack of trade knowledge; we didn't apologize.Back to Mr. Trump: "But if you look at their polls that they came out with one day and two days, two polls before the election, they turned out to be so wrong that they should honestly they should fire their pollster. So I don't care what The Wall Street Journal says, what they say doesn't -- and, in fact, if anything, I would do the opposite because then it'll turn out to be more correct."Our editorial board has nothing to do with the WSJ/NBC/Marist polls, and sometimes polls are wrong, but by now all his listeners heard is that the newspaper must be biased against him. Mr. Stephanopoulos tries again: "So no release before you're a nominee?"Mr. Trump: "No, at some point. Well, they'll talk about it. At some point we'll release. There's no rush. Why is there such a rush? I'm supposed to rush like crazy?"By the way, I released my financial statements which are much more important. I released my financial statements and everybody was amazed at how big and how great the company is, much bigger than they thought and it's a great company. Very little debt, tremendous cash flow, some of the best assets in the world."And I say that only because that's the kind of thinking the United States needs now because our country is in financial trouble and military trouble. We're in every kind of trouble you can have. Our country's a mess. We're going to strengthen the border. We're going to do all of the things that you and I have been talking about for a long time now, George. And it's going to be great."Mr. Stephanopoulos: "Mr. Trump, thanks for joining us this morning."What a performance. Mr. Trump says he doesn't have to release his tax returns because his business is fabulous, though at some point he may release them, maybe, but there's no rush because, well, he doesn't say, though in January he said "we're working on that now" and that they would be "very beautiful." In any case he's going to fix the country because he's a business success. By the time Mr. Stephanopoulos surrenders for the next guest, viewers can't remember what the original question was.As we wrote Saturday, Mr. Trump should release his tax returns now to avoid Mitt Romney's mistake of waiting for Democrats to make an issue of it, which they will. As the potential GOP nominee, he also owes the details to Republicans so they know as much as they can about the man who would be President. Is there something in those tax returns you want to hide, Mr. Trump?(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Doesn't Take Long to Release a Filed Return" -- WSJ Mar. 1, 2016)

article name: Election 2016 --- CAPITAL JOURNAL: How Trump's Army Is Transforming the GOP
article text: Amid all the odd changes unfolding in this election cycle, the most startling may be the way the Republican Party is transforming right before our eyes.Whether Donald Trump is responsible for this transformation, or merely the beneficiary of it, is a chicken-and-egg question for history to decide. But the change now has been unleashed regardless of his electoral fate.Through balloting in three states, it appears that a new set of voters is driving the GOP now. Their agenda is more populist and less ideological than has been the case for Republican voters in the past. They are prepared to break with the party's traditional positions on a number of fronts, particularly on issues important to the Republicans' core business constituency. They have little respect, and to some degree outright antipathy, for the party's leaders.Some of these voters appear new to the GOP, but many have been bouncing around in the party, lured in over the years by their differences with Democrats on cultural issues. The difference now is that they are energized, as opposed to apathetic, and united behind a single candidate. They are driving the primary process and changingthe party in the process.The voters Mr. Trump has pulled together in winning New Hampshire and South Carolina and coming in second in Iowa is a coalition of the economically and culturally alienated, voters who look angry but also a bit frightened. It is a far cry from the traditional GOP winners' coalition.In each of the first three states that have voted, Mr. Trump has carried by a wide margin Republican voters with a high-school education or less, according to polls of voters. In New Hampshire, he won almost half of such voters. In South Carolina, he also won 40% of those with some college education but not a college degree.He also has won in each of the first three states among ideologically moderate Republicans and among those who consider themselves politically independent. He does better among older voters than younger ones; in both New Hampshire and South Carolina, he won among those age 65 and older. He does better among those on the lower half of the income scale than those on the upper half.It's important to note that Mr. Trump is drawing votes from across a broad spectrum of Republican voters; he fishes in every pond. But his core voters are in this new populist alignment.To some extent, the Trump core looks like the voters who propelled Pat Buchanan, Mike Huckabee and Rick Santorum in earlier Republican election cycles. But not exactly: Their coalitions were more heavily tinged with evangelical voters, who are part of but not the heart of the Trump crowd. And those earlier contenders eventually became marginal candidates, not front-runners.To some extent, this coalition also is a descendant of the tea-party movement that sprang to life in 2010, largely in response to the health-care law of President Barack Obama and his Democratic Party. Yet this coalition is different from that as well. Tea-party adherents were, by and large, ideologically conservative. The Trump coalition isn't conservative in the traditional sense, or ideological at all.This isn't the country club, Wall Street,Chamber of Commerce or religious-conservative set within the GOP. It isn't the deficit-hawk coalition, either, for Mr. Trump has proposed a tax plan that, according to outside analysts, would blow the biggest hole in the side of the budget. And he's the GOP candidate most outspoken about not cutting benefits for Medicare and Social Security recipients.Nor is this the coalition of neoconservatives on security policy, for Mr. Trump has blasted the Iraq war those neocons inspired, and has kind words to say about Vladimir Putin, the Russian leader they abhor.Ronald Reagan used to define the Republican Party as a three-legged stool made up of social conservatives, fiscal conservatives and national-security conservatives.The Trump coalition isn't precisely any of those three.This is a populist coalition, and Mr. Trump has won its support in part by breaking defiantly with traditional Republican economic policies. He mocks free-trade agreements that have had broad support within the party, and particularly within its normally powerful business wing. He has shredded the more open Reagan philosophy on immigration. He can sound more like a Democratic populist than a Republican one when talking about taxing hedge funds and private-equity firms.He has openly ridiculed the last three presidential contenders of the Republican Party: Sen. John McCain, former President George W. Bush and former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney. He is critical of his party's leaders in Congress and mocks his party's donor base.The voters drawn to these apostasies have moved from the GOP fringes to its heart -- and other candidates trying to catch Mr. Trump ignore them at their peril.(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Trump Is Overruning the Republican Party" -- WSJ Feb. 29, 2016)Credit: By Gerald F. Seib

article name: Cruz vs. Kasich vs. Trump; Plus, Obama drives a hard bargain with the Little Sisters of the Poor, but a soft one with the Castro brothers of Havana.
article text: Your humble correspondent has been making the case for Ted Cruz as the only candidate who can deny the Republican nomination to Donald Trump without a change in GOP rules. But so far I'm not finding many takers around the office. Today the Journal's editorial board expresses a different view : "The case for Mr. Kasich staying in the race is that he has a better chance than Mr. Cruz of stealing moderately conservative voters from Mr. Trump in the more moderate states. In the states that allocate delegates proportionally, the Ohio Governor can reduce Mr. Trump's margins." The editorial continues , "The other case for Mr. Kasich is that he's theonly candidate consistently beating Hillary Clinton in head-to-head November polling."Donald Trump wants his own rewrite of a GOP rule to allow him to win without attracting the majority of convention delegates. Karl Rove writes , "The rule that the Republican nominee must win a majority of the national convention has been in force for 160 years, since the party's first convention in 1856 selected John C. Fremont as its standard-bearer. Five Republicans who went on to become president trailed in the convention when voting began ."Morning Editorial ReportClick here to receive WSJ Opinion headlines and commentary via email.Yesterday the Supreme Court heard oral arguments in Zubik v. Burwell, testing ObamaCare's requirement that many religious organizations offer contraception services via their insurance companies. The Becket Fund, representing the Little Sisters of the Poor, points out that the Obama Administration is trying to enforce on the nuns a contraception mandate from which it has already exempted Exxon, New York City and the U.S. Department of Defense, among others.While the President is taking a tough line with the nuns, he seems to have adopted a softer one with the communist regime in Cuba . During a Monday joint press conference with Mr. Obama, Cuban dictator Raul Castro offered to immediately release political prisoners if presented with a list of their names. Names were immediately given to Mr. Obama but so far it's unclear whether Mr. Obama has even mentioned them to the Cuban strongman.President Obama is "a product of the American left's revisionist interpretation of revolutionary movements as ultimately benign and rational. The Obama foreign policy has been about reasoning with revolutions," writes our columnist Daniel Henninger . "After Paris, San Bernardino, Brussels and the rest of Islamic State's daily slaughter routine, the moment has arrived to bring back the Cold War . The alternative view held then by national leaders was that large revolutionary movements can be inherently violent, implacable and unappeasable. And that a civilized world order survives by containing or defeating them .""The media have ignored the IRS targeting of conservative groups, but the courts haven't," notes a Journal editorial. "On Tuesday the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals tore into the agency's obstructionist conduct and ruled that the IRS must turn over the spreadsheets it created on the targeted groups .""As the scientific case for a climate-change catastrophe wanes, proponents of big-ticket climate policies are increasingly focused on punishing dissent from an asserted 'consensus' view that the only way to address global warming is to restructure society--how it harnesses and uses energy," write David Rivkin and Andrew Grossman . "That we might muddle through a couple degrees' of global warming over decades or even centuries, without any major disruption, is the new heresy and must be suppressed ."Credit: By James Freeman

article name: College Athletes Already Get Paid; Plus, Trump's NATO warning.
article text: Finally, amid an ongoing debate about whether to pay college athletes, someone is pointing out that in fact they are compensated --tax-free. "These athletes are already treated like campus royalty, enjoying far more perks, and richer ones, than their classmates could dream of," writes Brown University's Howard Chudacoff . "On top of their $40,000-$50,000 scholarships and presumably debt-free education," athletes are routinely provided with private tutoring services and live in complexes outfitted with plasma televisions and Maserati leather seats , among other amenities.Colleges spending big on athletesmay also soon be paying state governments , if Democrats in Connecticut's legislature have their way. Faced with a budget shortfall, the pols are going after Yale's endowment.Donald Trump's "ramblings on NATO are a double-edged warning: Europeans need to invest more in defense, both to prepare for the possibility if Americans take an isolationist turn in November, and to ensure that America's security role in Europe remains politically palatable to U.S. voters," writes the editorial board .Our columnist William McGurn argues that a Donald Trump victory over Hillary Clinton could happen. While a sky-high 63% of Americans hold a negative view of him, 54% have a negative view of her . Also, Mr. Trump could do to the Democratic candidate in debates what he's already done to Republicans. ("Did Goldman Sachs pay you to say that, Hillary?") Mr. McGurn also notes that Mrs. Clinton still can't put away "angry, white-haired socialist" Bernie Sanders , even though "the entire primary season has been orchestrated to serve Mrs. Clinton's interests by a party that is mostly in her pocket .""Donald Trump is Barack Obama squared," writes the Journal's Bret Stephens . "The president and The Donald are two epic narcissists who see themselves as singularly suited to redeem an America that is not only imperfect but fundamentally broken ."Credit: By James Freeman

article name: Woman Suing Trump University Can Back Out of Case, Judge Says; Federal judge cites 'media obsession' with case during presidential race
article text: A federal judge will allow a woman suing Trump University to bow out of the case under certain conditions, citing a "media obsession" with claims against the real estate school founded by the billionaire mogul and presidential candidate Donald Trump.The case, which is being pressed by several other former students, will continue to move forward. Mr. Trump's opponents in the Republican presidential primaries have seized on the controversy in recent weeks.The woman, Tarla Makaeff, filed the lawsuit in 2010, claiming that Trump University defrauded students around the country and made false promises about helping them achieve financial success.A separate fraud lawsuit filed by New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman against the now-defunct Trump University, seeking $40 million, is also pending .Lawyers for Mr. Trump have denied the allegations.Ms. Makaeff asked U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel in San Diego to leave the lawsuit as a named plaintiff, saying Mr. Trump and his lawyers have used the perch of his candidacy to publicly demean her .Judge Curiel said he would grant her request, on the condition that lawyers for Mr. Trump be allowed to depose another plaintiff in the case. The judge also permitted lawyers for Trump University to introduce Ms. Makaeff's deposition testimony if the case goes to trial.Ms. Makaeff could still benefit if the remaining plaintiffs win, as a member of a class of people who attended Trump University workshops.Lawyers for Ms. Makaeff and the other plaintiffs declined to comment."Neither pundits, counsel, or the parties anticipated the media obsession that this case would create due to Defendant Trump becoming a candidate for President of the United States," Judge Curiel wrote in his March 21 order. "It is also plain that with every additional candidates' debate and state primary, the attention given to the case has grown."Ms. Makaeff had written the judge, saying she was "concerned about the toll that the trial would take on my emotional and physical health and well-being."In response to Ms. Makaeff's lawsuit in 2010, Mr. Trump sued her for defamation, seeking $1 million. An appeals court ultimately dismissed the defamation claim, ordering Mr. Trump to pay her just under $800,000 for legal fees.Mr. Trump has decried Ms. Makaeff at rallies, and he tweeted earlier this month, "The primary plaintiff in the phony Trump University suit wants to abandon the case. Disgraceful!"In 2008, Ms. Makaeff attended one of Trump University's three-day workshops called "Fast Track to Foreclosure" and then signed up for a "Trump Gold Elite" program, which allowed her to attend additional workshops. In total, she said she spent $60,000 in Trump University fees.Mr. Trump's lawyers said Ms. Makaeff's failure to achieve success in real estate wasn't the fault of Trump University.Judge Curiel gave lawyers for the plaintiffs seven days to decide whether to accept the conditions.Write to Joe Palazzolo at joe.palazzolo@wsj.comCredit: By Joe Palazzolo

article name: Still Time for a Conservative Independent; Anti-Trump forces need a convention strategy plus a plan to get ballot access.
article text: Donald Trump's disturbingly isolationist remarks to the Washington Post's editorial board this week have fortified the determination of many Republicans to find a viable alternative--at their convention if possible, through an independent conservative candidacy if necessary.Some observers may believe that such a candidate couldn't even get on the ballot because the filing deadlines have come and gone. If so, they are wrong. Back in 1980, from a standing start in late April, Republican John Anderson's underfunded independent presidential campaign managed to get on the ballot in all 50 states plus the District of Columbia by mid-September.As Richard Winger, the publisher of Ballot Access News, has reminded me, the laws in 1980 were less hospitable to independent candidacies than they are today. The reason: The Anderson campaign was determined to leave a legacy of lowered barriers to the ballot for future candidates, so the campaign pursued the issue all the way to the Supreme Court, and Mr. Anderson prevailed. In 1983's Anderson v. Celebrezze, the court held that Ohio's early deadline for independent candidacies to file nominating petitions with the required number of signatures violated the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of association.Anderson v. Celebreeze remains a binding holding today, and it has had an impact. Mr. Winger points out that lower courts have used it to strike down June filing deadlines in five states--Alaska, Nevada, South Dakota, Arizona and Kansas.As matters now stand, most states' deadlines are months away. Nine fall in July, 32 in August, and five in September. Four deadlines--Illinois, Indiana, New Mexico and North Carolina--are in June, and precedent suggests that the deadlines would be struck down if challenged.That leaves Texas, the only state with a May filing requirement. Texas has never been taken to court over this, but it seems clear that its law would not survive a challenge. Among other vulnerabilities, Texas imposes an earlier deadline on independent presidential candidates than on aspirants for any other office.This flies in the teeth of the Supreme Court's opinion, which found that state-imposed restrictions on presidential elections affect a "uniquely important national interest." Moreover, said the court, a state has a "less important interest in regulating Presidential elections than statewide or local elections." It is hard to see how a more stringent requirement for presidential candidates than for others could be squared with the court's reasoning.Not only is there plenty of time remaining for independent candidates to file, but the threshold that ballot petitions must meet is far from onerous.Thirty-four states require fewer than 10,000 signatures, and only two (Florida and California) demand more than 100,000. Moreover, some states make ballot access easier for minor parties than for independent candidates; others do the opposite.In Florida, for example, an independent candidacy would take about 119,000 signatures to get on the ballot; an organized minor party, none whatever.A systematic effort to get on the ballot everywhere would be free to choose its approach, state by state. A well-organized and funded effort could get the job done in a matter of weeks.This is not to say that Republicans who cannot accept a choice restricted to Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump will have a smooth path. The Republican National Committee is understandably opposed to the idea of an independent candidacy. Months ago, every candidate in the race for the nomination pledged to support their party's nominee, which would make it impossible for any of them to run as an independent conservative without fatally undermining his or her credibility. Other individuals who step forward will probably burn their bridges with the Republican Party, at least as it now stands.And there is a delicate timing issue. It isn't too late right now to mount an independent candidacy, but it will be when the Republican Convention convenes in late July. So this venture would have to be launched well before the identity of the party's nominee is known. The trick for the anti-Trump forces is to proceed simultaneously along two tracks without allowing Plan B to fatally weaken the effort to deny the New York billionaire a first-ballot victory.The most obvious objection to this course has nothing to do with the technicalities of ballot access. An independent conservative candidate who earned even 5% of the popular vote would doom the Republican nominee to defeat in November. The supporters of an independent effort would be compelled to press the case that Mr. Trump cannot win anyway and also would bring down the party's Senate majority--and perhaps the House as well, if the margin of defeat were large. The independent candidate might bring out enough traditional Republicans to save their congressional majorities.A more principled argument--albeit a harder sell for many loyal Republicans--is that Mr. Trump's victory would spell catastrophe, not only for their party, but for the country.Credit: By William A. Galston

article name: Christie Faces Ire at Home --- Out-of-state pitches for Trump spur calls from critics to resign; governor stands firm
article text: The collapse of Gov. Chris Christie's presidential campaign fueled hope he would return his attention to New Jersey, but his continued march across the national stage has rekindled criticism that he is shirking responsibilities at home.Mr. Christie endorsed former rival Donald Trump, a fellow Republican, for president on Friday, a surprise move that brought him back to the campaign circuit and national television. On Tuesday, Mr. Christie attracted widespread attention as he stood behind Mr. Trump, staring blankly, during the front-runner's victory speech in Florida.In New Jersey some of Mr. Christie's harshest critics have called on him to resign, and others are talking about a recall effort. A new poll from Fairleigh Dickinson University PublicMind on Wednesday showed 61% of registered voters disapproved of Mr. Christie's job performance.Some members of the governor's own party who were previously loyal to him said Wednesday that Mr. Christie should resign if he continues to campaign for Mr. Trump."There's a lot of work to be done in New Jersey," said state Sen. Jennifer Beck, a Republican from Monmouth County. "I think the governor needs to pick where he's going to spend his time."Senate Majority Leader Loretta Weinberg, a Democrat, said the governor has abandoned the state."I think he should resign," said Ms. Weinberg, adding that she believes a recall effort would be too difficult and distracting. "Whether there are grounds for impeachment because of dereliction of duty -- maybe that's an alternative."Kevin Roberts, a spokesman for Mr. Christie, declined to comment on calls for the governor's resignation or discussion of a recall. He didn't comment on Ms. Weinberg's impeachment proposal."The governor always has balanced out-of-state political activity with his duties as governor," Mr. Roberts said. "That will remain the case moving forward."During his monthly call-in radio program Monday, Mr. Christie said he would be spending much more time in the state and was focused on New Jersey affairs. "This is where I've been every day," he said.Mr. Christie spent 261 partial or full days traveling outside of New Jersey in 2015, or 72% of the year, according to administration figures. Critics have said the governor has allowed problems -- ranging from worker pensions to the near-bankrupt state transportation fund -- to pile up in Trenton.Since his endorsement of Mr. Trump on Friday, Mr. Christie has introduced Mr. Trump at three campaign events in three states.Mr. Christie traveled on Mr. Trump's plane for the events, and his expenses were picked up by the campaign, said Corey Lewandowski, Mr. Trump's campaign manager.The governor's security detail travels with him at all times and will continue to do so for campaign events, following state policy, Mr. Roberts said.In 2012, when Mr. Christie was traveling as a surrogate for GOP presidential nominee Mitt Romney, Mr. Christie's security cost $260,000, state records show. Taxpayers routinely pay for security for governors.Mr. Christie has nearly two years left in office and can't run for re-election because of term-limits. To launch a recall effort, 25% of the state's registered voters, or 1.4 million people, would need to sign a petition to force a recall election, according to the state constitution.Six Gannett-owned New Jersey newspapers penned a joint editorial Tuesday urging a recall vote if the governor declines to resign. Some of the papers have written critical editorials of Mr. Christie in the past.John Currie, chairman of the New Jersey Democratic State Committee, said a recall effort "may be the only recourse New Jersey has for holding our absentee governor to account."Sam Raia, chairman of the New Jersey Republican State Committee, said state Democrats should stop playing games."It's time for Trenton Democrats to take a break from their tired and divisive rhetoric and answer the governor's call for bipartisan solutions," he said.The governor has weathered worse political storms, such as the George Washington Bridge lane-closure scandal in 2013, and will probably survive this one, said Brigid Harrison, a professor of political science and law at Montclair State University."The reality is, if it were easy it would have been done during Bridgegate," Ms. Harrison said of a recall effort.Still, Mr. Christie faces an uphill battle advancing his agenda. Democrats who control the Legislature said they have grown tired of Mr. Christie's travels out of state, and his endorsement of Mr. Trump poured fuel on the fire. "He is apparently becoming Donald Trump's opening act, which takes away from us here and the things we need to focus on," said Assembly Speaker Vincent Prieto.Carl Golden, a former aide to Republican Gov. Tom Kean, said the endorsement is overshadowing Mr. Christie's moves currently, but getting out behind a front-runner early has political advantages."If you look at it from Christie's point of view, if he was going to endorse somebody, he did it the right way," he said.Credit: By Heather Haddon and Kate King

article name: Trump's Pottery Barn GOP
article text: Donald Trump claims to have opposed the Iraq war before opposition was fashionable. So perhaps he won't mind if we apply Colin Powell's adaptation of the Pottery Barn rule to Mr. Trump's attempted takeover of the Republican Party: If you break it, you bought it.The rule comes to mind after examining the paradox of Super Tuesday's primary results: Mr. Trump was the clear winner and his support is solidifying, but Republican resistance to his candidacy is mounting at the same time. A front-runner at this stage of the primaries would normally be expanding and consolidating his party support, as Hillary Clinton is among Democrats. This is what happened in every other recent GOP presidential race.Mr. Trump is winning, but his Super Tuesday performance was less than commanding. He generally underperformed his percentages in the pre-election polls, and he cracked the 40% mark in only two states -- Massachusetts and Alabama. Overall he averaged about 35% of the vote, lower than his totals in Nevada and about what he received in New Hampshire. Yet the same media sages who said he could never win now say the race is over.One possible explanation is that the attacks on Mr. Trump that began in earnest only late last week have begun to break through to voters. In two of Mr. Trump's weakest states, Oklahoma (28% and second place) and Arkansas (33% and a narrow first), the Club for Growth ran ads against him.Those two states were also so-called closed primaries in which only declared Republicans can vote. Mr. Trump has done better in open primaries in which independents can cast ballots. This matters for closed-ballot contests in the next week, such as Michigan on March 8. The New Yorker also does worse in caucuses, losing to Marco Rubio in Minnesota on Tuesday, and Kansas and Kentucky will hold caucuses Saturday.All of which means that Mr. Trump can still be denied the nomination if enough Republicans mobilize against him. The businessman won some 237 delegates to bring his total to about 319, or a little more than 25% of the way to the nomination. His competitors must still beat him in the large winner-take-all states, which is a tall task, but if they do they could block him from gaining a majority before the GOP convention. Then anything could happen.This will require continued pounding on Mr. Trump from all of the remaining candidates, including John Kasich, who seems to think he can win the nomination as a conscientious objector.By campaigning in Virginia where he had no chance of winning, the Ohio Governor received some 96,500 votes or a mere 9.4%. But that was enough to deny the state to Mr. Rubio, who took 32% but lost to Mr. Trump by about 29,000 votes. Mr. Kasich would be helped in winner-take-all Ohio on March 15 if Mr. Rubio now stayed out of the state, but Mr. Kasich's Virginia move didn't earn him any forbearance.If Mr. Kasich is going to justify staying in the race, he at least has to join Mr. Rubio and Ted Cruz in educating voters about the ways that Democrats will carve up Mr. Trump in the general election. How about joining the calls for the billionaire to release his tax returns? Mr. Trump keeps stonewalling, which by now suggests that his returns contain something that could cost him the nomination. Democrats and the media will pound Mr. Trump to release his returns only after he's nominated.The GOP resistance to his candidacy will be a major problem if Mr. Trump does win the nomination. In the Virginia exit polls, no less than 54% said they would not be "satisfied" if Mr. Trump is the party's nominee. That's an astonishing figure in a swing state that a GOP candidate must win in November. The figure was 38% for Mr. Rubio.All of this suggests that Mr. Trump is winning by fracturing the GOP rather than persuading it. Already thoughtful conservatives like Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse and Wisconsin Rep. Reid Ribble have said they cannot vote for Mr. Trump in November. Mr. Sasse is a freshman Senator who ran as an outsider himself. He is no establishment factotum.Mr. Trump dismissed Mr. Sasse's declaration on Tuesday night as unimportant, but that's a mistake. The public defection signals widespread dismay across the GOP about having to vote for a standard bearer who has few political convictions and has scorched so much earth on his way to the nomination.Mr. Trump is aware of his problem because he was at pains to call himself "a unifier" on Tuesday night. But asked about working with Congress, Mr. Trump couldn't resist a threat: "I'm going to get along great with Congress, OK? [House Speaker] Paul Ryan, I don't know him well, but I'm sure I'm going to get along great with him, and if I don't? He's gonna have to pay a big price, OK?"Not OK if Mr. Trump wants to have any hope of assembling a winning GOP coalition that he is doing so much to split apart.

article name: Trump's Blueprint: His Own Book
article text: Donald Trump, who emerged from the Super Tuesday presidential primaries in a commanding position, reached this point by mixing bluff and bluster, by cajoling allies and intimidating opponents, and by being alternately tough, sensational and flattering.He has, in short, handled the presidential campaign as if he were negotiating a deal.The blueprint has been hiding in plain sight all along, say those who know Mr. Trump best."The Art of the Deal," the best-selling book he wrote in a quite different context almost three decades ago, lays out many elements of his unorthodox effort.The book's 11 tenets include advising negotiators to find ways to "get the word out" about their position -- and "the more sensational, the better." One key strategy is to "fight back," and to do so "very hard" against "losers." The successful negotiator needs to "think big."Mr. Trump acknowledges the parallels. "This is the biggest deal of my life," he said in an interview. "I've done big deals, but this is a very complex series of deals that ultimately hopefully gets us to the right place to make America great again." The book's lessons are "there psychologically" for him, he said. "It's automatic."Mr. Trump's unconventional approach has yielded a string of primary victories that have shaken the Republican establishment and left opponents struggling to devise ways to counter him. As much as his deal-making approach contains the seeds to his success, opponents also are looking to it for grounds to attack him. His frequent references to negotiating have prompted some conservatives to openly question his fealty to their core principles.Many Republican leaders strongly oppose Mr. Trump, who has broken with party orthodoxy on issues as diverse as trade and national security, and some have vowed they won't support him if he wins the party's nomination. An anti-Trump advertising campaign, funded by a few big donors, is gearing up.And though Mr. Trump won the majority of states in Tuesday's voting, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz took his home state, Oklahoma and Alaska, and has begun a push to consolidate the anti-Trump vote.Mr. Cruz, in fact, is trying to use Mr. Trump's history as a deal-maker against him. Though Mr. Trump has said his ability to negotiate ensures he will be able to deal successfully with Congress and strike tougher bargains with other countries, Mr. Cruz says Mr. Trump is too inclined to negotiate.Mr. Trump "is promising if he's elected he will go and cut deals in Washington," Mr. Cruz said at the latest GOP debate in Houston last week. Critical of his opponent's contributions to Democratic lawmakers and past liberal positions, Mr. Cruz, who is currently second in the delegate count, distinguishes himself as "a proven conservative."Mr. Trump's campaign-as-negotiation is about to enter a new phase as he launches a charm offensive to win over skeptical party officials. Trump's campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, said the campaign began Tuesday night by reaching out to senior Republican leaders including House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.There has never been a modern presidential candidate quite like Mr. Trump, and certainly not one in recent years who has leaned as hard on his business success as the rationale for his quest for the nation's highest political office.Mr. Trump has been able to tap into a large chunk of Republican primary voters so alienated from professional politicians they are prepared to go in a radically different direction. Even Mr. Trump acknowledges he didn't expect his effort to unfold as it has."I didn't know I'd be doing this well, in all fairness," he said. "I never thought I'd be this far out in the lead. I thought I'd be somewhere in the middle of the pack and edge it out."A look at how Mr. Trump arrived at this point shows parallels between his campaign efforts and his writings in "The Art of the Deal." His son Eric said that many of the book's principles are at work on the campaign trail. Mr. Trump's communications director, Hope Hicks, has read the book three times since she was hired.The parallels start on the book's first page. "Most people are surprised by the way I work," Mr. Trump wrote. "I play it very loose."That is the style in which his campaign was launched last June. Mr. Trump descended an escalator at his Trump Tower skyscraper to announce his candidacy. Without reading from a text or notes, he stunned the political world by describing illegal immigrants from Mexico as rapists, drug dealers and murderers.Early in his book, Mr. Trump describes 11 "elements of the deal." They include:'Think Big'With that adage in mind, Mr. Lewandowski said, Mr. Trump from the outset decided not to pursue "a one- or two-state strategy," but to mount a national campaign."You have to win them all," Mr. Trump said in the interview. "It doesn't help to win one or two."The think-big philosophy led Mr. Trump to quickly adopt positions that produced shock and outrage. He created a firestorm by suggesting that the U.S. temporarily ban Muslims after the Paris and San Bernardino terrorist attacks.'Know Your Market'Mr. Trump viewed the electorate as a target market, and he concluded voters were angry, antiestablishment, frustrated with Washington's gridlock and fed up with what they perceived as weakness at home and abroad. He didn't see that market as narrow or made up of niches, but broad, he said."My market is the people in the country who want to see America be great again," he said. "It's very simple. That's a lot of people. That's not broken down by age, or race or anything."'Enhance Location'Early trips to Iowa and New Hampshire showed that his celebrity status enabled him to draw larger crowds than other candidates did in traditional house parties. An early event at the home of New Hampshire state Rep. Stephen Stepanek produced a crowd that threatened the stability of the floors. After that, the campaign sought big spaces.The effort was criticized as a move away from the traditional cozy settings for New Hampshire political gatherings, but it attracted bigger crowds, which brought more media coverage. "Enhancing location brought enhanced benefits," Mr. Lewandowski said.'Get the Word Out'In the book, Mr. Trump advised: "If you are a little different, or a little outrageous, or if you do things that are bold or controversial, the press is going to write about you."That is what happened when Mr. Trump proposed a temporary ban on Muslims entering the U.S., and when he questioned whether former GOP presidential candidate John McCain was a war hero because he was captured. Mr. Trump's controversial statements dominated news coverage for weeks, prompting pundits and politicians to predict his demise. Instead, his poll numbers rose.He also adopted another powerful weapon for getting his word out: Twitter. Mr. Trump tweeted early, late and often. "Some people don't like the idea that you use Twitter and you're running for president," said Mr. Trump, who doesn't use a computer, but tweets from his phone. "Those people are backward."Through his Twitter, Facebook and Instagram accounts, the Trump campaign is followed by nearly 14 million people. The campaign has more than 50 million "engagements" on Facebook, said campaign social-media director Daniel Scavino.'Contain the Costs'Access to so many potential supporters through social media and data obtained from rally attendees helped the Trump campaign meet this tenet. A few weeks ago, the campaign began posting a five-digit number on Mr. Trump's podium for supporters to get the latest news. "It costs us zero, and we've gotten one million inbound texts," Mr. Lewandowski said, making it unnecessary to buy databases to connect with voters.Mr. Trump also pays no money for his own pollsters, the cost-saving measure of which he is proud.'Fight Back'This may be the "Art of the Deal" advice Mr. Trump has followed most assiduously. Mr. Trump openly proclaimed he would hit back if hit, and hard. From the start, Mr. Trump skewered the other candidates, especially former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, whom he repeatedly called "low energy."More recently, his opponents have hit back.Sen. Marco Rubio has called Mr. Trump a "con artist" who may have "wet his pants." Mr. Trump shot back that "little Marco" is a "lightweight" "choker" with "big ears."Fighting back is a must, in the deal blueprint and in the campaign, Mr. Trump said. "I don't like it, but I have no choice," he said. "I watch people say Trump shouldn't do it because he's the front-runner, but when somebody attacks you, you have to."'Have Fun'This is the final element of deal-making, Mr. Trump said, and something he is doing in the campaign, even in long rope lines after events when he shakes hands and poses for selfies.Many supporters are fans of his book. Jeff Washenberger, 57 years old, of Salem, Va., said he read "The Art of the Deal" and found it useful for running the motel and rental properties he owns. He said he believes Mr. Trump will bring his "deal-making forte to the White House."After a Trump rallyMondayin Radford, Va., several supporters held up "The Art of the Deal," which Mr. Trump delights in signing."They know 'The Art of the Deal,' probably the No. 1 business book of all time," Mr. Trump said.Credit: By Monica Langley

article name: Next for Trump: A Golf Tournament --- His political ambitions have complicated the front-runner's relationship with the sport of golf
article text: Following his triumphant performance in the Super Tuesday primaries, Donald Trump got on the phone with a journalist Wednesday to talk about golf.That may sound unusual for a front-running presidential candidate. But this week, the Trump National Doral Resort is hosting the WGC-Cadillac Championship. An annual stop on the PGA Tour, the tournament has become an accidental political event thanks to the White House ambitions of the resort's owner.Since Trump took over the Doral Resort four years ago, he has been a grandstanding presence at the PGA Tour's annual stop there. Typically he touches down in a Trump-emblazoned helicopter near the ninth hole.In the interview on Wednesday, Trump said he would attend the event only on Sunday and that he wasn't sure about arriving in a helicopter.Security is one concern. Another is that he doesn't want his larger-than-ever presence to disrupt the world's top golf pros.It's also the case that Trump's relationship with the sport of golf has become more complicated because of controversial comments he has made on the campaign trail, particularly about immigrants.In December, the Tour said it would reassess its 53-year relationship with Doral after this year, possibly moving the tournament elsewhere. "Mr. Trump's comments are inconsistent with our strong commitment to an inclusive and welcoming environment in the game of golf," the Tour's statement said.Last summer, the Tour and golf's three other major governing bodies in the U. S. -- the U.S. Golf Association, the PGA of America and the LPGA -- issued a joint statement that similarly distanced themselves from his remarks about immigration.Asked on Wednesday whether he understood why those organizations felt compelled to issue that statement, Trump paused for an unusually long time. "I have a very good relationship with the governing bodies. I've done a good job and I think they appreciate it. I like the people and I want them to do what's good for them, not necessarily what's good for me," he said.Then there is the matter of the PGA of America canceling its 2015 PGA Grand Slam of Golf event played at a Trump course in California.With regard to the cancellation of that event, Trump said he released the PGA of America from its contract because the event, a two-day exhibition with each year's major winners or their substitutes, didn't much matter to him.As for future events scheduled to take place on Trump-owned properties, such as future WGC events at Doral, next year's U.S. Women's Open in New Jersey and the Senior PGA Championship outside Washington, D.C., Trump took a tougher if somewhat ambiguous stance."Just so you'll understand, I have contracts and I'm very good with contracts," he said. "They sat down, they signed contracts, binding contracts, totally binding contracts. Including with Doral, just so you understand. That being said, I like people to be happy and I have great relationships. But I do have contracts."A spokesman for the PGA Tour on Wednesday said it would not discuss the future of the Doral tournament until after this week's event. The USGA in a statement Wednesday said that although Mr. Trump's views on immigrants were "inconsistent with our strong commitment to an inclusive and welcoming environment in the game of golf," it hasn't changed its plans to stage the 2017 U.S. Women's Open at Trump's Bedminster New Jersey course. As for the Senior PGA Championship, a PGA of America spokesman said, "We are continuing to monitor developments, but have no other update to offer."Trump himself has mostly checked out of golf since the campaign got hot and heavy. He last played a month ago at his West Palm Beach, Fla., course, and he has no specific plans to play again soon."I love golf, but let me tell you. when you finish making a speech in front of 25,000 people, you're not in any mood to play golf. It's a completely different mind-set. My primary focus is (politics) now," he said.If he is elected president, he said he would probably play some -- "More than I'm playing now!" -- but not nearly as much as he would like to. "I would use golf mostly to get to know people. You develop relationships on a golf course that are far better than you can develop over lunch or dinner or any other way," he said.Having a golf-lover in the White House would be good for the game, Trump said. Asked whether his association with golf has helped or hurt his campaign, since some of his populist supporters might regard the game as elitist, Trump said it was neutral."Nobody has said that because I have golf courses, that's a negative politically. I have never heard that," he said.There's no questioning his competitiveness. "I had a good night last night," he said. "A lot of winning."Credit: By John Paul Newport

article name: Election 2016: Trump's Run Was Years in Making --- GOP front-runner trademarked slogan in 2012, hinted at interest to Oprah in 1988
article text: Donald Trump and a small team of confidants began planning his White House bid just weeks after Mitt Romney's 2012 loss to President Barack Obama.The businessman trademarked his "Make America Great Again" slogan in November 2012, according to federal records. He spoke about the dangers of illegal immigration at the Conservative Action Political Conference in 2013, and campaigned in 2014 for Republican Rep. Steve King in Iowa, home of the first contest in the presidential nomination process.Between 2012 and his campaign launch last June, Mr. Trump gave more than $1 million to GOP candidates, super PACs and groups such as the Republican Governors Association, records show. He declined to renew his contract to host "The Apprentice" in early 2015.Establishment Republicans have watched the rise of Mr. Trump's bid this year with shock. And yet, Mr. Trump has been telegraphing his presidential ambitions for decades, including when the ever-confident businessman told Oprah Winfrey in 1988 that he would probably win the presidency if he ever competed for it."I don't think people realized he has always had presidential aspirations," said Sam Nunberg, a Republican strategist who advised Mr. Trump from 2013 until last August. "He knows the voters he attracts. He knew it from the beginning."Mr. Trump first explored a presidential bid as a Reform Party candidate in 2000. Although he withdrew from the race, he won the party's California primary, and his supporters amassed scrapbooks of newspaper clippings from the effort.In the following years, he hosted "The Apprentice," gave paid speeches and built up his brand. He also grew increasingly frustrated with the direction of the country and its leadership.Despite his endorsement of Mr. Romney in 2012, he came to view him as a weak candidate and was disappointed by his own understated surrogacy role, his advisers at the time said.As 2016 approached, Mr. Trump's children, particularly his daughter, had taken over the management of an increasing share of his corporate dealings. Some of his new investments -- such as the Doral Miami golf resort and Old Post Office Pavilion in Washington, D.C. -- were well in the works.Accustomed to playing a hands-on role in his company, Mr. Trump was looking for another challenge."This was another mountain to climb. How many great hotels, great buildings and great golf courses can you build?" said Roger Stone, a longtime adviser to Mr. Trump who no longer works for the campaign but remains supportive of it.When New York allies tried to draft him to run for governor, he demurred. "I have much bigger plans in mind -- stay tuned, will happen!" Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter in March 2014.Mr. Trump and his advisers knew that his celebrity was key to a successful presidential campaign, and his June announcement was designed around his sense of showmanship. The kickoff featured Mr. Trump descending an escalator in marble-clad Trump Tower."What we've been doing from day one is building something that's much bigger and broader than most people thought and understood," said Corey Lewandowski, Mr. Trump's campaign manager.The businessman's pledge during his announcement to build a wall along the U.S.'s southern border with Mexico to prevent drug-dealers and "rapists" from immigrating was swiftly criticized.Mr. Trump ad-libbed most of his speech, his advisers said, but his wall proposal had been hatched earlier as an idea uniting his role as a builder with a hard-line stance on immigration. "It was simple, finite," Mr. Nunberg said."He likes that he's making history. His likes that his name is up in lights," Mr. Stone sums up. "And he's having fun."Credit: By Heather Haddon

article name: Election 2016: Fight to Be Trump's Only Foe Intensifies --- As Carson departs, Rubio aide's call for Kasich to quit is met with derisive response
article text: The Republican presidential primary is getting smaller, nastier and more intense amid new attacks on front-runner Donald Trump and fears that he's on the verge of opening an insurmountable lead in the delegate hunt for the nomination.Behind the scenes, Mr. Trump's top aide, Corey Lewandowski, sought to open lines of communications with senior Republicans in Washington while his opponents sought to push each other out of the race.Mr. Trump is now the undisputed front-runner for the GOP presidential nomination, with the other remaining campaigns openly labeling themselves as underdogs. Mr. Trump has won 319 delegates so far, to 226 for Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas, 110 for Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida and 25 for Ohio Gov. John Kasich.The escalating tension will be on display Thursday in a Detroit debate that comes days before another half dozen primaries and caucuses that represent the waning opportunities to stop or slow Mr. Trump's ascent.The most anticipated primary is in Michigan next Tuesday when 59 delegates will be up for grabs. A candidate must win 1,237 delegates to clinch the GOP nomination.Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, who has won just 8 delegates, won't join his rivals on the stage in Detroit, he announced Wednesday. "I do not see a political path forward," he said in a statement.The campaigns of Messrs. Rubio and Kasich are trying to shrink the field even further. On a Wednesday call with donors, Mr. Rubio's campaign manager, Terry Sullivan, called Mr. Kasich "selfish" for remaining in the race. Mr. Sullivan said Mr. Rubio's donors who know Mr. Kasich should contact him and urge him to end his campaign."No one is doing more to help Donald Trump than John Kasich," Mr. Sullivan said, according to details provided by a person on the call. "He is not getting delegates for himself, just for Trump."Mr. Kasich's campaign manager, John Weaver, brushed off the suggestion his candidate should drop out. "Terry can getback to me after Rubio wins Florida," Mr. Weaver said. "Good luck."The most recent polling shows Mr. Rubio trailing Mr. Trump in Florida by 16 percentage points. Mr. Rubio's aides have guaranteed victory in his home state.Mr. Cruz, who won three states Tuesday, campaigned in Kansas Wednesday, one of three states holding GOP caucuseson Saturday. Louisiana is also holding a primary.Mr. Cruz's performance Tuesday fell short of the high expectations he once had for the March 1 primaries, when he treated the red-state swath as his campaign's "firewall" that would guard against runaway losses to his rivals.But the evangelicals and conservative voters who seemed like his natural constituents in the region went to Mr. Trump in numbers unimaginable when the Cruz campaign hatched its strategy months ago.Now the hope for the Cruz campaign lies in upcoming states holding nominating contests closed to anyone who isn't a registered Republican. Mr. Cruz won the primary Tuesday in Oklahoma, which operates by such rules. The senator took 34% in the Sooner State to Mr. Trump's 28%."We're going to do well on Saturday and Tuesday," Cruz campaign manager Jeff Roe said. "At midnight on March 15 [after primaries in several states], it will be a two-person race."The conflict between Rubio and Kasich forces comes amid a broader effort by some Republicans to stop Mr. Trump's momentum a day after he won seven of 11 state contests. The GOP 2012 presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, is scheduled to speak on the 2016 primary Thursday at the University of Utah. Mr. Romney won't be endorsing a candidate, an aide said, but he has been a harsh critic of Mr. Trump.Three new TV advertising campaigns -- one from a pro-Rubio super PAC and two from conservative groups that aren't backing any one other candidate -- are seeking to damage Mr. Trump by attacking elements of his business history.The super PAC backing Mr. Rubio is highlighting Mr. Trump's hesitation before disavowing support from former Ku Klux Klan grand wizard David Duke during a Sunday CNN interview. In other appearances before and since Mr. Trump has said he doesn't want and rejects KKK support.Our Principles PAC, the stop-Trump group primarily bankrolled by the Ricketts family, is investing in a seven-figure TV ad campaign in Michigan, Illinois and Florida that slams his involvement in Trump University, a now-defunct school that is facing a civil fraud claim in New York.And the Club for Growth is beginning a $1.5 million Florida campaign. The Club was the first third-party group to spend significant sums against Mr. Trump last October, when it invested $1 million in an anti-Trump campaign in Iowa. Mr. Trump lost to Mr. Cruz in those caucuses last month.The Club's new ad, which will air across Florida cable television and online, hits Mr. Trump for his use of eminent domain and bankruptcy filings.Mr. Trump, whose campaign events are regularly carried live on cable television, has yet to purchase any television advertising time in Florida.---Janet Hook and Beth Reinhard contributed to this article.Credit: By Reid J. Epstein

article name: Trump Wins Nevada Vote
article text: Donald Trump won the Nevada Republican caucuses Tuesday, giving him his third state victory in a row and reinforcing his status as the front-runner for the GOP presidential nomination.The outcome, declared by the Associated Press, gives Mr. Trump another blast of momentum heading into the next contest March 1, when 11 states will hold primaries and caucuses, and when more convention delegates will be awarded than on any other primary day of the 2016 calendar.The March 1 Super Tuesday primaries cut deeply through the Bible Belt, featuring many of the most conservative and religious states in the nation.Mr. Trump is leading in polls in nearly all the states voting that day. He is most vulnerable in Texas, where home-state Sen. Ted Cruz is ahead. Since none of the states is winner-take-all, Mr. Cruz and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio have a chance to pile up delegates under rules that split them proportionally.Mr. Cruz will be working to win the backing of more evangelical Christians after a third-place finish in South Carolina, staff tumult and charges of underhanded campaign tactics.
