He has invested heavily in these southern states and will be battling Mr. Rubio, who is trying to gather establishment support to emerge as the leading alternative to Mr. Trump.All of the candidates will have to convince voters like Cheryl Teel, a sales consultant for a gift company. "We were founded on Christian values," said Ms. Teel, a 52-year-old Republican from Titus, Ala., near Montgomery, who remains undecided. "I want them to have a relationship with Jesus Christ."Mr. Trump rolls into the region having proven in South Carolina -- where he won all 50 delegates -- that many social-conservative voters are eager to embrace him despite his brash, sometimes profane statements."I'm not looking for a preacher. I'm looking for a man who leads," said Bonnie Shanahan, a 72-year-old retiree in Montgomery who admires his business savvy and resoluteness. Though she is evangelical and has knocked on doors to try to enlist new religious adherents, she said she doesn't care whether Mr. Trump can quote the Bible.States voting on March 1 in what has been dubbed the SEC primary after the college-sports conference will award more convention delegates -- 595 -- than on any other single day of the 2016 primary season. In addition to Texas, states awarding delegates include Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Tennessee, Alaska, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Oklahoma, Vermont and Virginia.For Mr. Cruz, Texas is a must win, with 155 delegates at stake, more than the first four states combined. Mr. Rubio is looking for fertile ground in the less conservative states such as Virginia and metropolitan areas like Atlanta. Ohio Gov. John Kasich is working Vermont and Massachusetts, neighbors to New Hampshire where he scored a second-place finish.But for everyone, Mr. Trump is the man to beat, and he could crush the rest of the field if his triumphs in South Carolina and New Hampshire are harbingers.The move from the early contests, where candidates had the luxury of campaigning one state at a time, will be a bracing test of their resources and endurance as they compete at a faster pace. "It's like going from a tricycle to the Daytona 500," said Henry Barbour, a Republican lobbyist in Mississippi who recently endorsed Mr. Rubio.Strategy now is more complex because of the states' varying rules for allocating convention delegates to candidates proportionately, setting up some opportunities to scoop up some delegates without finishing first statewide.Mr. Rubio campaigned Tuesday in Minnesota. Mr. Kasich, who barely competed in Nevada, appeared in Virginia on Monday and Georgia on Tuesday. Mr. Trump plans to campaign Friday in Oklahoma. All the candidates gather Thursday in Houston for the next Republican debate.One reminder of how conservative the region is: In 2012, three of the states in the SEC primary went for former Sen. Rick Santorum, a conservative Catholic; in 2008, Mike Huckabee, a former Arkansas governor and Southern Baptist minister, captured four.That profile would appear to benefit Mr. Cruz, who has courted evangelical Christians assiduously, but the South Carolina results showed that Mr. Trump has struck a chord with many voters in the South, despite the New York businessman's blustery style. Exit polls in South Carolina showed that Mr. Trump beat Mr. Cruz among evangelical voters, 34%-26%, with Mr. Rubio following with 21%.In Alabama, where evangelical Christians made up 80% of the Republican primary voters in 2012, voters like Ms. Teel worry the U.S. has lost its moral compass. She is a devout Southern Baptist and wants to hear how the GOP contenders' religious convictions will shape the way they govern.Among such voters, opposition to gay marriage and abortion is strong. Cheered by some conservatives, Roy Moore, chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, fought last year against implementation of the U.S. Supreme Court decision legalizing same-sex marriages. And the state's abortion clinics have long battled legal efforts to shut them down.In interviews with more than two dozen voters around the state, such issues came up regularly, along with concerns about the economy, immigration and national security."The Constitution is written on Judeo-Christian laws, the Ten Commandments, which Obama threw out a long time ago," Debbie Rangel, a 67-year-old retiree, said at a recent gathering of Republican women in Trussville, near Birmingham. "I think Cruz will bring us back to that."Some in the group questioned Mr. Trump's religious conviction and bristled at what they considered his demeanor."The arrogance that Trump has, the rudeness -- we're just not that way," said Sandy Lancaster, a former business instructor who described herself as "ultraconservative" on social issues and favors Messrs. Cruz and Rubio.Yet Mr. Trump enjoys strong support among many social and religious conservatives. "I want somebody that can win," said Jeannine Svenson, a retiree in Montgomery, Ala., and a conservative evangelical Christian.The Cruz campaign has organized a coalition of pastors and enlisted captains in Alabama's seven congressional districts and most of its 67 counties, said Alabama co-chairman Ann Eubank.The Rubio team has recruited county leaders as well, and sought to galvanize groups ranging from students to farmers to hunters, said Republican state Rep. Will Ainsworth, a state co-chairman.One recent afternoon at a Trump office in Montgomery, former Republican state Rep. Perry Hooper Jr. was plotting outreach efforts with volunteers when Donica Knight arrived.A country and rock singer whose most recent album is titled "Can't Buy a Southern Girl," Ms. Knight said she was a Trump supporter and planned to write a song about him to perform at campaign events. "It'll be patriotic," she said.---Reid Epstein, Byron Tau and Alexandra Berzon contributed to this article.Credit: By Janet Hook and Arian Campo-Flores

article name: Election 2016: Trump Wins Broad Backing
article text: LAS VEGAS -- Donald Trump's Nevada victory Tuesday was propelled by support from across the Republican spectrum, with big margins among evangelicals, conservatives, moderates and all age groups surveyed in entrance polls.The Associated Press declared Mr. Trump the winner shortly after 9 p.m. local time, when the caucuses closed. It hadn't yet declared the winner for second place between Sens. Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio.Mr. Trump won by big margins among both men and women, and led his rivals among all age groups surveyed. He was the top choice for both conservative and moderate voters. He also led his rivals among Republican voters of all education levels -- but drew his highest level of support from caucus-goers with no college degree.Mr. Trump also won pluralities among both white and nonwhite Republican voters, though whites made up 85% of the Republican caucus electorate in Nevada.At a Trump rally Tuesday in Sparks, Nev., Frank Mooney, 69 years old, said he would caucus for Mr. Trump because he found the billionaire "energetic" and "exhilarating.""He is an outsider, and I think that is his greatest virtue," Mr. Mooney said. "Not since Ross Perot has there been a businessman, who is willing to take on Washington, and that is what we have to have happen."After winning primary contests in New Hampshire and South Carolina, Mr. Trump barely campaigned ahead of Nevada's caucuses. The New York businessman held just two campaign rallies, while Messrs. Cruz and Rubio crisscrossed the state in advance of Tuesday night's contest.Messrs. Rubio and Cruz also invested heavily in both television advertising and extensive ground operations here. In recent days, Mr. Cruz launched blistering attacks on Mr. Trump for his support of maintaining federal land management in the state. But Mr. Cruz was distracted when he was forced to dump a top aide Monday over the aide's social-media postings.Mr. Rubio sought to remain above the fray, never mentioning his rivals' names during five campaign stops in three days. But to reporters, Mr. Rubio delivered a blistering critique of Mr. Cruz and suggested Mr. Trump hasn't studied up on issues enough to be commander-in-chief.Support for Mr. Trump among Republican voters only appears to be growing, despite an increasing consensus among the party's establishment in favor of Mr. Rubio, and to a lesser extent Mr. Cruz. Elite party opinion quickly coalesced around Mr. Rubio after former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush ended his presidential bid last weekend.Mr. Rubio announced nearly two dozen new endorsements since Saturday night, including the former presidential candidates Tim Pawlenty and Bob Dole, Sens. Orrin Hatch, Jeff Flake and Dean Heller, as well as four members of the Florida congressional delegation who had previously backed Mr. Bush. Trump supporters gathered Tuesday night at Treasure Island casino on the Las Vegas Strip let out periodic cheers as they watched results come in on television. They lined up through the casino floor and waited in long lines to go up an elevator and head into a ballroom, taxing security efforts and upsetting some of the people trying to get to their rooms.Supporters began a countdown before 9 p.m. and then began cheering loudly as the television stated Mr. Trump had won. Cheers of "Trump! Trump! Trump" came through the crowd.Samantha Fenner, a Las Vegas massage therapist who cast her ballot at Bonanza High School in Las Vegas, said she chose Mr. Trump because of his strong stance against illegal immigration. "I felt strongly that national security is a huge, important issue," she said. "I want people to come legally. We want someone who is sure in that conviction to make that happen."Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, who appeared to place well behind the first three candidates -- and finished fourth in Iowa, eighth in New Hampshire and sixth in South Carolina -- told supporters in Las Vegas that his campaign will continue.Credit: By Reid J. Epstein, Byron Tau and Alexandra Berzon

article name: Trump and the Obama Power Temptation
article text: Of all the Republicans campaigning in Iowa, perhaps none is campaigning harder than Ben Sasse, a Republican senator from Nebraska. Mr. Sasse isn't running for president. He's running against Donald Trump. The particular focus of his opposition deserves a lot more attention.Mr. Sasse is a notable voice in this debate. He's a heavyweight conservative -- a grass-roots favorite, the furthest thing from the "establishment." Before winning his Senate seat in 2014, he had never held elected office. He was the president of Midland University in Fremont, Neb., when he decided that he had to try to get to Washington and help restore the constitutional vision of the Founders.Which is his point in Iowa: "We have a President who does not believe in executive restraint; we do not need another," said Mr. Sasse in a statement announcing that he would campaign with Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz and other "constitutional candidates." On Twitter, Mr. Sasse issued a string of serious questions for Mr. Trump, including: "Will you commit to rolling back Exec power & undoing Obama unilateral habit"?That's a good question for every Republican candidate. President Obama has set a new lawless standard for Washington that might prove tempting for his successor from another party. Why suffer Democratic filibusters when you can sign an executive order? Why wait two years for legislation when you can make it happen overnight? The temptation to cut constitutional corners would be powerful given the pent-up conservative desire for a Washington overhaul.Here's another question for the Republican contenders, a corollary to the Sasse challenge: Do you promise to reject dark power?How the candidates answer ought to matter to every conservative voter. For almost a decade conservatives have suffered under a liberal movement that has honed the tactic of deploying government against its political opponents.The Internal Revenue Service targeted conservative nonprofits -- after Mr. Obama and Democrats encouraged the tax agency to act. Prosecutors hostile to Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker staged predawn raids on conservative activists, part of a secret John Doe probe into bogus campaign-finance violations. Powerful Democratic senators harassed and intimidated conservatives for giving money to free-market groups like the American Legislative Exchange Council. Democrats singled out conservative donors, who found themselves subject to government audits.The Republican presidential contenders would undoubtedly decry those nefarious acts -- and be offended if asked whether they would do the same. Yet power is seductive, and plenty of voters are angry enough to embrace a "Republican Obama" -- that is, someone who would go after their perceived political enemies. Witness the Washington Republicans who last year called on the IRS to hound the Clinton Foundation. Somewhere, Lois Lerner was smiling.Mr. Trump's broadsides are no doubt part of his allure. But how would he conduct himself in a post-Obama White House? Mr. Trump, after all, doesn't merely call out opponents; in this campaign he has threatened individuals and organizations for daring to criticize him. In September he sent a cease-and-desist letter to the Club for Growth, promising a "multi-million-dollar" lawsuit if the group didn't stop running ads in Iowa highlighting his tax ideas.In December Mr. Trump's representatives sent a letter threatening litigation to a wealthy Florida businessman, Mike Fernandez, who ran an ad against the candidate in a local newspaper. Another Trump letter threatened to sue a political-action committee backing presidential rival John Kasich. The company StopTrump.us, which was selling anti-Trump merchandise, was another object of Mr. Trump's litigious saber-rattling. He has also threatened lawsuits against newspapers, including this one. Mr. Trump in November threatened to sue The Wall Street Journal if it didn't retract and apologize for an editorial that criticized him for not understanding the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal. The Journal refused, and his lawyer withdrew the threat.This follows a lifetime of Mr. Trump's using the judicial branch, or simply the threat of legal action, to try to silence his critics. He (unsuccessfully) sued the author of a book that claimed he wasn't really a billionaire. He (successfully) sued a Miss USA contestant for claiming the pageant process was "rigged." He threatened legal action against an activist who had ginned up a campaign to get Macy's to stop selling Trump-branded products (he didn't sue in the end).Sometimes Mr. Trump's legal actions are less about hushing critics than blocking business competition. He sued New York state for letting bars offer a lottery game that might have cut into his casino revenue. He sued New Jersey for funding a tunnel project that would have funneled more people to a rival casino owner's resort.More worrisome is Mr. Trump's willingness to use government to punish a critic. In September on Fox News, National Review's Rich Lowry praised GOP candidate Carly Fiorina by saying that in a debate exchange with Mr. Trump, she had "cut his balls off with the precision of a surgeon." Mr. Trump -- who often derides political correctness -- called on the Federal Communications Commission to fine Mr. Lowry.Mr. Trump is a fan of government power generally, as alarmed constitutional conservatives will tell anyone willing to listen. He has never offered deeply considered views about the office of the presidency -- on its obligations, the limits of its power, the need to exercise restraint."The current administration has resurrected Nixon's weaponization of the bureaucracies against its opponents," says Mr. Sasse. "And I don't have great hope that a guy who brags, 'If someone screws you, screw them back,' is going to return to the rule of law."Mr. Trump on Friday night last week finally responded, sort of, to Mr. Sasse's tweeted queries. "@BenSasse looks more like a gym rat than a U.S. Senator. How the hell did he ever get elected?" Mr. Trump tweeted. Mr. Sasse responded: "Thanks. As the sonuva football &wrestling coach, this is high praise." Then he went back to prodding Mr. Trump about how he would wield power if elected president.A few of Mr. Trump's GOP rivals, perhaps caught up in the public anger or desperate to catch him in the polls, have also flirted with suggesting that they would govern beyond the law. Maybe that's what some voters want. But as those voters weigh their choices, they might spare five minutes to remember the years-long IRS nightmare suffered by dozens of tea party groups, or the fear that grass-roots conservatives felt as Wisconsin police swept into their homes.Government possesses a terrible power that must be used sparingly. Conservatives should prefer a president who agrees.---Ms. Strassel writes the Journal's Potomac Watch column.Credit: By Kimberley A. Strassel

article name: The Trump-Sanders China Syndrome; The charge of currency manipulation was always off-base, but now it's starting to look ludicrous.
article text: Presidential candidates Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, with a phalanx of lawmakers behind them, continue to bash China as a "currency manipulator." Both men claim that Beijing is engaged in a permanent strategy to keep the yuan weak and prop up its trade surplus. But the reality was never that simple, and the charge is ludicrous at present.Beijing began pegging its currency to the U.S. dollar over two decades ago, as part of its plan to integrate the Chinese economy into a global marketplace in which transactions were overwhelmingly priced in dollars. It stuck by this strategy even during the height of the Asian financial crisis, in 1998, when much of the world was expecting it to devalue. This earned it great praise from the U.S. government. "China, by maintaining its exchange rate policy," pronounced President Clinton's Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, "has been an important island of stability in a turbulent region."But once market pressures reversed, and capital began flowing into China, U.S. lawmakers suddenly decided that currency stability was bad: They wanted the yuan to rise, while China continued to keep it fixed. In a 2006 op-ed for this newspaper, Sens. Charles Schumer and Lindsey Graham declared that "one of the fundamental tenets of free trade is that currencies should float." Such a tenet, remarkably, was unknown to either Adam Smith or John Maynard Keynes, neither of whom ever supported any such thing.Fast forward to 2016, and capital is now flowing out of China at a prodigious rate. In an effort to slow the resulting fall in its currency, China's central bank has been selling vast amounts of dollars and buying up yuan. At $3.2 trillion, China's reserves still seem enormous. But they are down $790 billion from their 2014 peak, and $325 billion in the past four months.At this pace of decline, China's reserves will fall to $2.8 trillion in July. To put this in perspective, China, using the International Monetary Fund's framework for reserve-adequacy measurement, needs to hold between $2.8 trillion and $4.2 trillion in reserves to safeguard against a balance-of-payments crisis. Once reserves fall below an adequate precautionary level, China is at risk of being unable to pay for essential imports or its dollar debts. The IMF estimate could be overly cautious, given China's relatively low level of external debt, but it could also be too sanguine in that some significant portion of China's reserves, estimated to be around a third, is believed to be tied up in nonliquid assets--and unavailable in a crisis. These include China's capital commitment to the new Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.So what can China do to stanch the rapid decline in reserves?The country has for years been pursuing what has been called the "Impossible Trinity": controlling interest and exchange rates while leaving the capital account significantly open. Chinese residents are permitted to send up to $50,000 overseas annually and this is enough to allow trillions in outflows. China could impose tighter capital controls to prevent this, as Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda recently urged it to do. This would allow it to operate safely with fewer reserves. The adequate level of precautionary reserves falls to between $1.7 trillion and $2.6 trillion when adjusted for capital controls. But this would put a halt to China's plans to transform the yuan into a major reserve currency--something it will be reluctant to do.China could also raise interest rates, which might encourage capital inflows and discourage outflows, but this would hurt growth in an already sinking economy.Finally, China could let the exchange rate fall significantly, but this would increase the debt burden on Chinese companies. Outstanding dollar credit to Chinese nonfinancial companies is estimated to be around $1 trillion. Too great a fall in the yuan, coupled with slowing economic growth, could precipitate a corporate solvency crisis.That China has no good options, and only a choice among painful ones, reflects the underlying structural problem in the Chinese economy--one that will take many years to fix. The economy was tooled to support grossly overoptimistic expectations of foreign demand for Chinese exports. Retooling it to encourage domestic demand will require time and a willingness by the Chinese government to allow businesses to die so that more promising ones may live.It also shows that American charges that China's currency was massively undervalued were based on the flawed assumption that capital would want, indefinitely, only to get into China and not out. It's a sure bet no one in Washington will be calling for China to float its currency again anytime soon.Mr. Steil is director of international economics at the Council on Foreign Relations and the author of "The Battle of Bretton Woods" (Princeton University Press, 2013). Ms. Smith is an analyst at the council.Credit: By Benn Steil and Emma Smith

article name: Ted Cruz, Donald Trump Split Republican Contests; The Texas senator emerged victorious in Kansas and Maine, while Mr. Trump won Kentucky and Louisiana; Democratic candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders was the victor in Kansas and Nebraska, but front-runner Hillary Clinton took Louisiana's primary
article text: Republican candidate for president Sen. Ted Cruz greets supporters after speaking at a rally on the campus of Boise State University in Boise, Idaho. The Texas senator won contests in Kansas and Maine.Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton speaks at a reception for the Michigan Democratic Party at the MGM Grand Hotel in Detroit. The former secretary of state won the Louisiana Democratic primary but lost the Kansas and Nebraska caucuses to Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont.Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump walks to the podium at a press event at the Trump International Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Fla. The celebrity businessman won the Louisiana GOP primary but lost the Kansas and Maine contests to Mr. Cruz.Mr. Sanders speaks at a campaign event in Warren, Mich., ahead of Tuesday's Michigan Democratic primary. The senator from Vermont came out victorious in the Kansas and Nebraska Democratic caucuses.Republican presidential candidate Sen. Marco Rubio waits to speak at a campaign rally in Jacksonville, Fla. Florida's presidential primary is scheduled for March 15.Republican presidential candidate Ohio Gov. John Kasich speaks at a rally in Traverse City, Mich. The Michigan primary election is scheduled for Tuesday.Supporters of Mr. Cruz in Boise, Idaho, cheer after the Texas senator announced that he won the Maine caucuses.Chris Johnson, accompanied by his daughter Audrey, signs in to vote in the Republican presidential caucus in Louisville, Ky. Saturday's Republican caucus is a first for the state, which had previously selected candidates in a May primary.Kelly Atherton, an official for the Kansas Democratic Party, performs an official count of Mr. Sanders's supporters during the Democratic caucus in Emporia, Kan.Two women in Wichita, Kan., cast their ballots in the state's Republican caucuses.Supporters of Mr. Sanders celebrate at a Democratic caucus in Bellevue, Neb.Jeremy Adkison, a supporter of Mrs. Clinton, leads a cheer for the former secretary of state during the Kansas Democratic caucus in Emporia, Kan.Voters stand in line to check in at the Kentucky Republican caucuses at the Knicely Conference Center in Bowling Green, Ky. The Republican race for president comes to the state with a little-publicized caucus that has some party leaders worrying about low turnout.Voters wait to get into the gymnasium at the Chelsea Elementary School in Chelsea, Maine, to cast their votes at a Republican caucus on Saturday.A voter casts her secret ballot at Saturday's Republican caucus in Chelsea, Maine.Informational tables for the Republican party candidates line the hallway of a caucus site in Wichita, Kan. Though Mr. Trump held a commanding lead in the latest poll, released a week ago by Fort Hays State University, 39% said they were undecided.Wichita, Kan., residents prepare for the Pledge of Allegiance at a caucus site. The state will be allocating 40 delegates on a proportional basis to candidates who earn at least 10% of the vote.

article name: Election 2016: GOP Candidates Make Their Final Appeals --- Trump, Cruz exchange barbs while Rubio says he will be a uniter as Iowa caucuses near
article text: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa -- The crowded Republican presidential race spilled into its final day here with the top-tier candidates making sharply different cases for why each should win the nation's first election contest.Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, returning to a theme he used to launch his campaign, promised to expand the party's electorate. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz accused his rivals of being insufficiently conservative. And Donald Trump, the unimaginable GOP front-runner when the campaign began a year ago, promised rallies across the state to "make America great again" without offering many specifics.The closing arguments reflected bets on who will decide Iowa's Monday night caucuses -- and what placing first, second or third would mean for each camp.Mr. Rubio, in a town-hall style meeting Sunday afternoon at the University of Northern Iowa, argued he is best equipped to unite the GOP's disparate elements as the party has been split by the anti-establishment campaigns of Messrs. Cruz and Trump."No one running for president can bring the conservative movement and the Republican Party back together faster than I can," Mr. Rubio said. "We won't just unite this party, we will grow it."Mr. Cruz closed his Iowa campaign yo-yoing between attacking his two top rivals and offering a strictly positive message about himself. In the campaign's final weeks, the first-term senator diverged from his once-disciplined commitment to avoid attacking other candidates, which endeared him to voters who see in him an alternative to politics as usual.Saturday night in Sioux City, Mr. Cruz went after both of his rivals for their supposed conservative apostasies."A vote for Rubio is a vote for amnesty" for illegal immigrants, Mr. Cruz said. "A vote for Trump is a vote for Obamacare."Mr. Trump fired repeated barbs at Mr. Cruz while essentially ignoring Mr. Rubio. He campaigned alongside Liberty University President Jerry Falwell Jr., who vouched for the New Yorker's appeal for evangelical voters. In a Sunday TV interview on Fox, Mr. Trump said he would "strongly consider" appointing Supreme Court justices who would seek to overturn last year's ruling legalizing same-sex marriage.To his crowds, Mr. Trump crowed over the latest polling numbers. In Council Bluffs, he reminded Iowa voters that Monday is their opportunity to "pick a winner" -- in a state that hasn't picked the GOP nominee since George W. Bush in 2000."You have a lousy record, you've gone 16 years without picking a winner," Mr. Trump said to a laughing crowd. "Please, pick a winner," he added, pointing to himself.Messrs. Cruz and Trump are each heavily invested in winning Iowa. Mr. Cruz declared himself the front-runner here in January, before Mr. Trump launched attacks on his Canadian birth and Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, the state's most popular Republican, said Iowans shouldn't vote for Mr. Cruz because of his opposition to federal ethanol mandates.If Mr. Rubio finishes in second place ahead of either rival, it would be a damaging blow to the candidate coming in third. Rubio aides have publicly played down their own expectations, providing an opening for a surprise finish.One Rubio target, Mike Hammer of Clive, said at Mr. Rubio's Saturday night rally in Urbandale that he remains torn between the Florida senator and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, after previously flirting with Govs. John Kasich of Ohio and Scott Walker of Wisconsin; Mr. Walker ended his campaign in September."Early on I liked governors," said Mr. Hammer, a 56-year-old financial planner. "Now . . . I want to get the guy who can beat Trump."Mr. Cruz's success in Iowa will hinge on winning over voters like Scott Hardwick, a landscaper from North Liberty who had been turned from Mr. Trump by his attacks on Mr. Cruz. "I wasn't anti-Trump until he came down like he did on Ted Cruz," said Mr. Hardwick. "It caused me to eliminate any doubt about who Donald Trump was."Lower-polling candidates aimed to peel away support from the front-runners.Mike Huckabee and Rand Paul are airing ads attacking Mr. Cruz. And Mr. Christie, with 3% support in the latest Des Moines Register poll, argued Messrs. Rubio and Cruz lack sufficient executive experience to be president and slammed Mr. Trump for being unserious.And former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who when the race began was considered a favorite because of his lineage and robust fundraising but is now polling at 2% support, found himself lamenting his inability to attract voters.Credit: By Reid J. Epstein, Janet Hook and Ben Kesling

article name: GOP Vote Hinges on Turnout --- Getting out first-time caucus-goers is seen as key to Trump's chances of winning Iowa
article text: DES MOINES, Iowa -- To pull off a momentum-building win here Monday night, Donald Trump is banking on turnout from people who would be caucusing for the first time, such as Maddie Hiatt.The 20-year-old Drake University student waited in the cold last Thursday to catch a glimpse of the Republican presidential front-runner. She said she definitely plans to caucus for him on Monday."He's running on his own terms, and he's not backed by big corporations," said the sophomore graphic-design major.The most important variable heading into caucus day is how many people will make the trip to their local precinct to vote. That number could prove the difference between a once-improbable win and a disappointing finish by Mr. Trump.Some 39% of likely GOP caucus-goers who haven't turned out in past contests prefer Mr. Trump over his rivals, according to a recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll, 10 percentage points higher than the portion of past participants who favor the front-runner. That poll found Mr. Trump leading the GOP field.Sen. Ted Cruz performs just as well among first-time caucus-goers as among Republicans who have turned out in the past, the WSJ/NBC/Marist poll found. Other surveys show him outperforming Mr. Trump among regular participants."The bigger the turnout, the better it is for Trump," said Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, a Republican.The Democratic race in Iowa features a similar dynamic, with many strategists saying a high turnout would favor Mr. Sanders in his race against Hillary Clinton. Mr. Sanders has made that argument himself. "My prediction is that if tomorrow night there is a large voter turnout we win," he said Sunday in Marshalltown, Iowa.Like Mr. Trump in the Republican race, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders leads among first-time Democratic caucus-goers and lags behind his top rival among those who have previously attended.In the Republican race, internal projections by GOP operatives involved in the race show the prospects of a Trump win improving as the electorate expands above the 120,000-vote range of the past two presidential cycles. But some of those same projections suggest turnout may need to exceed 140,000 voters for Mr. Trump to defeat a Cruz campaign that has focused on caucus-goers who regularly participate in the event.Just under 119,000 Republicans turned out for Iowa's caucuses in 2008, and a record 121,500 caucused in 2012.Iowa GOP Chairman Jeff Kaufmann has suggested as many as 150,000 people could participate, thanks to the exceptionally large field, higher-than-normal interest in the race and, of course, the presence of Mr. Trump.The size of the turnout isn't the only factor that could tip the scales; the makeup of the electorate is also critical. Roughly half of all caucus-goers in 2012 described themselves as "very conservative," and 57% said they were evangelical Christians. But public polls, including the WSJ/NBC/Marist survey, predict a much smaller share of both groups will appear this time around.If that trend holds, Mr. Trump could be in for a big night. He does best among less-conservative voters, while Mr. Cruz, of Texas, outpaces the New York businessman among evangelicals. According to public polls and internal campaign models, the race gets a lot tighter if evangelicals represent a similar share of the caucus-night electorate as they did in 2012."The Cruz coalition largely consists of Iowans who caucus every four years like it's their job," said Matt Strawn, who chaired the Iowa GOP during the 2012 presidential election. "The power of Iowa's Christian-conservative voting bloc would be diluted if a surge of first-time caucus attendees turn out to support Trump."But the risk for Mr. Trump is that people who haven't voted before will be put off by the caucus process, which can involve spending hours Monday night listening to political speeches before casting a ballot. One voter attending Mr. Trump's Davenport rally Saturday wasn't sure whether she could vote that night."Is this the caucus?" asked Ellen Kine of Davenport, before being reminded that it was just a rally for Mr. Trump.There is little evidence of a big surge in new, Republican voters. A Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics poll found that first-timers accounted for 40% of the expected GOP electorateMonday, in line with the 38% of newcomers in 2012.The Register poll in 2008 successfully predicted the surge of new caucus-goers who boosted Barack Obama to victory in the Democratic contest. Nearly 240,000 Democrats showed up that year.The campaigns spent the final weekend before balloting doing everything they could to juice turnout. The Cruz campaign has assembled 12,000 volunteers, making more than 20,000 calls a day to likely caucus-goers and knocking on more than 1,000 doors."At this point, it is all turnout," Mr. Cruz told reporters in Sioux City on Saturday.While the Cruz camp prioritizes traditional caucus-goers, the Trump campaign is particularly focused on voters who attended his rallies or visited his campaign website or Facebook page, Iowa Republicans said. On Saturday night, Mr. Trump's daughter Ivanka took to a Facebook video to explain in minute detail how to caucus for her father.Despite his lead in most polls, Mr. Trump remains a polarizing figure among Republicans here. Some regular caucus-goers who had planned to back the billionaire said they were jumping ship in the closing days, with many noting his decision to skip the final candidates' debate last Thursday."The people of Iowa deserve to hear his closing argument," said Bryan Moon, 54, a Republican from West Des Moines who had planned to vote for Mr. Trump.Love him or not, Mr. Trump remains the biggest attraction in the race. Thousands of students and supporters stood outside an auditorium on the Drake campus Thursday night to get a seat for his impromptu fundraiser for veterans after he backed out of the Fox News debate."I'm not sure I could be this excited about another candidate," said Alec Bognor, 18, a Drake student who spoke on Mr. Trump's behalf at the school's mock caucus event. "I wouldn't sit in line for three hours for Marco Rubio."---Janet Hook contributed to this article.Credit: By Patrick O'Connor

article name: Election 2016: Trump Campaign Makes Last Push
article text: DAVENPORT, Iowa -- Furniture sales manager Lee Kerr laughed when the bartender said the crowds coming for a drink after the Donald Trump rally here Saturday were wearing him out."We got too many Trump people down here who just want to spend money, people who want to put money into the economy!" bellowed Mr. Kerr, a stout fellow holding a bottle of Bud Light, who said he's a Trump man through-and-through. "Everything he touches turns to gold!"Mr. Kerr headed to the Me & Billy bar and restaurant rather than the rally in part because he's already made his mind up on who he's going to caucus for Monday, when voting finally begins in the 2016 presidential primary races.He knows where the candidate stands because of the GOP front-runner's personal appearances in the state -- and the controversy and the free media exposure that comes with it. Mr. Kerr has gotten calls from the Trump machine to make sure he turns out for his first-ever caucus.In short, Mr. Kerr is an example of just how unusual the Trump campaign has been. The first-time candidate has broken almost all the political rules, by insulting women, minorities and even Fox News, the media darling for most conservative Republicans.It's another surprising element in the candidacy of Mr. Trump, a reality television star and billionaire businessman-turned-politician. His unorthodox campaign, once dismissed by party insiders as a political folly, has dominated one of the longest and most unpredictable beginnings to a presidential race in modern history. If he wins the GOP nomination, his campaign could fundamentally change both the Republican Party and the way business is conducted on the campaign trail.Mr. Trump's campaign has been calling voters, but those interviewed said they weren't cajoled by campaign representatives to do any volunteering and weren't even helped to find their caucus locations. Campaign workers sometimes work the crowd to get contact information and pass out literature, but not always.In response to a request for the size of Mr. Trump's operation in Iowa, his campaign said, "Seventeen paid staffers, thousands of volunteers!"Mr. Trump closed his Iowa campaign by covering the state in recent days, using his signature Boeing 757 to make appearances in front of huge crowds in places like Davenport rather than the traditional close-up meetings with voters. He also made whistle stops in places like Dubuque, where he held a rally in a hangar at the regional airport. The plane did a low flyby of the crowd as soaring music played on a public address system before circling back around, landing and pulling right up next to the throng so he had to walk just a few steps to address them.The most recent Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics Iowa Poll released Saturday shows Mr. Trump, with 28% support of likely voters, pulling even further ahead of his closest rival, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, who slid to 23%.His message has remained consistent even in the closing days of the Iowa campaign. Build a wall on the Mexican border, freeze immigration, support gun owners, mock the Iran deal and tout independence from the establishment. His recent courting of evangelicals has also taken more prominence, with Jerry Falwell Jr., Liberty University president, joining him Saturday and Sunday.Mr. Trump added some final flourishes to the usual script to ensure supporters get out to vote. "It all doesn't matter if you don't caucus on Monday," he said at the Davenport rally Saturday. "The polls don't matter, nothing matters. The only thing that matters is the poll that's going to be taken on Monday."At a Sunday rally in Council Bluffs he praised Iowans' intellect, telling them, "People are very smart, they just get it," and adding, "You are going to make a decision soon and we're going to do a hell of a job."Credit: By Ben Kesling

article name: Election 2016: Voters Question Moves by Trump --- Accusations over Iowa don't sit well with some Republicans in New Hampshire
article text: EXETER, N.H. -- After a second-place finish in the Iowa caucuses, Donald Trump has been making accusations and shifting his message and tactics as he tries to regain the title of Republican presidential front-runner.Some of it isn't sitting well with New Hampshire voters just as they are settling on their candidate of choice in next Tuesday's primary.The celebrity businessman has accused the Iowa winner, Ted Cruz, of cheating after the Texas senator's campaign and his supporters incorrectly suggested to voters that retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson was quitting the race."Actually, I think I came in first," Mr. Trump said to cheers at a campaign rally in Arkansas on Wednesday night. "That voter fraud, these politicians are brutal," he said.While Mr. Cruz apologized to Mr. Carson, who hasn't suspended his campaign, Mr. Trump's complaints -- and his demand for a do-over in Iowa -- were off-putting to some voters here."I just think he's being a poor loser," said Elizabeth Bavely, a 48-year-old independent from Concord, N.H. "When it came down to the people in that room, that's what it came down to, and we have to respect that decision," she said in a reference to the Iowa caucuses.Dave Connors, 71, of Hampton, N.H., who attended a Cruz event Thursday, said that he and his wife "were really big Trump supporters, but his lack of filter is really getting to me."Other voters remained steadfast in their support for Mr. Trump, who continues to lead in New Hampshire polls.Paul Giovannucci, 47, is sticking with Mr. Trump, but said the campaign should move on, and that Mr. Trump's second place was good enough for him. "I think he did wonderful," said Mr. Giovannucci.For those already leaning against Mr. Trump, his reaction to his first political loss only cemented their opinion."He's used to being in charge all the time. So for him to not be in charge this time, I think it is hard for his ego," said Stephanie Bissonnette, 49, a medical worker from Weare, N.H.On Thursday, Mr. Trump eased off his accusations and began shifting his message and tactics. As he started atown-hall event here, he didn't rattle off a series of polls showing him in first place -- even though a recent New Hampshire survey has him ahead.A University of Massachusetts-Lowell/7News survey taken since Iowa's caucuses found that Mr. Trump had 36% of support among GOP primary voters, with Florida Sen. Marco Rubio at 15% and Mr. Cruz at 14%.The poll showed that Mr. Trump's support fell slightly in the days after the caucus votes, but it was within the margin of errorof 3%.Mr. Trump also salted his campaign schedule with the sort of smaller, retail events that he had previously mocked his competitors for holding.The town hall was held at a historic site with room for hundreds of people, not the thousands he has typically drawn to rallies.During it, he added a new issue to his agenda -- using the power of the presidency to negotiate lower drug prices -- and reminded attendees that he isn't beholden to the drug industry because he isn't soliciting campaign donations.After the town hall, Mr. Trump met with supporters at a nearby business for a retail stop that was closed to reporters. He later delivered remarks at a shift change for the Manchester police department."The police have been so amazing in our country, and they're not really recognized the way they should be," said Mr. Trump. He told the officers that every time he mentions the police, he gets an ovation at his rallies.Patrol Officer Adam Beland said the officers talk about politics every day -- and he is firmly on team Trump, as are many of the officers. "I just think he speaks what people are trying to say, and he has the nerve to say it," he said.Mr. Trump's attacks on Mr. Cruz have resonated with some voters in the state. "I liked Cruz but I'm not liking how he's handled Iowa," said Lois Flad, 69, a retiree, while waiting in line to see Mr. Trump address a crowd gathered here Thursday. "That was the last straw."Meanwhile, Mr. Cruz sought to turn the tables and use Mr. Trump's complaints against him. He coined the phrase "Trump-tantrum" on Wednesday and said Thursday that Mr. Trump seemed "rattled.""I don't know anyone who would be comfortable with someone who behaves this way having his finger on the button," Mr. Cruz told the crowd in Nashua, N.H.During a Thursday evening interview on CNN's "Anderson Cooper 360," Mr. Trump said he was over Iowa and was now focused on New Hampshire. He said that he wanted to win the state.Asked about Mr. Cruz's tantrum attack, Mr. Trump embraced it as a sign of his forceful personality. "I love that phrase. I actually like that," Mr. Trump said.---Patrick O'Connor and Natalie Andrews contributed to this article.Credit: By Heather Haddon

article name: The Economy Trumps Everything
article text: Donald Trump, it may truly be said, drove to the surface of our politics heretofore unrecognized degrees of voter anger. It may be Mr. Trump's misfortune that he has wrongly calculated the core reason for that anger.He believed the big revelation of his June presidential announcement speech was support for his criticism of U.S. immigration policy. And so he rode it.Elections are won or lost at the margin, and the margin is where Mr. Trump lost Iowa to Ted Cruz by three points.The Iowa entrance polls reveal that Mr. Trump got 44% of the vote from people who believe immigration is the campaign's top issue. Unfortunately, at least in Iowa, only 13% think that. Ted Cruz got 34% of their vote. Immigration matters, but Messrs. Cruz and Trump may be overweighting its importance in election outcomes.On the central conservative issue of government spending -- Iowa Republicans' top concern at 32% -- Mr. Cruz led with 27% to Mr. Trump's meager 19%. Mr. Trump also trailed Marco Rubio here.Sophists might argue that spending is Republican code for suppressing outlays on Social Security and Medicare, which Mr. Trump, with an eye toward the general election, has said he won't do. Then let's move on to the less partisan subject of jobs and the economy, which Iowa Republicans' identified as their second most-pressing issue. Marco Rubio won them with 30% of the vote.At the margin, Mr. Trump lost votes to Messrs. Cruz and Rubio on spending and to Mr. Rubio on the economy.For the purposes of my argument -- that the U.S.'s economy should be dominating the 2016 primaries -- I combine government spending and economy/jobs into one issue. For Iowa Republicans, that puts economic concerns at nearly 60%.Meet the Democrats. The economy and jobs are the top concern for 33% of Iowa Democrats. As an ideological obsession, they substitute "income inequality" for spending, at 27%. Toss in "health care" at 30% and the economy is the only issue for Democrats.What makes Iowans' elevated economic worries intriguing as a proxy for the primaries is that their state isn't doing badly. Iowa's nominal unemployment rate is 3.4%. New Hampshire's is 3.1%.But in South Carolina, which votes on Feb. 20, unemployment is 5.5% Three days later come the caucuses in Nevada, whose jobless rate is 6.4%. At least three states in the March 1 Super Tuesday primary are hurting -- Georgia, Tennessee and Alabama.Conventional wisdom holds that Hillary Clinton will sink Bernie Sanders once she gets to the family's automatic black votes in the South. Don't be shocked, though, if Bernie's economic populism finds an ear there, too.The unemployment rate for black men in South Carolina was 12.2% when last measured in the first quarter of 2015. In Arkansas it was 13.2% and over 9% in Texas. Mrs. Clinton better hope young black males are still mooning over a Clinton presidency that ended 15 years ago."It's the economy, stupid" is a famous phrase about the importance of political messaging in a presidential campaign. Most Americans, who aren't stupid, know that in the eighth year of Barack Obama's presidency, the U.S. economy is simply not normal.U.S. economic growth in last year's final quarter was 0.7%. The stock market has taken up cliff-diving. That's tough on the former savers who decided they couldn't survive two presidential terms with the Federal Reserve's microscopic interest rates, and moved into stocks.This newspaper reported days ago that the number of initial public offerings from young companies in January was . . . zero. The reason is "a broad retreat from risk by investors."Let us not forget China, which permits us not to forget Donald Trump's role in all this.Last year China's economy grew at its slowest rate in more than 20 years. The International Monetary Fund has lowered its 2016 growth estimates for the world economy.Amid nearly every arrow out there pointing downward, Mr. Trump floated the idea of imposing a 45% tariff on Chinese goods imported into the U.S.Another Republican TV debate bubbles up this Saturday. The Trump tariff came up the last time he participated, and one wonders if this time someone will push the argument further -- to the 1930 Smoot-Hawley tariff and the Great Depression. He may win New Hampshire, but if the others close the gap, doubts about his economic statements will be the reason.Ted Cruz also tanked on the economy and jobs in Iowa, receiving a surprisingly small 18% of that vote. He's doing all right on the two issues he has politicized -- immigration and Washington spending -- but has little voter resonance on the economy itself.The details of Iowa's voting suggest Mr. Cruz is self-defining himself out of the economic-growth issue. For now, Marco Rubio has taken control of the one subject with the biggest base in American politics -- the economy and jobs.Credit: By Daniel Henninger

article name: How Trump Blew an Easy Win
article text: It was quite a turnaround. After he led in Iowa most of December, Ted Cruz's numbers started falling Jan. 6, after Donald Trump declared him ineligible for the presidency because he was born in Canada. But Mr. Cruz unleashed a disciplined, data-driven get-out-the-vote effort aimed at social conservatives. The Texan won Iowa with 28% of the vote, four points ahead of where he stood going into caucus day, according to the Real Clear Politics polling average.Then Mr. Cruz gave the evening's most undisciplined victory speech, droning on for 32 1/2 minutes, nearly as long as the other major candidates combined. He said his win meant that the GOP nominee would not be chosen by "the media," the "Washington establishment" or "lobbyists." Yet The Donald is championed by none of those.Mr. Cruz expressed, at length, his thanks for 800,000 contributions, a volunteer who quit his job to help in Iowa, two Chicago law students who spent their break canvassing the state, a teenage Texan who made 823 phone calls in one day, his campaign's top Iowa officials, his cousin Bebe, and his parents. Approaching the half-hour mark, his promise that "morning is coming" seemed a threat about how long he would speak.As impressive as his win was, Iowa is a state tailor-made for Mr. Cruz. His challenge now is New Hampshire, which lacks Iowa's substantial number of evangelicals, and where he hasn't spent the time or built the same kind of organization.Going into Monday's caucus Mr. Trump led by nearly five points in the Real Clear Politics average. But he barely came in second, with 24% of the final vote. Mr. Trump's refusal to attend the last debate, focus on the ground game or even have surrogates at many caucus meetings contributed to his defeat. He acted as if traditional rules didn't apply to him, and killed his chance for an easy victory.Mr. Trump's speech was the evening's shortest -- four minutes -- and surprisingly gracious. Yet he bragged that he was up by 28 points in New Hampshire (seven points higher than his actual lead in the polling average). He may prevail, but why raise expectations?Speaking of expectations, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio beat his, running six points ahead of his polling average, ending with 23%, just behind Mr. Trump. He gave the evening's best speech, describing himself as the underdog, assailing President Obama, and saying that Hillary Clinton's emails show "she thinks she's above the law." Mr. Rubio's Reagan-like challenge for Republicans was steeped in optimism. "We will embrace all the principles that made America great," he said, "and we will apply them to the unique challenges of this new century."But if Mr. Rubio wants to emerge from the pack, he must keep his momentum in New Hampshire, which doesn't often follow Iowa's lead. His challenge is that others -- Ohio Gov. John Kasich, former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie -- have all invested more time there.On the Democratic side, Mrs. Clinton said Monday night that she was "breathing a big sigh of relief." Not long ago it seemed she could lose Iowa to Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist. Mr. Sanders had enthusiasm: 43% of likely Democratic caucus-goers described themselves as "socialist" in a Jan. 10 survey for Bloomberg Politics and the Des Moines Register.But Mrs. Clinton invested millions in the ground game that produced her narrow win. Her victory speech was angry, joyless and plaintive, as she begged Democrats to remember "we have to be united." By contrast Mr. Sanders told raucous supporters that by fighting Mrs. Clinton to a virtual draw, they had beaten "the most powerful political organization in the United States." Iowa, he declared, has sparked "a political revolution."Unlikely. Mr. Sanders leads in New Hampshire by 18 points, according to the polling average, and it's unclear whether Mrs. Clinton's organization alone can make up the difference. But when the race turns to the South, her advantage among nonwhite and moderate Democrats will probably sink Mr. Sanders, though he has enough money and youthful left-wing enthusiasm to ride on until the convention.The future on the GOP side remains opaque. New Hampshire will further narrow the field, but only 2% of delegates will be selected there and in Iowa. By February's end less than 5% will have been chosen. In 2012 the contest didn't dwindle to one candidate until May 14, and Mitt Romney didn't secure his delegate majority until May 29. This year, if three or maybe four Republicans are still standing after South Carolina, it could take until June -- or the convention -- for anyone to clinch the nomination.If Donald Trump had won Iowa, he could have run the table. Not now. We're in for a long haul.---Mr. Rove helped organize the political-action committee American Crossroads and is the author of "The Triumph of William McKinley: Why the 1896 Election Still Matters" (Simon & Schuster, 2015).Credit: By Karl Rove

article name: Election 2016: Trump's D.C. Hotel to Open Early --- The high-profile project has, at times, been drawn into campaign politics
article text: Donald Trump's real-estate company is planning to open its closely watched Washington, D.C., hotel project ahead of schedule, a move that could help underscore the Republican presidential candidate's skills as a developer.The Trump Organization, which has been converting the Old Post Office building with its soaring clock tower into a luxury 263-room hotel, is set to open it in early September, according to Ivanka Trump, Mr. Trump's daughter, who has been spearheading the project. The opening had been expected by the hotel industry later in 2016.But Ms. Trump said in an interview that the opening of the Trump International Hotel actually would be two years ahead of schedule. She said the U.S. General Services Administration -- which owns the landmark building and is leasing it to the Trump Organization for 140 years -- said the $200 million project had to be completed by August 2018.Given the complexity in working with numerous government agencies and restoring a building built in the late 1800s, the September opening amounts to a "herculean" feat, she said."It requires a lot more time on site than a ground-up project," she said.Mr. Trump, who has been leading the polls in the New Hampshire Republican primary, has no experience holding government office and has made his business career a cornerstone of his campaign. While the ups and downs of his half-century career have been hotly debated, few have challenged his success as a developer in bringing most of his real-estate projects in on time and on budget.Ms. Trump said the Trump Organization is announcing the opening of the Washington hotel now because it is going to start accepting reservations, and the timing has nothing to do with Tuesday's New Hampshire primary.Hotel experts have viewed the Washington project as a risky one for the Trump Organization partly because of the cost of the renovation and the large amount of competition that it faced in winning the GSA bid. Also, there are about 3,500 to 4,000 new hotel rooms in the pipeline in Washington, D.C., including a luxury Conrad Hotel now under construction at CityCenter, a few blocks from the Old Post Office building, according to Kannan Sankaran, managing director of CBRE Hotels.Mr. Trump so far has spent $42 million of his own money on the Washington hotel project, an unusually big bet for him to make at this stage in his career. While he was well-known for taking big risks in his early years, more recently many of his real-estate deals have involved licensing the Trump brand to other developers.But the Post Office conversion project was unique in its architecture, history and location on Pennsylvania Avenue between the White House and the Capitol, Ms. Trump said. "It's impossible not to be incredibly passionate about a project such as this," she said.The hotel will include a 13,200-square-foot ballroom, a nine-story atrium topped with a glass skylight and a suite called the "Trump Townhouse," with its own entrance. The building's 315-foot clock tower is one of the highest points in the city and will be open to guests and tourists.Other bidders for the GSA long-term lease included Hilton Worldwide and Hyatt Hotels & Resorts.Some were surprised when the Trump Organization won, partly because its Trump Hotels chain -- which includes properties in New York, Chicago, Las Vegas, Toronto and other locations -- doesn't have the global reach of some of its competitors.Ms. Trump says GSA liked the fact that the Trump Organization was a family business and planned to hold the property for generations."The joke was that my daughter, Arabella, who I was pregnant with at the time, was going to be negotiating with the government in decades to come," said Ms. Trump, who is close to nine months pregnant with her third child.Although the Trump Organization tries to keep business and politics separate, the Washington hotel project has gotten caught up in the campaign from time to time.Celebrity chef Jose Andres backed out of a plan to open a flagship restaurant at the hotel, citing the remarks Mr. Trump made in a June speech that Mr. Andres said disparaged Mexicans.Also, some have questioned whether other controversial statements Mr. Trump has made might turn away some hotel guests.Ms. Trump said that Mr. Andres's planned restaurant has been replaced with a BLT Prime steak house. She also disagreed that there would be any adverse business impact from her father's campaign remarks."The support he's generated and enthusiasm we've seen across the country speak for themselves," she said.The Washington, D.C., hotel market currently is enjoying strong occupancy levels thanks to record tourism and demand from business travelers, CBRE's Mr. Sankaran said. Luxury hotels in particular are doing well because of the limited supply, he said.Room rates of the new Trump hotel haven't been announced, but Ms. Trump said that they would be "at the highest level" in the city. Mr. Sankaran said that luxury rates in the city range from $350 to $425 a night. He said he thought those rates would be "achievable" by the new Trump hotel.Credit: By Peter Grant

article name: Rubio Challenges Trump, Cruz in Poll
article text: MANCHESTER, N.H. -- The Republican presidential race in the Granite State increasingly looks like a referendum on Sen. Marco Rubio as much as on the current front-runner, Donald Trump.While the celebrity businessman still holds a double-digit lead ahead of Tuesday's New Hampshire primary, Mr. Rubio ranked second in the latest Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll of likely New Hampshire primary voters, released on Friday. It caps a week of the Florida senator rising in the polls following a surprisingly strong third-place finish in Monday's Iowa caucuses.Well-heeled donors in New York and other wealthy enclaves are showing renewed interest in Mr. Rubio. Other Republicans are rallying around him, including former Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, his onetime rival who endorsed Mr. Rubio late Friday.Mr. Rubio has emerged as a clear alternative to Mr. Trump and the Iowa winner, Sen. Ted Cruz, for Republicans looking to back someone else. He was the top pick of 17% in the Marist poll, jumping six percentage-points from a pre-Iowa survey. Mr. Cruz had 15% and Mr. Trump led with 30%.Meanwhile, three current and former governors -- Jeb Bush of Florida, Chris Christie of New Jersey and John Kasich of Ohio -- are fighting to keep their bids alive, according to the new poll.Mr. Rubio's crowds have swelled, and in a sign that he can go deeper into the primary season, the Las Vegas newspaper owned by GOP mega-donor Sheldon Adelson, chief executive of Las Vegas Sands Corp., on Friday endorsed Mr. Rubio, a potential boost ahead of the Nevada caucuses on Feb. 23."Even though he's scripted, he's solid on the issues," said James Betti, 58 years old, a physician from Rye, N.H., who attended a Trump event Thursday but is leaning toward supporting Mr. Rubio.Other Republicans will get a chance to slow Mr. Rubio's rise Saturday night at the last candidates' debate, sponsored by ABC News and WMUR, the local affiliate. Mr. Christie's attacks have been particularly fierce, dubbing Mr. Rubio "the boy in the bubble" for his reluctance to stray from his stump speech and questioning his record of achievement in the Senate.Joe McQuaid, publisher of the Union Leader, which has endorsed Mr. Christie, penned a stinging editorial that ran on the front page of Friday's paper criticizing Mr. Rubio. "Young Rubio must think New Hampshire a bunch of rubes," he wrote. "He hasn't spent much time here but is trying to sell himself with TV ads as someone who can go to Washington to clean up the Washington mess. Earth to Rubio: You are a U.S. senator. The Senate meets in Washington. You are hardly an outsider."Mr. Cruz also enjoyed a post-Iowa bump in the poll following his win over Mr. Trump. He laughed off the increased attention on Mr. Rubio. "If momentum was measured by the media, Marco Rubio would already be the Republican nominee," Mr. Cruz told reporters after a campaign stop in Weare, N.H. "In the media's telling, bronze is the new gold. And Iowa demonstrated the media doesn't get to the pick the Republican nominee."Some of the attacks -- that Mr. Rubio is too young, that he supported a pathway to citizenship for people in the country illegally, and that he has skipped too many Senate votes -- have sunk in with some voters here."The thing that concerns me is him not being at the votes," said Charlie List, 58, of Derry, N.H., who attended a Rubio event Friday night but is still on the fence. "Most people, if you don't show up for work, you don't get paid."People fundraising for Mr. Rubio's team said fence-sitting Wall Street donors are finally warming to him. Bankers, hedge-fund managers, private-equity executives and other financial-industry professionals are promising to open their wallets, according to interviews with existing donors and some others who are planning to contribute.Investors would like to see Mr. Rubio prevail because he is a "very business-friendly but competent, likeable candidate," said David Bahnsen, chief investment officer at HighTower Advisors.Mr. Rubio, 44, has already attracted some younger Wall Street donors who have not previously been all that politically active, including: Thomas Farley, president of NYSE Group; hedge-fund manager Eric Mandelblatt of Soroban Capital Partners LP; Brian Levine, a managing director at Goldman Sachs Group Inc.; and Sean Klimczak, a senior managing director at Blackstone Group LP, say people familiar with the matter.In his closing argument to Iowa Republicans, Mr. Rubio talked up his conservatism, religious faith and ability to unite disparate wings of the GOP. In New Hampshire, he has spoken of uniting the entire country, an appeal that could resonate more in a state where independents accounted for nearly half of the GOP primary electorate in 2012."We need to stop pitting Americans against each other," Mr. Rubio told hundreds of people packed into a second-floor bar in Dover, N.H., citing his work across the aisle in the Florida Legislature.Some undecided GOP primary voters here said Mr. Rubio's performance in Iowa, coupled with a perception that he would perform well against a Democrat in the general election, are the biggest factors working in his favor. In addition, they note that he seems more viable than other Republicans seeking the support of the party's less-conservative voters.But Mr. Rubio hasn't sealed the deal with them yet. Mark Swartz, 55, an undecided primary voter from Rye, said he is torn between Messrs. Kasich, Rubio and Trump. "I'm not sure Kasich has the legs to make it to November," Mr. Swartz said. "That's why I'm leaning toward Rubio."---Reid J. Epstein contributed to this article.Credit: By Patrick O'Connor and Anupreeta Das

article name: One Year Later, It's Still a Terrible Iran Deal; Donald Trump is right that the Iran nuclear deal is one of the worst ever made.
article text: The issues raised by Ambassador Yousef Al Otaiba in "One Year After the Iran Nuclear Deal " (op-ed, April 4) should not come as a surprise to anyone. One thing Donald Trump is right about is that the Iran nuclear deal is one of the worst deals ever made. The U.S. virtually negotiated against itself by constantly rewarding Iran for missing deadlines and failing to negotiate in good faith. In the end, Iran got $150 billion to aid its economy and sponsor terrorism throughout the world, and we got assurances that the country would inspect its own nuclear sites. As one commentator said, it's like mailing a baseball player a drug test and allowing him to return the results. The deal failed to limit Iran's ability to fund terrorism and didn't deal adequately with the country's ability to develop intercontinental ballistic missiles that can be used to carry nuclear weapons.Unfortunately, Mr. Otaiba's hope for the reimposition of sanctions will likely fall on deaf ears. President Obama has continued to bluster but economic sanctions against Iran will be opposed by our allies who are prepared to do billions of dollars of business with the mullahs. This Humpty Dumpty will not be put back together.R.M. SussmanParadise Valley, Ariz.India, Pakistan, North Korea, China and Russia all have become nuclear nations without our permission. What makes the ambassador think that Saudi Arabia, Japan or South Korea need our permission to go nuclear? Post-World War II history has clearly shown that nations will or won't go nuclear strictly on the basis of their own welfare--regardless of America's wishes. Iran is proceeding along these lines despite the U.S. begging it not to.As for the U.S. safety umbrella, let's get real now. We have proved that our "red line" is a myth. Bandit nations may and do cross it at will. This is not the America of the Greatest Generation."Robert SmithAllentown, Pa.

article name: Election 2016: Trump Wades Into Debate on Property Rights
article text: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump waded into a thorny controversy over land-use issues in New Hampshire just before voters head to the polls to cast ballots in the state's presidential primary.Mr. Trump, who made his fortune in the real-estate industry, said during a Republican presidential debate on Saturday that he was in favor of robust use of eminent domain, the practice of government entities forcing property owners to sell land for development or infrastructure uses.Mr. Trump's support for the practice has potential risks nationally, as many conservatives oppose the practice as government overreach. The issue is particularly fraught in New Hampshire, where many residents are deeply skeptical of eminent domain -- especially Republican primary voters who are wary of government and strongly believe in private-property rights.For many officials in towns and cities across the Granite State, "eminent domain is not in their toolbox at all, even for the most worthy of public projects," said Richard Uchida, a land-use lawyer at law firm Hinckley Allen's office in Concord, N.H.Angry voters amended New Hampshire's constitution to bar any use of eminent domain for "private development" following a controversial 2005 U.S. Supreme Court decision in a Connecticut case, Kelo v. City of New London, that affirmed the right of governments to seize property and hand it another private owner to further economic development.The Kelo decision sent lasting political tremors well beyond New England. It set off a swift backlash in most state capitals and remains deeply unpopular in many quarters. John Paul Stevens, who crafted the Supreme Court's ruling in Kelo, later called it the "most unpopular opinion I ever wrote."In this weekend's debate, Mr. Trump launched into a defense of eminent domain, calling it "an absolute necessity." He endorsed using eminent domain to build the Northern Pass project -- a controversial 192-mile electrical transmission line that would carry power from Quebec to southern New England."His embrace of eminent domain in the Northern Pass could certainly cost him votes in the north," said Ryan Williams, a Republican consultant who has worked in New Hampshire politics and now supports Jeb Bush.Northern Pass backers have long said it won't rely on eminent domain. Still, worries in recent years that land might be taken for that or other projects have sparked a flurry of bills in the state legislature, and skepticism about them crosses party lines.A spokeswoman for Mr. Trump's campaign didn't respond to a request for comment.Some of his Republican rivals have taken the opposite tack on the issue of eminent domain in advance of the New Hampshire primary -- and the issue could be a salient one for some voters with libertarian leanings. Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush criticized Mr. Trump's history of using eminent domain when he was a real-estate developer. And at a stop in Peterborough, Sen. Ted Cruz called the 2005 Supreme Court decision on eminent domain "a disgrace."Credit: By Byron Tau and Ben Leubsdorf

article name: Trump, Sanders Roll in N.H. --- Cluster of GOP Rivals Leaves Field Muddled
article text: MANCHESTER, N.H. -- Donald Trump won the New Hampshire Republican presidential primary by a decisive margin Tuesday, claiming his first victory of the 2016 campaign and leaving the rest of the GOP field as murky as ever.The billionaire businessman received 35% of the vote -- more than double his nearest competitor -- allowing him to regain momentum in a race that he has led since the summer on the strength of his blustery, tradition-defying style.Lagging far behind was a cluster of rivals, none of whom broke from the pack enough to establish himself as a singular alternative to Mr. Trump.The biggest beneficiary was Ohio Gov. John Kasich, buoyed by a surge of late-deciding voters from far back in the pack. His second-place finish rescues him from near-certain elimination if he had failed to catch fire in a state he had made almost the sole focus of his campaign.New Hampshire had been expected to be a springboard for Sen. Marco Rubio, but his widely panned debate performance Saturday, where he was attacked repeatedly by New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, proved damaging. Exit polls found two-thirds of voters said recent debates had been important to their decision on how to vote.For Mr. Christie, his withering takedown wasn't enough to elevate his own flagging campaign, casting doubt on his ability to continue in the race. He canceled his appearances in South Carolina, the site of the next GOP primary, opting to head home to New Jersey to consider his next steps in the presidential race. "We're going to take a deep breath and see what the results are tonight," he said.Lou DeRosa, an energy consultant from Hampstead, said the debate left Mr. Rubio bruised by charges that he was too inexperienced and ill equipped for the presidency. "I think that Rubio got destroyed by a little love tap in the debate," said Mr. De Rosa, who voted for Mr. Kasich.As returns came in, Mr. Rubio was trailing Mr. Kasich, Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas -- winner of the Iowa caucuses -- and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, a former mentor whose own faltering campaign may get some breathing room from the New Hampshire results.Mr. Rubio had been counting on his surprisingly strong third-place finish in Iowa to give him a head of steam -- "Marcomentum," as his campaign has dubbed it in recent days. Polls had shown him steadily in second place in New Hampshire before the weekend debate.The results bring little clarity to the competition among GOP candidates who are seeking to be the mainstream GOP alternative to Mr. Trump and Mr. Cruz. That portends a lengthy and difficult race because the longer there are at least three viable candidates amassing delegates, the harder it becomes for anyone to clinch the nomination.Mr. Trump's victory declaration by the Associated Press and television networks came so soon after the polls closed that many of his supporters had yet to arrive at his victory party.He hailed his win with characteristic bombast: "We are going to do something so good, so fast and so strong, and the world is going to respect us again -- believe me."Mr. Kasich promised his supporters a tough fight ahead. "If you don't have a seat belt, go get one."Mr. Trump's big lead belies skepticism about whether he could translate his huge rally crowds and high poll numbers into victory in a state where voters have high expectations of contact with presidential candidates.The near-deadlock among the next tier of candidates means that a robust competition among Messrs. Rubio, Kasich and other candidates will continue into the next primary contests on terrain less hospitable to those more-establishment oriented candidates.The nominating contest now moves to deeply conservative Southern states more hospitable to the candidacies of Messrs. Trump and Cruz, who won the Iowa caucuses last week largely on the strength of evangelical Christian support.Next up are South Carolina and Nevada, where evangelicals and a stauncher brand of conservatism dominate. Beyond those states, the path to the nomination doesn't get much smoother for the party's establishment-oriented candidates. On March 1, 11 states vote in the so-called SEC primary, which includes Alabama, Georgia and Arkansas.Mr. Kasich, the candidate who diverges most often from conservative orthodoxy, is undaunted by the prospect. He has three events scheduled in South Carolina Wednesday, chartered a plane to carry the press along, and promised a full-court press even though he has only slim political organization beyond New Hampshire."We take our snow boots off and put our flip-flops on," Mr. Kasich told reporters outside a polling site in Concord. "We're going to go to South Carolina. We'll go tonight."To be sure, New Hampshire could drive one or more candidates from the race but no one was ready to concede anything over the past week of intensive campaigning in the snow-blanketed Granite State.All nine candidates were scrambling to woo the many voters -- Republicans and independents -- who were undecided until the last minute. According to exit polls, 46% of GOP voters made up their mind on Tuesday or in last "few days.""In New Hampshire you can throw those polls away," said John Lyons, an 83-year-old Portsmouth independent who even put off the decision about which party's primary to vote in. "People will go into that booth, and they won't mean a thing. People are different here in New Hampshire."The GOP electorate is indeed distinctive. In New Hampshire, exit polls showed that 25% of voters said they are evangelicals or born-again Christians; they were 64% in Iowa and are projected to be 65% in South Carolina. New Hampshire's voters also are less conservative: 29% of primary voters said they were "very conservative" -- compared with 40% in Iowa and 36% in South Carolina.Exit polls showed Mr. Trump winning among almost every major demographic group. Only among evangelical voters did he not dominate, essentially tying Mr. Cruz for their votes. Among GOP primary voters who described themselves as "moderate," Mr. Trump only narrowly beat Mr. Kasich, exit polls showed.Those voter surveys showed New Hampshire voters were more concerned about the economy and terrorism than they were about immigration, but among those who were worried about immigration, Mr. Trump garnered the biggest share of the vote.New Hampshire polls were unanimous in predicting a Trump victory, but the battle among the rest of the field came to resemble "The Hunger Games," a fight for political life among several candidates.That battle for second and third place intensified in large part because Mr. Rubio seemed to lose momentum after a fumbling debate performance Saturday that fueled his rivals' claims that he is too inexperienced and ill-equipped for the presidency.The exit polls indicated a substantial number of late deciding voters went to Mr. Kasich. He benefited from voters like Sonya Bouchard, a Concord resident, who said she found his more upbeat campaign style appealing at a time when most candidates were attacking each other. "I like that he's positive," she said, adding that she didn't decide on him until Tuesday morning. "I don't like all the fighting."New Hampshire exit polls suggest that Republicans may remain divided long after they pick a nominee. More than half of GOP primary voters said they would be disappointed if either Messrs. Cruz or Rubio claim the nomination. They split almost evenly on whether they would be satisfied or dissatisfied by Mr. Trump becoming the nominee.---Paul Overberg, Heather Haddon, Colleen McCain Nelson and Reid J. Epstein contributed to this article.(See related article: "Clinton Defeat Prompts Retooling" -- WSJ Feb. 10, 2016)Enlarge this image.Credit: By Janet Hook and Patrick O'Connor
