She easily won the state in the 2008 Democratic presidential primary. The state's rules limit participation to registered Democrats, excluding the independent voters who have favored Mr. Sanders all year.Her husband, former President Bill Clinton, who campaigned separately for her, won the state twice and remains popular. During her appearances, she repeatedly invoked his economic record and promised to put him to work helping to revive the economy.There was concern, though, in the Clinton campaign that the electorate would include conservative Democrats who would cast their ballots against Mrs. Clinton, and therefore for Mr. Sanders. That appeared to be the case last week in West Virginia.She faced other headwinds, including fallout from a comment earlier this year when, in the course of discussing a plan to help coal communities, she predicted that her energy agenda would put a lot of coal miners out of work.Sunday and Monday, she worked to make amends, speaking emotionally of how coal miners' sacrifices allowed the nation to power itself and grow. "We do need to transition" to cleaner forms of energy, she said Monday in Bowling Green, "but we need to take coal country and coal miners and their families with us and not leave them behind."Arian Campo-Flores contributed to this article.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Laura Meckler

article name: The Trump-Ryan Summit: Who Needs Whom? Donald Trump didn't need House Speaker Paul Ryan in the primaries and certainly doesn't need him now.
article text: Fred Barnes writes "Trump Needs Ryan More Than He Knows " (op-ed, May 10). I find this hysterical. Donald Trump didn't need House Speaker Paul Ryan in the primaries and certainly doesn't need him now. Mr. Ryan is part of the establishment which has had its chance, and we have seen its incompetence. Trump voters want to finish off the establishment and turn this country around.Gary NicholsAtlantaThe problem with Speaker Ryan and the conservatives in the Republican Party is cowardice. Mr. Barnes emphasizes the dilemma of the conservative members of Congress. He says that Mr. Ryan "considers himself a 'movement' conservative." Yet the "movement" is going nowhere. It couldn't even nominate a Republican conservative as its candidate for president.What Mr. Ryan and his conservative Republicans need to do is take a page out of Great Britain's playbook and form a political party specifically named after its beliefs: the "Conservative Party." Then it should name Paul Ryan its first presidential candidate. This would demonstrate the conservatives' courage and eliminate the confusion. If Mr. Ryan really believes in conservative values, the timing couldn't be better.John R. ByersScarsdale, N.Y.

article name: Election 2016: Trump Would Block Funds Sent to Mexico
article text: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said he would demand Mexico pay between $5 billion and $10 billion to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, and if the payment weren't made, he would block remittances from undocumented Mexicans living in the U.S.He pushed the tough-on-immigration plan -- which has won him support in the past -- as he faced a difficult primary in Wisconsin on Tuesday. Mr. Trump billed the proposal as an "easy decision for Mexico: Make a one-time payment of $5-10 billion to ensure that $24 billion continues to flow into their country year after year." To carry it out, Mr. Trump would need to change parts of the Patriot Act to restrict undocumented immigrants' ability to send remittances to their home countries via wire transfers.If Mexico makes the payment, the memo says, remittances would keep arriving. The U.S. government estimates remittances to Mexico totaled $24.8 billion last year; just how much was sent by undocumented workers is unclear.The plan, contained in a two-page memo sent to the Washington Post, sparked sharp criticism from President Barack Obama, who called it "impractical" and "half-baked." "The notion that we're going to track every Western Union bit of money that's being sent to Mexico, good luck with that," he said in remarks at the White House.Mr. Obama also said the plan would hurt the Mexican economy, suggesting that if it were to collapse, more immigrants would come to the U.S. "because they can't find jobs back in Mexico." He added: "This is just one more example of something that is not thought through and is primarily put forward for political consumption."For recipients in Mexico, it was personal. The Trump plan "would hurt the well-being of the family that receives the remittances," said Elvira Azpeitia Fuentes, a teacher in central Hidalgo state whose family receives money from a relative in the U.S. and uses it to run a small hotel. "If he [Trump] uses that money, it wouldn't make sense for them to be sending it. It's being used to develop a small business in the future that will allow us to live easier."Michelle Buckalew, a spokeswoman for MoneyGram International, said, "Many of our customers depend on our services to pay for basic needs like education, housing and health care." The Dallas-based money transfer company is the second-largest sender of remittances to Mexico with a 14% market share.Under the Patriot Act, banks, savings associations, credit unions and certain other financial institutions are required to follow customer-identification procedures when a customer opens a new account. Wire-transfer companies, like Western Union and MoneyGram, aren't included, because customers don't need to set up a formal banking relationship.Mr. Trump's proposal would reclassify all money transfers as an "account," meaning customers would provide identification and their immigration status. The proposal would be a broad expansion of financial regulatory law, extending banking regulations to a new industry sector.Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto and cabinet officials have repeatedly rejected the idea of a border wall, or that Mexico would pay for it."Under no circumstances is Mexico going to pay for the wall that Mr. Trump is proposing," Finance Minister Luis Videgaray said last month in a television interview. "To build a wall between Mexico and the U.S. is a terrible idea. It's an idea based on ignorance and has no grounding in the reality of the integration of North America."---Rachel Louise Ensign and Anthony Harrup contributed to this article.Credit: By Gabriel T. Rubin

article name: Wisconsin Trump Stop
article text: Donald Trump's defeat in Wisconsin on Tuesday marks a major turn in the Republican race for President that now may not be settled until the July convention in Cleveland. With a chance to make his nomination all but inevitable, Mr. Trump was rejected by a majority of the Badger State's engaged and well-informed GOP voters.Ted Cruz won the state as the party's establishment rallied behind him, including Governor Scott Walker and his political operation. Badger State talk-radio hosts also opposed Mr. Trump, in contrast to national radio talkers who are more populists than they are reform conservatives. The exit polls also showed that Wisconsin voters aren't as angry as GOP voters elsewhere in the country, perhaps because they've seen what a united reform movement can accomplish in their state.Mr. Trump also hurt himself with a string of mistakes and uninformed statements that have caused millions of GOP voters to have second thoughts. His standing among women in particular has fallen to lows unheard of for a potential major party nominee -- upwards of 75% negative. This raises doubts about whether he has any chance even against a candidate as flawed as Hillary Clinton, and whether he might cost the GOP its Senate and House majorities.Mr. Trump's core support -- a third to 40% of GOP voters -- remains loyal, and he is still the front-runner. But Wisconsin shows that the same blunt, polarizing style that thrills his supporters alienates most Republicans. His campaign is now saying Mr. Trump will shift to giving more serious policy speeches to look more presidential, but the businessman has never shown he has the discipline to carry that out. Maybe this defeat will get his attention.Mr. Cruz says his victory shows he is the only alternative to Mr. Trump, but that will be tested later this month in the New England and mid-Atlantic states where he hasn't done well. The Texan is second in the delegate race but neither he nor John Kasich can reach a 1,237 delegate majority before the convention. The best outcome for Republicans now is that no one gets 1,237 before the convention, leaving it to the delegates to choose a nominee who looks like he might actually be able to win the election.

article name: Election 2016: Trump, Clinton Seek Home-State Boost
article text: Presidential front-runners Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton will turn their attention to New York this week, where they lead in polls and hope to use their home-state advantage after encountering bumpy stretches in a long race.Mrs. Clinton has struggled to fend off Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, losing a string of states recently, and expects the April 19 primary in New York to give her a firewall as she seeks to clinch the Democratic nomination.Mr. Trump's path to the Republican nomination has hit a difficult patch recently amid his controversial comments on abortion and national security and his campaign manager's being charged with battery. A victory in his home state would give him a significant boost in his efforts to avoid a contested GOP convention.In an interview, the businessman said he would travel widely upstate, where there are serious economic problems that he described as "very sad." Mr. Trump said he plans to talk about terrorism, citing the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, and take aim at rival Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas for criticizing him for having "New York values.""I can't imagine any New Yorker wanting to vote for Cruz," Mr. Trump said. "He doesn't like New Yorkers. He was mocking New Yorkers."Aides to Mr. Cruz didn't return requests for comment.Last month in New York, Mr. Cruz previewed his arguments against Mr. Trump, saying New Yorkers would be reluctant to back the real-estate mogul because they know him better than the rest of the country does.The senator noted that Mr. Trump gave campaign donations to a number of prominent New York Democrats, including Mrs. Clinton and Gov. Andrew Cuomo. "So the next time you think of all the disastrous policies that have been foisted on the people of New York, you can thank Donald Trump for bankrolling those efforts," Mr. Cruz said.Mr. Trump defended the donations, saying he gave to "everyone" as a businessman.Among likely GOP voters in New York, Mr. Trump leads with 56%, while Mr. Cruz is at 20% and Ohio. Gov John Kasich at 19%, according to a Quinnipiac University poll.Other than California, New York has the most delegates up for grabs in the remaining contests. The GOP gives away 95 delegates, while the Democrats award 291.Ahead of Tuesday's Wisconsin primary, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Sanders in pledged delegates by 1,243 to 980. A total of 2,383 is needed to clinch the nomination. Mr. Trump had 737 delegates, Mr. Cruz had 475, and Mr. Kasich 143, with 1,237 needed to win.The primaries this year have given New York, usually an afterthought in the nominating contests, a rare turn in the spotlight. Locals have joked about Mr. Kasich's choice to eat pizza with a fork while in New York City and about Mr. Sanders's saying city subway riders used tokens to pay, a long-abandoned method.Mr. Cruz invoked former Mayor Michael Bloomberg's proposal to ban large sugary drinks -- Mr. Cruz was against it -- while praising police officers who turned their backs on the current mayor, Bill de Blasio, during a dispute more than a year ago.The city's Democratic politicians, meanwhile, have publicly criticized Messrs. Trump and Cruz for their views on immigration and social issues.The GOP candidates are likely to spend much of their time upstate, which contributes about 52% of the state's GOP registration, according to Bruce Gyory, a political consultant in New York. Republicans upstate vote far more frequently in GOP primaries than those in other parts of the state, he said.Mr. Trump is likely to do better in the state's western portion but have more difficulties in the New York City suburbs, Mr. Gyory and other observers said, citing the struggling economy and more antiestablishment views there.Among likely Democratic voters, Mrs. Clinton holds a 54% to 42% lead, according to the Quinnipiac poll. So far, in New York City she has campaigned in predominantly African-American neighborhoods.Mrs. Clinton, a former New York senator, is expected to mobilize labor unions and downstate Democrats, who have widely endorsed her, to fend off Mr. Sanders, who has played up his Brooklyn roots and support from the Working Families Party. Mr. Gyory said New York City is likely to contribute 50% to 55% of the primary vote.Mr. Sanders needs to show he can dent Mrs. Clinton's support among black and Latino voters, who dominate the New York Democratic primary, said Bill Hyers, who managed Mr. de Blasio's 2013 mayoral campaign.The Vermont senator will do well upstate, Mr. Hyers predicted, where liberal Democrat Zephyr Teachout performed better among white liberals than Mr. Cuomo in the last gubernatorial election.Credit: By Josh Dawsey

article name: Trump, We Knew Ye
article text: Donald Trump never wanted it enough.Though some will think it premature to write his presidential obituary while the Wisconsin results have yet to come in (thanks to our deadline) and while the GOP nomination contest is far from decided, in fact the obituary is overdue.Hillary Clinton and her donors are fully committed and probably have been since 2000. A presidential race is all-or-nothing. You either win or you don't. And you don't get your money back.Mr. Trump has not been all-in. The most obvious way is with his unwillingness to put up the money, though many overlooked his hesitance because he was doing so well with free media coverage.The money was significant of something larger: his unwillingness to work out the whole path to the presidency, and his lack of 100% commitment to do the things necessary to succeed. Control his mouth. Recruit credible advisers. Produce a thoughtful policy program. Though it received surprisingly little commentary, his insistence on using his primary-victory rallies to flog his golf courses, product lines and related business interests.There were signs to be read. The smarter half of his already-committed voters were looking, after Michigan, for him to show he could expand his coalition and fill out the image of a president. He didn't.Athletes, in postgame victory interviews, frequently say, "Our guys wanted it more." The guy whose preferred epithet is "loser," who defines himself as life's ultimate winner, failed this test. It's hard to know exactly why. Maybe winning is only winning if he does it his way, refusing to meet expectations, including the media's demand that he fill out an acceptable picture of a president-in-waiting.He certainly was willing for voters to award him the office by acclamation, without having to risk his fortune or submit to the usual indignities. But only a wild surrender to unrealism about our political system explains why so many sophisticated observers became willing to read his limited, early successes as heralding a candidate who could go all the way.His presidential campaign began as a lark and, despite his primary wins, remained one. He was never serious in the Hillary sense. He has been fingering his get-out option since he got in. If you didn't see it, it's because you forgot what a presidential race really is.Let's talk about the convention. Mr. Trump is all but certain now to show up without enough delegates to clinch the nomination -- which, in his case, means his race is over.He offers his remaining fans a claim that somehow he is entitled to the nomination as long as he can boast the most delegates, never mind that the rules specify a majority of half-plus-one.Many state and local elections do, of course, award office to whichever candidate attracts one more vote than the second-highest vote-getter. But that's because, in our two-party system, much of the winnowing and consensus-seeking takes place within the parties, in primaries and caucuses, in the competition for donations and endorsements, before a candidate is ever presented to the general electorate.That's exactly what's going on in the GOP nomination contest. Delegates to the convention are empowered to finish the job if voters in the primaries don't. And primary voters have pretty much missed their opportunity to do so barring some unexpected landslide for Mr. Trump or Ted Cruz in the remaining primaries.And this is perfectly right. Polls strongly suggest that Mr. Trump is opposed by more Republicans than support him. He would likely lose a straight-up, one-on-one nomination fight against several of the GOP candidates who've already dropped out of the race. He would lose to Hillary Clinton in the fall, polls suggest, and John Kasich would win.Mr. Trump hints at riots if he is denied the nomination. This is a joke. He has little or no organization at the state and local level. He only now has hired a professional canvasser to reach out to delegates. Though some conventioneers may also be Trump fans in their hearts, all delegates will be GOP lifers picked by their state parties. These aren't people who would walk out or sabotage a convention for Mr. Trump's sake.He might try calling on his rank-and-file voters to converge on Cleveland and mount street protests. He won't. He does not want criminal liability. He doesn't want his Trump brand associated with hooliganism and tear gas. Most of all, he would be humiliated in the likely event that only his skinhead admirers show up.The big irony of the Republican race, of course, is that Ted Cruz is a minority taste in the GOP as well. Here resides another testament to the convention designers' wisdom. After the first ballot, delegates will be free to skip over Mr. Cruz and seek a nominee who isn't just the handiest non-Trump, but who can command broad support from the Republican Party and the U.S. electorate.Credit: By Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.

article name: Trump, Sanders and the Populist Anti-Policy Surge; Washington 'experts' stir many Americans' loathing. Time to put the public back into public policy.
article text: If there's one thing that unites the populist campaigns of Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, it's a desire to put the "public" back into "public policy." Many Americans apparently feel that policy is something done to them, rather than with them. They disdain the unknown "experts" in distant Washington, D.C., who devise everything from trade deals to overtime rules.As the dean of a graduate school in public policy, I've been thinking: Are programs like mine partly responsible for this state of affairs? How should graduates in the Class of 2016 react as they enter a world increasingly skeptical of their expertise?It's true that government has often failed to engage citizens. During a recent conference on land use at Pepperdine, the planning director of a large California city explained it this way: "The problem is that we always put people up in front of the public who are the least prepared to be there."Her staff were experts in the technical aspects of their work--from limits on building heights to requirements for setbacks. But she recognized that when her planners met with citizens, who often had different priorities, they were incapable of facilitating productive dialogue. The public simply concluded that the government couldn't--or wouldn't--"listen."Graduate programs in public policy and public administration have wrestled with this for years. The discipline sends into the field alumni who may be very good at formulating something called "policy," but not so good at understanding the public's role in its creation. "Large segments of mainstream public administration scholarship," Robert F. Durant and Susannah Bruns Ali wrote three years ago in Public Administration Review, "privilege bureaucratic expertise and marginalize the deliberative role of unorganized interests and citizens in agency deliberations."The general tendencies of these academic programs toward quantitative knowledge and standardized solutions has created what we see today: from local planners who don't listen, to White House advisers who believe that ObamaCare passed because of the "stupidity of the American voter."At Pepperdine, we host a training series titled "Public Engagement: The Vital Leadership Skill." More than 1,000 public officials have taken part, learning the basics of facilitating input from citizens. We developed the program about five years ago after realizing that many midcareer public leaders never learned these skills in college and graduate school.Are this generation's successors being taught them? The retirement of the baby boomers will effect one of the greatest changes in public leadership in American history. Now is the time to update these programs to ensure that generational change becomes cultural change.First, we should teach students to think of the public not as a faceless mass, but as actual, individual human beings. "Modern public administration," the great sociologist Robert Nisbet wrote, "has been generally dominated by the nineteenth-century rationalist's conception of society as a vast aggregate of unconnected political particles." That was in 1953.Public-policy programs should integrate essential quantitative coursework into a liberal-arts approach. Students should read what the Great Books say about the role of a citizen in a democracy, while studying what the latest social-psychology research shows about the myriad biases people bring to "fact based" decision-making. These will help them see that the policy they develop for Rome, Ga., may not work in Rome, N.Y., (or Rome, Italy, for that matter) and that some government services might be better provided by a local nonprofit or through collaboration with the private sector.Second, schools must teach a set of skills--how to facilitate public meetings or publicize them to increase participation. The "public comment" process by which local boards and councils usually involve citizens does not succeed at informing either the public or policy makers. In 2013 Pepperdine, working with the League of California Cities, surveyed over 900 public officials . Seventy-six percent said that their public meetings were "typically dominated by people with narrow agendas."It's the same phenomenon that played out in the conflagrations known as town halls when ObamaCare was being passed. Citizens came out in force against the bill, but Congress passed it anyway. Some argue that these failed public meetings led to the creation of America's last populist movement: the tea party.Finally, students of public policy should be taught about the role of technology in mediating the relationship between the citizen and his government. A couple of months ago, my hometown of Santa Monica invited me via Facebook to complete an online survey regarding a downtown building project. Tomorrow's public leaders must be prepared to involve and inform residents in ways the private sector has employed for decades--engaging them on social media, or posting budget data online to increase transparency.In the months ahead, thousands of future leaders will be awarded degrees in public policy. Meanwhile, graduate schools should ponder the role they play in American democracy--and how they can respond to the populist moment that is upending politics (and policy) as usual.Mr. Peterson is the dean of the Pepperdine School of Public Policy.Credit: By Pete Peterson

article name: Obama Front-Runs Trump on China; The new 522% steel tariff will hurt U.S. companies. Worse may be coming.
article text: The Obama Administration may not sound like Donald Trump when talking about trade with China, but it isn't above using protectionism for political gain. On Tuesday the U.S. Commerce Department increased a tariff on "dumped" Chinese cold-rolled steel to 522%, a move that will hurt American manufacturers who need the steel to remain competitive.The tariff might score some populist points with voters in an election year. It also may be a ploy to get lawmakers to ratify the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement before President Obama leaves office. But past experience suggests that such gambits inflame protectionist sentiment rather than tamp it down.President George W. Bush imposed tariffs of up to 30% on a broad range of Chinese steel products in 2002. The Consuming Industries Trade Action Coalition says the tariffs cost the U.S. economy 200,000 jobs and $4 billion in lost wages. The Obama Administration made a similar mistake in 2009, slapping "safeguard" tariffs on Chinese tires. Punitive tariffs on a range of other Chinese products followed, and Beijing retaliated with its own tariffs and cases at the World Trade Organization. Both sides are now in violation of WTO decisions that followed these tit-for-tat taxes.Beijing's trade record is marred by export rebates and discrimination against foreign companies. Government policy in various forms is behind the quadrupling of Chinese-steel capacity since 2000, whether through cheap credit to build new mills or the wave of public construction projects after the 2008 financial panic. China now produces about half of the world's steel, and as its own demand has subsided the excess has flooded the world market, driving down prices.But this is good news for the U.S. Since steel is an important raw material for many industries, China's trade partners benefit from its wasteful policies. Lower prices make companies that use steel more competitive and bring down prices for consumers.Daniel Pearson of the Cato Institute conservatively estimates that American companies using steel produce $990 billion in value added, more than 16 times the output of the U.S. steel industry, and also employ 16 times more workers. If tariffs on Chinese imports raise the U.S. price of steel, these companies' costs will be higher than foreign competitors', hurting their ability to grow and provide more jobs for Americans.U.S. steel makers and unions argue for high tariffs on the basis that steel users will buy American. But manufacturers complain that the U.S. mills don't produce the same range of products as the Chinese. So some will simply have to pay the tariff-inflated prices and endure the competitive damage.The steel tariff is a warm-up for the fight over granting China market-economy status in December. Beijing's 2001 accession to the WTO included a 15-year adjustment in which China was treated as a nonmarket economy for purposes of antidumping investigations.The U.S. and EU have been able to use input prices from other developing companies to estimate Chinese producers' cost of production. This lowered the evidentiary bar and resulted in high tariffs such as those on cold-rolled steel. Antidumping cases are dubious even without this statistical legerdemain, and U.S. unions and companies will lobby the next President to renege on the WTO accord.The larger question is whether the steel tariffs herald a new and more bitter era of trade retaliation. Previous skirmishes have been damaging but stopped short of full escalation. But Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton have run for President as protectionists, and Mr. Obama's surrender to steel interests is a bad omen. Chinese officials who think they can keep flooding the world with surplus goods could be in for as rude an awakening as U.S. consumers.

article name: Election 2016: Trump Effect Is on Display In Texas Race --- Republican in heavily Latino district tries to distance himself from his party's front-runner
article text: EL PASO, Texas -- Republican Rep. Will Hurd, whose district snakes along the Mexican border, thinks there are better ways to prevent undocumented immigrants from crossing into the U.S. than constructing a wall like the one Donald Trump wants to erect."Building a wall from sea to shining sea is not the silver bullet," Mr. Hurd said. "Besides, that's the most expensive way, and least effective way, to do border security."Mr. Trump's presidential candidacy has been marked by often-incendiary remarks on topics that include border security and the dangers posed by various ethnic groups. In announcing his candidacy last summer, for example, the New York billionaire claimed some Mexican migrants were drug dealers and rapists.But while Mr. Trump's hard-line positions and from-the-gut style have helped catapult him to the top of the GOP presidential field, they pose risks for down-ballot Republicans, particularly those running in communities with a higher share of minorities, college graduates or higher-income voters. That is especially true for Mr. Hurd, whose district is 67% Latino and 17% foreign-born, according to census data.David Wasserman, who analyzes House races for the Cook Political Report, recently downgraded Republicans' chances of holding six of their seats and upgraded prospects for Democrats in holding four of theirs, citing the likelihood that Mr. Trump or Texas Sen. Ted Cruz would be the GOP presidential nominee.At this point, Mr. Wasserman doubts Democrats will win the 30 seats needed to retake the House in the fall, but he said Mr. Trump, in particular, could alienate large chunks of more-educated and higher-income voters and motivate minorities to come out against him, particularly Latinos."Trump at least gives Democrats some signs of life," Mr. Wasserman said.Democrats, of course, are doing everything in their power to make many of these races referendums on the Republican front-runner by trying to force their opponents to take sides in his frequent controversies."Trump is deeply unpopular in the Latino community," said New Mexico Rep. Ben Ray Lujan, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.Mr. Hurd and other Republicans in similar positions are trying to distinguish themselves from the front-runner."I've been talking to voters since before I got elected," Mr. Hurd said in an interview. "People are not going to associate me with the comments of anybody else up ballot because I'm building independent relationships with them."Building those relationships -- and surviving a potential big year for Democrats -- is harder than it sounds in a district that stretches from the San Antonio suburbs to the outskirts of El Paso.The race was always going to be a fight. The seat has changed hands in each of the past four elections. This year's matchup pits Mr. Hurd against former Rep. Pete Gallego, a Democrat beat by just 2,422 votes in 2014.Two years ago, Mr. Hurd spent much of the campaign trying to tether Mr. Gallego to the president. This year, Mr. Gallego is using a similar tactic against Mr. Hurd, challenging him to denounce Mr. Trump and trying to tie him to GOP leaders in Washington."He's essentially cowering in the corner," Mr. Gallego said, of Mr. Hurd's reluctance to say whether he would vote for Mr. Trump in the fall. "He can't seem to make up his mind."Mr. Hurd still ducks the question, saying, "We've got to see how these races pan out."The 38-year-old first-term congressman, one of two black Republicans in the House, comes across as far less ideological than some of his GOP colleagues. He pitches himself as a politician more interested in delivering for the district than observing partisan purity."I don't need to get into an ideological battle with someone, just to get into an ideological battle," Mr. Hurd said.Few issues in the district provoke more discussion, or opposing viewpoints, than border security.Mr. Hurd wants the federal government to empower local officials to have a greater say in how they police the border, which could mean a wall in more urban settings."You cannot have a one-size-fits-all solution," he said.At an event in Fabens, Mr. Hurd encouraged a crowd of mostly migrant farmworkers, many with small children in tow, to reach out to his office if they have any problems with Medicare, Medicaid or Social Security. An aide, translating in Spanish, added immigration.The shared heritage between Mexicans and Americans in this corner of West Texas was on display in late March when Mr. Hurd organized a forum to discuss securing a special United Nations designation for the region's centuries-old Spanish missions. A member of the county council suggested the stakeholders reach out to Mexican officials to help make their case, drawing agreement from much of the room. As the group discussed the next steps in the process, Mr. Hurd issued a gentle reminder to the roomful of mostly Democrats."You need to make sure the current officeholders stay in office," he said, flashing a big grin.Enlarge this image.Credit: By Patrick O'Connor

article name: What His Believers See in Donald Trump
article text: Orlando, Fla. -- It's a warm, sunny Saturday afternoon. More than 10,000 people have gathered here at the University of Central Florida's CFE Arena -- one mother and her high-school son had driven five hours Friday evening -- to hear Donald Trump speechify.The crowd, a sea of red, white and blue, waves placards that say "The Silent Majority Stands with Donald Trump." Many have donned "Make America Great Again" trucker caps and "Trump 2016" T-shirts. At a bazaar outside, vendors hawk unofficial Trump merchandise, such as shirts with the candidate's face superimposed on Superman.The depth and range of Mr. Trump's support has been reflected in polls and election exit surveys, which generally show him leading the Republican field among voters of all ages, and all levels of education and income. In Mr. Trump, many GOP primary voters have found a sort of messiah -- or false prophet if you ask his opponents -- who promises to restore American leadership and strength in the world."The country is a mess, and he's the only one who can help us," says Susan Muchacho, a retired woman who attended the rally with her brother. Kori Duval, an African-American mother of two who recalls the Reagan and both Bush presidencies fondly, shares similar sentiments: "He will make America a country that other countries will look to again for support."The Trump disciples I encounter aren't angry so much as they are agitated by what they perceive to be America's fall from greatness. They complain about the country's slow-growing economy, aimless leaders, lawless government and uncontrolled southwestern border. And they sincerely believe that only Mr. Trump can fix these problems. The irony is that they seem to demonstrate more conviction and resolution than the mercurial Mr. Trump.By 10:30 Saturday morning, thousands had already lined up for blocks around the arena. The rally had been scheduled to begin at noon, but it was postponed to 2:30 after Mr. Trump abruptly canceled a Saturday morning appearance at the Conservative Political Action Conference to campaign in Kansas. Even so, Mr. Trump arrived nearly another hour late.During the long prelude, Elton John's "Tiny Dancer" and the Rolling Stones' "You Can't Always Get What You Want" repeatedly played. A prayer was said asking God for "divine intervention" in the election and to give Mr. Trump "the wisdom of Solomon."A laid-off Disney employee spoke about having to train foreign workers, purportedly hired on H-1B visas, to replace her. (During Thursday's Fox News debate, Mr. Trump repudiated his earlier opposition to high-skilled immigration -- and then repudiated his new position an hour later.)Trump adviser Stephen Miller lambasted Marco Rubio's immigration bill, saying it would have allowed "12 million illegal immigrants to take jobs from every single working American in this country" and given "amnesty to drunk drivers, sex offenders, gang members, criminal aliens."By the time Mr. Trump finally took the stage, the crowd was restless. He received a rock-star welcome, which was fitting since his speech was a remix of his debate lines and news conferences, delivered in a faux-folksy manner. "The last thing that you people are going to take is having a lightweight like Marco Rubio" or "lyin' Ted Cruz or some kind of politician in charge of this country," he inveighed. At one point, he slipped, saying "we gonna protect our Second Amendment, me more than anyone else up here." No one else was on stage.There were dog whistles intended to bait the barbarians and bigots whom he ostensibly believes are among his supporters. For example: "We have a terrible president who happens to be African-American." There were very few blacks and Hispanics in the crowd. Mr. Trump's critics sometimes deride his fans, which has the effect of alienating them. But Mr. Trump's invective evinces his own contemptuous opinion of his "base."The speech was repeatedly interrupted by muted protesters who, after being flagged by the crowd, were hauled out by security. "He's lucky it's not 10 years ago. Ten years ago it'd be a different situation for him," Mr. Trump said of one, before launching into a discussion of waterboarding and torture.Many supporters claim to be energized by his bombast. "Trump says what people are thinking," explains Bill Montgomery, a money manager, who believes the country needs some tough love. "No pain, no gain." But there are also plenty who back Mr. Trump in spite of his provocative rhetoric. "Personally, he wouldn't be a friend of mine," says John Young of Melbourne, Fla., "but I work with a lot of people I don't like."Most aren't swayed by attacks on Mr. Trump's business record, such as his bankruptcies and the allegations of fraud at Trump University. His opponents are "grasping at straws to try to find something against him," says Jennifer Howland of Indian Harbour Beach. Many even view his business failures as a testament to his resilience. As Mr. Young sees it, "Sometimes you're going to fail. That's life."According to rational choice theory -- a model used to explain economic behavior and outcomes -- people make logical decisions that optimize their interests after considering the costs and benefits. This may help explain voting behavior: Trump supporters seem to consider his pugnacity a positive attribute and view the other Republican candidates as inferior.They want a fighter who won't sugarcoat the truth or accept America's slide toward mediocrity. Yet Mr. Trump has avoided discussing perhaps the U.S.'s biggest long-term problem: exploding entitlement spending. Neither Mr. Rubio nor Ted Cruz, despite presenting more detailed policies, projects the frustration that Trump voters feel. Therefore, they're perceived to not "get it."While Trump supporters seem to be motivated by genuine patriotism -- a real desire to make America great -- it's hard not to detect an underlying strain of religiosity to the campaign. At the end of the rally, Mr. Trump asks his followers to take an oath swearing to vote for him in Florida's primary on March 15. "This isn't a campaign," asserts Regina Reifinger of Palm Coast. "It's a movement." Whatever you want to call it, these people are true believers.---Ms. Finley is an editorial writer for the Journal.Credit: By Allysia Finley

article name: Election 2016 --- CAPITAL JOURNAL: Why Trump Backers Look Past Contradictions
article text: Donald Trump is a man of huge contradictions.He regularly decries that the U.S. has accumulated a national debt of $19 trillion, yet has proposed a tax cut and associated economic ideas that the nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget estimates would add between $11.7 trillion and $15.1 trillion to the debt over the next decade.He calls journalists -- and this is a direct quote from a rally in Florida over the weekend -- "the most dishonest people on earth. . .disgusting, dishonest human beings." Yet he is conducting a campaign that is built around the free media coverage their organizations provide.He promises to smash Islamic State fighters harder than anyone else, yet evinces little interest in putting American troops into Syria to do it -- the kind of position that prompted 117 former Republican national-security officials to declare in an open letter opposing his nomination that he "swings from isolationism to military adventurism within the space of one sentence."Yet none of this seems to matter to his many fervent supporters. Why?Two reasons. First, the Trump army supports him because of his attitude rather than his agenda. They take him at his word on the big stuff: He'll stop illegal immigration, he'll trash old trade deals and negotiate great new ones, he will stop American companies from moving overseas by pressuring them.It's more important that he says he will repeal Obamacare than have a detailed plan for replacing it.In short, goals matter more than any mechanism to achieve them. And since it's been a decade or so in which few of those detailed, 10-point plans that other politicians offer have gotten enacted in Washington, voters probably don't take policy papers seriously. Dysfunction in Washington is Mr. Trump's friend; the politicians who now curse his rise have created the gridlock that enables him.The second reason is that Mr. Trump makes clear that everything is negotiable anyway. His policy proposals, to the extent they exist, are opening bids rather than a set of immovable principles."Now, sometimes you ask for more than you want and you negotiate down to the point," he said in the most recent Republican debate, in Detroit last week. Later he added: "There's always give and take. There's always negotiation."So Mr. Trump gets away with saying things that simply can't be taken at face value. One example: He seems to suggest at his rallies that the recently concluded deal with Iran over its nuclear program would somehow require the U.S. to pay Iran $150 billion. In the Florida rally over the weekend, he said he would tell Iran, "We don't have $150 billion" for you.Yet that impression is simply false. To the extent Iran will reap a financial windfall from the deal -- and it's probably less than $150 billion -- it will be from the return of Iran's own assets and proceeds from oil sales that have been frozen in international accounts abroad. It isn't U.S. money.At some point, though, a candidate moving closer to a presidential nomination will be taken at his word, as Mr. Trump found in that Detroit debate last week when Fox News moderators called him on the gap between his condemnations of federal debt and his economic ideas that seem destined to add to it.That problem is worth a closer look. The Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget attempted to pull together the few economic-policy proposals Mr. Trump has laid out -- a giant tax cut, immigration enforcement and expanding health care for veterans -- to see what effect they would have on the budget.The center says its best estimate is that Mr. Trump's tax plan would reduce federal revenues by between $9.5 trillion and $11.9 trillion over a decade. Add in the higher cost for veterans' benefits and higher interest costs, and the broader plan would reduce government receipts by $11.7 trillion to $15.1 trillion over 10 years.Mr. Trump says spending cuts, eliminating waste and spurring higher growth would make up the difference. But he also says he would protect Social Security benefits. To balance the budget on those terms would require cutting all other federal spending -- including on Medicare -- by 55% to 65%. Add on the cost of Mr. Trump's pledge to strengthen the military, and "it becomes literally impossible to balance the budget with only spending cuts," the center says.Could Mr. Trump generate enough economic growth to make up the difference? The center estimates it would require annual economic growth of 7.7% to 9% just to avoid adding to the debt, and 10.4% to 11.4% to balance the budget in a decade -- twice as high as the fastest growth period in the past six decades.That would be a huge achievement indeed.Credit: By Gerald F. Seib

article name: Trump's Crumbling Wall Plan
article text: For a guy who brags incessantly about his business acumen, Donald Trump doesn't seem to know how capital markets work. If he did he never would have sent a memo to the Washington Post detailing a crackpot plan to force Mexico to pay for a Berlin Wall separating our two nations by threatening to block remittances. Even the humblest Mexican farmworker knows that's not going to work.The remittance blunder is a reminder that Mr. Trump is far better at issuing ultimatums than crafting thoughtful policy that will advance U.S. interests. For all of his bluster and braggadocio, he comes off to most of the world like a spoiled child in short pants shouting orders at the help.If voter surveys are correct, Trump supporters are largely native-born and economically aggrieved. As such, they are susceptible to ultranationalist attacks on foreign countries. Mexico is the perfect whipping boy.The centerpiece of the Trump campaign is his silly claim that he can restore America's lost economic mojo by more tightly controlling immigration and adopting a protectionist trade policy. Nothing excites Trump supporters at rallies more than when he promises that Mexico will pay for his big, tall, "beautiful wall" on the southern U.S. border.Mexico's political class rarely unites on anything, but there is unanimity that Mr. Trump will have to look elsewhere to finance his continental partition. In February former President Vicente Fox captured the popular sentiment when he used a vulgar adjective to describe Mr. Trump's wall.Mexican defiance apparently sent Team Trump into the bunker to craft an offer that Mexico could not refuse. The resulting memo presents a number of options "to compel Mexico to pay for the wall," among them the threat to block remittances by rewriting provisions of the Patriot Act from the Oval Office.When Mexico got wind of this, the memo explains, it would cry uncle and hand over the money for the wall. "It's an easy decision for Mexico. Make a one-time payment of $5-10 billion to ensure that $24 billion continues to flow into their country year after year," the memo states.This document would not exist had Mr. Trump not believed that it reflects his brilliant management and negotiating skills. But if you're smarter than a third-grader, you can see that it is unlikely to yield the intended results. Instead, expect there to be unintended consequences, like greater criminality for one.As a matter of national pride neither the Mexican executive nor the Congress would entertain the idea of making this payment. They would have the broad backing of the Mexican people who widely object to Mr. Trump's characterization of their compatriots living in the U.S. as rapists and drug dealers.If Mexico refused to pay, under the Trump plan the U.S. government would invoke the revised Patriot Act to begin prohibiting aliens in the U.S. from wiring money unless they could prove that they are in the country legally.A rewrite of the Patriot Act is the prerogative of Congress and an attempt by the executive to do it would be challenged in court and probably ruled illegal. But even if it were not, it is absurd to think that it will stop the flow of dollars to Mexico.The most obvious way around the new provision would be for those who can prove legal residency to send the money for those who cannot. But wire transfers are only one way of moving money. It could also be deposited in a U.S. bank and withdrawn from automatic teller machines in Mexico by intended recipients.The only way Mr. Trump might inhibit the flow of dollars to Mexico via the formal banking system would be to impose targeted capital controls. But that's likely to violate U.S. obligations under a variety of international agreements.It would also place a huge burden on Americans and the American economy. More than one million gringos live in Mexico and another 20 million visit the country every year. Plus, Mexico is America's third largest trading partner and U.S. manufacturing is highly integrated with Mexico. Capital controls would blow up a production-sharing relationship that has made the North American economy the envy of the world.Not all migrant workers have access to bank accounts, so even without capital controls the Trump plan would be a jobs program for organized crime. Cartels already specialize in bringing profits from U.S. drug consumption across the border to Mexico. They would no doubt be happy to offer their delivery services to new customers.Team Trump wants the world to know that there is more in its bag of tricks than the remittance squeeze. The memo floats the idea of new trade tariffs and making it more difficult and expensive for Mexicans to secure visas.Call it the art of the shakedown. But also call it a dumb idea.Credit: By Mary Anastasia O'Grady

article name: Hillary Clinton Seeks Momentum in California Race; Democratic front-runner focuses on Donald Trump as Bernie Sanders campaigns hard in Golden State
article text: RIVERSIDE, Calif.--Hillary Clinton is seeking to close out a surprisingly contentious presidential primary with a victory here that would send her into the general election with momentum and mute Democratic rival Bernie Sanders's argument that she's a weak front-runner."I need your help in this upcoming primary because we want to finish strong," Mrs. Clinton told supporters Tuesday at a rally here. "We want to send that message that we are going to fight every day."Both candidates are working hard for the 475 delegates at stake in the June 7 primary in California. There are also contests in five other states, and barring a total collapse, Mrs. Clinton is likely to capture enough delegates that night to claim the presidential nomination, possibly before the polls close in the Golden State.Confident in her position, Mrs. Clinton declined to participate in a final debate and she ignored questions about a State Department report released Wednesday that found her private email system violated agency policies.But a new poll released Wednesday by the Public Policy Institute of California found the candidates in a statistical tie, with 46% of likely Democratic primary voters and 44% preferring Mr. Sanders. Earlier polling had Mrs. Clinton ahead.Her campaign said late Wednesday that it would start airing TV ads in three markets, a "six-figure" buy and a proposition her campaign had hoped to avoid. It also appears to be running an aggressive get-out-the-vote operation. It has nine field offices, and an aide said phone banks in seven languages and door-to-door visits have been under way for two weeks.Mrs. Clinton has also pressed her advantage with party leaders. Elected officials at every level, union leaders, women's rights activists and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, all have headlined events. On Wednesday, she was introduced by actress Jamie Lee Curtis.The state should set up well for Mrs. Clinton. She easily won the 2008 primary. That year, nearly half the electorate was nonwhite, and she has done well with minority voters this year.At rallies, Mrs. Clinton doesn't even mention Mr. Sanders, focusing instead on the Republican presumptive nominee Donald Trump. On Wednesday in Buena Vista, she said the money he wants to spend on a border wall with Mexico could pay for 16 Golden Gate Bridges or 1,500 new elementary schools. She also hit him for comments ahead of the housing crisis that appeared to be rooting for prices to fall, saying he could make a lot of money."A good result in Donald Trump's world is he gets his and you get hurt," she said.But even as Mrs. Clinton looks to the fall, many of her backers remain uneasy with Mr. Sanders's continued presence in the race."He should just stop," Conni Lira, 70 years old, of Pico Rivera, who saw Mrs. Clinton at a union organizing event Tuesday. "He's just making it more difficult for her when he doesn't have a chance."Mr. Sanders isn't going away. He has 17 rallies planned or completed over an 11-day stretch. He projects he will have spoken to 200,000 people by June 7. He has four field offices and 80 paid workers.Mr. Sanders has already spent about a half-million dollars on satellite-TV ads, which can be carefully targeted, according to tracking by Kantar Media CMAG. The campaign says it has bought $1.5 million on its new buy.Mr. Sanders released a new TV ad this week that urges voters to think beyond the nomination contest itself to what has become a broader effort to transform the Democratic Party. The unspoken message is that a Sanders vote isn't wasted, even if he can't win."What choice do Californians have in this election?" Mr. Sanders asks in the ad. "The biggest one of all: You have the power to choose a new direction for the Democratic Party."As Mr. Sanders campaigned in recent days in liberal strongholds of California, he drew crowds of thousands; his supporters treat him like a rock star, chanting his name.At a rally in San Jose, supporters stood for hours in a dusty state fairground to hear the hoarse-voiced candidate speak. He mixed in mentions of local issues, such as one likely to be on the California ballot this fall."If I lived in California, I would vote 'yes' to legalize marijuana,'' he said, drawing loud cheers from the mostly young audience.He has also endorsed a California ballot initiative designed to control prescription-drug prices by restricting the amount state agencies could pay for them.His campaign also has been bumpy. Some staff have recently departed, and his last finance report showed the campaign running short of money.But he has built a grass-roots operation aimed at tapping into the enthusiasm that runs strong for him and his cause. That includes a Bay Area campaign headquarters in Oakland, a storefront where three dozen people were working on phone banks one recent weekday morning.They were focusing heavily on voter registration, working up against a deadline just four days away for voters to change their party registration and become eligible to participate in the Democratic primary.Iris Safar of Modesto was among the volunteers. A 36-year old yoga instructor, Ms. Safar said the only time she has voted in a presidential race was in 2000 when she voted for Ralph Nader's third-party bid."I'd never marched, never protested, never been involved in anything political,'' Ms. Safar said. "When I go to a Bernie event, I'm with a group of people that have a higher level of consciousness. You are with kindred spirits."Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Janet Hook at janet.hook@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler And Janet Hook

article name: Trump, Cosby and the Clintons; The day the Bills came due.
article text: No doubt it was just a Freudian slip. The Washington Free Beacon reports:MSNBC host Steve Kornacki confused former President Bill Clinton and Bill Cosby on Tuesday while talking about Cosby's appearance in a court in Norristown, Pennsylvania over sexual assault allegations."We're going to begin with that breaking news we told you about at the top," Kornacki said. "Right now out of Pennsylvania, Bill Clinton is set to arrive at a suburban--excuse me, Bill Cosby is set to arrive at a suburban Philadelphia courthouse any moment now for a key hearing in his criminal sex assault case."But then get a load of this headline, from a piece by Salon's Mary Williams : "It's Not Just Bill Cosby: It Takes a Village to Exploit Women--and to Keep It All Quiet." Although Williams never mentions the Clintons by name, "It Takes a Village" is almost too obvious an allusion to have been subliminal.As it happens, your humble columnist was in the studio at MSNBC, waiting to go on the air with Kornacki, when he made that slip, which escaped our notice at the time. MSNBC.com describes our segment as follows: "Democratic strategist Emily Tisch Sussman shares her reaction to Donald Trump's latest dig at the Clintons. She says he will say anything and is guided by 'misogyny, racism and self-enrichment.' James Taranto of the Wall Street Journal also joins the discussion."You can watch the clip and judge for yourself whether that summary does it justice. Here we'll just point out, as we did on MSNBC, that Sussman offered essentially the same defense of Mr. Clinton that Cosby's lawyers, according to MSNBC correspondent Ari Melber, are putting forth for their client, to wit: Bill C. is an elderly man, and it is unfair to hold him to account for things he did a long time ago.We arrived at 30 Rockefeller Center early and spent some time in the green room watching "Morning Joe," which featured a panel of pundits pooh-poohing Trump for raising questions about the Clintons' history. He was damaging his candidacy, they insisted, by bringing up crazy conspiracy theories, such as that the Clintons killed deputy White House counsel Vince Foster. Our thought was that if this was what they were talking about on MSNBC, Mrs. Clinton was probably not having a good day.Foster's death in 1993 was in fact a suicide. "But it is fair game to talk about Foster's relationship to the Clintons," argues the Weekly Standard's Mark Hemingway :Initially, Foster worked with Hillary Clinton at the Rose Law Firm in Arkansas, where he was instrumental in making her the firm's first female partner. Among the other notable things he did at the firm, Foster and Webb Hubbell, with Hillary Clinton's approval, brought in a bunch of women alleged to have had sexual relationships with Bill Clinton and offered to represent them when a political opponent threatened to expose the affairs. The goal was to intimidate and silence the women, and it appears to have worked. Gail Sheehy reports that Hillary Clinton herself sat in at least one of the meetings with the women. (Hillary Clinton would later tell Sheehy in 1992 to look into unproven accusations of infidelity against George H.W. Bush.)It takes a village, all right.As Vox's Dylan Matthews reports, Broaddrick makes a similar claim about Mrs. Clinton:About six months after her initial interviews in 1999, Broaddrick told the Drudge Report that mere weeks after the alleged assault, Hillary Clinton had tried to thank her for her silence on the matter at a political rally:"[Hillary] came directly to me as soon as she hit the door. I had been there only a few minutes, I only wanted to make an appearance and leave. She caught me and took my hand and said 'I am so happy to meet you. I want you to know that we appreciate everything you do for Bill.' I started to turn away and she held onto my hand and reiterated her phrase--looking less friendly and repeated her statement--'Everything you do for Bill.' I said nothing. She wasn't letting me get away until she made her point. She talked low, the smile faded on the second thank you. I just released her hand from mine and left the gathering."This wasn't included in the initial reports on Broaddrick's story by the Wall Street Journal, Washington Post, New York Times, and NBC News. But after this article's initial publication, Lisa Myers, who conducted NBC News' initial report on Broaddrick, wrote Vox to clarify that Broaddrick did tell NBC that Hillary Clinton had an encounter with her after the alleged assault, though this did not make the final cut of the Dateline segment.Trump is challenging the false media narrative that Mr. Clinton was just high-spirited and Mrs. Clinton the passive victim of what are variously called her husband's "alleged infidelities ," "marital indiscretions ," "past peccadilloes " and--our favorite--"what he did with his penis ." In doing so, he is revealing many in the media to be little more than palace guards for the Clintons.A Saturday Washington Examiner headline summed the matter up succinctly: "Media in Agony as Trump Makes It Relive Clinton Sex Scandals." The Examiner's T. Becket Adams reviews the media reactions after Trump, in an interview with Fox News's Sean Hannity, "used the word 'rape' " in reference to Broaddrick's accusation of rape:Over at NBC News, Andrea Mitchell characterized Broaddrick's story--that then-Arkansas Attorney General Bill Clinton raped her in a hotel room in 1978--as "discredited and long-denied."ABC News's Tom Llamas took Mitchell's lead and reported this week that the rape charge is "decades-old and discredited."However, the former NBC investigative reporter who first interviewed the alleged victim in the late 1990s sees things a bit differently."Nothing has come up since that story was reported that in any way undercuts what Juanita Broaddrick said," Lisa Myers said in a 2014 C-SPAN interview.Early yesterday Trump released an Instagram ad featuring audio of Broaddrick's interview with Myers and a still photo of Mr. Clinton smoking a cigar. It's far from subtle, but the timing--just before Cosby's preliminary hearing--was a stroke of either luck or genius.Supporters of Mrs. Clinton take comfort in the 1990s' denouement, in which Mr. Clinton, charged by Congress with perjury and obstruction of justice, skated; the public supported him; and Mrs. Clinton parlayed her role as victimized wife into a U.S. Senate seat. They expect history to repeat, but it may not.For one thing, Mr. Clinton's wrongful acts may be old news to voters of middle age and older, but it is new to the under-30 generation, which has not been supportive of Mrs. Clinton in the Democratic primaries.For another, the Democrats won in the 1990s by cleverly flipping the script, making criticism of Mr. Clinton's misconduct more unrespectable than the misconduct itself. They did so in substantial part by depicting Mr. Clinton's adversaries as prudes and hypocrites engaged in what the New York Times's Amy Chozick just yesterday called a "Javert-like pursuit" of poor Bill.Donald Trump doesn't care about respectability. And accusations of prudishness and hypocrisy won't stick to him. He has many faults, but those are not among them.Fox Butterfield, Is That You? "The dwindling diversity in the pews has occurred even as the denomination has become increasingly liberal in its attitude, theology and partnerships, [departing dean of the Washington National Cathedral Gary] Hall said."--Michelle Boorstein and Julie Zauzmer, Washington Post, May 24Metaphor Alert "It's very important for [the unwieldily named Democratic National Committee chairman, Debbie Wasserman Schultz] to adopt a role of pouring oil on troubled waters. She did the opposite last week when she poured gasoline on the events that occurred in Nevada."--Sen. Jeff Merkley (D., Ore.), quoted by the Washington Examiner, May 24We Blame George W. The gist of it is that he and a lot of other people are avoiding discussions of Donald Trump because they are incapable of respecting those with opposing points of view:I have many relatives who loyally vote Republican, regardless of their excitement about the particular nominee. There's a definite chance that some of them back Trump. So I steer clear of talk about this election, though we've spoken plenty--and placidly--about every other election.One of these relatives routinely pushes back at any Trump-negative columns I write, and I've convinced myself that he's just baiting me and playing devil's advocate. I've never said to him, point blank, "Are you actually voting for Trump?" And I won't. It's my goal to get to and through Election Day without learning the truth.If you're a journalist whose goal is not to learn the truth, perhaps you've chosen the wrong line of work.Follow @jamestaranto on Twitter.Join Fans of Best of the Web Today on Facebook.Subscribe to the Best of the Web email with one click.(Carol Muller helps compile Best of the Web. article name: Democratic Fictions About the GOP and Trump
article text: The prospect of Republicans nominating Donald Trump for president has the party of Lincoln and Reagan teetering on the edge of the abyss. Democrats are enjoying the spectacle, but that doesn't mean they should be allowed to revise history.The conventional wisdom on the left is that the GOP brought the Trump phenomenon on itself. For years, insists the New York Times, Republican leaders have embraced and exploited "the darkest elements of the party's base." The Washington Post adds that the party "has subtly and not so subtly played on racial resentment." Other liberal pundits have cited the tea party movement as evidence of supposedly ascendant GOP white nationalism. Republican leaders, in other words, have greased the skids for this New York vulgarian and now want to feign shock at his success.The tea party charge might be the most absurd, and not just because the movement abetted the election of racial and ethnic minorities such as Tim Scott, Nikki Haley and Marco Rubio. Liberals who are eager to ascribe racial motivations to the tea party are ignoring activists' pre-Obama anger at George W. Bush's spending policies.In truth, the GOP leadership has made concerted efforts in recent years to expand the party's appeal to nonwhites. More can and should be tried, but the notion that the GOP has been waiting and hoping for a Trump figure to lead the way is an MSNBC fantasy. Mr. Trump's commanding lead in the polls can be attributed primarily to his celebrity status and strong support among economically anxious working-class voters who don't trust professional politicians.In 2002, after Sen. Trent Lott of Mississippi lauded Strom Thurmond's 1948 Dixiecrat presidential bid, President Bush condemned the statements before a group of black ministers in downtown Philadelphia and then helped orchestrate Mr. Lott's ouster from his leadership post. In 2006 Mr. Bush addressed the NAACP's annual convention and spoke openly about his party's racial history. As head of the Republican National Committee (RNC) from 2005 to 2007, Ken Mehlman spoke to more than 50 black audiences nationwide, including the major civil-rights organizations. He acknowledged that in the past the party had tried "to benefit politically from racial polarization" and that "we were wrong." In 2009 Michael Steele became the first black chairman of the RNC.This is rather odd behavior for a party playing to the darkest elements of its base. So is the fact that the Republican presidential nominee was John McCain in 2008 and Mitt Romney in 2012 -- hardly the first choices of immigration hard-liners. Mr. McCain denounced the birthers, and Mr. Romney refused to make an issue of Mr. Obama's controversial pastor, Jeremiah Wright. Both men acted in the interest of racial comity, and if they hadn't, charges of racism surely would have ensued. That those charges ensued anyway says something about the left's heads-I-win-tails-you-lose racial politics.After Mr. Romney's defeat in 2012, the RNC released a 100-page assessment of its missteps and outlined a strategy for moving forward. "The Republican Party must focus its efforts to earn new supporters and voters in the following demographic communities: Hispanic, Asian and Pacific Islanders, African-Americans, Indian Americans, Native Americans, women, and youth," the report said. "The pervasive mentality of writing off blocks of states or demographic votes for the Republican Party must be completely forgotten. The Republican Party must compete on every playing field."Donald Trump is not the answer to the GOP's problems. He was not part of their future plans. He wasn't really invited to this party. He crashed it. And judging from the primary election results so far -- he's winning pluralities, not majorities -- most Republicans want him to leave. Democrats and their friends in the media are much more eager for Mr. Trump to be the face of the GOP than are Republicans, even if liberal pundits are pretending otherwise.Today, it is the Democratic Party that stands to gain the most politically from racial and ethnic division. And no one knows this better than the Obama administration. The president counts Al Sharpton as an adviser; has dispatched Vice President Joe Biden to tell black audiences that conservatives want to put them "back in chains"; and used his attorney general to stir up the Democratic base by claiming that Republicans are trying to disenfranchise black voters.Most people who follow politics assumed that Mr. Trump would fade eventually if he didn't implode first. The window is closing but it's still a possibility.A new ABC News/Washington Post polls finds that just 42% to 45% of voters who lean Republican "call Trump honest and trustworthy, say he understands their problems, think he has the right personality and temperament, or say he has the right experience to be president." Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio score much higher on those attributes, from 50% to 64%. Mr. Trump's lead is shrinking. The more voters learn about him, the less they seem to like.---Mr. Riley, a Manhattan Institute senior fellow and Journal contributor, is the author of "Please Stop Helping Us: How Liberals Make It Harder for Blacks to Succeed" (Encounter Books, 2014).Credit: By Jason L. Riley

article name: Trump, Voters and the GOP Convention
article text: Donald Trump may pile up more than enough delegates in the primaries to make his GOP presidential nomination this summer a formality. But what if he doesn't? Mr. Trump, Ted Cruz and their media mouthpieces are claiming it would be political theft to choose the nominee at a contested convention. These timid souls need an education in party rules, political history and muscular democracy.The Republican Party's rules say a candidate needs the votes of 1,237 of the 2,472 delegates at the July convention in Cleveland to win the nomination. They don't say all one needs is a plurality, or to have won the most primaries. There is no moral right to the nomination because a candidate wins 40%, or even 49%, of the delegates. He needs a majority, and the 1,237 number is no secret.Parties set this public requirement because they exist to win elections, and a nominating majority is the best indicator of the rough consensus necessary to unite the party behind the winner. A candidate who can't put together a majority of delegates is unlikely to unite the party and is probably a loser in November.Before the primary system became the norm in the decades after World War II, party nominees were always chosen at the convention. But even in the primary era, a convention fight has been possible.As recently as 1976, Gerald Ford came into the convention with more delegates than Ronald Reagan, who offered the vice presidency to Senator Richard Schweiker to turn the Pennsylvania delegation his way. The influential Drew Lewis chose to honor his pledge to Ford, kept the Pennsylvania delegation in line, and denied Reagan the nomination.Democrats had to go three rounds of balloting in 1952 to produce Illinois Gov. Adlai Stevenson as their nominee. In 1956 Democrats staged a floor flight over which of more than a dozen candidates to nominate for vice president. Estes Kefauver won. And in 1980 there was a short-lived effort at the Democratic convention to change the rules to help Ted Kennedy catch Jimmy Carter, who had lost nearly every late primary to the Massachusetts Senator.With this history in mind, each party continues to have rules for how long delegates are pledged to a candidate. Under the GOP rules, about 1,700 delegates out of 2,472 (69%) are bound in the first ballot to vote for the candidate for whom they are pledged -- usually by a primary or caucus result. The 31% who are unbound come from states that don't hold binding presidential preference contests, or from states that allow some of their delegates to remain uncommitted.If the first ballot doesn't produce a majority, nearly 80% of the delegates then become free to vote for the nominee of their choice on the second ballot. By the third ballot, 89.4% are free to choose. This gradual liberation is designed to prevent a stalemate and let the delegates work their will to coalesce eventually around the best nominee. This isn't cheating or "stealing the nomination." It's how the process is supposed to work.Ah, but aren't the delegates part of the "establishment"? If by establishment you mean stalwart party members in the provinces, then yes. They are often the rank-and-file GOPers who run state and local party operations. But others are activists chosen to become delegates by the various candidates.It's true that three delegates from each state are Republican National Committee members. But the rules this year require nearly all of those RNC members to vote in the first ballot for the candidate who won the most at-large votes in a state primary or caucus. So those RNC members, a small minority of delegates, are expressing the will of the voters in the first go-round.The premature protests by Messrs Cruz and Trump are entirely self-serving. Both men think they have a good chance to win a plurality of delegates but can't be sure they'll get all the way to 1,237. They want to cry havoc in advance so party members will shrink in fear of a GOP breakup if there's a nominating fight at the convention.These candidates and Republicans generally should toughen up. If Messrs. Trump or Cruz couldn't sway a majority at the convention, it would be because they couldn't convince their fellow Republicans that they have the best chance of winning. Every candidate entered the race knowing the rules, and every candidate has an equal opportunity to exploit them. Mr. Trump certainly has used the accelerated primary calendar to his advantage, racking up a delegate lead before he's been subject to any real scrutiny.It's always possible that a losing Mr. Trump would bolt the GOP and run as a third-party candidate or urge his supporters to boycott in November. But the same might happen in reverse if Mr. Trump becomes the nominee despite what is growing opposition from traditional Republicans. If the businessman can't rally a majority at the convention, then he can't unite the GOP enough to beat Hillary Clinton.Many primaries have yet to be held, and the odds are that the voters will give one candidate a clear majority before Cleveland. But if they don't, the voters themselves will have set the stage for the convention fight. The event could a great education in party democracy, and it certainly would do better in the ratings than the usual four-day infomercial.

article name: Main Street: Trump: A Bill Maher Republican
article text: Forget asking GOP consultants. Or the other candidates. For any Republican Party elder who is still scratching his head over the rise of Donald Trump, the man with the answer is comedian Bill Maher.The HBO host gave it on "Real Time with Bill Maher" last August when he summed up Mr. Trump's appeal to the electorate this way:"They are desperate to have somebody lead them," Mr. Maher explained. "Somebody to say, 'You know what, I just don't bend to your bull----.' And Donald Trump, I've got to say, I don't agree with him on a lot, but I kind of get him. We've been doing the same thing."Yes indeed. When Mr. Trump goes unfiltered -- boasting about his genitalia from the podium of a presidential debate -- it baffles polite society that such comments do not sink him the way they would mere mortal pols. Especially since his response when called on it almost always is to double down on the provocation, even when he's wrong.One explanation for the Trump phenomenon is that it proves the American people (or at least Republicans) are just what the Democrats say they are: an odd bunch of gun nuts, bitter clingers, homophobes, racists, sexists, Muslim haters and other assorted kooks. In this view, all Mr. Trump has done is bring the ugliness out into the open.The other explanation is a version of Mr. Maher's. Americans are tired of the pieties that prevent our leaders from addressing problems honestly. They see, for example, their president refusing to utter the words "Islamist terror" even after bloody terrorist rampages that leave Americans dead. These include the 2009 attack on Fort Hood, which was called "workplace violence" even though the killer -- Army Major Nidal Hasan -- had been in communications with an overseas al Qaeda leader and was shouting "Allahu akbar!" as he went about his murderous shooting spree.So when Mr. Trump vows to kill not just the terrorists but their wives and children too, it doesn't follow that this is what his supporters are in fact cheering on. More likely what they hear Mr. Trump saying is this: I am going to keep you safe, and I'm not going to let political correctness get in the way. At a time when two out of three Americans are telling pollsters that political correctness is a huge problem for our country, Mr. Trump is tapping into a powerful sentiment.Unfortunately, there are two kinds of political incorrectness, and Mr. Trump's is the inferior version.The better kind of political incorrectness challenges what George Orwell called "the smelly little orthodoxies which are now contending for our souls." It does so with reason and a willingness to go where the facts take it.This is the political incorrectness that is under siege today. Especially in the academy, and especially if the orthodoxy being challenged is a progressive one, the challenge often carries a high price for the challenger.Question the science behind global warming, for example, and you will be met with accusations you are a "denier." Hold the same views on marriage Barack Obama claimed to hold until very recently -- that it ought to be confined to one man and one woman -- and you will lose your job if you are the CEO of Mozilla. If you are African-American and you write about black crime and the crisis of fatherless families, you will be denounced as an "Uncle Tom."Mr. Trump's political incorrectness, by contrast, is rooted in outrage and coarseness. This is also Mr. Maher's specialty, along with the easy yuck. Thus his most recent show featured Trumplike subtitles (e.g., "We're going to make Germany great again") superimposed on a video of Hilter giving a fiery speech.A Republican as the Fuhrer. Amusing, yes. Brave, hardly.Into this world comes Mr. Trump, real-estate-mogul/reality-TV star. As the Good Book puts it, Never spake man like this man before. And a huge chunk of the American people find it refreshing.Here's the further complication: Even Maher-style political incorrectness, like Mr. Trump's, occasionally veers into a substantive point. Mr. Maher, for example, has done so in his warnings about the threat of radical Islam and a Democratic Party trying to pretend it doesn't exist.The Donald makes his own contributions here.
