The Clinton campaign would be wise to take this to heart when facing a national grass-roots movement looking to break up the rigged system in Washington and elect a true outsider like Donald Trump."For his part, the Clinton campaign manager identified North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Florida as key battlegrounds in this election, sketching plans for appealing to distinctly different voter groups in each state.Some political pundits have suggested that Georgia, which has backed Republican presidential candidates in the last five presidential elections, could be more competitive in this election.But Mr. Mook shied from any bold predictions."Georgia is going to be a battleground state," he said. "It's just a question of when."Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Chelsea Clinton Set to Make Her Case for Her Mother; Like Ivanka Trump a week earlier, the would-be first daughter will introduce the nominee
article text: PHILADELPHIA--A day before Chelsea Clinton was to address the Democratic convention, she stepped away from the convention hall on Wednesday to rail against what she called Donald Trump's "divisive" and "degrading" rhetoric.Ms. Clinton faces the unprecedented task of preparing for the prospect of becoming the first daughter for a second time. In recent years, the Clintons' only daughter has become increasingly involved in the family businesses--politics and the Clinton Foundation. In 2008, she hit the campaign trail for her mother's failed bid to win the Democratic nomination. She has been back on the stump for her mother since last year.Ms. Clinton on Thursday will introduce her mother at the convention, before the nominee's acceptance speech. Her friend Ivanka Trump did the same for Donald Trump at last week's GOP convention, promoting her father's candidacy, committing him to some progressive stances on women's issues and never mentioning the Democratic nominee by name.But unlike Ms. Trump, who is active in managing her father's properties, Ms. Clinton's future beyond this campaign is less clear. In 2011, Ms. Clinton joined the foundation created by her father, Bill, when he left the White House, but the foundation's prospects under a Clinton White House remain unknown.In June, Mr. Clinton acknowledged the political reality that should his wife be elected president, the foundation would have to make changes about fundraising and mission. About the same time, a senior Clinton campaign adviser told The Wall Street Journal that Mr. Clinton wouldn't be able to continue to raise money for the foundation.The adviser added that if Mrs. Clinton is in the White House, the foundation couldn't function as it did when she served as secretary of state.People close to the Clintons said they could see Ms. Clinton, should her mother be elected, taking on some of the roles traditionally reserved for the first lady, such as organizing holiday parties and selecting menus for state dinners.Ms. Clinton has been outspoken on the campaign trail in recent months. Speaking at an event Wednesday hosted by the Human Rights Campaign, a gay-rights advocacy group, Ms. Clinton criticized the Republican Party platform, finalized at last week's convention, which she called the "most regressive, least inclusive platform in modern political history.""I thought a lot about what I found most offensive last week," she said. "It's hard to pick just one part."Calling the election the "most important" of her lifetime as the first in which she will cast her vote as a mother, Ms. Clinton, 36 years old, said Wednesday that her mother provides a "stark contrast" to the gay-rights stances of Mr. Trump and his running mate, Indiana Gov. Mike Pence.The Republican platform opposes same-sex marriage and supports parents' right to consent to medical treatment on behalf of their children. Gay-rights advocates read that as a tacit endorsement of conversion therapy, a practice intended to stop gay people from being gay. Ms. Clinton on Wednesday likened conversion therapy to "child abuse" and said her mother would federally ban the practice.Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus, asked in an Associated Press interview whether the GOP supported that practice, replied, "It's not in the platform."Ms. Clinton, who has degrees from Stanford, Oxford and Columbia, has benefited from her family connections. She worked for a time at Avenue Capital, an investment firm run by Marc Lasry, a close Clinton friend. She is a paid board director of IAC/InterActiveCorp., the media company run by Barry Diller, a longtime friend of the Clintons.Ms. Clinton's husband, Marc Mezvinsky, operates a hedge fund, and several of the top investors have been longtime friends and supporters of the Clintons and their foundation.She has also seen other personal relationships complicated by politics--including her friendship with Ms. Trump. At an event here on Tuesday, Ms. Clinton was asked about Ms. Trump's speech assertion that her father would back "equal pay" for women--a subject he has rarely discussed.Ms. Clinton said she is dubious about Mr. Trump's commitment to the issue "given it's not something that he has spoken about, [and] there are no policies on any of those fronts that you just mentioned on his website." She added: "So I think the 'how' question is super important."Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.comCredit: By Rebecca Ballhaus and James V. Grimaldi

article name: Trump, Sanders and the Populist Anti-Policy Surge
article text: If there's one thing that unites the populist campaigns of Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, it's a desire to put the "public" back into "public policy." Many Americans apparently feel that policy is something done to them, rather than with them. They disdain the unknown "experts" in distant Washington, D.C., who devise everything from trade deals to overtime rules.As the dean of a graduate school in public policy, I've been thinking: Are programs like mine partly responsible for this state of affairs? How should graduates in the Class of 2016 react as they enter a world increasingly skeptical of their expertise?It's true that government has often failed to engage citizens. During a recent conference on land use at Pepperdine, the planning director of a large California city explained it this way: "The problem is that we always put people up in front of the public who are the least prepared to be there."Her staff were experts in the technical aspects of their work -- from limits on building heights to requirements for setbacks. But she recognized that when her planners met with citizens, who often had different priorities, they were incapable of facilitating productive dialogue. The public simply concluded that the government couldn't -- or wouldn't -- "listen."Graduate programs in public policy and public administration have wrestled with this for years. The discipline sends into the field alumni who may be very good at formulating something called "policy," but not so good at understanding the public's role in its creation. "Large segments of mainstream public administration scholarship," Robert F. Durant and Susannah Bruns Ali wrote three years ago in Public Administration Review, "privilege bureaucratic expertise and marginalize the deliberative role of unorganized interests and citizens in agency deliberations."The general tendencies of these academic programs toward quantitative knowledge and standardized solutions has created what we see today: from local planners who don't listen, to White House advisers who believe that ObamaCare passed because of the "stupidity of the American voter."At Pepperdine, we host a training series titled "Public Engagement: The Vital Leadership Skill." More than 1,000 public officials have taken part, learning the basics of facilitating input from citizens. We developed the program about five years ago after realizing that many midcareer public leaders never learned these skills in college and graduate school.Are this generation's successors being taught them? The retirement of the baby boomers will effect one of the greatest changes in public leadership in American history. Now is the time to update these programs to ensure that generational change becomes cultural change.First, we should teach students to think of the public not as a faceless mass, but as actual, individual human beings. "Modern public administration," the great sociologist Robert Nisbet wrote, "has been generally dominated by the nineteenth-century rationalist's conception of society as a vast aggregate of unconnected political particles." That was in 1953.Public-policy programs should integrate essential quantitative coursework into a liberal-arts approach. Students should read what the Great Books say about the role of a citizen in a democracy, while studying what the latest social-psychology research shows about the myriad biases people bring to "fact based" decision-making. These will help them see that the policy they develop for Rome, Ga., may not work in Rome, N.Y., (or Rome, Italy, for that matter) and that some government services might be better provided by a local nonprofit or through collaboration with the private sector.Second, schools must teach a set of skills -- how to facilitate public meetings or publicize them to increase participation. The "public comment" process by which local boards and councils usually involve citizens does not succeed at informing either the public or policy makers. In 2013 Pepperdine, working with the League of California Cities, surveyed over 900 public officials. Seventy-six percent said that their public meetings were "typically dominated by people with narrow agendas."It's the same phenomenon that played out in the conflagrations known as town halls when ObamaCare was being passed. Citizens came out in force against the bill, but Congress passed it anyway. Some argue that these failed public meetings led to the creation of America's last populist movement: the tea party.Finally, students of public policy should be taught about the role of technology in mediating the relationship between the citizen and his government. A couple of months ago, my hometown of Santa Monica invited me via Facebook to complete an online survey regarding a downtown building project. Tomorrow's public leaders must be prepared to involve and inform residents in ways the private sector has employed for decades -- engaging them on social media, or posting budget data online to increase transparency.In the months ahead, thousands of future leaders will be awarded degrees in public policy. Meanwhile, graduate schools should ponder the role they play in American democracy -- and how they can respond to the populist moment that is upending politics (and policy) as usual.---Mr. Peterson is the dean of the Pepperdine School of Public Policy.(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Populist Anti-Policy Surge Has Deep Roots" -- WSJ May 26, 2016)Credit: By Pete Peterson

article name: Donald Trump's Day in Court
article text: Donald Trump took an unusual step for a presumptive presidential nominee on Wednesday by naming 11 potential Supreme Court candidates -- and the list shows that someone is giving him sound judicial advice. One obvious worry about Mr. Trump is that he has given voters no clear idea of how he would govern, so offering some specific pre-election guidance is good politics that could lead to better judicial choices.Mr. Trump said in March that he'd release a list of Supreme Court candidates that he will "100% pick, that I will put in for nomination." On Wednesday he offered a generally impressive roster of six judges sitting on federal courts and five from state Supreme Courts. The latter is a healthy bow to the nation's "vast expanse in-between," as the late Justice Antonin Scalia put it in 2014 when he noted that nearly all recent Justices have been coastal lawyers from Harvard or Yale.One promising choice is the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals' Diane Sykes, who also served on the Wisconsin Supreme Court and wrote an opinion in 2014 that declared "labryinthian" regulation on political speech unconstitutional. Another is the Sixth Circuit's Raymond Kethledge, who in March rebuked the IRS for obstructing a lawsuit on the agency's targeting of conservative groups, a matter he called "among the most serious allegations a federal court can address."The lineup is clearly intended to bring along social conservatives who have been leery of Mr. Trump: Several have a paper trail defending religious liberty, restrictions on abortion, or vouchers for parochial schools. Steven Colloton is a highly regarded judge from the Eighth Circuit who clerked for former Chief Justice William Rehnquist and joined an opinion supporting a religious exception to ObamaCare's contraception mandate. First and Second Amendment cases are another common theme of their jurisprudence.Mr. Trump tweeted Wednesday that he might be "adding" to the list, and if he does we'd include the D.C. Circuit's Brett Kavanaugh and the Sixth Circuit's Jeff Sutton. Both are powerful minds who could replace some of the conservative intellectual heft that the Court has lost in Justice Scalia.Some conservatives say the names are irrelevant because Mr. Trump changes his mind on everything, but such a public list raises the political cost if he picks an unknown or a crony. His list includes some of the more solid constitutional originalists in the country, which suggests interest in unifying the GOP. A Republican Senate could hold him to his own standard if he goes rogue, much as it did George W. Bush when he nominated Harriet Miers.The bitter history is that voters have never been sure who GOP Presidents would nominate to the High Court. The Presidents who appointed the great Clarence Thomas and Scalia -- George H.W. Bush and Ronald Reagan -- also picked David Souter and Sandra Day O'Connor, who tacked left once they joined the Court. Our main concern would be whether Mr. Trump would stick to his list if Republicans lost the Senate and he turned to the "art of the deal" with Chuck Schumer.Nothing is certain with Mr. Trump, but that's far preferable to the certainty that Hillary Clinton would nominate a down-the-line liberal. The direction of the Supreme Court for a generation is up for grabs in November, and Mr. Trump's list makes him far superior to Mrs. Clinton on that score.

article name: Election 2016: Trump Looks to NRA for Boost --- Republican to address gun group that Clinton has called an enemy she is proud to have
article text: Presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump is banking on one of the GOP's most faithful constituencies -- gun owners -- as he tries to rally a party fractured by his candidacy.He will address a convention on Friday hosted by the political arm of the National Rifle Association, expected to draw tens of thousands of people to Louisville, Ky.Guns represent one of the sharpest policy contrasts between him and Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton.Mrs. Clinton has put gun control near the top of her agenda and has shifted to the left on the issue while fighting off a challenge from the liberal wing of the party.Mr. Trump has significantly changed his position on gun policy over the years. In 2000, he backed an assault-weapons ban and longer waiting periods for gun purchases, but he has retreated from those positions during this campaign. He also has vowed to do away with gun-free school zones and backs a top NRA priority: allowing permits to carry concealed weapons in one state to be valid in another.In the eyes of many gun enthusiasts, Mr. Trump's reversals on assault weapons and gun-sales checks are small quibbles compared with Mrs. Clinton's campaign to "take on" the gun lobby.Mrs. Clinton named the NRA -- along with the insurance and drug industries, the Iranians and the Republican Party -- as the enemies she is most proud of during a debate last year. She hailed President Barack Obama's executive orders aimed at expanding and improving background checks, which Mr. Trump says he would do away with."We're looking at what people would do as president, and Donald Trump has laid out positions that show a strong commitment to Second Amendment rights," said Jennifer Baker, an NRA spokeswoman."This should be a very friendly audience for him."Mrs. Baker added, "When it comes to motivating our members and turning them out and getting them to vote against Hillary, it will be easy."Activists on both sides of the debate are seeking to frame the November vote as a referendum on guns. In a twist on Mr. Trump's "Make America Great Again" slogan, the gun control group Everytown for Gun Safety is promoting "Make America Safe Again" during the NRA convention.Mr. Trump's opposition to gun control could make it harder for him to improve his standing with two slices of the electorate that could tip the scales in the November election: women and minorities. In a Wall Journal/NBC News poll in December, majorities of female, African-American and Hispanic voters said they were concerned the government wouldn't do enough to regulate firearms, while most men and white voters were more concerned that the government would go too far in restricting gun rights.On the other hand, Mr. Trump's positions could help him in pro-gun states carried by Mr. Obama, including Pennsylvania, Virginia, Colorado and New Hampshire.Guns didn't come up much in the Republican primary, but received a lot of attention in the Democratic race, as Mrs. Clinton repeatedly attacked rival Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders for voting for a 2005 law that shields gun manufacturers from most lawsuits. Mr. Sanders has defended his vote, but also co-sponsored a bill to repeal the law this year.As Mr. Sanders tried to lock down the liberal wing of the party, gun control was one of the only issues on which Mrs. Clinton could attack him from the left. Mrs. Clinton also has campaigned with African-American mothers who lost children to gun violence, as part of her support for the BlackLivesMatter movement.Mrs. Clinton's emphasis and tone have differed considerably from her 2008 campaign, when she shared memories of learning how to shoot a gun as a child and criticized then-Sen. Obama for suggesting some Pennsylvania voters "cling to guns and religion." In past elections, Democrats have tended to be cautious about offending gun owners."We've been encouraged by the total sea change in how guns have been addressed in this election cycle," said Erika Soto Lamb, a spokeswoman for Everytown for Gun Safety. "What was once considered a third-rail issue is now front and center."Mr. Trump's speech will be closely watched for signs he was serious when he said while campaigning in January in Vermont: "I will get rid of gun-free zones on schools . . . . My first day, it gets signed, OK?"Mr. Trump would need Congress to repeal a 1990 federal law signed by former Republican President George H.W. Bush that forbids firearms near school grounds. Mr. Trump's campaign website, however, doesn't mention gun-free school zones in the gun policy section.A Trump campaign spokeswoman declined to comment.Credit: By Beth Reinhard

article name: Obama Front-Runs Trump on China
article text: The Obama Administration may not sound like Donald Trump when talking about trade with China, but it isn't above using protectionism for political gain. On Tuesday the U.S. Commerce Department increased a tariff on "dumped" Chinese cold-rolled steel to 522%, a move that will hurt American manufacturers who need the steel to remain competitive.The tariff might score some populist points with voters in an election year. It also may be a ploy to get lawmakers to ratify the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement before President Obama leaves office. But past experience suggests that such gambits inflame protectionist sentiment rather than tamp it down.President George W. Bush imposed tariffs of up to 30% on a broad range of Chinese steel products in 2002. The Consuming Industries Trade Action Coalition says the tariffs cost the U.S. economy 200,000 jobs and $4 billion in lost wages. The Obama Administration made a similar mistake in 2009, slapping "safeguard" tariffs on Chinese tires. Punitive tariffs on a range of other Chinese products followed, and Beijing retaliated with its own tariffs and cases at the World Trade Organization. Both sides are now in violation of WTO decisions that followed these tit-for-tat taxes.Beijing's trade record is marred by export rebates and discrimination against foreign companies. Government policy in various forms is behind the quadrupling of Chinese-steel capacity since 2000, whether through cheap credit to build new mills or the wave of public construction projects after the 2008 financial panic. China now produces about half of the world's steel, and as its own demand has subsided the excess has flooded the world market, driving down prices.But this is good news for the U.S. Since steel is an important raw material for many industries, China's trade partners benefit from its wasteful policies. Lower prices make companies that use steel more competitive and bring down prices for consumers.Daniel Pearson of the Cato Institute conservatively estimates that American companies using steel produce $990 billion in value added, more than 16 times the output of the U.S. steel industry, and also employ 16 times more workers. If tariffs on Chinese imports raise the U.S. price of steel, these companies' costs will be higher than foreign competitors', hurting their ability to grow and provide more jobs for Americans.U.S. steel makers and unions argue for high tariffs on the basis that steel users will buy American. But manufacturers complain that the U.S. mills don't produce the same range of products as the Chinese. So some will simply have to pay the tariff-inflated prices and endure the competitive damage.The steel tariff is a warm-up for the fight over granting China market-economy status in December. Beijing's 2001 accession to the WTO included a 15-year adjustment in which China was treated as a nonmarket economy for purposes of antidumping investigations.The U.S. and EU have been able to use input prices from other developing companies to estimate Chinese producers' cost of production. This lowered the evidentiary bar and resulted in high tariffs such as those on cold-rolled steel. Antidumping cases are dubious even without this statistical legerdemain, and U.S. unions and companies will lobby the next President to renege on the WTO accord.The larger question is whether the steel tariffs herald a new and more bitter era of trade retaliation. Previous skirmishes have been damaging but stopped short of full escalation. But Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton have run for President as protectionists, and Mr. Obama's surrender to steel interests is a bad omen. Chinese officials who think they can keep flooding the world with surplus goods could be in for as rude an awakening as U.S. consumers.(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Moves Against Chinese Steel Are Not Protectionism" -- WSJ May 27, 2016)

article name: The Entrepreneur's Case for Trump
article text: The rise of Donald Trump has exposed a deep chasm in America between the haves and have-nots. I could go on, but you have probably read that story by now. You've also likely read about conservatives who think that stopping Mr. Trump is the only way to save their cause. I'm here to explain why they couldn't be more wrong. What principled conservatives fail to understand is how the nation would benefit from putting a right-leaning entrepreneur in the White House.I too began the primary cycle as a critic of Donald Trump. I've never come across a candidate who perfectly matched my philosophical fingerprint -- have you ever found such a match? -- but I am a Republican because the party best represents the ideals of human liberty and economic empowerment that fuel the American dream. Mr. Trump shares those values.Here are four things that the movement from the right to stop Donald Trump is missing:-- He has empathy. Mr. Trump is both a beneficiary and victim of the soundbite generation. He has leveraged social media to run a thrifty campaign, but critics have also latched onto one-liners rather than examine the whole of his record. You couldn't find one person who knows Donald Trump who thinks he's a racist. While his stance on immigration has often been expressed in brutish terms, the substance of his message -- securing America's borders and pausing the Syrian refugee program -- is not crazy. Mr. Trump's empathy, when voters see it properly expressed, will lead to victory in November and to policies fortified by longstanding conservative values.-- He is a pragmatic entrepreneur. What elitists misinterpret as uneven principles, entrepreneurs understand as adaptability. Whether you like or dislike Mr. Trump personally, you have to respect the business empire and brand he has built. He has always demonstrated an ability to take punches and get up off the mat while others without his fortitude and ingenuity would have crumbled. Most of his critics have never dared to step into the entrepreneurial arena where there exists the potential of embarrassing defeat. Mr. Trump would be the greatest pragmatist and deal maker Washington has ever seen.-- He is a team builder. I have spent several hours over the past few weeks with Mr. Trump, and I came away with the feeling he has the analytical depth to excel at the job of the presidency. Mr. Trump has put his ego aside to reinforce Corey Lewandowski's formidable campaign team with a talented group of people: Gov. Chris Christie, Sen. Scott Brown, Paul Manafort, Rick Wiley and Steven Mnuchin, to name a few. Mr. Trump has shown a willingness to welcome Republican establishment figures into his coalition. The establishment should be constructive in return. If he were elected president, like any smart entrepreneur Mr. Trump would continue to surround himself with brilliant people.-- He can win. Pundits cherry-pick polls to suit their narrative, but the reality is that Mr. Trump is already in a good position even before turning his full attention to Hillary Clinton. Skeptics point to a recent CNN poll showing her with a double-digit lead, but a Rasmussen poll showing Mr. Trump leading by two points gets less attention. The electoral map is ultimately all that matters, and a Quinnipiac University poll released May 10 showed the two candidates basically in a dead heat in three crucial swing states. All of the momentum in the general election will swing to Mr. Trump, but establishment Republicans had better realize abstention would in effect be a vote to put Hillary Clinton in the White House.As the product of a middle-class household and an entrepreneur who loves this country, I understand both the appeal Mr. Trump has to the electorate and the opportunity to put Republican policies at the forefront of American politics for a generation. I'm not willing to lose this election over bruised egos.I urge my fellow Republicans to listen to the will of the people, shun the destructive cynicism of the past eight years, and unite not only for the good of the party, but for the good of the nation.---Mr. Scaramucci is the founder and co-managing partner of SkyBridge Capital.Credit: By Anthony Scaramucci

article name: Hillary Clinton to Emphasize Experience, Steadiness in Speech to Democratic Convention; Democratic nominee expected to argue for staying the course, against Donald Trump's message for change
article text: PHILADELPHIA--Hillary Clinton was set to accept the Democratic Party's nomination for president Thursday, hoping her message of experience, steadiness and inclusion would prevail despite an electorate anxious for change.Her historic rise as the first female nominee of a major political party comes almost a century after American women were given the right to vote in 1920.Mrs. Clinton, who was expected to be introduced on stage by her daughter Chelsea, will leave the Democratic National Convention with a largely unified party, set for a general election that will test whether she can lead them to a third straight term in the White House.Her chief challenges include convincing Americans dissatisfied with the slow and uneven economic recovery and fearful of a spate of new terrorism attacks that staying the course is better than betting on the unpredictable agenda of Republican rival Donald Trump. All week, Democrats have argued from the convention stage that the New York billionaire was temperamentally unfit for the job."No major party nominee in the history of this nation has ever known less or has been less prepared to deal with our national security," Vice President Joe Biden told the convention on Wednesday.But Mrs. Clinton's task was further complicated by the passions stirred by former Democratic rival Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who drew millions of supporters with his outrage over income inequality and campaign against the political and financial establishment.While Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders made their peace ahead of the convention week, his supporters sporadically protested his defeat outside and inside the Wells Fargo Center. And, on the final day of the convention, party officials were bracing for outbursts during Mrs. Clinton's acceptance speech.Mr. Trump's fiery message of unfairness and decline in America has resonated with white, working-class voters in particular. On Thursday, Mrs. Clinton's goal was to paint a more hopeful, optimistic vision of a nation that comes together and is, as her campaign slogan puts it, "stronger together."To underscore that message, the prime-time roster of speakers included Kareem Abdul-Jabaar, one of the nation's highest-profile Muslims, and two Republicans, Doug Elmets, who served as a speech writer in the Reagan administration, and Jennifer Pierotti Lim, co-founder of Republican Women for Hillary.One of her speech themes, aides said, would be the lessons from her book "It Takes a Village," where she wrote about the impact a community can have on children.She also planned to provide a clear road map showing how she would work to boost jobs, particularly for workers whose incomes have stagnated since the 2007 recession. Her prescriptions include a big increase in federal infrastructure spending, paid family leave and significant new subsidies to make public college tuition-free for most families.A June Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll underscored her task ahead. Asked if they wanted the next president to take a steady approach to the way government operates or to bring major changes even if it isn't clear what those changes will be, 56% favored change compared with 41% who wanted a steady approach."Hillary Clinton cannot afford to simply embrace the status quo, but must show that there will be a separate route for the country's future," said Peter Hart, who co-directs the Journal/NBC News poll.President Barack Obama sought to clear the road ahead for Mrs. Clinton. In his address Wednesday , he reminded voters that his administration had rescued the economy from the depths of a recession, and pointed to steady job gains since then. The unemployment rate has fallen to below 5% from nearly 10% in 2009."I am more optimistic about the future of America than ever before," Mr. Obama said. "How could I not be after all that we've achieved together?"But those gains haven't translated into higher incomes for many Americans, which has left the electorate conflicted. While the president's approval ratings have risen above 50%, some seven in 10 Americans say the country is now on the wrong track.Those wrong-track numbers illustrate Mrs. Clinton's major problem, said Republican pollster Whit Ayers. "If this election gets defined as change represented by Donald Trump and status quo represented by Hillary Clinton, Trump could win it," he said.The Democrats are well aware of that risk, and former President Bill Clinton's Tuesday convention address was aimed at redefining his wife as a "change agent," for her ability to take on problems and find solutions."We'll see how successful that is," Mr. Ayers said.It is never easy for a party to retain the White House for three straight terms. Mr. Hart said this election is fundamentally different from 2000, the last time Democrats tried to do so. In that case, he said, voters were satisfied with the nation's direction, but Vice President Al Gore mistakenly ran from Mr. Clinton's economic record.A better analogy, he said, would be 1988, when Vice President George H.W. Bush sought to follow Ronald Reagan's two terms as president. The nation wanted change, but Mr. Bush was able to win by presenting a new "kinder, gentler" vision of America--combined with an aggressive negative campaign aimed at Democrat Michael Dukakis.Mrs. Clinton already has tied herself tightly to Mr. Obama, in part by necessity to win the Democratic primary, and in part because she's inevitably connected to him as his former secretary of state.That impression was advanced by the symbolic passing of the torch from Mr. Obama, when Mrs. Clinton joined him on the convention stage at the end of his final, major moment on the national stage.Still, Democrats are eager for her to use his address to tell voters about her own agenda for improving their lots. "You've got to acknowledge (the anxiety) and say here's my plan," said Rep. Tim Ryan (D., Ohio).Others from the party's populist wing suggest she go even bigger. "My advice would be to embrace change," said Mark Longabaugh, a top adviser to Mr. Sanders. He suggested she emphasize her newly expanded college plan, which she adopted to win over Mr. Sanders and his young supporters."In every campaign, there's always a tension between the cautious approach and the bold approach," he said. "The country is in the mood for much bigger change than incremental change."More on Election 2016* Pennsylvania Poll Shows Hillary Clinton Keeping Sizable Lead* Obama Rallies Democrats Behind Hillary Clinton at Convention* Donald Trump on Hacking Comments: 'Of Course I'm Being Sarcastic'* Clinton's Strategy Begins With Parrying Trump in Rust Belt* Hillary Clinton's Inner Circle* Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump on Foreign-Policy IssuesCredit: By Laura Meckler and Siobhan Hughes

article name: Economists Lower Forecasts for Mexican Growth; U.S. elections seen adding to the uncertainty amid anti-Mexico comments from GOP candidate Donald Trump
article text: MEXICO CITY--Economists surveyed in July by the Bank of Mexico reduced their expectations for economic growth this year, seeing weak external demand and a sluggish global economy as the main risks for Mexico.Mexico's gross domestic product is expected to grow 2.3% in 2016, according to the median estimate of 35 analysts polled last month by the central bank, compared with 2.4% forecast in June.Responses to the survey were received before Friday's preliminary GDP report , which showed Mexico's output of goods and services falling 0.3% in the second quarter from the first, equivalent to an annualized seasonally adjusted decline of 1.2%.The downturn in the economy comes at a complicated time given Mexico's widening current-account deficit, which relies in part on financing for short-term capital inflows and increased levels of public-sector debt, the Vector Casa de Bolsa brokerage house said in its weekly report."As if that wasn't enough, the Mexican economy is also suffering from an additional external shock related to the U.S. electoral process," Vector added. Mexico has been a point of focus for Republican candidate Donald Trump, who says he plans to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border and renegotiate or abandon the North American Free Trade Agreement.The U.S. election process is generating uncertainty and could be putting investment decisions on hold, Vector added.Only 12% of analysts polled in July by the central bank considered now to be a good time to invest, down from 18% in June, while 35% considered it a bad time to invest, up from 21%. The remaining 53% were unsure.The most-mentioned obstacles to growth in Mexico were weak external markets and the global economic slowdown, followed by international financial instability and reduced Mexican oil production.The Bank of Mexico survey showed inflation expectations for 2016 rising modestly to 3.2% from 3.1% in June, while the median estimate for core inflation--which excludes energy and fresh fruit and vegetables--remained unchanged at 3.2%.The Mexican peso is expected to end the year at 18.62 to the U.S. dollar, compared with 18.31 in the June survey. The currency was recently quoted in Mexico City at 18.8570 to the dollar. The central bank cited inflationary risks from a weaker peso in its June 29 decision to raise its reference interest rate by half a percentage point to 4.25%.Write to Anthony Harrup at anthony.harrup@wsj.comCredit: By Anthony Harrup

article name: Trump, Trade, Technology and American Jobs
article text: Regarding Mary Anastasia O'Grady's "Wharton Grad Trump Fails Economics" (Americas, July 25): I farm in Iowa and provide consulting services to agribusiness companies at home and abroad. I recall that most basic of Economics 101 lessons about "the gains from trade." It amazes, shocks and disappoints me (and many of us in agriculture in the Midwest who depend on exports) that so many of our politicians are ready to "tear up trade agreements" and erect trade barriers. Have any of these people, including Donald Trump, ever heard of the Great Depression?For the pork industry, Nafta and the Mexican market demonstrate a classic case in point. Before Nafta, U.S. pork producers had virtually zero market in Mexico. Today, the U.S. pork industry exports about one quarter of its production, around $6 billion a year, and thanks to Nafta Mexico is now our No. 1 market in volume and No. 2 market in value. The Trans-Pacific Partnership represents another exciting opportunity for U.S. agriculture to continue to grow exports of American food, feed and fiber.It's truly disheartening to hear the presidential candidates disavow the benefits of trade to the American economy. Ms. O'Grady's piece is spot-on by pointing out that it is technology that is putting people out of work, not trade agreements.Brian M. FosterHampton, Iowa---The move of our company, California Cedar Products Co., to China had nothing to do with advances in technology. We are a manufacturer of slats for the subsequent manufacture of pencils. Our company (with about 1,500 employees including six sawmills) was the last slat factory to produce in the U.S. We were the last one here because we survived due to our advanced technology using very thin saws to increase the yield from wood. But the saving in wood wasn't enough to offset the cost of labor.China began selling finished pencils in the U.S. in the late 1980s at prices lower than our slats. We moved our factory to China, even after negotiating a 14.8% decrease in wages and benefits in 1998. After the move our labor costs in China decreased 90%. The problem was that by then the Chinese had taken a large share of our business.The Chinese were selling pencils below cost: therefore a tariff would have been the proper temporary solution. Perhaps the American consumer can buy pencils cheaper now that there are hardly any manufacturers left here but think of the economics and buying power of employing the 15,000 or so former U.S. pencil-making workers in our society. Luckily we're still in business, but we have only about five employees in the U.S.Before we moved we even contacted President Clinton and California Sen. Dianne Feinstein. The former completely ignored our petition and the latter canceled an appointment the day before she was supposed to attend a big factory meeting with our employees. So don't rely on the government to do anything except tax you to death.Philip C. BerolzheimerStockton, Calif.---As one of the analysts crunching the numbers, I can absolutely assure Ms. O'Grady that the reason why the company I worked for moved over 7,500 manufacturing jobs from the U.S. to Mexico was 100% due to the ability Nafta afforded the company to take advantage of lower Mexican wages. The technology used in the U.S. plants was all shipped to the Mexican ones.Frank ViolaJenkintown, Pa.---Technology has certainly made it easier for government regulators to grind out and enforce a never-ending stream of onerous rules that increase the cost of production without increasing the value of the product or service regulated. Technology-based labor is much easier to relocate to a less expensive and less restrictive job market.Technology has reduced not only the overall cost of production of most goods, but also the logistics cost associated with bringing those products to market.Yes, there is still a major international market for U.S.-produced goods, but there is also good reason to restore a more appropriate balance of "free trade" based on terms that are at least equally favorable to the U.S.Jack HamiltonSilverdale, Wash.---What is missing is an accounting of the number of foreign companies that are building factories and setting up businesses here in America. We should be encouraging more foreign companies to come here.Tom HatfieldHilton Head Is., S.C.

article name: Economy Buffets Presidential Election; Mixed economic signals complicate sharply different views of Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump
article text: The U.S. economy is flashing mixed signals heading toward November's election, complicating the narrative for both presidential campaigns in a race featuring sharply different views of the vitality of the seven-year expansion.Historically, elections often hinge on popular perceptions of the economy's health, particularly those that solidify in the early summer of an election year. That puts a premium on economic gauges in June and July, be it on overall output, the pace of hiring or measures of consumer sentiment.New figures out Friday showed U.S. gross domestic product, a broad measure of output, averaged a paltry 1% seasonally adjusted annual growth rate through the year's first half, well below historical norms. That has raised fears the economy is slowing heading into the election, with some economists warning of a possible recession by year end.That would add a new headwind for Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton as she tries to fend off Republican contender Donald Trump, since her campaign in part is based on praising the success fellow Democrat President Barack Obama has had in rejuvenating the economy since 2009. Research shows voters can take a dimmer view of incumbent parties when the economy is underperforming.At the same time, other important measures, related to jobs, wages, consumer spending and consumer confidence, suggest a degree of resilience for the seven-year expansion, undercutting Mr. Trump's portrayal of an economy in dismal shape.Economic ups and downs almost always play into presidential campaigns, as they did in 2012, when steady hiring aided Mr. Obama.In the past three elections comparable to this one, in which a two-term president was stepping down--1988, 2000 and 2008--the state of the economy played a key role, but in highly unpredictable ways.In 1988, George H.W. Bush won his first term, and the Republican Party's third consecutive term, in the White House. The economy, in the fifth year of a robust expansion, certainly helped.GDP, for example, advanced at a 3.9% pace during the first half of that year, faster than the post-World War II average of about 3.2%.The labor market also was expanding at a solid clip. Nonfarm payrolls grew by more than 3.4 million from mid-1987 to mid-1988.By mid-1988, consumer spending had climbed 8% from a year earlier. (Currently it is up less than 4%.) The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index showed confidence on the rise.In 2000, a vibrant economy failed to propel Al Gore into the White House, which would have been a third straight term for Democrats.At the midpoint of 2000, GDP was averaging a 4.5% growth rate, the labor market had added close to three million jobs over the previous year, consumer spending was up 7.7% and consumer sentiment was coming off a record high.Republican George W. Bush won the contested election by a whisker after a Supreme Court case over Florida vote counting was decided in his favor.In mid-2008, the housing market was collapsing, Lehman Brothers was on the brink of bankruptcy and the economy was months into a deep, protracted recession. GDP contracted and the labor market was shedding jobs. While consumers continued to spend, confidence was in free fall. Mr. Obama defeated Sen. John McCain (R., Ariz.).How does the economy look now?The biggest mark against the economy is found in the broadest measure of growth. GDP is up a meager 1% through the first half of the year, dragged down by a pullback in investment by companies, a drawdown in business inventories and slower government spending.The labor market has been performing well, though not as well as the 1988 and 2000 cycles. Nonfarm payrolls are up by about 2.5 million over the past year, while the unemployment rate in June was 4.9%, compared with 5.4% in 1988, 4% in 2000 and 5.6% in 2008.Consumers are offering a key support for the economy, with their spending up 3.7% from a year earlier. Consumer confidence is roughly in line with 1988 but well short of 2000 levels."The economy in terms of the growth rate of GDP is clearly not a plus for the Democrats in 2016," said Ray Fair, a Yale University professor who has written extensively on the economy's impact on elections. Tepid output combined with the electorate's tendency to vote out a two-term incumbent party are working against Mrs. Clinton, he said.Based on his model, which isn't always right but did forecast a Bush victory in 1988, an Obama victory in 2008 and an election too close to call in 2000, Mrs. Clinton is poised to capture only about 45% of the vote come November.Still, Mr. Fair said, 2016 is an unusual election and Mr. Trump an atypical candidate for the Republican Party.Write to Jeffrey Sparshott at jeffrey.sparshott@wsj.comCredit: By Jeffrey Sparshott

article name: Election 2016: Trump Is Slow to Organize in Key State --- Presumptive nominee lags behind Clinton in building team in Ohio; Kasich still on sideline
article text: PLAIN TOWNSHIP, Ohio -- Though Donald Trump dispensed with his last primary opponent months before Hillary Clinton will, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee trails far behind the leading Democrat in organizing in a key general-election state.Ohio, which has backed every presidential winner since 1964, presents both Mr. Trump's best opportunity to carry a big swing state and reveals his team's steep logistical challenges.Mr. Trump doesn't have any general-election staff in Ohio, and senior aides in New York and Washington haven't made contact with the state Republican Party. Efforts to recruit the state's experienced operatives who helped elect Gov. John Kasich have so far been unsuccessful, people familiar with the matter said.Mrs. Clinton has a small team of full-time aides in Ohio, where they are working to rebuild the organization that twice carried the state for President Barack Obama."It's like we're all at ground zero," said Ed Rollins, who is co-chairman of the pro-Trump super PAC called the Great America PAC. "I think we have a superior candidate. It's a question of whether you can build the resources."Mr. Trump's slow start, here and elsewhere, could undermine his goal of expanding the Republican presidential map into the industrial Midwest.Ohio's electorate is tailor-made for Mr. Trump's populist message on immigration and trade. Among states that were competitive in the 2012 general election, only New Hampshire has a smaller percentage of Hispanics -- who overwhelmingly disapprove of Mr. Trump -- than Ohio's 3.5%.Restricting foreign trade, one of Mr. Trump's signature issues, is a particularly potent issue in the manufacturing-heavy state and has emerged as a centerpiece of Democrat Ted Strickland's campaign to oust GOP Sen. Rob Portman.And this year's March primary, which Mr. Trump lost to Mr. Kasich, added 363,000 more Republican voters to the state's voter rolls than Democrats, according to Ohio Secretary of State Jon Husted.Mr. Trump's troubles recruiting Ohio staff come as the latest Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll shows broad sections of Republicans are coalescing behind the New York developer, helping him narrow the gap with Mrs. Clinton to 3 percentage points.In the past week, Mr. Trump's political director Rick Wiley began his search for top Ohio staff, which he hopes to have in place by June.One of Mr. Wiley's first Ohio calls went to Jeff Polesovsky, the political director for Mr. Kasich's presidential campaign and a senior aide during his two runs for governor. Mr. Polesovsky told Mr. Wiley that he isn't ready to join the Trump campaign, according to people familiar with the conversation. Mr. Kasich has declined to endorse Mr. Trump.The governor hasn't put out a formal notice to his aides to avoid working for Mr. Trump, but several of them interviewed said they wouldn't take a job with him without first discussing it with Mr. Kasich."There's no one in a senior- or midlevel position in the campaign in Ohio or in any of the states where we had staff who would or will be going to work for Donald Trump," said John Weaver, Mr. Kasich's senior strategist during his presidential campaign. "The very things that attracted them to John are the things that would keep them from working for Trump. Plus, they would be shot."Meanwhile, Clinton aides are preparing to open the first campaign office in Columbus and have begun coordinating with the Ohio Democratic Party to recruit an army of volunteers who backed both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders in the state's primary.At the same time, Priorities USA, the super PAC backing Mrs. Clinton, last week began airing the first $6 million of TV advertising attacking Mr. Trump in Ohio, Virginia, Nevada and Florida. The super PACs backing Mr. Trump are still trying to raise money while his campaign is only now building a national fundraising apparatus.Mr. Wiley said the Trump campaign has "made tremendous strides" building its general election team since becoming the presumptive nominee.Yet senior Trump aides have had no communication with the Ohio Republican Party and very little with aides to Mr. Portman, who has built his own statewide get-out-the-vote apparatus as he prepares for a difficult re-election bid. The Ohio GOP chairman, Matt Borges, who emerged during the primary campaign as one of the nation's most strident anti-Trump voices, said he hasn't done anything to help Mr. Trump because he hasn't heard what the campaign would like him to do.Mrs. Clinton's team here is led by Chris Wyant, a veteran of Mr. Obama's two Ohio campaigns. Last week, Mr. Wyant and another Clinton aide watched as 30 local Democratic Party activists made calls to recruit volunteers.About half of the activists interviewed said they backed Mr. Sanders during Ohio's primary, but each believed they must work to elect Mrs. Clinton."The difference between any Democrat and Trump is so spectacular that I had to come help," said Tony Collins-Sibley, a 54-year-old cabinet maker who wore a "Bernie 2016" T-shirt.Credit: By Reid J. Epstein

article name: Trump Narrows Gap With Clinton
article text: Republicans have rallied behind Donald Trump in the weeks since he effectively clinched his party's presidential nomination, helping him narrow Democrat Hillary Clinton's once double-digit lead to just 3 percentage points, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll shows.Mrs. Clinton leads the New York businessman, 46% to 43%, in a test matchup between the two likely nominees, the poll finds. That represents a much tighter margin than her 11-percentage-point lead in April and marks the first time in Journal/NBC News polling this year that her support has dropped below 50% in a contest with Mr. Trump.Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who faces long odds of wresting the Democratic nomination from Mrs. Clinton, leads Mr. Trump by a much wider, 15-point margin, 54% to 39%, in a hypothetical matchup.The main reason Mr. Trump has eaten into Mrs. Clinton's lead is he enjoys much wider support from GOP voters after his decisive win in the Indiana primary earlier this month, a victory that prompted his two remaining rivals to exit the race. The presumptive GOP nominee has also opened a modest lead among self-described independent voters.In the matchup against Mrs. Clinton, Republican support for Mr. Trump jumped to 86% from 72% in mid-April, while the share of GOP voters who said they would support Mrs. Clinton fell to 6% from 13% a month earlier. Democrats' support for Mrs. Clinton, meanwhile, remains largely unchanged.The poll shows the race at this early point is virtually a statistical dead heat. That is in keeping with other polling done since Mr. Trump vanquished his remaining Republican primary foes.To some extent the polling reflects for Mr. Trump the boost that naturally comes when a candidate prevails in a primary race and stops coming under direct attack by his primary rivals, a luxury Mrs. Clinton doesn't have and may not until her party's July convention. Still, the results, though early, are troubling for the Democratic team because they may suggest how much damage the bruising primary fight has done to her, which could linger after the battle ends."Republican voters are consolidating behind Trump. And a more united Republican Party, combined with an electorate looking for major change, has made this a too-close-to-call campaign," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who conducts the Journal/NBC News survey with Democrat Fred Yang.The two likely nominees still suffer from the worst public images in the modern history of presidential politics, with 58% viewing Mr. Trump negatively and 54% expressing similar sentiments about Mrs. Clinton. But that tally marks an improvement for Mr. Trump since April, when some 65% of voters expressed an unfavorable opinion about him."Either one is a terrible choice," said Steve Swanstrom, 78, a Republican in Fort Myers, Fla., who favored Texas Sen. Ted Cruz in the primary and isn't sure what he will do in November.A more favorable view of Mr. Trump among Republicans is primarily responsible for his improved image. In April, GOP voters split 42% to 42% between those who viewed him favorably and those who saw him in a negative light. This month, after Mr. Trump essentially sealed the nomination, the split was 58% positive to 25% negative.Mr. Trump also enjoys a slightly better -- if still overwhelmingly negative -- image among independent voters, with 58% viewing him negatively and 26% viewing him positively. Independents now see him slightly more positively than they do Mrs. Clinton, helping the Republican open a 5-percentage-point lead over the likely Democratic nominee among these voters."Again, Donald Trump defies the conventional wisdom by consolidating the GOP support early, but a much steeper hill lies ahead with independents and persuadable voters," said Peter Hart, a Democrat who is part of the Journal/NBC News polling team.Perhaps the best news in the survey for Mr. Trump is that he outpaces Mrs. Clinton, 46% to 43%, in the 12 most competitive presidential battleground states -- states that President Barack Obama won by 1.5 percentage points in 2012. He does particularly well in the South and Midwest.But national polls such as this don't fully capture the two candidates' standing in these 12 states because they aggregate the numbers, which can vary dramatically from one state to the next.The share of Democratic primary voters who view Mrs. Clinton favorably dropped from 84% last June to 65% in the latest poll, while the share who view her negatively jumped from 7% to 21%.A chief task for any nominee is to unify his or her party ahead of the general election. In the new survey, some 83% of Democrats said they prefer Mrs. Clinton over Mr. Trump, down slightly from 87% in April.A remarkable 1-in-10 voters say they wouldn't vote for either Mrs. Clinton or Mr. Trump, and 47% say they would consider an independent or third-party candidate in the fall, up from 40% in the spring of 2012.Mr. Yang, the Democratic pollster, said that "despite a rough couple weeks and the prospect of a tough campaign ahead, the fundamentals look favorable for Hillary Clinton. Her advantage in the trial heat against Trump for the most part mirrors the Obama '12 numbers among key constituencies; in fact, Trump is doing slightly less well among white voters overall than Romney did four years ago."The survey of 1,000 registered voters was conducted May 15-19 and has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.Credit: By Patrick O'Connor

article name: Trump Is Closing Deal With Republican Elite
article text: WASHINGTON -- Republican leaders and donors, who for months took a frosty, hands-off view of Donald Trump, this week significantly warmed to the New York real-estate mogul as the fractured party began closing ranks behind its presumptive presidential nominee.Beginning with his visit with GOP congressional leaders on Capitol Hill late last week, Mr. Trump has made steady inroads with the party's elite as prominent skeptics have dropped or buried their objections in deference to their shared quest to defeat likely Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in November."You're better off riding the beast than trying to ignore it," said Stewart Verdery, the founder of lobbying and public-affairs firm Monument Policy Group and a former Senate Republican aide.In one pivotal moment this week, social conservatives and tea-party members said that Mr. Trump's release of 11 possible candidates to fill the Supreme Court vacancy assuaged one of their biggest concerns about the businessman -- that he isn't a true conservative and abortion foe."The list of the judges was a very good step in the right direction. We're making progress," House Speaker Paul Ryan (R., Wis.) told reporters.Mr. Ryan, who jolted the party by saying earlier this month that he wasn't ready to endorse Mr. Trump, still hasn't backed the candidate, some of whose stances clash with his own limited-government philosophy. But Mr. Ryan said his policy aides were now meeting regularly with Mr. Trump's staff to "make sure that we are unifying around our commonly held principles and policies."Significant pockets of resistance to Mr. Trump still remain within the party. Many lawmakers are mum about his candidacy and some say they won't attend the party convention in July. A few leaders who have qualms over his style, rhetoric and contentious policy stances -- including a hard line on immigration and an expansive view of presidential power -- continue a quiet effort to field an alternate independent or third-party candidate.Many high-ranking Republicans said they were caught off-guard by the speed with which Mr. Trump became the presumptive GOP nominee after his decisive May 3 Indiana primary victory prompted his rivals to end their campaigns. With a contested GOP convention no longer looming in Cleveland in late July, the ranks of holdouts to Mr. Trump's polarizing brand of politics have started to shrink.The GOP's growing acceptance of Mr. Trump coincides with a raucous week in the Democratic primary. Although she holds a commanding lead in delegates, Mrs. Clinton still faces attacks from her rival, Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who continues to win some primary contests, including in Oregon this week.But Democrats projected confidence that Mr. Trump's plans to deport all illegal immigrants and ban Muslims from entering the U.S., as well as critical comments about women, would incite a revolt against him in November."Donald Trump is going to unite the Democratic Party in a way we haven't seen in a generation," Sen. Ed Markey (D., Mass.) said this week. "The choice is going to be stark."Mrs. Clinton's campaign has targeted foreign policy as a weakness of Mr. Trump, who has questioned the value of long-held international alliances and praised contentious foreign leaders, including Russian President Vladimir Putin.Meanwhile, Mr. Trump notched an important organizational victory this week, finalizing a joint fundraising agreement with the Republican National Committee that will allow donors to write checks of up to $449,400. Heading the Trump Victory committee as finance chairman will be Lew Eisenberg, a veteran fundraiser who also serves as finance chairman of the RNC.Since declaring earlier this month that he didn't plan to self-fund his general-election campaign, Mr. Trump has drawn some of his party's traditional top donors, though others are staying on the sidelines. Oil billionaire T. Boone Pickens endorsed his campaign last week and is planning to hold a fundraiser for the pro-Trump super PAC, Great America PAC, at his Texas ranch next month.Minnesota broadcasting billionaire Stanley Hubbard, who backed the presidential bids of mainstream party favorites, including Sen. Marco Rubio and former Gov. Jeb Bush, has also endorsed Mr. Trump and signed on to the super PAC as a co-chairman.On Capitol Hill, attendance is growing at a weekly meeting of Mr. Trump's House GOP supporters and his campaign advisers. Even some vulnerable Republicans, who have refrained from endorsing Mr. Trump, have praised some of his recent actions.GOP Sen. Pat Toomey, locked in a tight re-election fight against former state official Katie McGinty in Democratic-leaning Pennsylvania, has so far not backed Mr. Trump. But on Friday, he told a talk-radio host Mr. Trump had released a "very good list" of potential successors for Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, who died in February.Mr. Trump patted himself on the back on Friday for the list's impact in wooing conservatives."The effect it's had is incredible," he said at a forum hosted by the political arm of the National Rifle Association.---Rebecca Ballhaus contributed to this article.Credit: By Kristina Peterson and Siobhan Hughes

article name: Trump for Blow-Upper in Chief?
article text: Correction: The Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids tells me that, while it has received donations from lawyers involved in the 1998 tobacco litigation, it has an "explicit policy" of not taking settlement funds.Washington can't protect workers against technological and competitive obsolescence. It can't excuse Americans from adapting to an economy and updating their skills.Instead, America's salvation has been a dynamic that, over time, creates more good jobs than it destroys. As much as anything, damage to this dynamic explains this election year. It explains the coalition forming around Donald Trump, consisting of people who believe what Mr. Trump says (fans of building a wall and starting a trade war) and those who don't (hedge funds).Leading the latter contingent is fund manager Anthony Scaramucci, once a ferocious denouncer of Mr. Trump, who now says The Donald has merely been "tweaking [the establishment] by saying this nonsense, to the great enjoyment of the middle and lower class." Thus does Mr. Trump prove the glory of the two-party system, the powerful, centralizing ballast of American national greatness, which forces incompatibles to get in bed with each other.A Journal story that probably didn't get the notice it deserved tells of the troubles of a small-business owner in Italy.The Italian economy hasn't grown in 10 years. Consumers aren't spending. A lack of bank lending for small business makes it impossible for restaurant owner Massimiliano Masuelli to invest in modern technology. He can't lay off workers because labor regulation makes it too expensive. Politicians, rather than helping, add to his overhead with new health and safety mandates.In Italy, dying small businesses, with 10 or fewer workers, employ 46% of the workforce.Readers may tire of antiregulation screeds but nobody persists in a project if government keeps raising obstacles to it. In the U.S., the administration has now embraced a $15 minimum wage, a favorite of big labor as a way to ward off competition from lower-downs. Its new overtime rule for salaried workers will arbitrarily raise costs for thousands of employers while imposing record-keeping duties on thousands more.The administration's Consumer Financial Protection Bureau wants to kill payday lenders because they charge high annual percentage rates. But lenders compete, prices reflect costs, and the administration offers no solution (except to go on disability) for a worker who needs $800 fast so he can fix his car, so he can keep his job, so he can pay his rent.The Obama Federal Communications Commission has been a real beauty. Through a succession of rules, orders and merger approvals, it has favored big broadband providers over small ones, rich urban communities over broadband-deprived rural areas and small towns, and consistently pressured broadband companies to keep broadband prices high for grannies and other light users in order to subsidize fixed rates and superfluous gigabit speeds for the avidly tweeting cyber elite.Why?Then the President's Council of Economic Advisers complains about a growing concentration in banking, airlines and telecommunications without noticing how the administration's own regulatory onslaught has made these industries unwelcoming to small companies lacking the requisite armies of lawyers and lobbyists.People can debate in every case where the public interest lies. Indeed, because such arguments are always possible, no area of life or decision-making is free of calls for federal intervention. But in the frantic rule-making of the late Obama administration, including its attempt to dictate state and local bathroom regulation, thoughtful consideration of the public good is absent. The administration is manufacturing talking points and wedge issues for the election, in the process creating costs for the American people that will long outlast the election. Why? Because Democrats must win, that's why.So, a former FCC staffer writes that his ex-agency is "now in the near-exclusive business of shifting profits among corporate giants."The Competitive Enterprise Institute finds that, last year, Congress passed a mere 114 laws and federal agencies issued a whopping 3,410 regulations. At 80,260 pages, last year's Federal Register was the third fattest in history.A Kauffman Foundation study cites a proliferation of "incumbent protection" rules as a reason for a decline in small-business entrepreneurship. A Brookings Institution study shows, in an unheralded change in American life, business closures exceeded business starts during much of President Obama's tenure.How many times have voters been heard saying they want Mr. Trump in Washington to "blow the place up"? Where they get their confidence that from the smoking wreckage something useful would sprout, only heaven knows. But it is not an irrational bet when you know the alternative.Credit: By Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.

article name: REVIEW --- Word on the Street: 'Goofy' as Trump's Latest Taunt
article text: Donald Trump's litany of disparaging nicknames for his political opponents shows no sign of abating, with Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren his latest target.At a campaign rally in Eugene, Ore., on May 6, Mr. Trump taunted Ms. Warren in a salvo against Hillary Clinton. "I just learned that Crooked Hillary, along with her friend -- you know, she's got this goofy friend named Elizabeth Warren, she's on a Twitter rant. She's a goofus."Sen. Warren swiftly responded on Twitter: "'Goofy,' @realDonaldTrump? For a guy with 'the best words' that's a pretty lame nickname. Weak!"University of Delaware English professor Ben Yagoda recently noted in a Chronicle of Higher Education blog post that Mr. Trump's penchant for nicknaming (his Twitter repertoire now includes "Goofy Elizabeth Warren" and "Crazy Bernie Sanders") could be seen as a "single-handed revival of the Homeric epithet." But Homer's epithets were descriptive rather than derogatory, and most were reserved for gods and heroes -- such as "swift-footed Achilles" or "gray-eyed Athena."Both "goofy" and "goofus" go back to "goof," originally a word for a simpleton or clumsy fool, with a possible root in the Middle French "goffe," meaning "awkward" or "stupid." In the early 20th century, "goof" became a popular put-down in American slang. Ring Lardner, for instance, has a character in his 1916 story "Gullible's Travels" say, "It ain't the same show, you goof!"The adjective "goofy," meaning silly or stupid, took off among U.S. soldiers in World War I. A 1918 article in the Idaho Daily Statesman listed the word among the slang used by young men training at Camp Lewis in Tacoma, Wash.: "The recruit of enfeebled intellect is no longer 'nutty' or a 'feeb'; he is 'goofy.'" A decade and a half later, Walt Disney's animated shorts would introduce the simple-minded anthropomorphic dog, Goofy.Around the same time, "goofus" emerged as a comical name for someone foolish. In 1916, the syndicated humor columnist Arthur "Bugs" Baer started using "Goofus" to label various silly characters, and that same year, a story in the magazine Our Navy featured a ship with a "pet hippopotamus mascot" named Goofus."Goofus" was also the title of a novelty hit for bandleader Wayne King in 1930. Gus Kahn's lyrics tell of a self-taught saxophone player from Iowa: "I'd start to play, folks used to say, sounds a little goofus to me."In the late 1940s, "goofus" got another boost of attention thanks to the children's magazine Highlights and its cartoon feature "Goofus & Gallant." In each installment, the behavior of a polite and respectful boy named Gallant was contrasted with his immature friend Goofus.Likely influenced by "goofus," the epithet "doofus" first showed up in the 1950s. John Lardner (a son of Ring) used it in a 1955 New York Times story to label a dimwitted boxer: "Doofus lost every round from the third . . . !"It remains to be seen if Mr. Trump will use "doofus" in his next round of name-calling.Credit: By Ben Zimmer

article name: Election 2016: Trump Slams Clinton, Wins NRA Backing
article text: LOUISVILLE, K.Y. -- Donald Trump delivered one of his sharpest attacks to date against Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton, telling thousands of gun enthusiasts Friday she would "abolish" the Second Amendment and pack the Supreme Court with antigun justices.The presumptive Republican presidential nominee received a rousing reception at a forum hosted by the political arm of the National Rifle Association and won the group's endorsement, taking another step toward being accepted as the GOP standard-bearer."Hillary wants to disarm vulnerable Americans in high-crime neighborhoods," he said. "I am going to put criminals behind bars and guarantee that law-abiding Americans have the right to self-defense."Mrs. Clinton has put gun control at the center of her campaign and has been traveling with mothers of children who died from gun violence and at the hands of law enforcement. She will speak Saturday at a Miami dinner sponsored by the Trayvon Martin Foundation, a gun-control group honoring the Florida teenager slain by neighborhood-watch volunteer George Zimmerman.Mr. Trump wasn't the top choice of some at the NRA event, in part because he backed an assault-weapons ban and a longer waiting period for gun sales in a 2000 book. But if the general election pits him against Mrs. Clinton, who has vowed to "change the gun culture" and "take on the gun lobby," firearm owners say their choice will be an easy one.NRA leaders at the annual forum cast the election more as a referendum on Mrs. Clinton than as an opportunity to support Mr. Trump. If she is elected, "you can kiss your guns goodbye," NRA Chief Executive Wayne LaPierre told the crowd."If your preferred candidate dropped out of the race, it's time to get over it," said Chris Cox, executive director of the NRA's Institute of Legislative Action, who announced the endorsement of Mr. Trump. The current vacancy on the Supreme Court means "the Second Amendment is on the ballot," he added.Mrs. Clinton signaled last week that she was ready to debate Mr. Trump on guns, posting on Twitter: "FACT: Donald Trump would force schools to allow guns in classrooms on his first day in the office."Mr. Trump floated a proposal earlier this year to do away with gun-free school zones. "I will get rid of gun-free zones on schools," Mr. Trump said in Vermont in January. "My first day, it gets signed, OK?"Mr. Trump would need Congress to repeal a 1990 federal law signed by former Republican President George H.W. Bush that forbids most firearms near school grounds.The candidate's previous support for an assault-weapons ban isn't the only issue some NRA members have with Mr. Trump, who switched in and out of the Republican Party before rejoining in 2012. He has challenged party orthodoxy on free trade, taxes and foreign policy, and once supported abortion rights."I'm holding my nose," said Marshall Mac Euen, a 62-year-old lighting salesman from Birmingham, Ala. "He's not a Republican. He's not a conservative. I just don't trust him."He and other gun owners wary of Mr. Trump, however, say they would rather see just about anybody in the White House than Mrs. Clinton."We will not vote for Hillary Clinton. We will not vote for Hillary Clinton," said 65-year-old Dan Bridges of Washington, D.C., who attended the conference with two fellow U.S. Naval Academy graduates.Credit: By Beth Reinhard

article name: Notable & Quotable: McCain on Trump; 'I'd like to say to Mr. and Mrs. Khan: thank you for immigrating to America.'
article text: From Sen. John McCain's statement Monday on Donald Trump's comments about Khizr and Ghazala Khan, the parents of a Muslim U.S. Army captain killed in Iraq:I claim no moral superiority over Donald Trump. I have a long and well-known public and private record for which I will have to answer at the Final Judgment, and I repose my hope in the promise of mercy and the moderation of age. I challenge the nominee to set the example for what our country can and should represent.Arizona is watching. It is time for Donald Trump to set the example for our country and the future of the Republican Party. While our Party has bestowed upon him the nomination, it is not accompanied by unfettered license to defame those who are the best among us.Lastly, I'd like to say to Mr. and Mrs. Khan: thank you for immigrating to America. We're a better country because of you. And you are certainly right; your son was the best of America, and the memory of his sacrifice will make us a better nation--and he will never be forgotten.

article name: Trump, Trade, Technology and American Jobs; Before Nafta, U.S. pork producers had virtually zero market in Mexico.
article text: Regarding Mary Anastasia O'Grady's "Wharton Grad Trump Fails Economics " (Americas, July 25): I farm in Iowa and provide consulting services to agribusiness companies at home and abroad. I recall that most basic of Economics 101 lessons about "the gains from trade." It amazes, shocks and disappoints me (and many of us in agriculture in the Midwest who depend on exports) that so many of our politicians are ready to "tear up trade agreements" and erect trade barriers. Have any of these people, including Donald Trump, ever heard of the Great Depression?For the pork industry, Nafta and the Mexican market demonstrate a classic case in point. Before Nafta, U.S. pork producers had virtually zero market in Mexico. Today, the U.S. pork industry exports about one quarter of its production, around $6 billion a year, and thanks to Nafta Mexico is now our No. 1 market in volume and No. 2 market in value. The Trans-Pacific Partnership represents another exciting opportunity for U.S. agriculture to continue to grow exports of American food, feed and fiber.It's truly disheartening to hear the presidential candidates disavow the benefits of trade to the American economy. Ms. O'Grady's piece is spot-on by pointing out that it is technology that is putting people out of work, not trade agreements.Brian M. FosterHampton, IowaThe move of our company, California Cedar Products Co., to China had nothing to do with advances in technology. We are a manufacturer of slats for the subsequent manufacture of pencils. Our company (with about 1,500 employees including six sawmills) was the last slat factory to produce in the U.S. We were the last one here because we survived due to our advanced technology using very thin saws to increase the yield from wood. But the saving in wood wasn't enough to offset the cost of labor.China began selling finished pencils in the U.S. in the late 1980s at prices lower than our slats. We moved our factory to China, even after negotiating a 14.8% decrease in wages and benefits in 1998. After the move our labor costs in China decreased 90%. The problem was that by then the Chinese had taken a large share of our business.The Chinese were selling pencils below cost: therefore a tariff would have been the proper temporary solution. Perhaps the American consumer can buy pencils cheaper now that there are hardly any manufacturers left here but think of the economics and buying power of employing the 15,000 or so former U.S. pencil-making workers in our society. Luckily we're still in business, but we have only about five employees in the U.S.Before we moved we even contacted President Clinton and California Sen. Dianne Feinstein. The former completely ignored our petition and the latter canceled an appointment the day before she was supposed to attend a big factory meeting with our employees. So don't rely on the government to do anything except tax you to death.Philip C. BerolzheimerStockton, Calif.As one of the analysts crunching the numbers, I can absolutely assure Ms. O'Grady that the reason why the company I worked for moved over 7,500 manufacturing jobs from the U.S. to Mexico was 100% due to the ability Nafta afforded the company to take advantage of lower Mexican wages. The technology used in the U.S. plants was all shipped to the Mexican ones.Frank ViolaJenkintown, Pa.Technology has certainly made it easier for government regulators to grind out and enforce a never-ending stream of onerous rules that increase the cost of production without increasing the value of the product or service regulated.
