Compared with his campaign stump speeches, Mr. Trump cuts a different, more personable and personal profile in the small question-and-answer sessions that are a feature of closed-door meetings on Capitol Hill."He is down to earth; he is spontaneous," said Rep. Chris Collins (R., N.Y.), one of Mr. Trump's early congressional endorsers. "I think what will come of the meeting is a comfort level for those who have never met him."Mr. Trump faces a dubious crowd. Not only has Mr. McConnell complained that Mr. Trump doesn't know the issues, but House Speaker Paul Ryan (R., Wis.) criticized Mr. Trump only a day after endorsing him June 2.On Tuesday, Mr. Ryan that it had to "clean up" its use of social media after the candidate's Twitter account on Saturday posted, then later changed, an image of Hillary Clinton and piles of cash along with a interpreted by many as a Star of David, with the words "Most Corrupt Candidate Ever!""Look, anti-Semitic images, they've got no place in presidential campaigns. Candidates should know that," Mr. Ryan told Wisconsin radio show host Charlie Sykes. "I don't know what flunky put this up there, they obviously gotta fix that," he said.One vulnerable Senate Republican, Mark Kirk of Illinois, has taken back his endorsement of Mr. Trump. Another, Sen. Mike Lee (R., Utah), in an interview last week listed concern after concern about the candidate. Mr. Lee isn't sure whether he will endorse Mr. Trump--or even attend the meeting.Sen. Ron Johnson (R., Wis.), who once suggested to CNN that he would campaign with Mr. Trump, joking that it would be "the Ronald and the Donald," said last week the remarks were taken out of context."I am not commenting on Donald Trump," Sen. John McCain (R., Ariz.) said last week, sticking to a line he has used regularly for weeks when asked by reporters.Mr. Trump's past remarks still sting on Capitol Hill, where many lawmakers fiercely protect the institution. It has also been personal. Mr. Trump said last year that Mr. McCain wasn't a war hero and this year suggested that Sen. Ted Cruz's father was involved in the assassination of former President John F. Kennedy.The likely Republican nominee told ABC in May that it would be better if the party were unified--although it didn't have to be--then said last week that the Republicans who challenged him in the primary but won't endorse him should "never be allowed to run for public office again."Though Mr. Trump met with congressional leaders in May, this week will be the first time his meetings will include rank-and-file GOP lawmakers. "Probably some people will give their opinions and ideas about how to run the campaign," Mr. McCarthy said.With the relationship between Mr. Trump and his nominal GOP allies still tenuous, some Republicans are working to put the two sides on the same policy ground before the convention. The most determined driver of a policy vision is Mr. Ryan, who has put forth House Republicans' six-part agenda, which includes replacing the Affordable Care Act, one of the few areas on which Mr. Trump and congressional Republicans have clear agreement.Mr. McCarthy, who will be attending the GOP convention as a California delegate, said Tuesday he expected the agenda would be the prime topic of Mr. Trump's Thursday visit.Still, more than a few Republicans are steering clear of the convention entirely, avoiding the need to clarify their common policy goals. The list includes Sens. Kelly Ayotte (R., N.H.), and Mr. Kirk, along with Mr. McCain and Rep. Trey Gowdy (R., S.C.)Besides Mr. Collins, possible bridge builders include Sen. Jeff Sessions (R., Ala.), who is Mr. Trump's most high-profile supporter in Congress, and Sen. Bob Corker (R., Tenn.), who met with Mr. Trump in New York in May and was scheduled to attend a rally in North Carolina with him Tuesday night, according to someone familiar with the event.Mr. Trump himself has begun taking the edge off of some of his positions. After last year calling for banning Muslims from entering the U.S., he has to calling for blocking immigrants from countries with terrorist links. Republicans in Congress were later reassured when Mr. Trump's chief policy adviser said that the likely nominee was "adamantly nonproliferation" after Mr. Trump had earlier suggested that the U.S. should with countries like Japan and South Korea and allow them to build their own nuclear arsenals.Some bridges may be impossible to build. Mr. Trump has hardened his opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the trade deal that many Senate Republicans have backed and that the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, a big supporter of Republicans, has embraced."We're going to agree to disagree on some things," Mr. Ryan told reporters last month. "What we do agree on is we don't want another Democrat in the White House."Write to Siobhan Hughes at siobhan.hughes@wsj.com and Kristina Peterson atCredit: By Siobhan Hughes and Kristina Peterson

article name: Trump Business Reach Stirs Conflict Questions --- Conflict-of-interest question would loom if the businessman were elected president
article text: NEW YORK--Back in his 26th-floor office after a recent campaign swing, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump sat down at his desk and began signing a two-inch stack of checks, including ones for $10,000 for fuel, $21,000 for concrete and $99,000 to a contractor at a hotel construction site.Mr. Trump personally oversees many of his routine business expenses this way. Yet he also says he would separate himself from that business empire, and the many potential conflicts of interest it might create, by putting his ownership into a blind trust, most likely with his adult children as its trustees, if he were elected president."I wouldn't mind a blind trust," he said in a recent interview. "I would be doing one thing. My total focus would be on making this country great again. I wouldn't even think about the company."As Mr. Trump heads into the general election, the conflicts-of-interest question is big and complex. That is because the Trump Organization, which is owned solely by him, consists mostly of operating assets, as opposed to passive investments. Hundreds of business entities, including some in foreign countries, own or manage hotels, commercial and residential real estate, golf resorts and even part of the reality TV show "The Apprentice.""Trump's empire would pose unprecedented conflicts of interest due to the size of its holdings, privately held nature of the family-run business, and concentration in one industry," said Richard Painter, University of Minnesota law professor who was the White House's chief ethics lawyer for President George W. Bush."A blind trust would never work in Trump's case, because his assets are known, not blind, and children aren't independent trustees," he added, noting that other modern-era wealthy presidents, such as Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy, were "old-money with diversified holdings" that didn't directly manage businesses the way Mr. Trump does.No federal law would require Mr. Trump, famous for putting his name on his swath of enterprises, to remove himself from running his empire, ethics experts say. But Mr. Trump, who has financed some of his real estate with debt and expanded his organization globally, would be closely scrutinized for any policy stance that would affect banking, real estate or the foreign countries where his properties sit.Mr. Trump dismisses those concerns, saying his business dealings wouldn't influence how he would approach the banking or real-estate sectors or foreign policy. He also said he would let other executives run the trust if his children would be considered too close to him to serve as trustees."I'll do whatever I have to do," the New York billionaire said in Trump Tower recently. "I'll do whatever makes people comfortable. It's very easy."Mr. Trump and a small coterie of executives and three of his adult children--Donald Jr., Ivanka and Eric--maintain a tight grip on all major assets, which . Even though Mr. Trump controls outgoing expenditures, he has transferred most of the day-to-day management of the empire's strategy and operations to those three children.But Mr. Trump seems unable to help himself from meddling in operations. When he recently stopped by the in Washington, D.C., which he is renovating into a luxury hotel, he inspected the finishes on wall moldings and queried the hotel manager on the size of a reception area. "Is it too late to change it now?" Mr. Trump asked.Yet, the , including the 100% owned-and-operated properties. Ivanka Trump oversaw the $350 million acquisition and renovation of Trump National Doral, the 800-acre Miami hotel and spa, while her brother Eric supervised improvements to indoor and outdoor public spaces throughout its golf resort.Donald Jr., who runs most of the company's commercial leasing, has pushed rents higher and occupancy to 97% at the commercial office building 40 Wall Street in a "re-set" with new leases on 750,000 square feet of the building, according to a Trump executive. By far, the most lucrative commercial lease in a Trump-owned property is the street-level Gucci store at Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue, which pays $18 million in annual rent, the executive said.The Trump empire also makes money on real estate it doesn't own. Trump International Hotel and Tower in Vancouver, set to open in August, is expected to provide a sizable annual revenue stream from management fees as the hotel operator and from licensing fees for real-estate sales of the condominiums.As Mr. Trump continued signing his stack of checks, which he occasionally does on his private jet when on the campaign trail, Mr. Trump added: "Signing checks is just one way...to know what's really going on...I sign my own checks as much as possible."The potential for conflicts abounds. In his campaign financial statement, Mr. Trump disclosed loans and personal guarantees ranging from $315 million to $500 million from a total of 10 creditors. "The loans are a tiny proportion of my net worth," he said.The Trump Organization now has five licensing deals for mixed-use luxury properties in India and other hotel, residential and development projects around the globe, Ivanka Trump said. Foreign interests provide revenue from management and licensing fees because Mr. Trump doesn't have ownership stakes, with the exception of Trump properties in the U.K., which are wholly owned, she said.Democrats have said Mr. Trump's conflicts of interest are already on display in his public comments. He handling a civil case against his now-defunct Trump University, based on the judge's ethnicity, and he cited an Internal Revenue Service audit of his taxes as a reason he won't release his tax returns. Last month, he commented on the U.K. vote to leave the European Union while in Scotland promoting a newly renovated golf resort.Significant conflicts of interest also arise over presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and her , ethics experts say. "Clinton's conflict also would be unprecedented with the scale and breadth of her family foundation, because it has been receiving substantial gifts from private parties, including some from outside the United States," said Mr. Painter, of the University of Minnesota. He suggests both candidates separate themselves and their family members from their organizations.Mrs. Clinton "stepped down from the foundation just prior to launching her campaign last year," a spokesman said. Former President Bill Clinton has said the foundation's work and structure would change if his wife were elected president.Mr. Trump dismissed the idea of the need for a complete undoing of his family business. "It's almost like there is no conflict," the businessman said. "The better I do as president, the better it is for my business--and everybody's business."Write to Monica Langley at monica.langley@wsj.comCredit: By Monica Langley

article name: An Explainer on the Tax Benefit Donald Trump May Have Used; Tax laws that allow net operating losses to be carried over to other tax years can be financially lucrative
article text: News that Donald Trump claimed a $916 million net operating loss on 1995 state tax returns has led to speculation that he could have wiped out his tax liabilities for more than 15 years. Net operating loss carry-overs are legal behavior and have long been a feature of the tax code. Here are some basics:Q. Where did the concept originate to allow certain losses to be carried over to other tax years?A. The Revenue Act of 1918 introduced the idea of allowing taxpayers to carry over net-operating losses, known as NOL, to other tax years, temporarily allowing for an NOL to be carried back one year and then forward one year. Today, carry-over periods reach 20 years; losses can be carried back two years.Q. What's the idea behind it?A. Allowing businesses to carry forward (and carry back) loss helps them better weather the economy's inevitable ups and downs, advocates argue. It lets businesses and their owners smooth out their incomes and tax bills over multiple years, giving them a better chance at long-term survival. Some economists argue that the carry-over also can help counteract economic downturns.Q. Who tends to use it the most?A. Cyclical businesses that can suffer heavy losses in downturns, such as consumer-goods makers. Owners of real-estate investment firms, with big interest and depreciation deductions, also can benefit. Other rules benefit real-estate investors such as Donald Trump, including the ability to use losses to offset other kinds of income.Q. Do taxpayers ever claim losses that didn't exist?A. Because the NOL carry-over is a potentially lucrative break, it has occasionally led people to concoct schemes aimed at generating big NOL's on paper that they then use to claim big refunds of prior-year taxes.Q. How controversial has this provision been in Congress?A. There has been debate, but the basic principle of business NOL carry-over has been embraced and expanded in recent years by both parties.Q. Is there any push now to take this away, or modify it?A. Progressives often criticize the NOL break as a giveaway to business, but there has been little serious effort in Congress to take it away. Some states have reduced the benefits of the NOL break, principally for budget reasons, and often state rules aren't as generous as the federal rules.Write to John D. McKinnon at john.mckinnon@wsj.comCredit: By John D. McKinnon

article name: Political Reporters' Hobgoblin; Trump and Clinton are inconsistent. So what? It's naive to expect otherwise.
article text: 'A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds." So wrote Ralph Waldo Emerson in his essay "Self-Reliance." Since Emerson himself was perhaps the least consistent of writers, often saying one thing in one place and its opposite in another, the remark bears the unmistakable stamp of self-justification. I haven't for a long while wandered through the journals, letters, sermons and other writing of this most overrated of American scribblers, but I shouldn't be in the least surprised to discover that somewhere Emerson also wrote that consistency is the hallmark of large minds.I have been thinking of that Emerson sentence a fair amount of late when watching television political reporters, anchors, commentators--Chuck Todd, Bret Baier, John Dickerson and others--interview politicians, their managers and so-called party strategists. Increasingly these interviews center on the search for inconsistencies (more precisely, contradictions). How do the politicians' current views compare with the views they held earlier in their careers? Or, in the case of our current presidential candidates, the views they held as recently as two or three days ago? By this ploy, television reporters attempt to demonstrate that politicians, like rubber sandals, flip-flop. But to what avail? The law of contradiction, after all, is not enforceable; if it were the jails would overflow.In the instances of Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, it is scarcely surprising that contradictions pop up with the regularity of fleas on a junkyard dog. Both are what I should call Kentucky-windage politicians: Without genuine beliefs, each always checks which way the wind--that is, voter sentiment--is blowing before firing away.It is naive to expect consistency from politicians, to say nothing of devotion to principles, and more than naive to think that catching their contradictions will slow them down in any significant way. With votes at stake, with polls changing almost hourly, it is only natural that politicians and their close supporters provide a nearly endless stream of pronunciamentos rife with contradictions.What does a reporter gain in confronting politicians with their inconsistencies? Pointing out to a politician that he claimed to be for this or that program in 2009 and now he claims to be against it is roughly as telling a criticism as informing a streetwalker that her hem is perhaps a touch too high. Do political commentators truly expect politicians, when confronted with evidence of their contradictions, to respond, "You're right. You know, I never thought of that."I've long held that the world's dumbest question, asked repeatedly by female reporters on the sidelines after sporting events, is "What was on your mind when . . . [fill in the event]?" A truthful answer is probably that the athlete knew once the game ended he would have to face the inanity of the question of what was on his mind and have an answer ready.Catching out a politician in a contradiction may be an even more empty exercise. Politicians never admit it. Instead, they waffle, they wobble, they claim to have been misunderstood, they bob and weave and artfully dodge the charge. Donald Trump and the dreary birther question is a case in point. Yes, the Trump camp avers, he may have doubted Barack Obama's birth. But they add that the lubricious Sidney Blumenthal started the rumor that the president wasn't born in this country when Mrs. Clinton ran against Mr. Obama in 2008.Even if politicians could be got to admit the contradictory nature of their current with their former views, would it really matter? Who knows: In their defense they might even cite the stale Emerson quotation.Rather than cite contradictions, which abound without ultimate significance, television reporters would be much more useful if they put politicians' and candidates' feet to the fire on views they currently claim to hold. They might ask Mr. Trump how, precisely, he plans to restore American military might and at what cost, or by what means he thinks he can defeat ISIS. He has been claiming for months now that he can easily do both without anyone pressing him on these matters.They might ask Mrs. Clinton, who is keen on aligning herself with the Black Lives Matter movement, for her thoughts on the vast number of black-on-black killings that now number in the tens of thousands in the black ghetto neighborhoods, and whether Black Lives Matter doesn't actually deflect attention from this much more serious problem.They might ask politicians who have served more than two terms in the Senate or six in the House how they happen to have become multimillionaires on their relatively modest political salaries. There is no want of good questions to ask politicians--none of which begin, "In 2011 you said . . ."Mr. Epstein's books include "Frozen in Time: Twenty Stories" and "Wind Sprints: Shorter Essays."Credit: By Joseph Epstein

article name: Election 2016: Trump and Pence Differ on Tone, Issues
article text: Republican Donald Trump ended weeks of speculation Friday by naming Indiana Gov. Mike Pence as his running mate, a choice meant to bolster the presumptive nominee with Midwestern voters and the party's conservative base.The selection was cheered by many of the same conservative leaders who haven't yet endorsed Mr. Trump, but it also spotlights some of the policy and stylistic stances that make the presumptive Republican nominee an outlier in the party he now leads.During the primary, Mr. Trump frequently criticized the war in Iraq; Mr. Pence voted to support it. Mr. Trump is a vocal critic of free trade; Mr. Pence is a strong proponent. Mr. Trump has panned Republican-led efforts to overhaul Medicare and Social Security; Mr. Pence has championed many of those efforts. And, of course, Mr. Pence endorsed Mr. Trump's top rival, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz.Temperamentally, the two Republicans are very different: Mr. Trump is a New York billionaire who regularly courts controversy, relishes name-calling and makes no secret of his mutable policy views, while Mr. Pence is a low-key Midwestern governor who presents himself as an always-upbeat conservative crusader with deeply held convictions, and whose net worth was less than $400,000 when he left the House.Messrs. Trump and Pence are hardly the first ticket to present a contrast of personalities or policy beliefs. Ronald Reagan picked George H.W. Bush in 1980 to shore up his support from the GOP's establishment wing, while a polished, young Barack Obama picked the older, plain-spoken Joe Biden in 2008 to give their ticket more experience.In many ways, picking Mr. Pence represents one of the few conventional decisions Mr. Trump has made in this campaign. The uncharacteristic choice and its rollout were amplified on Friday.Hours after Mr. Trump confirmed his pick in a Twitter post, campaign aides had to rebut multiple reports that Mr. Trump had second thoughts and even inquired about dumping the governor as his running mate."Totally false," Mr. Trump said in an interview on Friday afternoon."There's no way to predict chemistry," said Kevin Sheridan, a top aide to the last GOP vice-presidential nominee, Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan, during the 2012 campaign. "If it works, the rollout will be forgotten. If it doesn't, people will point to it as the first sign of a troubled marriage."Mr. Trump and his running mate both favor tax cuts as a way to spur the economy. Mr. Pence has consistently championed tax cuts since taking over as governor in 2013, leading efforts to lower Indiana's income tax and reduce others. The two Republicans also see eye-to-eye about increasing the defense budget, cracking down on illegal immigration and protecting gun rights.Their views align on most social issues, but Mr. Trump is a recent convert in opposing abortion and gay marriage. Mr. Pence has a much longer record of fighting to restrict both. He signed legislation making it easier for business owners to deny service to gay couples, before an outcry forced him to soften the law.Their biggest splits come on trade and foreign policy. Mr. Trump regularly bashes the 2003 U.S. invasion of Iraq. Mr. Pence was an early and consistent supporter of the war. Mr. Pence has also been critical of Russian President Vladimir Putin and called for the U.S. to strengthen the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mr. Trump has been a fierce critic of NATO and pledges to work more closely with Mr. Putin.Mr. Pence criticized Mr. Trump's proposed ban on Muslims entering the country, following the shooting rampage in San Bernardino, Calif., last year.Differences between the two men could serve them well with some of the conservative activists who are reluctant to back Mr. Trump. "Mike Pence would be an outstanding vice president," said David McIntosh, a former Indiana congressman and president of the Club for Growth, which spent millions trying to deny Mr. Trump the nomination.Democrats quickly sought to turn the pick against Mr. Trump, with Hillary Clinton's campaign dubbing the Indiana governor the "most extreme VP pick in a generation."---Damian Paletta contributed to this article.Credit: By Patrick O'Connor

article name: Christie Keeps Focus on Trump
article text: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie saw his last hope to run on the 2016 presidential ticket dashed Friday, but some state lawmakers and political observers said the governor's national ambitions will keep pulling his attention away from the Statehouse.Mr. Christie, who has 18 months left in office, has been accused of shirking responsibilities at home during the past year as he waged his unsuccessful bid for president and then campaigned for Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee.While Mr. Trump didn't choose Mr. Christie as his running mate, Mr. Christie is leading Mr. Trump's transition team, which is responsible for preparing the candidate for the possibility of the presidency. Mr. Christie is also expected to keep campaigning for Mr. Trump as the general election heats up.Aides to Mr. Christie didn't return requests for comment on Friday after Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter that he tapped Indiana Gov. Mike Pence to join him on the GOP ticket. On Thursday, Mr. Christie said in an interview with MSNBC that he would remain closely involved in Mr. Trump's campaign regardless of whether the governor appeared on the Nov. 8 ballot."He is a great friend and a person Mr. Trump has tremendous respect for," Mr. Trump's spokeswoman said in an email, referring to Mr. Christie.Assemblyman John Wisniewski, a Democrat from Middlesex County, said he expects the governor, who is prevented by law from seeking a third term, to make "auditioning for a cabinet post" in a possible Trump administration a priority over addressing state issues, such as New Jersey's depleted transportation trust fund.Mr. Wisniewski pointed to Mr. Christie's insistence on cutting the state sales tax in exchange for a gas-tax increase to fund transportation projects as evidence that the governor is seeking to burnish his national conservative credentials."His policy decisions in New Jersey are more about hewing to a certain political orthodoxy so he can be viable on a national stage," said Mr. Wisniewski, who believes Mr. Christie's proposed sales-tax cut would be too costly.Assemblyman Jon Bramnick, the chamber's GOP leader, said the governor's sales-tax proposal is about "giving money back to the taxpayers" and accused Democrats of blocking Mr. Christie's efforts to overhaul the state's school funding formula and reduce public-pension costs."It doesn't make any difference if Chris Christie is here, in Iowa or traveling the country with Donald Trump," Mr. Bramnick said. "Democrats who are controlling the Legislature won't make the necessary changes to make the state more affordable."Mr. Christie, who spent 261 partial or full days traveling outside of New Jersey in 2015, has sought to quell criticism about his out-of-state travel since ending his presidential bid in February.The governor held frequent news conferences this spring as he pushed for a state takeover of Atlantic City, personally negotiated still-pending legislation to renew the state's transportation trust fund and held several town-hall meetings to lobby for his proposed school funding overhaul.Still, the governor faces low job approval numbers, a looming federal trial involving former top allies accused in the George Washington Bridge lane-closure scandal and a Legislature that is already anticipating his departure.Ben Dworkin, director of the Rebovich Institute for New Jersey Politics at Rider University, said he believes the federal investigations, in particular, made Mr. Christie a less attractive option for vice presidentDavid Samson, a former appointee and longtime ally of Mr. Christie, pleaded guilty Thursday to a federal bribery charge. Two of the governor's former top aides are scheduled to go on trial in September in connection with the 2013 bridge scandal."It doesn't matter that the governor isn't on trial. It's going to be revelation after revelation of how the Christie administration did business," Mr. Dworkin said. "A six-week corruption trial involving top members of your administration puts a story that you don't want in the news in the heart of the final push for the election."Mr. Christie wasn't charged by federal authorities and has denied any wrongdoing.State Sen. Joe Kyrillos, a Republican, said simply being vetted for vice president was an accomplishment."Given the significant obstacles in his way, it's amazing that he got as far as he did and I'm happy for him," Mr. Kyrillos said. "It will be tricky to lead the transition preparation, be on the campaign trail and be the governor of a major state, which in the easiest of times is not a part-time job."Former New Jersey Gov. Tom Kean, a Republican, said he thinks Mr. Christie is "lucky" that he wasn't selected as Mr. Trump's running mate. Mr. Christie is better suited for another federal position, such as chief of staff or attorney general, Mr. Kean said.In the coming months in Trenton, Mr. Kean said, Mr. Christie may find willing negotiating partners among Democrats to deal with some thorny issues."Some of the Democrats he's been negotiating with think of themselves as future governors," he said, "so it's very much in their interest to get these issues off the table before they're in office."Credit: By Kate King

article name: The GOP's Trump Power Play
article text: Every poll shows that Donald Trump needs to shore up his support among wary Republicans if he wants to win in November. He and his allies at the Republican National Committee didn't help their cause with their power play Thursday night to shut off any debate at next week's convention in Cleveland.The RNC put the hammer down in a late-night session of the 112-member rules committee, which pounded through a rule requiring delegates to vote based on their state primary and caucus results. Allies of party chief Reince Priebus even twisted arms to squelch support for a minority report supporting a "conscience clause" that would have let delegates vote as they please. The minority report needed 28 votes to get a floor hearing next week but failed on a voice vote.Mr. Priebus and Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort want an orderly convention that suggests the GOP is more united than it is. But the irony is that by imposing such iron discipline they demonstrated that groups like Delegates Unbound were right in claiming that delegates aren't automatically bound to candidates, and that only a tailor-made convention rule could force delegates to follow state results. RNC lawyers vigorously denied that claim, but that's precisely the kind of rule they passed Thursday.Dianna Orrock, a national committeewoman for Nevada, bragged on Facebook that the "strategy" was that "by our staying to complete our work late last night, rather than end at 6 pm and reconvene today, [we] wore down our opposition and didn't give them any opportunity to regroup." Mr. Manafort crowed on Twitter: "Anti-Trump people get crushed at Rules Committee." Ah, the glories of backroom democracy.The real test for Messrs. Priebus and Manafort comes in November, and that will require persuasion more than loyalty tests. The "anti-Trump" representatives that Mr. Manafort disparaged represent hundreds of delegates who are loyal to Ted Cruz and other candidates, and whose support Mr. Trump needs. These are the state-level ground troops who get out the vote.The dissenting delegates weren't likely to get close to denying Mr. Trump the nomination, especially with Mr. Trump's choice of Mike Pence as a running mate and his recent gains in the polls. But allowing a debate would have been good democratic drama that might have attracted more news coverage, and Mr. Trump would be that much stronger as a nominee for having prevailed after a debate. Dissenting delegates will still find ways to express themselves, perhaps in media interviews and no doubt in the reception for Mr. Cruz when he speaks.The GOP last felt obliged to impose such strict delegate-binding rules in 1976, when Gerald Ford was trying to avoid floor defections to Ronald Reagan. Ford, aided by a young delegate manager named Paul Manafort, controlled the floor. He lost the election.

article name: Clinton Foundation Amends Its Filing With New York; Move comes day after rival Donald Trump's charitable foundation was told to suspend fundraising in state
article text: Officials at the foundation of Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton said they filed information Tuesday with the New York attorney general's office that was missing from previous disclosures.The move comes a day after Republican rival Donald Trump's charitable foundation was told to suspend its fundraising in the state because it violated registration requirements.A Clinton Foundation spokesman said the charity has complied with New York law, but amended its annual charitable filing with the office of Eric Schneiderman, a Democrat, "out of an abundance of caution." The group said it would disclose more detailed financial data on its affiliates.A spokesman for Mr. Schneiderman said the foundation's filings for at least one year--in 2012--were incomplete. The attorney general's office didn't immediately release the new information provided by the foundation, and it wasn't clear whether it included additional audited information about the charity's foreign affiliates.The foundation's move comes as presidential contenders' philanthropic ventures have come under scrutiny.Mrs. Clinton's political rivals have questioned the Clinton Foundation's acceptance of foreign government donations, including some that came during Mrs. Clinton's tenure as secretary of state. Mrs. Clinton has denied any conflicts of interest and said she is proud of the foundation's work.Mr. Schneiderman's office said Monday it is demanding that Donald Trump's charitable foundation suspend fundraising activity in New York, issuing a cease-and-desist letter accusing Mr. Trump's family nonprofit of failing to register as a charity that raises money in the state.The foundation has 15 days from Sept. 30--the day the notice was dated--to correct its registration and file required paperwork.A spokeswoman for Mr. Trump said the candidate questioned the political motives of Mr. Schneiderman, who supports Mrs. Clinton, and said the foundation would comply with Mr. Schneiderman's broader investigation into the charity.The Clinton Foundation has offered to share more details with Mr. Schneiderman's bureau about contributions from foreign governments. But a spokesman for the foundation said it hasn't received a request to do so from Mr. Schneiderman's office.New York requires that charitable organizations annually disclose and itemize the dollar amounts of grants made by a "government agency."The attorney general and the Clinton Foundation said they are currently interpreting that rule to be limited to grants from domestic government sources.The foundation in recent years has disclosed to New York officials its foreign government grants as a lump sum. The Clinton Health Access Initiative, the foundation's largest project, also makes annual financial disclosures to the attorney general, but neither itemizes its foreign government grants nor specifies a summary total dollar figure, a practice scrutinized in a Scripps News report from September."CHAI also received foreign government contributions and can provide those in more details if needed," the group told the attorney general's office in a letter accompanying its most recent annual filing.Mr. Schneiderman's office says it has never demanded itemization of foreign government grants, but has said it is considering clarifying its requirements.Some foundations and charities have itemized foreign government grants in recent annual tax filings, including Family Care International, Action Against Hunger and the George W. Bush Foundation, which reported a $5 million grant from the Royal Family of Saudi Arabia in its 2013 filing.Write to James Grimaldi at James.Grimaldi@wsj.com and Jacob Gershman at jacob.gershman@wsj.comCredit: By James V. Grimaldi and Jacob Gershman

article name: The Apology of Donald J. Trump
article text: What follows is a draft of a speech Donald Trump is scheduled to deliver Tuesday, Oct. 4 in Prescott Valley, Ariz. We haven't confirmed its authenticity because, like the rest of the corrupt media, we're totally dishonest.Thank you, everybody, thank you. It's good to be back in Arizona. And you know we're going to win, right? The polls say we're going to win in Arizona, and we will.The polls also say we'd lose the general election if it were held today. But they're wrong. So wrong. You know how pollsters work? They guess who will show up to vote on election day, and then they poll these "likely voters."But let me tell you something. The pollsters have no clue. None. They don't have a clue who the electorate is, and they don't have a clue of what's going on in America. Believe me, folks, on election day they're going to find out.The other day, in Colombia -- I'm talking about the country in South America -- they held a vote. A referendum. President Santos staked his reputation on a, quote-unquote, peace deal with the terrorists of the FARC.Now the FARC, they're the worst people in the world. They've killed tens of thousands of people. They make their money through drug trafficking and kidnapping. They've been terrorizing Colombians for 50 years.Along comes Santos, and he makes this terrible deal that says to the FARC: We're not going to send you to jail. We're going to sentence your leaders to community service. We're even going to guarantee you seats in the Congress.And all the polls said the deal was going to win in a landslide. Obama and Kerry lined up behind it. Santos told Colombians they had no choice, that it was the only road to peace.Guess what? The polls were wrong. The Colombians knew a bad deal when they saw one. They weren't going to let killers get away with their crimes. The only deal they want with the FARC is the same deal Reagan got from Russia: We win, they lose.Folks, it was the same story with the Brexit vote in June. All the polls said the Brits wouldn't vote to leave the European Union. They did. All the experts said the sky would fall if the Brits voted to go. It didn't. These geniuses said that Britain was too small to be the master of its own destiny. The British people believe otherwise, and I'm with them!What happened in Britain, in Colombia, it's going to happen here. Because, like them, we're sick of it.We're sick of hearing ObamaCare is working when even the New York Timesadmits it's a total disaster. We're sick of hearing how great the economy is when it's floating on a big wave of cheap credit that benefits Wall Street at the expense of savers. We're sick of hearing how great the Iran deal is, then watching our sailors being humiliated while we secretly fork over pallets of cash.You know what we're also sick of? Liberal hypocrites.I'm not supposed to say the name I'm about to say. Well, two words: Alicia. Machado.Who is this Alicia Machado, other than a political prop for Hillary? She was a beauty queen for a business I helped run called "Miss Universe." The business of beauty queens is to be beautiful, just like it's the business of athletes to be fit. Duh! And when she gained some weight, I insisted she lose it. Did I call her "Miss Piggy"? Boo hoo. Get over it.For this I'm being treated very badly. Let me ask you something: Other than Lena Dunham, when was the last time Anna Wintour ran a fat person on the cover of Vogue? And when was the last time Hillary said no to one of Ms. Wintour's big fundraisers because of Vogue's "lookism"?So spare me the sensitivity lectures. Spare me the business lectures, too. Those tax returns someone stole and the New York Times published? The ones that showed I once lost nearly a billion dollars and used every legal trick in the book to stage a comeback?All of you here understand this is how business is done in America. Some years you make money. Some years you lose. You take advantage of every tax break you can because the government is trying to screw you every other way.That's the real world. It's only in the unreal world that Hillary lives in that you can make a fortune by being a failed secretary of state and then cash in on obscene speaking fees, or arrange for Bill to get an $18 million salary to be "honorary chancellor" at a for-profit college while the Obama administration destroys every other for-profit. That's called corruption, no matter whether it's legal or not.Folks, there's a giant wave coming. A tsunami of Americans who won't stand for being told we don't know what's good for us. Who refuse to be lectured by political grifters about how to make an honest buck. Who don't need our morals improved by Hillary Macbeth and Billy Caligula. And who refuse to accept that we have to make lousy deals, or make do with less, or that America can't ever be great again.To all the liberals and Never Trumpers who don't get why Hillary isn't ahead by 50 points -- I just explained it. To all of you, get ready for Nov. 8. It's going to be a beautiful thing. Believe me.---Write bstephens@wsj.com.Credit: By Bret Stephens

article name: Declarations: Trump and the Unknowable Moment
article text: Cleveland -- Two headlines on the week, and some speeches.Donald Trump effectively won the Republican primary in the first week of May, meaning the GOP has had 2 1/2 months to do what it has always done, even under duress, such as in 1964 and 1976: come together. They have not. From day one of the convention it was clear the GOP is a bitterly divided party and not even bothering to hide it.It failed to unite not because it had poor leadership or the nominee didn't know how to do it, though both are true. More killingly it failed to unite because it didn't want to. Everyone's in his corner. Donald Trump failed to change his style in a way that would have given cover to those who would have, with considerable relief, joined him. On the other hand, anti-Trump forces continued to look down on Mr. Trump's supporters and grant them nothing in terms of motivation, sincerity, insight.Most important, though no one in Cleveland was keen to talk about it, there is the split between the base and the top on such huge and fundamental issues as immigration, trade and entitlements. The base came to this convention, which was middle-class and dressed down. The wealthy and connected largely stayed away. You didn't see them swanning from reception to party to caucus. It spoke volumes. Now and then you remember that snobbery is an actual force in life.If each side hates the other and believes in different things, how do they come together again?Connected to that, the second headline, which has to do with the unknowability of the moment we're in. The shrewdest old political pro, the brightest young delegate, the owlish political journalist -- they didn't know exactly what they were witnessing. Was it the formal start of an epic political disaster? The birth of a new GOP more identified with the struggles of its base? Is 2016 a particular and contained event, or does it mark the beginning of some long-term realignment? As for Mr. Trump, is he a lightning storm that lit things up, caused some damage, will play itself out and pass? Or is he an earthquake that changed the actual shape of things, the literal lay of the land?Nobody involved here, nobody watching, knew. I've never quite seen such intellectual modesty among people who are usually quick in their eagerness to explain it all to you.There were a number of good speeches. Donald Trump Jr. was strong and persuasive on Tuesday night. The next morning, at a Wall Street Journal event, he made a better case for his father than his father has. He talked about the forgotten middle American and referred to himself, humorously, as "a Fifth Avenue redneck." When pressed on how a man as divisive as his father could unify the nation, he answered that one way to unify the country is to see that its people have jobs: "When people are doing well it's amazing how much unity you'll get from that." I had the distinct impression I was listening to a future political candidate.Mike Pence's speech was modest, simple and strong. He is going to be a powerful and effective figure in the coming campaign. A longtime staffer told me he was surprised how relaxed the governor was as he prepared. He'd seen him over the years be nervous about smaller, less important speeches. Mr. Pence, the staffer said, told him the reason was that he was completely at peace with his decision to run with Mr. Trump.Ted Cruz did himself damage. By the end of his tireless campaign for the nomination he was semi-endearing. Wednesday night he resurrected Snaky Ted. He spoke highly of freedom and went after President Obama. Sometimes he half-laughed after speaking a line, as if to say You know this is showbiz, right? It showed an unbecoming detachment. He told the audience not to stay home in November but vote for the right person, then forgot to say who that person might be.If you can't endorse, good for you and stay home. That isn't politics, it's basic human comportment. If someone you're certain is awful invites you to a party, you politely decline. You don't go, walk into the room, and punch your host in the head. Mr. Cruz miscalculated, thinking if he snubbed Trump half the delegates would cheer. Instead almost all booed. He thought the media would laud his courage and integrity. They saw him as wounded and treated him as prey.When his campaign ended in June, I attended a small dinner in his honor. Mr. Cruz was charming, modest and funny. When we said goodnight I told him I felt, in retrospect, that I hadn't always been just to him and was glad I'd have a chance to be more generous in the future. Apparently I will need still more time. What a jerk.Donald Trump's speech was important. He is a vivid figure and for a year has elicited strong reactions. By now he's exhausting. We have Trump Fatigue. Also, who doesn't know how he feels about him? His acceptance speech was an opportunity to break through in a new way and flesh out his purpose. I think he succeeded, though with a certain grimness. He'd probably reply that the times are grim.We have to assess the true facts of our nation, he said: "We cannot afford to be so politically correct anymore." He spoke of "the plain facts that have been edited out of your nightly news," including the costs of illegal immigration and the victims of economic decline.He argued that the past eight years of U.S. foreign policy have been disastrous to peace and stability. "But Hillary Clinton's legacy does not have to be America's legacy."Does he want a ban on Muslims? No. "We must immediately suspend immigration from any nation that has been compromised by terrorism until such time as proven vetting mechanisms have been put in place." This stand has always driven his enemies crazy, and Mr. Trump usually spoke of it sloppily, either deliberately or not. But to most Americans it will sound like simple common sense.He was frankly populist: "I have joined the political arena so that the powerful can no longer beat up on people who cannot defend themselves . . . . My greatest compassion will be for our own struggling citizens." He stands, he asserted, for "the forgotten" -- not as their tribune or their leader, but "their voice."Cleverly: "My opponent asks her supporters to recite a three-word loyalty pledge. It reads, 'I'm with her.' I choose to recite a different pledge: 'I'm with you, the American people.'"It was not an eloquent speech, not lofty, very plain and blunt. It covered a lot of territory and went too long. It had no leavening humor. It is strange to see a New Yorker so uninterested in wit. It was at points too hyped and declarative, and it was sometimes grandiose.But it was powerful. After reading a copy of the speech leaked in advance, an anti-Trump conservative intellectual emailed me. "He's going to win," he said. The moment at least was not unknowable to him.Credit: By Peggy Noonan

article name: At Bridge Tables, 'No Trump!' Takes On a New Meaning --- Traditional game lingo loses neutrality as some players inject politics
article text: Corrections & AmplificationsThe American Contract Bridge League is the governing body for the card game in North America. A Page One article Saturday about the term "no trump" taking on new meaning in the game incorrectly referred to the group as the American Contract Bridge Association.(WSJ July 25, 2016)At gatherings of the Glenshaw Duplicate Bridge Club outside of Pittsburgh, players sip soft drinks in the social hall of a Presbyterian church and chat quietly between hands. Mainly they avoid small talk, especially politics, once the cards are on the table.But lately, partisanship has crept into the deck."No trump!" said a player at one recent event, using game-speak to request that a hand begin without a trump suit. In this particular utterance, though, the player's tone suggested he was also referring to the Republican presidential nominee.John Bernhard, who directs five bridge clubs around the city, didn't catch who made the comment. "It was obviously a liberal," he said. "No one threw any punches. I'm a Trump supporter, but I'm like a Buddhist; I detach."Donald Trump, known for his brash political style, is now roiling the quiet world of contract bridge -- where trump suits, which carry more weight than others in a given hand, are an integral part of play.A few bridge fans have even appealed to governing authorities to replace the timeworn term to avoid political connotations.At the Oaxaca Bridge Club in Mexico, where many of the players are either U.S. or Canadian expats, "no trump" bids are a badge of pride."We do it with gusto," said Barbara Perez, the director of the club in the town about 800 miles south of the U.S. border, where Mr. Trump's proposal to build an anti-immigration wall is far from popular.On the flip side, such jokes aren't welcome at the Whitford Country Club in the Philadelphia suburb of Exton."You're not likely to hear 'no trump' puns here," said Susan Shenkin, noting a strong anti-Clinton bent in the group. "People kind of assume everybody else is on the same page."Bridge, a contest of strategy and finesse, likely evolved from an older card game called Whist in the 1800s, according to games historian David Parlett. The modern form of bridge was developed by Harold Vanderbilt in 1929.The term "trump" stretches back even further, with roots in the 15th century, said Mr. Parlett, and is thought to be semantically related to the word "triumph."Today, organized games are played around the U.S. at homes, church basements, recreation centers and country clubs. There's also a healthy tournament circuit. Many players are retirees; fans include the likes of Bill Gates and Warren Buffett.Representatives for both Hillary Clinton, the presumptive Democratic nominee, and Mr. Trump declined to comment on the bridge-table controversy."The word 'trump' has been part of bridge's vernacular long before Donald Trump was even a twinkle in his parent's eye. And it will be around long after he is gone," said Darbi Padbury, spokeswoman for the American Contract Bridge Association.In bridge, players go around the table and try to get their preferred suit as trump for that hand -- part of a process known as bidding. Each player also has the chance to declare "no trump" in hopes of making all four suits equal.At the Beverly Hills Bridge Club, someone hung a recent New Yorker cartoon depicting four players at a table. The caption reads: "One no-trump. Oh, please, God, no Trump.""I think everyone looked at it and laughed a little bit," said Om Chokriwala, a manager of the club.At the recent Flying Pig Regional bridge tournament in Cincinnati, a vendor had a new offering: a jaunty hat declaring "No Trump" in big letters accompanied by the four suits in a deck of cards."They sell like hot cakes," said club director A.J. Stephani -- though he acknowledged that he and others felt the hats crossed a line."What brings us together is love of the game. You have to keep politics out," he said.The hat salesman, Brett Butterman, of West Palm Beach, Fla., said he is used to taking flak from Trump supporters.A company that makes bridge markers, a sign that reminds players of the suit for each hand, is playing both sides of the aisle. It offers markers that say "No Clinton," instead of "No Trump" and another one that says "Vote Clinton, No Trump," said James Esteph, owner of Newt's Playing Cards in Circleville, Ohio."So far, the 'No Clinton' ones are winning, but only by a few," Mr. Esteph said.A few members of the American Contract Bridge League have even written in to demand the organizations drop the use of the word "trump," said Paul Linxwiler, editor of the group's magazine, "Bridge Bulletin."Mostly, though, Mr. Linxwiler says he gets unsolicited jokes and cartoons from members. Riffling through a stack to find a funny one, he is disappointed."If you have a heart, bid no trump," he read. "Everybody thinks they're a comedian."Credit: By Ben Kesling and Beckie Strum

article name: Trump Celebrates, But Feud Simmers
article text: CLEVELAND -- A satisfied Donald Trump celebrated "one of the most love-filled conventions in the history of conventions" on Friday, and then he capped the week of his Republican presidential nomination by reopening one of the week's most contentious moments: his feud with primary rival Sen. Ted Cruz.Mr. Trump lashed out at Mr. Cruz for failing to endorse him after being granted a prime speaking slot at the convention this week. "I don't want his endorsement," Mr. Trump said. "If he gives it, I won't accept."With emphasis on immigration, crime and "America first" policies in trade and foreign policy, Mr. Trump's acceptance speech and overall convention program echoed the signature messages that have brought people to his campaign. Quick survey and poll results brought positive news for Mr. Trump.An instant CNN/ORC poll found that 56% of those viewing the speech said they would be more likely to vote for Mr. Trump, 10% said it made them less likely to vote for him, and 32% said it had little effect.In a Reuters/Ipsos poll taken over the course of the Republican convention, Mr. Trump pulled closer to Democrat Hillary Clinton. The July 18-22 national online poll found that 41% of likely voters supported Mrs. Clinton, while 38% supported Mr. Trump, with a margin of error of about 4 percentage points. On Monday, he trailed her by nearly 10 percentage points in the poll.Traditionally, parties and their presidential nominees take their national conventions as an opportunity to turn from the primary-season focus on their own party to an effort to address a broader audience of independents and swing voters who will be needed to win a general election.There were some efforts to do that at the GOP gathering by nodding to groups that haven't been Republican regulars: Mr. Trump's acceptance speech called for protecting the gay, lesbian and transgender community from intolerance and terrorism, and he commented that he was glad to hear the GOP audience applaud his remarks. Technology executive Peter Thiel took the podium and noted he was the first openly gay Republican to speak to a GOP convention.The speech beforehand by Mr. Trump's daughter Ivanka was designed mainly to address women and counter accusations that her father demeans them. And she introduced herself as a millennial who, like about half of her generation, doesn't identify solely with either party.Initial reactions suggested Mr. Trump made little progress with gay community leaders. The Human Rights Campaign said that "Donald Trump appallingly feigned support for LGBTQ people after opposing equality at every turn."Far more of the convention's program, and most of Mr. Trump's speech, appeared designed to shore up his base. That may have been a strategy born of necessity, in light of divisions within the party."It wasn't a speech that was uplifting, but Trump's never been about that," said Doug Heye, a former aide to House GOP leaders who has said he wouldn't vote for Mr. Trump. "It was a speech still aimed at the base -- not at trying to build a broader coalition of voters, but again that's not something Trump has ever tried to do."Trump supporters argue that he doesn't need a new message tailored to attracting new voters. "The key to appealing to the potential new voters to put you over the top is not to be more milquetoast and more moderate," said Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama, an early Trump backer. "So what he did was show strength: 'I understand you, I'm on your side.' And I think that message will resonate until November. It's going to get stronger, and I'm pretty confident that his vote total will grow."Even some who aren't sold on Mr. Trump said the approach was smart. "Trump has cleverly positioned himself as the candidate of change, versus Clinton as the puppet of the status quo,"" said Scott Reed, political adviser to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce who has been skeptical of Mr. Trump. "Watch for a healthy bump in the battleground-state polls."Mrs. Clinton, speaking in Florida on Friday, strongly objected to the theme of Mr. Trump's speech that he would speak for working people and the downtrodden. "Last night, Donald told us 'I am your voice,'" said Mrs, Clinton. "Well, I don't think he speaks for most Americans, do you? . . . Contrary to what they tried to say at their convention, I don't think he speaks for women."Analysts from both parties will be watching closely to see how much and how lasting a bump in the polls Mr. Trump might get -- and whether it moves swing voters.John Della Volpe, director of polling at the Harvard Institute of Politics who conducted a town hall meeting with young people in Cleveland during the convention, said that Ivanka Trump was very appealing to young voters, but that her message of inclusion was overshadowed by her father's speech."Some of the good will created by her speech might have been lost, or at least not extended," by the nominee's acceptance speech that followed, Mr. Della Volpe said.Some Republicans saw the greatest risk in the paucity of outreach to Hispanics, a fast-growing part of the electorate that GOP leaders want to court to bolster the party's future, but who have been particularly negative about Mr. Trump because of his anti-immigrant message."As a Hispanic, I didn't like what I heard," said Al Cardenas, former president of the American Conservative Union, who had supported Trump rival Jeb Bush. "If you were expecting him to pivot and cast a wider net going into the general election, you were wrong. I don't see how he gets enough people to follow him on such a narrow path."Mr. Trump's morning-after attack on Mr. Cruz also renewed one of the most bizarre issues of the primary campaign, returning to allegations made in the National Enquirer tabloid that Mr. Cruz's father, Rafael Cruz, was linked to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963.---Beth Reinhard, Reid J. Epstein and Kristina Peterson contributed to this article.Credit: By Janet Hook and Heather Haddon

article name: Why Peter Thiel Really Supports Trump
article text: For a Trumpian nonbeliever, the most interesting speech of four days was always going to be technology superinvestor Peter Thiel's.The Silicon Valley wunderkind and early Facebook backer is known for his singular diagnosis of American ills. The undersea cities, flying cars and three-star restaurants on Mars we promised ourselves in the optimistic early '60s haven't materialized. Outside of infotech, the rate of American innovation and progress is very much less than we like to tell ourselves it is. In the world of bits, deregulated entrepreneurialism prevails. In the world of atoms, not so much, thanks to overregulation and politicized risk aversion.Six years ago, Mr. Thiel explained why this was a disaster for Americans: "In a world where wealth is growing, you can get away with printing money . . . . In the '30s, the Keynesian stuff worked at least in the sense that you could print money without inflation because there was all this productivity growth happening." In today's world where technology is failing, printing money is "not going to work" and "you probably have to get rid of the welfare state."Mr. Thiel at the time foresaw a "grim Malthusian politics," a period of "long-term stagnation," leading to a "near revolutionary situation" in the U.S. It's a view (increasingly shared by secular stagnation theorists) that he has continued to elaborate in speeches and interviews ever since.So if Mr. Thiel this week gave himself the job of speaking for a candidate whom many of his Silicon Valley friends and peers frankly revile, one readily supposes the reasoning went like this: The Valley sees Trump as anti-trade, anti-immigration, and nothing in Mr. Thiel's speech suggested Mr. Thiel is anti-trade, anti-immigration. But Mr. Trump is a wrecking ball at a time when Washington needs a wrecking ball. It needs a candidate whose very existence forcibly disrupts its ways and patterns.Even Mr. Trump's vulgarities, his reprehensible impulses (kill the innocent family members of terrorists), his dangerous suggestions (decide when the time comes whether to uphold NATO's guarantee of the Baltics) might seem virtues, in a sense. They expand the boundaries of the sayable.Of course, making so counterintuitive a case in a convention speech isn't practical, especially when doing extra duty as a representative of gay outreach. So Mr. Thiel contented himself with saying that he supported Mr. Trump because Mr. Trump "is a builder." He harked back to the 1960s, when government was competent -- it got us to the moon in less time and for less money than it takes today to repair a bridge. Every industrial city was a Silicon Valley, because businesses everywhere were innovating and investing. We need to recover that spirit. Today's fights about gender-bathroom assignment are a distraction. "Who cares!"You had to know where Mr. Thiel was coming from to know where he was going with his support of Mr. Trump. Few voters did. Yet the job Mr. Thiel gave himself is an important one. The Republican convention has now wrapped up. Those immune to histrionics and heavy breathing have only one question: Will Mr. Trump mount a fall campaign equal to the task of returning a Republican majority to both houses of Congress?Even voters sensitive to the many ways that Donald Trump has given lip to an agenda that likely would do more harm than good can see him as a gift of providence. He's here to scare the bejesus out of the establishment.Mr. Trump fulfills this role even if he loses by a smidgen to Hillary Clinton. Mrs. Clinton and the GOP House and Senate leadership of Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell will be left acknowledging a near-run thing. Mrs. Clinton will have no second term, no legacy; Mr. Ryan will have no hope of the presidency; Mr. McConnell will finally fall to the Tea Party types who have been gunning for him so long -- unless they make the deals that begin America's renewal.Mr. Trump's own speech, give him credit, was a masterful if lengthy exposition of his nationalist-Peronist viewpoint: America is a nation of lovely people of every creed, ethnicity and sexual orientation beset by murderous illegal aliens, Islamic terrorists and the predatory trade practices of other countries.At least gone was the impractical and dangerous idea of rounding up 11 million illegals and deporting them (instead Mr. Trump would slow new arrivals to a trickle). In every other way, Mr. Trump sticks to a diagnosis that blames non-Americans for America's problems. We wait to find out how this plays with the American voter. Politically, Mr. Trump piles his chips on a high-risk, all-or-nothing gamble. He seeks to ignite a populist prairie fire that will burn a path to the White House. He does not engage in the tactical (and expensive, media-wise) base broadening that most presidential campaigns engage in.All or nothing, of course, is also the Trump strategy most likely to end with a Hillary landslide, with Democrats inheriting all three branches and trying to cure America's malaise with bigger government and more redistribution. If Mr. Thiel aligns himself with a handful of base-expanding Wall Streeters who also have endorsed Mr. Trump as a blower-upper of the status quo, this fear is probably partly why.Credit: By Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.

article name: City News: Students for Trump Stick Together
article text: Vassar College economics student Ian Vasily cuts an unusual figure walking through campus in a hat bearing Donald Trump's campaign slogan, "Make America Great Again."Many students at the upstate New York school ask:"'Are you actually supporting him?' " Mr. Vasily said, " 'Or is this ironic?'"At liberal-arts colleges in the Northeast and on many campuses nationwide, where left-wing activism often flourishes, there is little love lost between the presumptive Republican presidential nominee and student bodies.But a phenomenon has sprung up at these schools, too -- the lonely Trump supporter waging a solitary battle and seeking like-minded peers in the shadows.From Yale University to New York University, students donning Trump gear across campus quads attract attention, if not hostilities, and spark debates.While sipping a milkshake on campus in his hat, Mr. Vasily faced questions from a student passerby about whether he thought some of Mr. Trump's comments were racist."Generally people are more curious than anything else because it's such an oddity," said Mr. Vasily, 19 years old.At Yale, philosophy student Karl Notturno is one of the few out-and-proud backers of the Republican candidate on the Connecticut campus, which, he said, has become his claim to fame. "I'm kind of known as 'The Trump Supporter,'" he said.Mr. Notturno, 21, said he has found fellow Trump voters while conducting his own informal polling, but "a lot of them are quiet about it, because it's a very, very unpopular opinion. It's not the type of thing you'd voluntarily disclose."While Mr. Trump has found a well of support in red state and Evangelical campuses, the New York businessman remains largely unpopular on college campuses in blue states like New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. According to a poll this spring of 3,183 voters under 30 from the Institute of Politics at Harvard University, 61% prefer presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton over Mr. Trump.At some New York colleges, campus GOP clubs have been riven by Mr. Trump's candidacy, mirroring the divide among GOP lawmakers in Washington.Students at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., treat active members of the campus Republican club -- all five of them -- "even less seriously than they did before" because of Mr. Trump's candidacy, said Elizabeth Barry, a member of the club.At Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., when "Make America Great Again" was scrawled on two faculty members' dry-erase boards, a campus panel tasked with investigating alleged acts of prejudice labeled it a bias attack. Both faculty members were racial minorities. The person responsible for the writing wasn't identified.A spokeswoman for Skidmore said Mr. Trump's slogan "is in its own right protected political speech" but when particular individuals are targeted "it may take it out of that realm and raise different concerns about its purpose."Some of Mr. Trump's backers described doing underground networking to find like-minded peers. Mr. Vasily said he found one supporter of Mr. Trump at Vassar through an app that allows students to gossip anonymously about one another.Some students were criticizing a fellow Vassar student for holding pro-Trump views, and Mr. Vasily and other campus conservatives tracked him down.Students with conservative views have long complained about feeling isolated on college campuses. Dylan Perera, a bespectacled NYU student, found a burst of right-wing celebrity after he revealed he supported Mr. Trump in a New York Post article about students at the school who were afraid to show they were Trump backers. Mr. Perera made the rounds on talk shows and blogs earlier this year.He declined to comment for this article because he said he is in talks about an internship with Mr. Trump's campaign.Their liberal peers say the fears are overblown. "It actually tends to be those that are more liberal -- particularly minorities and urban youths -- who are truly threatened on a day-to-day basis," said Michael DeLuca, 21, president of the NYU College Democrats.At Columbia University, 22-year-old Eric Steven Wimer, who identifies as a "leftist," said he didn't know of a single Trump supporter at the school of 30,000 students. "The fact that we can't find any of them means they're probably hiding," he said.Credit: By Mike Vilensky and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

article name: Cleveland Set for a Trump Show
article text: CLEVELAND -- Republicans gathered here to elevate Donald Trump as their presidential candidate and party leader, an outcome almost no one among the GOP's leadership saw coming at the campaign's outset.The convention that begins Monday will, in some ways, be as unorthodox as the process that led to it. Trump aides say they hope to use it to showcase the New York developer as not merely the slashing political figure Americans saw in the primary debates, but as an accomplished business leader and a family man.Toward that end, the television spectacle this week will be more heavily focused on the first-time candidate rather than the party around him. A member of the Trump family -- three adult children and his wife -- will each be featured on one of the convention's four nights, as will those who have known him personally in multiple walks of life.The tenor of the gathering now figures to be affected by a series of shocking news events in recent days. The killing of five police officers in Dallas and Sunday's killing of three in Louisiana have led Mr. Trump and his newly minted running mate, Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, to declare themselves the "law and order" candidates.Those messages, however, could be undermined by rowdy street protests by both supporters and opponents of Mr. Trump that are expected to attract thousands, including some who have vowed to take advantage of Ohio's law allowing them to openly carry firearms.Recasting and broadening Mr. Trump's image, a key convention goal for the campaign, is critical because he begins the general election against expected Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton behind. A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News national poll shows him trailing Mrs. Clinton, whose convention will be held next week in Philadelphia, by a 46%-to-41% margin.The survey also shows that Mr. Trump has a lot of work to do this week uniting the party behind him.Few Republicans -- 13% -- see their party as unified, and just 38% say they are satisfied with Mr. Trump as the party's nominee. Dozens of high-profile party officials -- senators and former presidents -- have refused to attend the convention because they oppose the New York businessman.The survey was done before the announcement of Mr. Pence as the GOP running mate, a pick that was specifically aimed at uniting the party. The governor is a favorite of the party's evangelical Christian base and is a former member of Congress popular with many lawmakers.In a joint interview with Mr. Pence on CBS's "60 Minutes," Mr. Trump said of his running mate, "Having Governor Mike Pence has really -- people that I wasn't necessarily liking or getting along are loving this pick, because they have such respect for him."The national conventions give both parties and their presidential nominees a chance to address not just their supporters but a wider audience of Americans, many of them sour on politics. The GOP has the bigger public-relations problem, the latest WSJ/NBC News poll found: Just 27% of registered voters have a positive view of the Republican Party, compared with 39% who view the Democratic Party favorably.Still, Mr. Trump is holding his own in a race where, according to the poll, a majority of voters wants a candidate who brings "major changes" to government rather than a "steady approach.""Donald Trump is a phenomenon we have never seen in American politics," said Peter Hart, a Democratic pollster who worked on the survey with GOP pollster Bill McInturff. "In an election of change, Donald Trump would be a favorite. But he is the chaos candidate, and that is likely to nullify the advantage he has."The conventions are meeting after several weeks of great tumult at home and abroad, including federal officials' conclusion that Mrs. Clinton had been "extremely careless" in handling sensitive government emails, gun violence, racial tensions, and, with the massacre in Nice, France, heightened fears of international terrorism.Still, the poll found one pillar of stability in U.S. politics: Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton remain the two most unpopular people in modern times to be major-party presidential nominees.Tammy Kirkiewicz, a 51-year-old in St. Louis, said she was backing Mr. Trump mostly because he is the alternative to Mrs. Clinton. "I'm not sure that he's the one; he's sort of a loose cannon," she said. "But if that's the only option, it's better than Hillary."Asked which candidate showed the right judgment to be a good president, 37% said Mrs. Clinton, and 25% said Mr. Trump. But 32% said neither candidate -- a huge difference from 2008, when only 6% said that neither Barack Obama nor John McCain had the right judgment."Let me summarize the poll in four little words: They hate them both," said Fred Yang, another Democratic pollster who conducted the survey.Mrs. Clinton continued to lead Mr. Trump when third-party candidates, Libertarian Gary Johnson and Jill Stein of the Green Party, were added to the mix.In that lineup, Mrs. Clinton draws 41% of the vote, Mr. Trump 35%, Mr. Johnson 11% and Ms. Stein 6%.The poll identified other factors that could redound to her benefit. Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Trump among Hispanic registered voters by a whopping 76% to 14%, meaning the Republican trails the 27% of Hispanic voters won by Mitt Romney in 2012.Meanwhile, more voters say they want a Democrat to be president than a Republican. Mr. Obama's job performance wins approval from 51% of voters for the third straight month. A growing share says the economy has improved and that Mr. Obama deserves credit.Still, the poll found that the FBI report on Mrs. Clinton's email practices is casting a long shadow over voters' view of her.Fully 55% of those surveyed said her use of a private email server while she was secretary of state was an "important factor" in deciding whether to vote for her.At the same time, a plurality of 43% said they believed the FBI investigation was "unfair and too partisan."William Reeves, 34, a Clinton supporter in Tampa, Fla., said Mrs. Clinton probably should have met punishment for her email use. But the matter wasn't enough to deter him from voting for her."When it becomes a choice between Hillary Clinton's proven track record and a complete nobody . . . it's a pretty clear, easy choice," Mr. Reeves said.Credit: By Janet Hook

article name: The Republican Convention: Rules Fight Is Set to End Quietly --- Anti-Trump movement fails to secure support for unbinding measure from top party officials
article text: CLEVELAND -- What might have been a disruptive fight about the party's rules and platform is now almost certain to end with a whimper when the Republican National Convention opens for businesson Monday.The rules fight, in the works for months as the Ted Cruz campaign worked to install the Texan's supporters on key committees, fizzled last week as Donald Trump's backers allied with key officials from the Republican National Committee to crush the anti-Trump faction.The only remaining drama will come when bands of renegade delegates try to slow the convention proceedings through a series of procedural maneuvers that are likely to fail -- just as the effort to block Donald Trump from becoming the party's presidential nominee did last week.Mr. Trump's opponents will seek a recorded roll-call vote by each state's delegation on the rules adopted in a marathon Rules Committee session last week.Organizers of the anti-Trump movement recognize their odds are slim but they expect the cause to live on."This is something that doesn't rise and fall at what happens here in Cleveland," Dane Waters, a leader of the unbinding effort, said Sunday. "They've riled up the base" in a way that could produce "longtime positive reform in reviving the Republican Party."RNC chairman Reince Priebus said the renegade delegates won't succeed in delaying the convention or unbinding delegates."I don't think they're going to be successful," he said in aSunday interview on ABC.Along with the effort to unseat Mr. Trump as the nominee, a faction of delegates loyal to Mr. Cruz continues to seek a conventionwide vote on a series of measures designed to help future conservative candidates in presidential contests.The Cruz delegates want to ban corporate lobbyists from serving on the RNC, provide a 20% delegate bonus to states that forbid Democrats and independents from participating in their primaries and caucuses, award more delegates to states with more Republican members of Congress and strip power from the RNC chairman.All of their proposals failed last week in the convention committee.In aFridaynight conference call, former Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli, who is leading the Cruz backers on the Rules Committee, promised to pursue a "minority report," which would require agreement from at least 28 of the 112 committee members. That number would allow Mr. Cuccinelli to force the entire convention to vote on the pro-Cruz measures."You can expect to see that this isn't done. It isn't over," Mr. Cuccinelli said. "If there was some notion on the part of the party or the Trump campaign that they wanted unity in this convention, it is an odd way to do it to kick the grass-roots in the teeth."In a Friday interview in Cleveland, Mr. Cruz, a Texas Senator, declined to explicitly criticize the Rules Committee but backed Mr. Cuccinelli's proposals. "I think a great many of us would like to see Republican nominees chosen by Republicans," Mr. Cruz said. "There are certainly common sense reforms that could be enacted to ensure that happens. But that's for the delegates to make those decisions."A fight promised last week concerning social-issues language in the party's platform also appears to have fizzled in recent days.Giovani Cicione of Rhode Island on Wednesday said he had commitments from enough members of the Platform Committee to back a full-convention vote to replace the 60-page platform, which takes a harsh stance on gay marriage, with a two-page document that avoids mention of it.Jim Bopp, a Republican National Committee member from Indiana, who whipped votes against the alternative plan, said he had convinced many to rescind their support for the two-page document."That effort is dead," Mr. Bopp said Sunday.Credit: By Reid J. Epstein

article name: Voters Don't Want Trump Children to Run for New York City Mayor; Donald Trump Jr. previous said he would "love to" run for City Hall
