The middle class is shrinking, and median household income today, in real terms, is lower than when Mr. Obama took office. By more than two to one, Americans believe the country is on the wrong track.What does Mr. Trump offer as an alternative?-- The biggest pro-growth tax cut since Ronald Reagan's 1981 reform. Mr. Trump would simplify the tax code and significantly reduce marginal rates, encouraging investment and economic expansion. His proposed corporate tax rate of 15% would make it easier for American firms to repatriate earnings, bringing capital home and making the U.S. a more hospitable place to invest. Mr. Trump's tax plan would do more for working-class and middle-class families than any scheme to redistribute income.Don't believe the phony claim that it will cost $10 trillion over a decade. As Americans will see when he reveals the entire plan in the next few weeks, any revenue loss would be a fraction of that amount.-- The repeal of ObamaCare, the fastest-growing entitlement program of all. Mr. Trump promises to replace the law with a consumer-choice health plan. He also wants to immediately repeal dozens of President Obama's antibusiness executive orders.-- A pro-growth energy policy. Mr. Trump wants to employ all of America's abundant resources -- oil, natural gas and coal. His plan could make America the world's No. 1 energy producer within five years, producing millions of new jobs and trillions of dollars of extra output -- along with new royalty payments to the government. Mrs. Clinton, by contrast, brags that she would put "a lot of coal miners" out of work.We don't see eye to eye with Mr. Trump on everything. In our opinion, legal immigrants are an asset to the country. We believe that deporting 11 million people is unworkable, and we hope in the end Mr. Trump comes to this same conclusion. Deportation should be pursued only when an illegal immigrant has committed a felony or become a "public charge."But the difference here is smaller than often portrayed. Although Mr. Trump is depicted as a close-the-doors nativist, he has said that he favors legal immigration, and he has hired thousands of legal immigrants. His proposals on illegal immigration -- to build a wall, increase enforcement of the law, deport criminal aliens, defund sanctuary cities, and reduce visa overstays -- are reasonable and sensible given that voters demand action.We are also free traders and oppose punitive tariffs. The U.S. needs trade. Yet it also must have a president willing to negotiate from a position of strength with countries that manipulate their currencies, steal Americans' intellectual property, or compel companies to disclose trade secrets as a condition of entering their markets. Negotiating better trade deals and enforcing the current ones would help the U.S. economy.Ideological purists miss a practical point. Right or wrong, working-class Americans believe that they disproportionately bear the burdens of free-trade deals. Taking a tougher stance might be necessary to restore dwindling support for open markets.Concern that Mr. Trump is a showman, temperamentally unsuited for the Oval Office, is misplaced. Running a successful business enterprise as CEO is an excellent qualification for the presidency. Mr. Trump has had prolonged success. He didn't fake that. We find it refreshing and uplifting that middle-class and working-class voters don't envy Mr. Trump or view him as an evil rich guy. Rather, they admire his success and want to emulate it.Trump's detractors love to point to his businesses that did not succeed. But one of the great things about the U.S. is that people can rise above their failures. Henry Ford and Steve Jobs did, and they changed the world. The skyscrapers that bear his name all over the world are evidence that Mr. Trump has maintained a level of success that few people ever achieve.Mr. Trump won the Republican nomination decisively against the best field of candidates that any party has put forth in modern times. To win the presidency, he will need to persuade millions of working-class voters that the party of Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton has abandoned them. In doing so, Mr. Trump will bring Reagan Democrats home to the GOP where they belong. Isn't this what the party has been trying to do for 30 years?---Mr. Puzder is chief executive officer of CKE Restaurants. Mr. Moore is a visiting economist at the Heritage Foundation. Both advise Mr. Trump.(See related letter: "Letters to the Editor: Trump's Plan Would Grow National Debt 'Beautifully'" -- WSJ July 22, 2016)Credit: By Andy Puzder and Stephen Moore

article name: Election 2016: Ginsburg Regrets Her Criticism of Trump --- After a growing backlash, Supreme Court justice calls her comments 'ill advised'
article text: WASHINGTON -- Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg walked back her criticism of presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump on Thursday, but the spectacle of the Supreme Court's eldest member trading potshots with a potential president further enmeshed the judiciary in the 2016 election."On reflection, my recent remarks in response to press inquiries were ill-advised, and I regret making them," Justice Ginsburg said in a written statement released by the Supreme Court. "Judges should avoid commenting on a candidate for public office. In the future I will be more circumspect."In three media interviews over the past week, Justice Ginsburg, 83 years old and the court's senior liberal member, criticized Mr. Trump and his candidacy in increasingly sharp terms. "At first I thought it was funny," she told CNN on Tuesday. She went on to call him "a faker" who was treated too gently by the media -- for instance, she said, he had "gotten away" without releasing his tax returns.Mr. Trump responded on Twitter. "Her mind is shot -- resign!" he tweeted earlier this week. On Thursday, the Trump campaign declined to comment on Justice Ginsburg's latest statement.The back and forth prompted a rare consensus by legal experts, politicians and editorial boards that Justice Ginsburg had crossed a line in criticizing Mr. Trump, despite the candidate's own attacks on Chief Justice John Roberts, several Supreme Court decisions and a federal judge handling litigation against Trump University.More broadly, observers bemoaned the blurring boundaries between the political and judicial branches, a trend reflected by polls that show an erosion in public confidence in the Supreme Court.Some observers said the damage done by the episode couldn't be undone. Her regret "does not unring the bell," said Stephen Gillers, a New York University legal ethics scholar. Mr. Gillers said Justice Ginsburg's remarks could put her under pressure to recuse herself "if the resolution of a case will determine whether Clinton or Trump becomes president.""It seems like a proper moment to think of what are appropriate guidelines for all of the justices, rather than getting engaged in a very partisan effort at criticism" of Justice Ginsburg alone, said Caroline Fredrickson, president of the American Constitution Society, a network of liberal lawyers and law students.Supreme Court justices aren't bound by the official code of conduct that governs other federal judges. The code states that judges "may not publicly endorse or oppose a candidate for public office."The political spotlight on the court intensified after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia in February, when Senate Republicans immediately vowed to prevent President Barack Obama from replacing the conservative icon. They have held firm, declining to grant a hearing to Mr. Obama's nominee, U.S. Judge Merrick Garland.In an interview published in Sunday's New York Times, Justice Ginsburg weighed in on that topic, too. Asked if the Senate should consider the nomination, she replied "that's their job."The court's modern trajectory toward the political sphere can be traced to December 2000, when it issued its extraordinary ruling in Bush v. Gore. The 5-4 split decided the presidential election and put George W. Bush in the White House by halting a Florida election recount with the Republican candidate ahead by 537 votes. That decision appalled Democrats, particularly because the majority justices all were appointed by Republicans.Republicans, for their part, have accused Chief Justice Roberts, a George W. Bush appointee, of joining with the court's liberals to uphold much of the Affordable Care Act in 2012 and 2015 out of a desire for political comity.Mr. Trump repeatedly has criticized the chief justice for those votes. "He could've killed it twice and he didn't," he said in a January radio interview. "That was terrible."Some conservatives say the problem has grown as the Democratically controlled executive branch and Republican-controlled Congress repeatedly clash, leading to efforts to have the judicial branch serve as a referee."Part of the problem is the political branches can't seem to work out their disputes between themselves," said Elizabeth Slattery, a legal fellow at the conservative Heritage Foundation.---Jacob Gershman contributed to this article.Credit: By Jess Bravin and Mark H. Anderson

article name: Trump's Pence Selection
article text: There's nothing normal about Donald Trump's presidential candidacy, which is why his mooted choice of Mike Pence as his running mate is so refreshingly conventional. The Indiana Governor is a career politician with an optimistic mien who is popular across the Republican ideological spectrum. Assuming Mr. Trump doesn't change his mind overnight, Mr. Pence is the right kind of boring.The most prominent GOP choices for Vice President -- such as Marco Rubio or John Kasich -- said they didn't want to be considered. That left lesser-known figures unvetted by the media, or GOP warhorses like Newt Gingrich. Mr. Pence may be the best among the available choices in being able to reassure Republicans and handle the media scrutiny that invariably hits GOP running mates.The first-term Governor would reassure social conservatives who have doubts about Mr. Trump's campaign conversion to traditional values. He is also a free-marketeer, having voted against the Medicare drug expansion during his 12 years in Congress and cut individual and corporate tax rates in Indiana.His foreign-policy instincts are more Reaganesque than Trumpian. He favors a robust American role in the world and is known as a strong supporter of Israel. He also has a history as a free-trader, having voted for U.S. pacts with Central America, Australia, Singapore, Chile, Peru, Oman, Colombia and South Korea.Mr. Pence wrote last year to the Indiana congressional delegation in favor of President Obama's Pacific and European trade initiatives. "I can tell you first-hand that TPP and TTIP provide an abundance of opportunities for Indiana businesses and will help to grow jobs in our state," he wrote. Mr. Trump opposes the Pacific pact, so Mr. Pence will have to explain these differences with Mr. Trump to voters -- though they are reassuring to those of us who fear the New Yorker would start a trade war.Mr. Pence is also a plausible governing pick, given his experience in Indianapolis and Congress. He was a friendly colleague of House Speaker Paul Ryan, and he could be an effective White House emissary to Capitol Hill. Mr. Trump's relations with congressional Republicans are nascent and wary, so voters may like the candidate's apparent self-recognition that he needs allies in the legislature.The 57-year-old Mr. Pence does come with some risks. He has never been vetted thoroughly in a national campaign, and the media will try to portray him as another too-eager sycophant. Hillary Clinton's researchers are no doubt listening to every available tape from his long career in talk radio hunting for political ammunition. It would be remarkable if they didn't find something.In 2015 Mr. Pence botched the handling of a religious liberty-gay rights flap in his state, which cost him support in the center and on the right. The political hangover has made him vulnerable as he has campaigned for re-election this year. More than a few of our Hoosier friends think he may want to join the Trump ticket in part to avoid the risk of defeat. If he does run with the businessman, Mr. Pence will have to drop out of the Indiana contest.These risks are probably worth taking if Mr. Pence can hold up under fire and rally GOP support. Mr. Trump has gained some ground in the polls since FBI Director James Comey's outline of her email lies last week. But Mr. Trump remains the underdog, in part because in most polls he is winning only some 80%, sometimes less, of Republicans.To win he'll need the votes of well over 90% of his own party, especially as Democrats consolidate behind Mrs. Clinton. Mr. Trump in particular needs to win over Republicans and independents with college degrees who dislike his crude populism, off-the-cuff insult-comedy and lack of policy knowledge.Mr. Pence is a conviction conservative who is also a nicer guy. That means he may have to adjust to the role of "attack dog," as Mr. Trump told the Journal this week he wanted his running mate to be. Then again, Mr. Gingrich and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie will still be Trump surrogates even if they are passed over for VP.Running mates rarely make a difference in presidential contests, even when they are controversial, though they do increasingly matter in governing. But rarely has a nominee needed less political drama in a choice than Mr. Trump. His problem since becoming the presumptive GOP nominee is that he has been making the election about him. That's a losing strategy when your negative ratings are above 60%.Mr. Trump needs to present an optimistic alternative to the frustrations of the last eight years and a restoration of the Clinton dynasty. A safer VP choice fits that bill.

article name: Transcript: Lawrence Kudlow at WSJ Pro Financial Regulation Event; The full transcript of WSJ Pro's interview with Lawrence Kudlow, senior contributor, CNBC, and informal adviser to Donald Trump, at the Future of Financial Regulation Conference.
article text: Lawrence Kudlow, Senior Contributor, CNBC; Informal Adviser to Republican Presidential Nominee Donald TrumpInterviewer: Jamie Heller, Deputy Editor, Finance, The Wall Street JournalLocation: Four Seasons Hotel, New York City, New YorkTime: 3:30 p.m. EDTDate: Tuesday, October 18, 2016Transcript By Superior Transcriptions LLC www.superiortranscriptions.comJAMIE HELLER: Larry, thanks so much for being here. Let's just pick it up where the congressman left off. CFPB - is it as entrenched in the American culture now as he seems to suggest? Is it here to stay?LAWRENCE KUDLOW: It could be entrenched. I don't know. I think its structure would be changed if you had a Republican administration and a Republican Congress. I mean, that's a big if. But I think that the issues here - you just had a Court of Appeals decision in something that troubled me. What you have here - putting aside their mission and whether they're accomplishing their mission or not, the constitutionality of the agency has been called into question.First of all, as an old Fed guy - I actually worked as a secretary a long time ago to the New York Fed chairman, Paul Volcker - I don't know what it's doing inside the Fed. I don't know why it's financed by the Fed. Never seen anything like it. I'm not sure the Fed would like it there. So I also think the director has too much power and if the thing does survive it should be reset as a board for an independent commission, which is usually, let's say, two, two and one - two Democrats, two Republicans and then the president gets to choose the chairman.I think it should be subjected to congressional authorization and appropriation oversight. Right now, I think it's just, you know, way too powerful and runs against checks and balances that are normally used for these various independent agencies. So - oh, and I think the president should have greater power than just cause to remove it - him or her. So I think you've got to make big structural changes. I'll leave alone the mission. I'm not an expert on the mission. Some people like it, some people don't. There's a fair debate about that. But I think under a Republican, shall we say, three houses, you'll get some structural changes. Jeb Hensarling, the chairman of the House Banking Committee - Financial Services Committee would like that as well.MS. HELLER: And what about Dodd-Frank and the congressman's assessment that it just needs some fine tuning? Is that your assessment?MR. KUDLOW: Well, actually, I'm inclined to agree with Barney on that. Barney is a friend of mine. We've debated many times - civilly, I might add - and there are a lot of issues swirling around Dodd-Frank. I'm not the best expert at every single detail in Dodd-Frank. I mean, what you hear from different banking organizations is, frankly, mixed. I think the smaller banks - the community banks don't like it.They feel it's overburdening them with regulations and red tape. They would argue that you already have all of these different regulatory agencies. You know, when I was a kid working at the New York Fed, in those days we had a big banking crisis in 1973 to '75. Banks were going under left and right. Arthur Burns, the then chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, made a speech where he said, essentially - I'm going to have to paraphrase - it was about 40 years go - but essentially said there's a crazy quilt of overlapping bank and supervisory bodies in the government. And, of course, you have federal and you have state, and then there's local. And the way I look at life, that's still true. That's basically still true.Now, I don't have a ready solution for it this afternoon. I've not given it enough thought. But it just strikes me that that's still a problem. Other people believe that Dodd-Frank and its red tape - I'm just going to use that word loosely - that may be unfair - have had a burdensome effect on loans, a burdensome effect on making institutions too big to fail, some of which have already been overturned. Some people want bankruptcy laws rather than the current system. So I don't know. I -MS. HELLER: Some say that it's great for the big banks because they're the only ones who could afford all this regulation.MR. KUDLOW: Yeah. I think that's a very fair point. I was reading one of the op-eds from my friend, Jeb Hensarling, and Jeb made the point that what you've had is more banks have become more powerful whereas smaller banks have become less powerful, less credit, and one interesting stat which needs to be pursued is that in the USA in the last 20 years, net new business formation has slumped very badly and as an economist I would say that's really the source of jobs. I mean, small businesses create jobs but it's the brand new businesses that have always made America, you know, kind of a super economy - sort of Schumpeterian gales of creative destruction. But they need credit.Now, bank credit is not the only source of financing but that's what you hear. There's probably something to that.MS. HELLER: So you have a new book out -MR. KUDLOW: Yes. Thank you.MS. HELLER: - "JFK and the Reagan Revolution."MR. KUDLOW: I forgot to bring my copy.MS. HELLER: And I'm reading it on my Kindle so -MR. KUDLOW: Thank you.MS. HELLER: - I don't have it right now. But economic growth is one of your heartfelt, really, almost concerns that it's almost - seems to me you're saying it's almost not even very valued the way it might have once been. You seem to try to make a point economic growth is a good thing.MR. KUDLOW: Yes.MS. HELLER: It's good for individuals.MR. KUDLOW: Yes.MS. HELLER: It's good for the country.MR. KUDLOW: Yes.MS. HELLER: Do you think that's -MR. KUDLOW: Makes people happy.MS. HELLER: - do you think that's not - just as a given is it becoming - I mean, do you think the Democrats would agree? Do they care as much as you do?MR. KUDLOW: Well, let me go back. I mean, part of my book about JFK and the Reagan Revolution, we know that Reagan was a supply-side tax cutter. He lowered marginal tax rates. He did so in two tranches - 1981 and the big one was '86. Both, I might add, were largely bipartisan. The '86 bill was completely bipartisan. OK.What you don't know or what many people don't recall is that the original pioneer supply-side tax cutter was John F. Kennedy, and to quote my friend, Art Laffer - my friend and mentor, Art Laffer, I am a former Democrat - I'm a Kennedy - I'm a JFK Democrat and a Reagan Republican because they were growth guys. A rising tide lifts all boats, and under their administration and later, we had terrific growth during the '60s and the '80s and the '90s. And by the way, I'm going to sneak Bill Clinton working with the Republican Congress. I thought he had some supply-side measures, particularly lowering the capital gains, even in the first term as he raised the income tax.So growth is very important. Growth is a job creator. Growth is a wage-increaser. Growth helps solve poverty. Growth helps lower budget deficits and long-term debt problems. Doesn't solve everything. There are structural issues. But growth is huge, and I don't think - I think Republicans are more in the growth path but the reason I say I think is that not necessarily to my satisfaction.MS. HELLER: Everyone's got to get more on the growth train -MR. KUDLOW: Right. Thank you.MS. HELLER: - right? For you?MR. KUDLOW: I think the tragedy in this story - and I don't mean to disrespect anybody - I'm sure there are a number of prominent Democrats in this group - but the tragedy of this story is that the Democratic Party in its officialdom is not promoting growth. It's, allegedly, trying to solve issues with inequality, redistribution, tax fairness, tax the rich people, tax rich corporations, tax capital gains. That's coming out in Ms. Clinton's campaign.And I think that's just dead wrong. I mean, we've had a period - and I don't want to go on forever on this - but in the last 16 years under Republicans and Democrats, presidents and Congresses, we've had less than 2 percent growth per annum and that is so far below America's long-run history - history. If you go back to the end of World War II or, you know, when the data got reasonably good in '48 or '49, to the year 2000, we grew at 3.5 percent per year and we had whatever - correct me if I'm wrong - 10 or 11 recessions and subsequent recoveries.I mean, in real terms, average wages went from about 16,000 (dollars) to 50,000 (dollars). We did great. Since 2000, on the other hand, basically real middle-income wages have not moved. The economy has slumped below 2 percent per year. Jobs are underperforming. Business investment has hardly moved. And those are issues that go right to productivity and the standards of living for individual American families. This is wrong.And I will go further on this. It's now an economic issue. I mean, the very beginning of our book, "JFK and the and the Reagan Revolution," and the intro that I wrote, Americans are not happy campers. You know, there are lot of reasons for that. I'm not a sociologist. I'm not a psychiatrist. I have had group therapy but that doesn't make me an expert. That was a joke. That was a joke. (Laughter.) Just to lighten up a little bit here.My friend Arthur Brooks, who is the president of the American Enterprise Institute, and a very distinguished sociology scholar, as well as just being a clever chap, he's done a lot of work, as have others, down through the years that shows people are happier - happiness - you can actually measure happiness. Maybe not to your satisfaction, but he's done a lot of work on this. People are happier when we have high growth rather than low growth. People are happier when they earn their income from a job, a private job. And they are less happy when they receive government assistance.Now, these are generalities, and I'm not against the safety net. I'm just remarking. This is Arthur Brooks' work. The point I make in the intro to "JFK and the Reagan Revolution," is that we are in a period where people are not happy, they are cranky, they are pessimistic, they are pointing the fingers are various people, groups - immigrants, you name it. And blame - the blame game is rampant. And unfortunately, in - to my way of thinking a perfectly dreadful presidential election going on right now - this has all come out. This has all come out.And I'm a Reagan guy. As I said, I'm a - I want growth, I want happiness, I want optimism. That's what I want. And I believe that evidence shows - and not everyone's going to agree with that - but I believe two of the key factors for promoting economic growth and all the good that goes with that is, number one, the lowest possible margin tax rates, which generate incentives to work, save, invest and take risks. And number two, a sound dollar - a stable, reliable, sound dollar.And I want to just cite my former boss and still sometimes intellectual mentor, Mr. Volcker gave a brilliant speech to the Bretton Woods Committee. I believe, Paul, it was late 2014, correct me if I'm wrong. Many of us read this speech. He basically said: We need to go back to a rules-based monetary policy. And we need to go back to international currency cooperation. And I would simply tag onto that, lowest possible tax rate with the least deductions and complexities - I hate complexities. And you can add regulations to that and a lot of other things, but that's the heart of it.To be short and overgeneralize, as I love to do, I call it tax cuts and king dollar. And when that worked, when that worked in the '60s, the '80s, the '90s, it really worked. When it was broken down, that model broke in the '70s, in the 2000s, and continues. So that's what I'm saying. And the guy who originated that was not a Republican, was not Ronald Reagan, was not Arthur Laffer, was not Larry Kudlow. It was John F. Kennedy. And there's no reason why the Democratic Party, which is moving way to the left, cannot come back and think about JFK's legacy. There's no reason for that.MS. HELLER: I mean, that's your point, Democrats can be supply-sider's too, right?MR. KUDLOW: You betcha. You betcha. And I just want to add to that, what we need now - Barney Frank made a very important point. He had many good insights with respect to Paul Ryan and so forth, and his political situation. Ryan may be a guy who is willing to put legislation on the floor that might have been blocked in the past for partisan reasons. I happen to agree with that. The JFK tax cuts and the Reagan tax cuts were bipartisan tax cuts. And I think what this nation needs to get a rising tide that lifts all boats is bipartisan, pro-growth tax reform. That's what we need. I'm not seeing it, much to my regret.MS. HELLER: What do you think three weeks from now - is there any chance of that happening, whichever candidate comes to win?MR. KUDLOW: You know, I'm a perpetual optimist, OK? I'm not crazy about this election. But, yes, there's always a chance. There's always a chance. We are, I think, perilously close to another recession, unfortunately. In fact, one would argue the whole business sector is in a recession. Production, business investment, productivity, profits are all falling. We're only growing at 1, 2 percent. So perhaps people can reason and develop something. And this leads me to my very last point this afternoon. I thank you for your patience.I have become a - not have become - but I believe one of the things that United States needs besides king dollar and tax cuts is civility - civility. Our discourse must improve. And I think that the art of persuasion, politely, has been lost. I think JFK and Reagan were very good at that. I thought Bill Clinton could be very good at that. I don't like insults. I don't like underhanded this and that, name calling. I don't like any of that. This is about principles, not personalities. I thought Reagan was real good at that. I thought JFK, who really had to convert the Democratic Party, and I think Bill Clinton at his best was very good at that. I'm asking you for civility. Our disagreements aside, there are some things that will work and we should talk about them.And I just want to add finally, I don't know if he's left or not, my friend Barney Frank, I've debated many times on CNBC. We went up to Nantucket and had a wonderful debate this past summer. We disagree on many things. We do agree on some things. But we are civil. That's all I ask.MR.: So we had promised to extend this group therapy session to the audience. (Laughter.) So before we wrap up, I wanted to see if we have any questions from anybody out there, and if so please raise your hand right away.If not, Larry, actually, let me throw a quick question at you, because I know you can't speak for the guy around the corner in Trump Tower. But just to throw a similar question at you that Dave threw at Congressman Frank. Who would you expect to see, or like to see, in financial regulatory areas in a Trump administration?MR. KUDLOW: I don't want to go there. That's just way too hard.MR.: Who would be your - or who do you consider to be sort of leading Republican lights on some of these issues?MR. KUDLOW: Oh, well, gee, the party's got a bunch of smart people. I hate to name names. It puts me on a difficult position.MS. HELLER: We're all just together here. It's OK.MR. KUDLOW: Kudlow says this. I'm a big fan of former Federal Reserve Governor Kevin Warsh, who I think is a young man with tremendous financial ability. I've been pushing him for many years. On the more academic side, I'm a big fan of John Taylor, who has been a Council member, he's been undersecretary of the Treasury, he's an astute monetary analyst. There are a number of businessmen, and they're on Mr. Trump's committee. I just don't want to get into that. I cannot speak for the campaign, as you may know. I'm an informal advisor. I helped write his economic and tax cut plan, which if I do say so myself I thought was pretty darn good. (Laughter.) I just wish he'd use it. (Laughter.)MR.: All right. Well, thank you very much.

article name: The Republican Convention: Ivanka Trump Set for Tough Role --- Nominee's daughter is expected to use convention speech to help win over women
article text: Presidential nominee Donald Trump handed his daughter Ivanka one of the most visible -- and toughest -- jobs at this week's Republican National Convention.When Ms. Trump introduces her father before his prime-time speechon Thursday, her goal isn't only to show he is a warm family man but also to assert that he is a friend of women.Trump campaign advisers expect the 34-year-old Ms. Trump, a senior executive in the Trump real-estate empire and founder of her own fashion line, to provide the American public "living proof" her father believes women can and should do everything men do.Mr. Trump needs his daughter's help to make headway with women -- the largest voter bloc and one with which he has dismal ratings -- as he begins a general election campaign against the first female presidential nominee for either national party.Democratic presidential presumptive nominee Hillary Clinton leads Mr. Trump by 15 percentage points among women, a recent Street Journal/NBC News poll found. Mrs. Clinton had support from 52% of women in July, compared with 37% for Mr. Trump.In the same Wall Street Journal/NBC poll, he trails Mrs. Clinton by 7 percentage points among women age 50 and older, but by a whopping 25 points among women 18-49 years old.Ms. Trump is facing "a challenging task but also an opportunity," says Nick LaLota, a New York delegate from Suffolk County. One potential problem: Ms. Trump avoids touching political issues that Republicans crave. Unlike her brothers Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, who comfortably take on issues like gun rights and immigration, Ms. Trump never speaks as a political surrogate, only as a daughter and business colleague.Ms. Trump won't persuade those GOP women that will vote mainly on issues, one Republican strategist said. Still, she will be able to show how she thrived in the tough real-estate business her father created, said David DiPietro, New York assemblyman and convention delegate.Ms. Trump, considered the "first among equals" of Mr. Trump's five children, is often put in the spotlight. At rallies where her father can be brash and confrontational, she softens his edges with her poise and stories of his encouragement as a father and mentor.At the same time, Ms. Trump is very keen at reading him. For example, after Mr. Trump's devastating Ohio primary loss, she wanted to give him a boost by introducing him at his next rally in New York, even though it meant appearing just six days after giving birth to her third child.Mr. Trump values his daughter's opinions, even though she is a political novice with many liberal friends and fashion colleagues. She couldn't vote for her father in the closed New York Republican primary, because she is registered as an independent.An early suggestion by Ms. Trump to her father that he offer some support for Planned Parenthood -- with the exception of its abortion services -- reflected Democratic leanings and caused flak in the Republican primaries. However, that position could be useful going into the general election now that Mr. Trump needs to attract Democratic and independent voters.Credit: By Monica Langley

article name: The Republican Convention: Trump, Allies Step Up Fundraising Efforts
article text: Republican nominee Donald Trump and his allies are using this week's convention to escalate their fundraising efforts, holding meetings with major donors and readying to deploy Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, Mr. Trump's newly announced running mate, to help bolster their coffers.Mr. Pence this week has met with some top fundraisers for Mr. Trump's joint fund with the Republican National Committee, as they begin scheduling events for the running mate to headline around the country.Donors who had given at least $100,000 to the RNC or to its joint fund with Mr. Trump gathered at the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame on Wednesday evening, as they waited for Mr. Pence to address the convention. And Messrs. Pence and Trump are set to address hundreds of donors at a lunch Thursday.Meanwhile, in a sign that billionaire Sheldon Adelson may be getting closer to opening his wallet for Mr. Trump, the casino owner also met with Mr. Pence on Tuesday, according to a person familiar with the meeting. Mr. Adelson has said he might spend around $100 million on Mr. Trump's behalf, but recent Federal Election Commission records show he hasn't yet donated to the joint Trump-RNC fund, called Trump Victory.A spokesman for Mr. Adelson didn't return a request for comment on the meeting.A pro-Trump super PAC called Rebuilding America Now is also planning to deploy Mr. Pence to raise money. About 30 donors attended a fundraiser for the group Wednesday, during which Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort told attendees the campaign was "grateful" for the group's efforts, according to Alex Castellanos, an official at the super PAC.Credit: By Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: The Republican Convetion: Trump Divides GOP in Key Ohio County
article text: DELAWARE, OHIO -- The Republican Party headquarters in Ohio's Delaware County was missing some key signage in its window last week: anything showing support for Donald Trump.There were signs for Sen. Rob Portman of Ohio and for other local candidates, but nothing visible for Mr. Trump, who officially became the Republican presidential nominee on Tuesday. The Trump signs were purposely in the back of the office, out of view, the staff said.Sara Marie Brenner, Delaware County chairwoman for the Trump campaign, wasn't surprised."The only reason they have any signs at all is I dropped a few hundred off there," she said in a sarcastic tone.The spat over political signs at the party headquarters signals the deeper divisions among the Republicans here who could determine the outcome of the Nov. 8 presidential election.The Republican National Committee chose Cleveland in August 2014 to host its presidential nominating party to maximize the exposure of its then-unknown nominee to voters in Ohio. It was a choice driven by history as much as the future: No Republican has won the White House without winning Ohio.The location of Mr. Trump's official nomination is calling attention to the challenges he faces in November -- from overcoming OhioGov. John Kasich's opposition to his former GOP primary rival to winning a state where his key messages resonate in some areas and repel in others. Mr. Kasich won the state's GOP primary in March.A bit of good news for the nominee is that he starts the general election against Hillary Clinton, the presumptive Democratic nominee, in a dead heat here. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll last week showed them tied with Ohio registered voters at 39%.For Mr. Trump to prevail in Ohio this fall, he must win big in places like Delaware County, an affluent, growing Columbus suburb of 193,000, where Republicans outnumber Democrats more than 3 to 1. But Mr. Trump's success is far from assured.County Republicans, many of whom consider themselves moderates, gave Mr. Trump 22% of their vote in the primary. Mr. Trump's signature issues don't resonate in a place where immigrants are prized as nannies and construction workers, and where international trade plays almost no role in the county's economic success.The New York businessman's troubles in Delaware County reflect a broader problem: His tough rhetoric on trade and his history of controversy over race and religion turn off many traditional Republicans.Holly Quaine, president of the Delaware Area Chamber of Commerce, said she is wrestling with the choice and may decide not to pull the presidential lever at all."The inertia in Delaware County is to vote Republican," she said. "But with Trump, you have to stop and think. He's Donald Trump -- Kardashians, reality TV."Politically, the area's establishment leanings can be seen in its loyalty to Mr. Kasich, who represented Delaware County and other parts of metropolitan Columbus when he was in the House. Mr. Kasich won 64% of the county vote in the primary.Mr. Kasich has criticized Mr. Trump for running a "divisive campaign" and creating what he called a "toxic atmosphere." The governor hasn't endorsed Mr. Trump, and he doesn't have a speaking slot at the convention.Mr. Trump's message is primarily targeted at workers who have gotten a raw deal in the global economy, an appeal that has helped him make important inroads to working-class voters."Globalization has made the financial elite who donate to politicians very wealthy. But it has left millions of our workers with nothing but poverty and heartache," he said at a rally in late June.But many Republican strongholds consist of the financial elite. The median household income in Delaware County, for instance, is $91,000, about $40,000 above the national average, and 51% of the 25-and-older population has at least a bachelor's degree, 20 points above the national average.During the 2016 primary campaign, Mr. Trump didn't do particularly well in urban centers that are prospering economically.(See related article: "Candidate Faces Challenge Surpassing Romney" -- WSJ July 21, 2016)Credit: By Dante Chinni and Bob Davis

article name: Trump's Personal Crucible: His Tumultuous 1990s --- 'Terrible, horrible' stretch helped forge traits that propelled the businessman to the nomination
article text: Donald Trump's real-estate empire was on the brink of crumbling under $3.4 billion in debt. His soon-to-be-ex-wife Ivana was demanding $10 million. Walking down Manhattan's Fifth Avenue, he saw a blind man with a paper cup and realized the beggar's net worth was hundreds of millions more than his.Those trying times of the early 1990s would turn out to be Mr. Trump's personal crucible. He survived, and he said the searing experience helped forge the characteristics that propelled him to the Republican presidential nomination he will accept Thursday night.He learned, he said, to create an enduring public image of success in the face of failure, to trust his instincts and to get even. "You have to do what you have to do," Mr. Trump said, in an interview on Friday with The Wall Street Journal, about his hardball tactics then and now. "You have to play weak spots.""I had some banks that I was negotiating with that were fabulous people," he said. "I also had some very terrible people that I was dealing with, and had I not been more terrible than them, I might not be sitting here talking to you right now."Mr. Trump averted personal bankruptcy and rebuilt his fortune by figuring out that instead of overleveraging real estate, he could leverage his brand. Years before he put his name on campaign T-shirts and staged news conferences at his golf courses, he mined the value of stamping "Trump" on everything he owned, tying his surname to affluence.He lost some prized assets, and his shoot-from-the-hip style and penchant for litigation soured relationships. But he emerged as the Donald Trump who knew better than ever how to launch withering personal attacks on foes and take charge of his own image.Mr. Trump said the publicity surrounding his financial travails and his divorce took a toll on his eldest children, Donald Jr., Ivanka and Eric. Still, they have emerged as among his closest campaign advisers. "I think it made my children tougher," he said. "I think it also taught them to stick together."In his book "The Art of the Comeback," he called that time his "most brilliant period" because he performed under so much pressure.This week, as the party formally nominated Mr. Trump at the Republican convention in Cleveland, he took his place as the GOP standard bearer.Decades before he put his name into politics, Mr. Trump faced the first big test of his brand in Trump Tower, the 68-story Fifth Avenue development. Completed in 1983 soon after New York surfaced from a fiscal crisis, it was a success. "If there was a Trump building on the north corner and a non-Trump building on the south corner," said Louise Sunshine, a marketing expert who worked for Mr. Trump at the time, "we were going to prove that the Trump building was worth $1,000-a-square-foot more."His success at creating a luxury brand stemmed from building his own celebrity as much as Trump Tower's fine marble. With Ivana, a former model, by his side, he flaunted his flashy lifestyle and surrounded himself with the rich and famous.Soon, his name emblazoned most of his investments, including the Trump Shuttle and Atlantic City casinos such as the Trump Taj Mahal. "He borrowed like a sailor, loaded them up with too much debt, spent too much money," said Ben Berzin, Jr., who headed the workout division for Midlantic Bank, which lent Mr. Trump about $100 million by 1990.Mr. Trump acknowledged his business was "overleveraged" but blamed falling property values for his financial woes. By then, the U.S. economy was in a tailspin and Mr. Trump couldn't make debt payments."That was a terrible, horrible period," Mr. Trump said. "All of a sudden you're in this position, when the world is falling around you, and it could take you down."He was saved, in part, by his brand. Creditors restructured his debts over five years, partly because they recognized his property was worth more if the Trump name wasn't tarnished with personal bankruptcy. Wilbur Ross Jr., who represented bondholders for Trump Taj Mahal, which sought bankruptcy protection in 1991, saw the brand's value during one of his visits with Mr. Trump to the casino. "It was sort of a rock star thing," he recalled. The adulation "was much like the reception he is getting now."Mr. Trump's star power, and the "America First" message that roused an angry electorate, helped him draw more votes than any other Republican primary candidate in history despite a string of inaccurate statements, shifting positions and policy-knowledge gaps."He has created a remarkable personality who is bigger than life," said Jay Goldberg, one of Mr. Trump's lawyers in the 1990s. "No matter how many darts they throw at him, he is able to survive."In part, that is because Mr. Trump meets darts with bayonets. After stock analyst Marvin Roffman questioned the financial stability of the Taj Mahal in 1990, Mr. Trump threatened to sue. Mr. Roffman signed a written apology, then tried to retract it. He was fired that day. He sued and won $750,000 from his former employer and an undisclosed settlement with Mr. Trump. "I was attacking his brand," said Mr. Roffman, now retired, "and that's something Trump can't allow." Mr. Trump said it was appropriate for him to strike back at critics, including Mr. Roffman.Mr. Trump has shown similar vindictiveness in 2016, attacking critics and long-vanquished opponents and banning some media outlets from events. He has brought a $10 million claim against former adviser Sam Nunberg, arguing he breached a confidentiality agreement.Mr. Nunberg said in court papers Mr. Trump is seeking revenge because he first backed former rival Ted Cruz and was mistakenly pegged as the source of reports about an affair between staffers. Mr. Nunberg declined to comment on the dispute. Mr. Trump's campaign called Mr. Nunberg's claims "categorically false.""If you attack him or say anything that's negative," Ms. Sunshine said, "you can expect to get it back, double-barreled."In the 1990s, while banks reconfigured his loans, Mr. Trump sold his jet and yacht and was limited to $450,000 a month for personal and household expenses. His marriage to Ivana fell apart after news of his affair with Marla Maples, whom he wed in 1993.Mr. Trump kept pressing bankers to reduce his debt, claiming he wasn't able to pay. In public, he kept up his ritzy image. The wedding to Ms. Maples was a star-studded affair. Bankers were stunned when they saw Ms. Maples flashing an engagement ring from jeweler Harry Winston "that looked like a golf ball," said Alan Pomerantz, a lawyer at the time at Weil Gotshal & Manges who represented Citibank. "We said, 'Donald where did you get the money for this ring?' " he recalled. "He said, 'I didn't pay for it. It's a loaner.' "Mr. Trump, in the interview, said: "As a celebrity when you would go out in those days, the Harry Winstons of the world would give you jewelry for the night. So maybe they're talking about that." That marriage ended after six years in divorce.Mr. Trump didn't repay his personal debts to the bank group until 1995. But he proclaimed his comeback as early as 1992 to the media. That year, he told New Jersey gaming regulators his net worth was $437 million to $1.6 billion.His new business model: He could do deals without taking on more debt by selling his brand and marketing skills. It was a more conservative strategy that foreshadowed a bare-bones primary campaign relying more on free publicity than fundraising and staff. "Having built a great name and a great reputation and a great brand I guess was good," Mr. Trump said. "And I get very high ratings. . .That's a tremendous advantage. No politician ever had that."Mr. Trump's licensing strategy made its debut in the mid-1990s when General Electric Pension Trust and Galbreath Co. put his stamp on the conversion of the old Gulf & Western Building in Manhattan into a hotel and residential tower.He followed this model with condominium and hotel projects and licensed his name to businesses including clothes, steaks and mattresses. Some, including the Trump University real-estate school, collapsed.In "The Art of the Comeback," Mr. Trump described himself during this period as "Ranting and raving, cajoling, always selling, and generally having to be either the nicest person in the world or one of the worst."Abe Wallach, who worked as a senior aide to Mr. Trump for 12 years, recalls writing a speech for him to give pension-fund advisers. "He gets up to the podium and says: 'My guy wrote a speech. You don't want to hear it. You want to hear about Marla and what we're up to,'" a story reminiscent of Mr. Trump's freewheeling campaign addresses.Many of the banks that worked with him during the 1990s never gave him another loan. The burned bridges presaged the fights Mr. Trump would pick with the political establishment in the 2016 race.Mr. Trump, who said he was "tough" with the banks but didn't need their money, adopts the same attitude toward Republicans who haven't endorsed him. "Who are they going to pick?" Mr. Trump asked at a rally in Las Vegas in June. "I beat everybody. I beat the hell out of them."Credit: By Beth Reinhard and Peter Grant

article name: GOP Split as Cruz Snubs Trump
article text: CLEVELAND -- Sen. Ted Cruz refused to endorse Donald Trump on Wednesday night, leaving delegates at the Republican National Convention shouting angrily, and laying bare the rift between traditional conservatives and the populist candidate.In a dramatic prime-time address the day after Mr. Trump officially won the nomination, the Texas senator congratulated Mr. Trump by name for the victory and then never mentioned him again, drawing boos as he concluded his speech.The episode laid bare fissures that have complicated the Trump campaign's efforts to broaden his appeal and unify the party behind him before entering what's expected to be a brutal general election against Democrat Hillary Clinton.It came after the collapse on Monday of the stop-Trump movement that had spent months trying to upend Mr. Trump's nomination. While Mr. Cruz never directly participated in or blessed that campaign, it was orchestrated at every stage by his supporters.Mr. Cruz's prime speaking spot was offered to him -- the longest time allotment of any of Mr. Trump's GOP rivals -- to try to defuse the intraparty fight. The dramatic refusal by Mr. Cruz to fulfill the Republican candidates' pledge to back the primary victor, a man who insulted his family and offended his conservative principles, is likely to propel Mr. Cruz's standing among many movement advocates.Mr. Trump, on Twitter, reacted to Mr. Cruz's snub by saying, "wow, Ted Cruz got booed off the stage." The nominee said he'd learned two hours earlier that the senator wasn't going to endorse him, "but let him speak anyway."The closest Mr. Cruz came to an endorsement was a bland exhortation to vote. "Please, don't stay home in November," Mr. Cruz said. "Stand, and speak, and vote your conscience, vote for candidates up and down the ticket who you trust to defend our freedom and to be faithful to the Constitution."The crowd roared. But as Mr. Cruz wound down his speech and it became clear there was no forthcoming Trump endorsement, many in the crowd started chanting, "Trump, Trump, Trump!" Others started booing the Texan. Entire sections shook their heads in disappointment.Mr. Trump created his own distraction toward the end of Mr. Cruz's speech. Knowing Mr. Cruz had no plans to back him, he stepped into view, drawing the sights of cameras across the arena, as the Texan concluded his remarks."Sore loser," Joe Mathis, a 68-year-old delegate from Alaska said of Mr. Cruz, as he leaned over to the woman seated next to him. "Ted Cruz had a chance to bring the party together," he said. "It's a shame. It didn't help the party."Mr. Cruz's speech brought furious criticism from some of Mr. Trump's big supporters. Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee called it a "betrayal" on Facebook. Retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn, on Twitter, said, "tonight Ted Cruz demonstrated he is willing to place self before country."New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, on ABC television, called the speech "awful" and "selfish."Former Florida Sen. George LeMieux, who backed Mr. Trump's defeated rivals Jeb Bush and Sen. Marco Rubio before endorsing Mr. Trump, said Mr. Cruz should have offered an endorsement."It's amazing to me that Ted Cruz would come to Donald Trump's convention and be given the privilege of speaking and not endorse him," Mr. LeMieux said. "He really hurt himself tonight with the grass roots."Mr. Cruz's refusal to back Mr. Trump comes 10 weeks after the end of a bitter primary battle between the two, in which Mr. Trump christened him "Lyin' Ted," mocked his wife's appearance and accused Mr. Cruz's father of having complicity in the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.Before he suspended his campaign in May, Mr. Cruz slammed Mr. Trump as a "pathological liar." Neither man has recanted their description of the other.While Mr. Trump's supporters have called for the GOP to unite behind him, Mr. Cruz told the convention hall that the onus is on Mr. Trump to do the uniting."We deserve leaders who stand for principle," he said. "Unite us all behind shared values. Cast aside anger for love. That is the standard we should expect, from everybody."Mr. Cruz's remarks marked the convention's most electric moment, calling for the Republican Party to adhere to his brand of conservative values -- an implicit criticism of Mr. Trump's populism.The Texas senator's rebuke of the party's nominee came after Mr. Trump's aides spent recent days hinting to reporters that they should expect Mr. Cruz to finally endorse Mr. Trump.Wednesday night's scene left the two men no closer to an endorsement, even though many of Mr. Cruz's supporters are now backing the nominee. Several delegates on the convention floor held signs that read "Cruz delegate for Trump."Matt Schultz, the former Iowa secretary of state who was the chairman of Mr. Cruz's Iowa campaign, said he is backing Mr. Trump and expects most of the Cruz coalition to do so, too, eventually.---Ben Kesling and Beth Reinhard contributed to this article.(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Cruz, Honor, Unity and the Fragmented GOP" -- WSJ July 25, 2016)Credit: By Reid J. Epstein

article name: Trump Makes His Case --- GOP Hopes to Blaze New Trail to Victory
article text: Corrections & AmplificationsJeff Roe was the campaign manager for Texas Sen. Ted Cruz's presidential bid. A Page One article Friday about Donald Trump's strategy for the fall election incorrectly said Mr. Roe was Mr. Cruz's pollster.(WSJ July 27, 2016)CLEVELAND -- Republican Donald Trump's fall campaign will test whether the most unconventional major-party presidential nominee in generations can cut an unconventional path to the White House.He aims to outmaneuver Democratic rival Hillary Clinton by capturing a handful of states in the Rust Belt and the Northeast that typically favor Democrats, with an appeal to less-educated, working-class voters.But the New York businessman leaves the convention here with the most negative public image of any nominee in modern history, particularly among minority voters, according to recent polls, and with many Republicans still hesitant to accept him as their standard bearer.Those headwinds to winning the 270 electoral votes needed to claim the presidency are particularly strong in some of the country's more racially and ethnically diverse swing states, polling shows, including Colorado and Virginia, where Mrs. Clinton leads.Her image, though, is nearly as tarnished as Mr. Trump's, and the convention here made it clear that Republicans want to make her the focus of the race. Most of the speakers dwelled on her perceived failings, often to chants of "lock her up.""In addition, the landscape could change drastically before Election Day, when the conventions will be a distant memory and Mr. Trump will have squared off with Mrs. Clinton in three fall debates. Republican George H.W. Bush, for example, surged past Michael Dukakis in the fall of 1988.Advisers to Mr. Trump point to Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin as states where he can outperform past GOP nominees, though the three states haven't voted Republican in a presidential race since at least 1988.His team is casting an even wider net, suggesting that Mr. Trump can compete in the solidly blue states of Connecticut, New Jersey and Oregon. "I'm not saying we're going to win, but we're going to put them into play," said Donald Trump Jr., one of the candidate's sons, at a breakfast this week hosted by the The Wall Street Journal.From the campaign's outset, the Electoral College math has favored Democrats, with Mr. Trump needing to win 64 more electoral votes than Republican Mitt Romney won in 2012.Still, when the race began last year, the political environment seemed to be tipping in Republicans' favor. Voters were eager for change, and it had been more than a decade since the share of Americans who thought the country was on the right track outpaced those who thought it was on the wrong track.That hasn't changed, and yet Mrs. Clinton still leads nationally, according to Wall Street Journal/NBC News polling throughout this year.The early polling doesn't paint a rosy scenario for Mr. Trump in traditional battlegrounds. Mrs. Clinton leads all seven states for which Real Clear Politics has aggregated polling. She also outpaced Mr. Trump in six of the seven states where the Journal, NBC News and Marist surveyed voters. That included Florida, the nation's largest swing state. The two were tied in Ohio, which is hosting the GOP convention."This should be a very close race, with a slight edge to the Republicans," said Democratic pollster Mark Mellman. "It's the first time we've had two candidates this disliked, but what matters is the difference between them -- he's more disliked than she is."Overall, the 2016 White House race has revealed the same stark racial and educational divide that defined the electorate four years ago. Mrs. Clinton's leads among African-Americans and Hispanics resemble President Barack Obama's support in 2012, while Mr. Trump leads by 14 percentage points among whites. Mr. Romney won white voters by 20 percentage points in 2012, according to exit polls.Mr. Trump notched a sizable 55%-33% lead among white voters who don't have four-year college degrees, according to July's Journal/NBC News survey. But he essentially tied Mrs. Clinton in the poll among white voters who do have degrees. Republicans tend to run stronger with these voters. The split along lines of educational attainment is a big reason Mr. Trump is outpacing earlier GOP candidates in whiter, working-class communities, pollsters say, and why Mrs. Clinton is doing better in well-educated suburbs."Trump has made the party more the party of the worker," said GOP pollster Kellyanne Conway, who recently joined his campaign, at an event sponsored by the Atlantic.There are some bright spots for the Republican in many of the states Mr. Trump needs to win in November.Jeff Roe, the pollster for Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, identified bellwether counties in seven battlegrounds that have correctly predicted the statewide outcome in each of the last four elections. Entering the convention, Mr. Trump had the lead in six -- in Florida, North Carolina, Colorado, Nevada, Ohio and Pennsylvania. Mrs. Clinton posted her only advantage in Loudon County, Va.Mr. Trump spent far less than his Republican rivals to win the primary, and he may have to defy convention again to have a good shot at winning the general election, given the large sums that presidential candidates have spent to win.The Republican ended June with $20 million in the bank, according to Federal Election Commission data, after raising $26 million for his campaign and $32 million for the party. Mrs. Clinton ended the month with $44 million in the bank, having raised $40 million in June for her campaign and $81 million for the party.That financial advantage has translated into a big edge in television advertising. Since May 1, the Clinton campaign has spent more than $31 million on TV ads in nine states, according to Kantar Media. The Trump campaign hadn't spent a dime in that period.Given both candidates' uniquely negative images, operatives in both parties are already predicting historically low turnout, increasing the importance of party unity for both candidates. Mr. Trump may still have work to do after a nasty spat with GOP rival Mr. Cruz."It does matter, if you don't have unity for a party coming out of a convention," said Chris Wilson, a pollster for Mr. Cruz, who was booed Wednesday night for refusing to endorse the nominee. "That's a big problem we have."Credit: By Patrick O'Connor

article name: Trump Makes His Case --- Fiery Speech Targets Democratic Rival
article text: Donald Trump ended his party's convention Thursday the way he began his history-making campaign: attacking the political establishment, playing to voters' fears of foreigners and crime, and making bold promises to fix America's ills."I have joined the political arena so that the powerful can no longer beat up on people who cannot defend themselves," said the first-time politician whose populist message helped him capture the Republican presidential nomination.The speech, which ran more than an hour, painted a grim view of the U.S. economy and world affairs under President Barack Obama, and intensified the attack the record of his rival Hillary Clinton."This is the legacy of Hillary Clinton: death, destruction, terrorism and weakness," he said.He returned to familiar campaign themes of opposing international trade deals and cracking down on illegal immigration. He drew strong applause when he reiterated his desire to ban immigrants from nations "compromised by terrorism," and departed from his prepared text to say, "We don't want them in our country."He homed in on Mrs. Clinton, the one issue sure to galvanize Republicans in November. Arguing that her tenure as secretary of state under Mr. Obama fomented instability abroad, he said, "America is far less safe -- and the world is far less stable -- than when Obama made the decision to put Hillary Clinton in charge of America's foreign policy," he said. "I am certain it is a decision President Barack Obama truly regrets."Mr. Trump's speech was the capstone of a tumultuous convention that exposed some of the risks he faces as he takes his unorthodox campaign into a general election campaign against Democratic rival Hillary Clinton's well-funded and well-oiled machine.Mr. Trump presented himself as uniquely equipped to lead the nation."Nobody knows the system better than me, which is why I alone can fix it," he said.Citing recent episodes of gun violence and attacks on police officers, he put fresh emphasis on law and order."Beginning on January 20th of 2017, safety will be restored," he said. "The first task for our new administration will be to liberate our citizens from the crime and terrorism and lawlessness that threaten our communities."Mr. Trump's message has been honed before oversize crowds on the primary campaign trail. It's less clear how it will play in a tough general election ahead with a broader audience of swing voters. Testing that was one of the chief convention goals, along with trying to unite the party and broaden Mr. Trump's personal profile.The stakes for Mr. Trump's speech rose in the wake of the missteps that marred the first days of the convention: the repeated passages in Melania Trump's speech from one delivered eight years earlier by Michelle Obama, a divisive fight over convention rules, and the chaos that erupted after Texas Sen. Ted Cruz's refused to endorse Mr. Trump during a prime-time address Wednesday."If you can't run a convention, how is he going to run a State Department, or the Pentagon?" said Rick Tyler, former aide to the Cruz presidential campaign. "The dominant message coming out of the convention is 'You may not like Donald Trump, but he is not Hillary Clinton.' If that's the dominant message, we've already lost."Trump allies dismiss the long-term significance of the tumult surrounding Mr. Cruz's actions, saying the nominee may have been strengthened because of the backlash against the Texas senator. "The person who shrinks after last night is Cruz not Trump," said former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, who said the choice of Indiana Gov. Mike Pence as Trump's running mate should help build bridges to disaffected conservatives.Gabriel N. Schwartz, a Trump supporter from Colorado, said he was confident that most Cruz dissidents are in the minority of the party and that Republicans will come around to vote Trump in November. "What the convention doesn't do to unify the GOP, Hillary Clinton will,"" he said.The Trump campaign used the GOP convention to showcase his family, which is considered one of his biggest assets -- and a potential antidote to one of his biggest political liabilities as he scores particularly low with women voters.The latest Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll found that among suburban women, a key swing voting bloc, 66% say they would be pessimistic or uncertain if he were elected president; among independents, it is 73%.His wife, sons and daughters all tried to present a softer image of Mr. Trump. And the appearance of his eldest daughter on the final night was intended to signal to young women that the businessman wants everyone to succeed.In her introduction of her father, Ivanka Trump sought to counter suggestions that he is a sexist, saying that he believes in wage equality and that there are more female than male executives in his company. "He hires the best person for the job. Period," said Ms. Trump.Yet the speeches by the Trump family offered only brief testimonials to their father's personal attributes before launching into themes that echoed his addresses at rallies.Mr. Trump has relied heavily on his family as advisers and surrogates; Mr. Gingrich and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie are Mr. Trump's most reliable outside advisers. But if their speeches are any indication, most of the party's heavy hitters are less inclined to make a robust case for Mr. Trump than they are to make the case against Mrs. Clinton.House Speaker Paul Ryan devoted more time to advancing his conservative vision for the party than to promoting Mr. Trump's virtues. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell mentioned Mr. Trump just five times and Mrs. Clinton more than a dozen times.---Beth Reinhard contributed to this article.Credit: By Janet Hook and Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: The Republican Convention: NATO Responds to Trump
article text: WASHINGTON -- The head of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization took the unusual step of wading into the U.S. presidential campaign on Thursday after Republican nominee Donald Trump rekindled a foreign policy debate by saying the U.S. may not come to the aid of alliance members if they are attacked by Russia."I will not interfere in the U.S. election campaign, but what I can do is say what matters for NATO," NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said. "Solidarity among allies is a key value for NATO."Without mentioning Mr. Trump by name, Mr. Stoltenberg said alliance members "defend one another."Article 5 of the 1949 treaty that established NATO stipulates that an attack on one member represents an attack on all and requires the alliance to come to the defense of any country attacked.Mr. Trump's campaign didn't respond Thursday to a request for comment.In an interview with the New York Times, Mr. Trump questioned the collective defense provisions of the NATO treaty on monetary grounds, saying that many members weren't paying their fair share. He told the newspaper that if Russia attacked the Baltic States, which are NATO members, he would decide whether to defend them only after reviewing "if they have fulfilled their obligations to us."Such a change in policy would put the alliance into question and fundamentally rewrite the rules of European security that have been in place since the end of World War II.Mr. Trump's campaign didn't respond Thursday to a request for comment.The White House said that President Barack Obama has an "ironclad" commitment to NATO allies. "There should be no mistake or miscalculation made about this country's commitment to our trans-Atlantic alliance," said Josh Earnest, Mr. Obama's spokesman.Mr. Trump's comments prompted an outcry from politicians and policy experts on both sides of the aisle, who warned that the U.S. couldn't go back on its word."Statements like these make the world more dangerous and the U.S. less safe," Sen. Lindsey Graham (R., S.C.) said in a statement, adding they would make Russian President Vladimir Putin "a very happy man."Sen. Ben Sasse (R., Neb.), a critic of Mr. Trump, said the U.S. stands with its allies in NATO. "Our friends should draw strength and our adversaries should take pause from this simple fact: Americans keep our word," he said.At the Republican National Convention in Cleveland, some lawmakers who said they plan to vote for Mr. Trump criticized his comments on NATO, including Rep. Bill Huizenga (R., Mich.)."I wholeheartedly reject that," he said. "We have a treaty, we have an obligation."A senior policy adviser to Hillary Clinton, the presumptive Democratic nominee, said Mr. Trump's comments on NATO show he is "temperamentally unfit and fundamentally ill-prepared to be our commander-in-chief."---Julian E. Barnes in Brussels, Damian Paletta in Washington and Kristina Peterson in Cleveland contributed to this article.Credit: By Paul Sonne

article name: Disputed Bench Reappears in Trump Lobby
article text: Donald J. Trump's bench is back in the public lobby at Trump Tower.The bench has long been a point of friction between Mr. Trump and the government in New York City.Mr. Trump faced an aggravated-building-code violation and $10,000 fine for removing the bench without permission from a public space in the 58-story Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue at East 56th Street.But in the past few weeks, while Mr. Trump prepared for the Republican National Convention, workers bolted four 6-foot metal benches side-by-side in a marble floor of the Trump Tower lobby."It is not too bad, but not too comfortable," said Gisela Skrzypnik, a dentist from Berlin visiting New York, as she sat with a friend on one of the metal benches on Thursday. "It is like a bench you would sit on waiting for a train."Michael Cohen, special counsel to Mr. Trump, said in an email that he was at the Republican convention and wasn't immediately available to comment on the bench. In the past he has said the building was in "full compliance" with all applicable statutes.The metal benches replace a 22-foot stone bench that was installed when the building opened in the early 1980s but was later removed.The original bench was required under a deal between the city and Mr. Trump in which he agreed to create a 6,626-square-foot public space, in the lobby and lower level, in exchange for the right to put up a bigger building.The new bench replaced a 40-foot-long sales counter that sold Trump-branded merchandise, and more recently accepted campaign contributions and sold hats with Mr. Trump's campaign slogan, "Make America Great Again."In February, a hearing officer found that the sales counter, and a second one across the lobby, violated terms of Mr. Trump's agreement with the city, and fined his company, Trump Tower Commercial LLC, $4,000.When the counters weren't quickly removed, a building inspector issued a second violation. In June, Mr. Trump's staff told the city that the violation was fixed, but an inspector found that the sales counters had been removed and the bench not replaced.The dispute over the bench goes back years. In 1984, soon after the building opened, plants were placed on the stone bench, blocking it from use as a sitting space. When the city planning commission asked about the space, Mr. Trump said the bench was used in large numbers by "drug addicts, vagrants, etc."Credit: By Josh Barbanel

article name: Trump-Branded Project Developer in Austin Seeks to Tap Immigrant Visa Program; EB-5 program grants U.S. green cards to foreigners in exchange for investment in U.S. businesses
article text: The Trump Organization is partnering with a developer on a Texas hotel project that seeks to tap a controversial program granting green cards to foreigners who invest in the U.S.The federal EB-5 program gives up to 10,000 green cards a year to foreigners who invest at least $500,000 in U.S. businesses deemed to create at least 10 American jobs per investor.The Republican presidential nominee's company is lending the Trump name to the 33-story luxury hotel and condominium development in downtown Austin, while its partner, Global Management Resources, would take charge of the construction, according to marketing materials reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.The developer is marketing the project in China, according to the materials.Donald Trump has made tighter immigration control a pillar of his presidential campaign. He has also criticized China's trade and financial policies, blaming them for economic woes at home."Our growth strategy is to expand the Trump Hotels portfolio by strategically opening properties in key U.S. and international locations," said a representative for Trump Hotels, part of the Trump Organization.The representative said the company hasn't invested its own capital in the Austin project, but remains interested in the market from a brand and management standpoint.Global Management executives didn't respond to a request for comment.The EB-5 program was created in 1990, and for much of its history was used by only a few hundred investors a year. But since 2008, real-estate developers have flocked to it as a form of low-cost loans for projects. Because many foreign investors are motivated primarily by the prospect of a green card--not the financial investment--they tend to accept below-market interest rates, meaning big savings for developers. A large majority of those investors in recent years have hailed from China, typically accounting for more than 80% of EB-5 visas.At least $8.7 billion has been invested in the U.S. economy through the program since Oct. 1, 2012, and an estimated 35,140 jobs have been created for U.S. workers through foreign investment via EB-5, according to the Immigrant Investor Program Office at U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services.While some in Congress have criticized the program's premise--giving green cards to wealthy investors--other issues also have cast a cloud over the program in recent years. Some developers and middlemen who have raised money through the program have been alleged to be involved in fraudulent schemes.The program also has become dominated by developers of projects in wealthy neighborhoods who are using a provision meant to aid economically ailing ones.A study released Wednesday by the U.S. Government Accountability Office found that just 12% of investment went to projects located in a census tract with an unemployment rate of at least 8%, even though those projects benefited from a provision earmarked for high-unemployment areas. A large chunk--36%--was for projects in a tract with an unemployment rate of 4% or lower.The program is due to expire in December, and lawmakers are clashing over proposed changes.The entity pooling the EB-5 money for the $170 million Trump-branded hotel, Renewable Texas Energy Regional Center LLC, is seeking $40 million from 80 EB-5 investors. The center estimated the project will create 1,427 direct and indirect jobs.The hotel will have 255 rooms and 22 condominium units and an outdoor rooftop terrace. It is a five-minute walk to Austin's 6th Street entertainment district. Trump Hotels will manage the property, according to documents on the center's website.While Mr. Trump has run for president, his company has continued to find new business opportunities around the world. In recent years, most of Mr. Trump's real-estate deals have been branding agreements in which he has licensed his name to others but hasn't taken any of the financial risk.Exceptions include the Trump International Hotel, which opened recently in a converted Post Office building in Washington, D.C.Another Trump-branded project has applied for EB-5 funding: an apartment tower in Jersey City, N.J., being developed by Kushner Cos. and KABR Group. The chief executive of Kushner is Jared Kushner, who is married to Mr. Trump's daughter, Ivanka.Josh Chin and Eliot Brown contributed to this article.Write to Esther Fung at esther.fung@wsj.com and Peter Grant at peter.grant@wsj.comRelated* EB-5 Program Benefits Rich Neighborhoods More, Study Shows* Senators Say EB-5 Visas Should Be Fixed--or Deep-SixedCredit: By Esther Fung and Peter Grant

article name: Forget Drinking Games: The Final Presidential Debate Calls for Yoga; A guide to keeping calm once Clinton and Trump take the stage in Las Vegas
article text: No matter whether you lean blue or red, the first and second presidential debates were stomach-churning experiences. The decline of civil discourse, the low popularity ratings of both candidates and the general feeling of gloom for U.S. democracy settled over living rooms, bars and Facebook comment threads.Some viewers deal with debates using drinking games. We suggest a healthier alternative for Wednesday's third and final debate : yoga.(Follow the Journal's live analysis of the final presidential debate.)These poses, designed to keep you facing the TV, will help you cope with every interruption, accusation and revelation. Take it slowly, and don't forget to breathe.The Everlasting EmailLie facedown with the tops of your feet on the floor and palms down with bent elbows. Push the floor away until your arms are straight and your upper body is off the floor.Strike this pose when someone brings up Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server while Secretary of State. It won't remove all traces of anxiety, but it might help.The Big DeductionLie facedown with legs side by side. Place your forearms on the floor parallel to each other with elbows under your shoulders.Hold the position for as long as it takes to explain all the perfectly legal ways to rack up millions of dollars in tax deductions . Or until your arms give out.The Locker-Room PushbackStand upright, arms reaching to the sky, then tilt forward at the waist and extend your right leg backward while balancing on your left leg.Strike this pose when someone brings up Donald Trump's lewd comments about women in a leaked video, which he described as "locker-room talk." Side benefit of this pose: You can use your arms to cover your ears.The Secret SpeechFrom a standing position, raise your arms then exhale and bend your knees until thighs are parallel to the floor.Hold this pose as long as possible when someone asks how Hillary Clinton's paid talks to Wall Street bankers square with her appeals to the working class.Anguished ElephantStart on your hands and knees with your back flat. As you slowly inhale, let your belly drop while tilting your chest toward the ceiling. Exhale, and let your back rise until it's flat again.Repeat as many times as Donald Trump says "rigged."Downward DonkeyStart on hands and knees with a flat back.
