Through a spokeswoman, Mr. Trump said Tuesday Mr. Bollenbach had "a brilliant financial mind."Mr. Bollenbach returned to Marriott as chief financial officer in the early 1990s and found its stock price was weighed down because real-estate holdings were out of favor. His solution was to divide the company into two: Marriott International Inc., a high-growth hotel operator, and Host Marriott Corp., a debt-laden real-estate company. That led to downgrades of bonds and resulted in litigation, but Mr. Bollenbach, who became CEO of Host Marriott, prevailed in court.Mr. Bollenbach disliked making presentations to investors and often considered them a waste of time. As CEO of Host Marriott, the new real-estate company, he went on a roadshow to meet investors and made a stop at a financial firm in Philadelphia, where only a junior chemical analyst was available to hear the pitch.Afterward, an investment banker who had arranged the visit began apologizing. Mr. Bollenbach shushed him, and they returned to a limousine in silence. Mr. Bollenbach spotted a cheese-steak peddler and rolled down the window to ask whether he might want to buy any Host Marriott securities. The peddler was baffled. Mr. Bollenbach told the banker he had a better chance of selling securities to the cheese-steak vendor than the institution just visited.Disney recruited him in 1995 as chief financial officer under CEO Michael Eisner. Mr. Bollenbach helped persuade Mr. Eisner to pay $19 billion for Capital Cities/ABC Inc., the second-largest U.S. acquisition ever at that time. ("Without him, I would never have the courage to take on this much debt," Mr. Eisner said.) The Disney chief then hired the talent agent Michael Ovitz as president. That seemed to dilute Mr. Bollenbach's clout at Disney. Barron Hilton, son of the hotel company's founder, swooped in to hire Mr. Bollenbach as CEO of Hilton Hotels in 1996.When he arrived, Hilton had a strong brand but was "just sort of plodding along," said Marc Grossman, who was a senior vice president at the hotel company. Within a week, Mr. Bollenbach presented a plan including purchases of casinos and hotels and wringing more value out of the Hilton brand. "What we really had lacked was a clear, concise, achievable story and strategy, and here it was," Mr. Grossman said.Mr. Bollenbach bought the gambling company Bally Entertainment Corp. to give Hilton more scale in casinos, and later spun off the gaming operations. In 1997, Mr. Bollenbach tried to buy ITT Corp., owner of the Sheraton hotel brand, but he was outbid by Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc. The battle got ugly, and at one point Mr. Bollenbach called ITT's CEO, Rand Araskog, a "weenie." When Starwood prevailed, Mr. Bollenbach played down his disappointment. "It's not as bad as when I stub my toe in the backyard," he said.He went on to make what colleagues say was a better deal, buying Promus Hotel Corp., giving Hilton a broader range of brands, including Hampton Inn. In 2007, Blackstone Group LP bought Hilton for $20 billion, and Mr. Bollenbach retired. He held board seats at companies including American International Group Inc. and Mondelez International Inc.In his spare time, Mr. Bollenbach drove sports cars including a Porsche 911 Turbo S and Ferrari Testarossa. He skied well, played golf poorly, collected wine and studied Civil War history. A family education fund he established provides scholarships.He is survived by his wife, Kimberly, whom he married in 2011, as well as two sons and two grandchildren from a previous marriage.Write to James R. Hagerty at bob.hagerty@wsj.comCredit: By James R. Hagerty

article name: The Media Do Scarlett; Trump's election threat is dumb, but the outrage is over the top.
article text: Quick, someone get the smelling salts for the media. Ever since that dastardly Donald Trump told Chris Wallace, "I'll keep you in suspense" about recognizing the election result, we haven't seen so much swooning and fainting since Scarlett O'Hara in "Gone With the Wind."Starting with the 2000 election, it became Democratic writ that election outcomes could be questioned and contested. To this day many Democrats have convinced themselves, via repetition, that George W. Bush stole the 2000 election in Florida.In fact, Mr. Bush won the original count and the mandatory mini-recount. Virtually all serious attempts to finalize the Florida vote came to the same conclusion. Mr. Bush won. It was Al Gore who pushed the result into the courts of Florida in an effort to have the initial result overturned. Finally, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that enough was enough.The Florida recount fight made for great melodrama, but it was a media circus, and a destructive one. The partisan divide created by that sensational event is responsible in part for the divisions that endure to this day.Four years later, Democrats again argued extensively that George Bush stole the election from John Kerry because the President's campaign surrogates engineered the vote in Ohio against John Kerry. Mr. Kerry conceded the election, and it must be noted that he kept his own qualms private for many years.Both parties have since created a cottage industry dedicated to bird-dogging future election results in precincts around the country. And that's fine. Keep the politicians honest.Now comes Donald Trump, with his usual rank amateur flair, suggesting that if he loses it will be because the entire U.S. electoral system--presumably encompassing all 50 states--was fixed against him. As always, it fell to post-debate surrogates to make the distinctions he himself is incapable of making between discrete events--Illinois in 1960, Florida in 2000--and the legitimacy of the entire system.For failing to make any such distinction, Mr. Trump once again reaps a media whirlwind that blows his candidacy off Hillary Clinton's manifest vulnerabilities.None of that excuses the American media's faux fainting spell over this episode. We know that the normal cynicism of the media class hasn't been displaced by an endemic naivete about politics. The extraordinary overweighting of Mr. Trump's ham-handed and self-defeating remark will only feed the widespread public impression that the media are trying to preordain the election's outcome.

article name: The Democratic Convention: Candidates Clash Over Foreign Policy --- An issue-by-issue look at how Clinton and Trump would deal with allies and foes
article text: The next U.S. president will confront a deeply unsettled world, with the Middle East in turmoil, Europe struggling to contain an outbreak of terror attacks and Russia expanding its influence. Here's a look at where the two presidential nominees, Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton, stand on a few key foreign-policy challenges.RussiaUnder President Vladimir Putin, Russia has sought to expand its power and international clout, often in ways that have heightened tensions with the U.S. Russian hackers have penetrated computer networks all over the world, including in the U.S. Russia has also threatened its neighbors in recent years.Mr. Trump has floated the idea of creating a new alliance with Russia, saying a reset of relations is necessary to help ease tensions in Syria and elsewhere. Mr. Putin has said complimentary things about Mr. Trump, leading some to suggest a close bond between them, which Mr. Trump has denied. This week, he invited Russia to unearth some of Mrs. Clinton's emails from her time as secretary of state, a statement alarming lawmakers from both political parties.Mrs. Clinton has called Mr. Putin a "bully," and has described the relationship between the U.S. and Russia as complicated. As secretary of state, she worked to broker more cooperation between the two countries, posing in 2009 with Mr. Putin for a photo-op in which they pushed a big, red "reset" button. By the end of her tenure, she warned in a memo to President Barack Obama that relations with Russia had hit a low point and the "reset" in relations was over, according to people who saw the document.NATOU.S. relations with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization mark one of the biggest differences between the two, with Mr. Trump saying the U.S. is paying too much to keep the alliance afloat, and Mrs. Clinton portraying it as vital to U.S. interests in Europe.Mr. Trump wants allies within NATO to pay more for the overall protection of Europe. He has suggested the U.S. might leave the alliance if that doesn't happen during a Trump presidency. He also said NATO was obsolete and had to shift its focus away from Russian deterrence and more toward dealing with terrorism and migration flows.Mrs. Clinton says that leaving NATO would only embolden Moscow. She has praised the existence of the alliance and said the U.S. should do more to strengthen allies, particularly against Russian aggression. She has said that NATO allies rallied to the U.S.'s aid after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks, and that the U.S. should be prepared to do the same.Islamic StateThe rise of the terror network Islamic State since 2013 has reshaped how the U.S. and other countries view Muslims and confront terror. It has also opened sharp divides between the candidates.Mr. Trump has said he won't give a fully detailed plan to defeat Islamic State, also known as ISIS, because it would take away the element of surprise. But he has said he would "bomb the shit" out of the group's oil operations. He said it could take 30,000 U.S. troops to defeat ISIS in the Middle East, but he hasn't committed to deploying a force of that size. To deal with suspected terrorists, he has proposed changing international rules that forbid the military's use of torture.Mrs. Clinton has said Sunni Muslims and Kurdish forces should play a bigger role in combating ISIS, and has also called for expanding U.S. airstrikes in Iraq and Syria to defeat the terror network. She has called for combating Islamic State's ability to use social media to recruit, train, and plan attacks, urging more cooperation from tech firms.ImmigrationImmigration has emerged as one of the most divisive issues of the 2016 campaign, with Republicans reversing course from an earlier push to enact a bipartisan overhaul of immigration rules. The focus has shifted in recent months to immigration rules for people fleeing places like Syria and other unstable regimes in the Middle East.Mr. Trump has called for building a roughly 1,000 mile wall, financed by Mexico, to secure the U.S.'s southern border. He has said the threats posed by Islamic extremists are too dangerous and that stark new measures must be put in place to bar entry to Muslims from certain countries. He has called for ending "birthright citizenship," which is the legal process for granting citizenship to anyone born in the U.S.Mrs. Clinton has said banning the entry of Muslims into the U.S. -- even the proposal of it -- will alienate Muslim allies in the Middle East and harm U.S. relations.She has called for a comprehensive immigration overhaul, including a pathway to citizenship for those in the U.S. illegally, aside from violent criminals.Credit: By Damian Paletta

article name: Clinton Makes Her Pitch --- Nominee to Take On Trump in Rust Belt
article text: PHILADELPHIA -- Hillary Clinton's first order of business after the Democratic convention is a bus trip in the battlegrounds of Pennsylvania and Ohio, the opening move in a strategy to defend her party's grip on states President Barack Obama won and to brand her rival as unfit to be president.It shows a campaign eager to close off a likely effort by Donald Trump, her Republican opponent, to build an Electoral College majority by winning working-class, white voters in the Rust Belt and other slowly diversifying states. Democrats hope to capitalize on a convention that has drawn stronger television ratings so far than those for the Republican convention last week.Initially viewing Mr. Trump as possibly the weakest general-election candidate in the Republican primary field, Mrs. Clinton's allies now accept that the campaign will be a slog. Polling shows the two candidates are running about even in the popular vote."I fully expect this to be a close and competitive election all the way through the end," said Geoff Garin, a pollster and strategist in Mrs. Clinton's 2008 presidential campaign.Mrs. Clinton has used the convention to address a basic vulnerability: Voters largely don't trust or like her. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll this month showed that 20% of Democrats have a negative view of her -- a higher number than for any Democratic nominee in the last quarter-century.A string of convention speakers from her husband, former President Bill Clinton, to President Barack Obama, told stories during the convention meant to show a warmer, more empathetic face of the former secretary of state, senator and first lady.As Mrs. Clinton tries to make an affirmative case for herself, another clear goal of the Clinton campaign is to undercut Mr. Trump, who himself is viewed negatively by a majority of voters, by raising concerns that he is so temperamentally unstable he can't be trusted with the nuclear codes.John Podesta, the Clinton campaign chairman, told reporters this week that the way to win is to demonstrate Mr. Trump is "unfit, that he's unprepared and that we can't put him in the Oval Office." He added: "That's the core of our strategy."Republicans counter Mrs. Clinton's persona is a liability. Michael Steele, a former Republican National Committee chairman, said in an interview: "This is not an election about policy and ideology. It's an election about, 'What do I think of you as a leader.' She has a lot of qualifications, but they just don't trust her or like her. That's hard" to overcome.Mr. Trump's campaign didn't immediately respond to requests for comment.Clinton aides are looking at the electoral map in granular detail to plot the best path to 270 electoral votes. It's no accident that Mrs. Clinton is planning a trip on Monday to Omaha. Under Nebraska's unusual system, candidates can pick up Electoral College votes by winning specific congressional districts. Mr. Obama picked up one electoral vote in 2008 by capturing the district that includes Omaha.The campaign also hopes to retake North Carolina, a state that Mr. Obama won in 2008 but lost in 2012. Mrs. Clinton has made repeated trips to the state -- the latest to Charlotte on Monday.Even Utah might be in play. Robby Mook, the Clinton campaign manager, said this week that the traditionally Republican state, which hasn't voted for the Democratic nominee since 1964, is a "heavy lift." But he added that Mr. Trump created "headwinds" for himself, having "alienated the Mormon Church."At a rally in Utah in March, Mr. Trump questioned whether the 2012 GOP nominee, Mitt Romney, was truly a Mormon."While I think it's going to be a close election in terms of the popular vote, she does have a distinct advantage in terms of the Electoral College map," Mr. Garin said. He said that she has "many more pathways" to an Electoral College majority than Mr. Trump has.For Mr. Trump to win, he would need to flip some states that Democrats have been winning, such as Ohio and Pennsylvania, which helps explain why Mrs. Clinton's bus tour starts in those two states, said David Axelrod, a former Obama White House and campaign adviser. "He's trying to put this together primarily among white voters," Mr. Axelrod said.Mrs. Clinton will start her bus tour accompanied by Sen. Tim Kaine (D., Va.), her running mate. A roster of high-profile campaign surrogates also will stump for Mrs. Clinton. Mr. Obama's political team has been coordinating closely with the Clinton campaign and expects the president to be a frequent presence on the trail in the fall. With a job approval rating topping 50%, Mr. Obama can be particularly helpful in mobilizing minority voters and getting them to vote.Mark Penn, a senior strategist in Mrs. Clinton's 2008 presidential race, said, "She now has an almost unprecedented team of surrogates, from President Clinton, who is great with swing voters, to President Obama, who can fire up the base and whose ratings have been rising."(See related article: "Candidate Underlines Contrasts to Rival" -- WSJ July 29, 2016)Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Carol E. Lee

article name: Election 2016: Trump Says Russia Remarks 'Sarcastic'
article text: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump said Thursday his comments inviting Russia to dig up Hillary Clinton's lost emails -- which caused an uproar from much of the U.S. national-security community -- weren't meant to be taken literally."Of course, I'm being sarcastic," Mr. Trump said during an appearance on Fox News.Asked about fears that Russia might be meddling in the U.S. election, a top U.S. intelligence official on Thursday said Moscow could be seeking payback for what it viewedas concerted attempts by the U.S. to interfere in elections in Russia."They see a U.S. conspiracy behind every bush and ascribe far more impact than we're actually guilty of, but that's their mind-set," said U.S. Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, speaking at a security conference in Aspen, Colo.Mr. Clapper said U.S. intelligence agencies haven't reached a firm conclusion on whether Russia or any other country was behind the recent computer breach that stole emails and other records from the Democratic National Committee."I'll just say that don't think we're quite ready yet to make a call on attribution," Mr. Clapper said. "I mean, we all know there are just a few usual suspects out there. But in terms of the process that we try to stick to, I don't think we're ready to make a public call yet."Close to 20,000 of those emails were released by WikiLeaks last week, a move that proved embarrassing to senior DNC officials because they involved plots in some cases to undermine the presidential candidacy of Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont. DNC Chairman Debbie Wasserman Schultz resigned after the emails were made public.The remarks by the nation's top intelligence chief came as Mr. Trump rejected criticism of his invitation Wednesday to the Russian government to hack into the emails of Mrs. Clinton, his Democratic rival.In the Fox News interview, Mr. Trump also said Russian President Vladimir Putin is "a better leader" than President Barack Obama."He's a better leader than Obama, because Obama's not a leader, so he's certainly doing a better job than Obama is," Mr. Trump said.Though Mr. Trump's invitation to the Russia government drew bipartisan criticism, the White House on Thursday said the GOP nominee would soon begin receiving classified intelligence briefings."The administration is confident that they can both provide relevant and sufficient briefings to the two major party presidential candidates, while also protecting sensitive national security information," White House press secretary Josh Earnest said.In response to a question about recent comments by Mr. Trump on foreign policy, particularly the U.S. relationship with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the development of nuclear weapons in Asia, Mr. Clapper said he wouldn't offer any opinion. But he said he has heard concerns from his counterparts overseas based on rhetoric on the campaign trail. "I can say with some authority that such statements, such rhetoric are very bothersome to our foreign interlocutors, our foreign partners," he said.Credit: By Damian Paletta and Reid J. Epstein

article name: The Democratic Convention: Clinton Aide Needles Trump on Strategy
article text: PHILADELPHIA -- Hillary Clinton's campaign manager on Wednesday challenged Donald Trump's statement that he could be competitive in Democratic strongholds, urging the Republican nominee to stump in traditionally blue states.Robby Mook joked that he stands ready to help Mr. Trump forge a game plan for competing in northeastern states where Republicans have long struggled. "I absolutely encourage Donald Trump to spend time campaigning in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey," Mr. Mook said at a lunch hosted by The Wall Street Journal.In response, Jason Miller, a Trump campaign spokesman, said: "Sun Tzu once said that overconfidence creates situations where you will be defeated by the unexpected. The Clinton campaign would be wise to take this to heart when facing a national grass-roots movement looking to break up the rigged system in Washington and elect a true outsider like Donald Trump."Mr. Trump repeatedly has asserted that he will expand the traditional battleground and carve a path to the White House by winning states where Republican presidential candidates rarely compete. The New York businessman has said his home state could be in play in the November election. And he has called New Jersey a second home, saying that he expects to do well there.Mr. Mook appeared to give such statements little credence, quipping that the Clinton team would help the GOP nominee develop an itinerary for campaigning in those states.For his part, the Clinton campaign manager identified North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Florida as key battlegrounds in this election.Some political pundits have suggested that Georgia, which has backed Republican presidential candidates in the last five presidential elections, could be more competitive in this election. But Mr. Mook shied away from any bold predictions.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Trump Urges Russia To Wade Into Race
article text: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump invited Russia on Wednesday to unearth some of Hillary Clinton's missing emails from her time as secretary of state, drawing sharp criticism that he was urging a foreign power to spy on the U.S.The comments, which Mr. Trump echoed on Twitter but that his campaign later sought to play down, came in the midst of a week in which Democrats accused Russia of attempting to meddle in the U.S. presidential election by hacking the Democratic National Committee's computers and handing over embarrassing emails to the WikiLeaks website. The accusations also cast a new spotlight on Mr. Trump's expressions of respect for Russian President Vladimir Putin."Russia -- if you're listening, I hope you're able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing," Mr. Trump told reporters at his resort near Miami. "I think you will probably be rewarded mightily by our press."Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic nominee, turned over about 30,000 emails to the State Department as part of a probe into her use of a private email server. Her attorneys said they erased another 30,000 they deemed personal.Mr. Trump's remarks came as part of an effort by the GOP candidate to draw media coverage during the week of the Democratic convention.National-security experts reacted sharply. "If he is talking about the State Department emails on her server, he is inviting a foreign intelligence service to steal sensitive American government information," said Michael Hayden, head of the Central Intelligence Agency under President George W. Bush.Timothy Naftali, co-director of New York University's Center for the United States and the Cold War, said he was "flabbergasted" by Mr. Trump's comments. "Even in jest, a presidential candidate should not give any foreign power anything but zero tolerance about espionage," he said. "He sent a signal to foreign powers that it's open season on U.S. secrets."Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook condemned "the idea that you'd have any American, let alone a presidential nominee from a major party, calling for a foreign power to commit espionage in the U.S."Adding to the sense that Mr. Trump had veered badly, his campaign released a statement from his running mate, Indiana Gov.Mike Pence, that took a more confrontational approach toward Russia minutes after the press conference ended.Mr. Pence threatened that "both parties and the United States government" will ensure "serious consequences" if the Federal Bureau of Investigation finds Russia responsible for hacking the Democratic National Committee emails, which WikiLeaks released on the eve of the convention. The emails showed party officials plotting to undermine Mrs. Clinton's challenger, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.GOP House Speaker Paul Ryan echoed Mr. Pence's stance. "Russia is a global menace led by a devious thug. Putin should stay out of this election," said Ryan spokesman Brendan Buck.Former GOP House Speaker Newt Gingrich, a Trump ally, said Mr. Trump was kidding about Russia looking for Mrs. Clinton's emails. "The media seems more upset by Trump's joke about Russian hacking than by the fact that Hillary's personal server was vulnerable to Russia," he said on Twitter.Later Wednesday, Trump spokesman Jason Miller sought to quell the mounting backlash to Mr. Trump's remarks. "To be clear, Mr. Trump did not call on, or invite, Russia or anyone else to hack Hillary Clinton's e-mails today," he said on Twitter.Mr. Trump was asked in the news conference whether he was urging Russia to hack Mrs. Clinton's emails. "That's up to the president," he said, referring to Mr. Putin. He added he had no intention to give orders to the Russian leader. "I'm not going to tell Putin what to do," Mr. Trump said. "Why should I tell Putin what to do?"Before Mr. Trump's remarks, the Russian government said it doesn't interfere in elections of other countries. "President Putin has repeatedly said that Russia never interfered and never interferes in the domestic affairs, especially not the electoral processes, of other countries," Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said, according to Russian news agencies. U.S. politicians were creating "Russian boogeyman stories," he added.Mr. Trump has drawn rebukes from Republicans and Democrats for trading compliments with Mr. Putin during the GOP primaries.On Wednesday night, Leon Panetta, former defense secretary and director of the Central Intelligence Agency under President Barack Obama, declared at the Democratic convention: "Donald Trump today once again took Russia's side . . . In an unstable world, we cannot afford unstable leadership."Trump spokesman Stephen Miller took issue with Mr. Panetta for keeping silent about Mrs. Clinton's email server and other issues: "He better than most should know how many lives she put at risk."Earlier on Wednesday, Mr. Trump sought to distance himself from the Russian president."I never met Putin. I don't know who Putin is," Mr. Trump said. "I would treat Vladimir Putin firmly, but there's nothing I can think of that I'd rather do than have Russia friendly, as opposed to the way they are right now, so that we can go and knock out ISIS."Mr. Trump's claim contradicted what he said about his relationship with Mr. Putin at a debate in November. "I got to know him very well because we were both on '60 Minutes,' we were stablemates, and we did very well that night," he said.According to a political watchdog group called FactCheck.org, the two men did appear on the same "60 Minutes" episode, which aired on Sept. 27. But Mr. Putin was interviewed in Moscow, while Trump was interviewed at his New York City penthouse.Credit: By Beth Reinhard and Damian Paletta

article name: Trump's Putin Illusions
article text: Will someone -- calling Ivanka -- please tell Donald Trump that Vladimir Putin is no friend of America, or for that matter of Donald Trump? An intervention is needed after the Republican's mouth-in-foot press conference Wednesday in which he invited Russia to turn over Hillary Clinton's 33,000 missing emails from her private server."Russia, if you're listening, I hope you're able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing. I think you will probably be rewarded mightily by our press," Mr. Trump said at his South Florida resort. "They probably have them. I'd like to have them released."The man who is representing millions of Republican voters between now and November added, when given a chance to reconsider, that "If Russia or China or any other country has those emails, I mean, to be honest with you, I'd love to see them." So would we, and everyone else in the media if they're honest, but that doesn't mean a presidential candidate should appear to invite a Kremlin hack.The Clinton campaign pounced on the news, and House Speaker Paul Ryan said he disagreed with Mr. Trump's comments. So, perhaps, did others in the Trump entourage, because the campaign quickly rolled out a statement from vice presidential nominee Mike Pence that took a much more sensible line."The FBI will get to the bottom of who is behind the hacking. If it is Russia and they are interfering in our elections, I can assure you both parties and the United States government will ensure there are serious consequences," Mr. Pence said in the statement. Let's hope so, though given how delicately the Obama Administration has treated hacks by China and North Korea, we aren't so sure.Mr. Trump's comments are indefensible on their own, but they are even more concerning because they come in the context of the nominee's seeming bromance with Mr. Putin. He's often said he likes the authoritarian for his ability to get his way -- military imperialism works that way -- and the American seems to think his superior negotiating skills would outwit the strongman.Get over it, Donald. George W. Bush looked into Mr. Putin's eyes and found him "straightforward and trustworthy," only to have Russia invade Georgia. President Obama vowed a "reset" with Russia, and Mr. Putin returned the favor by invading Ukraine and buzzing NATO jets. You don't have to credit the conspiracy theories that Mr. Putin has something on Mr. Trump to conclude that the Republican needs a crash course in geopolitics. Even as a nominee who hasn't been elected, his statements are followed around the world by adversaries looking for weaknesses to exploit.At the same time the press corps should hold Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Obama to the same standard. Four years ago Mr. Obama famously mocked Mitt Romney for saying that Russia was America's foremost "geopolitical foe." Mr. Obama said the 1980s are "calling to ask for their foreign policy back because, you know, the Cold War's been over for 20 years." Mr. Romney was right.As for Mrs. Clinton, she wasn't merely a candidate when she exposed America's top secrets on her private email. She was Secretary of State. She thus made herself and the U.S. vulnerable to Mr. Putin's blackmail. That's at least as troubling as Mr. Trump's geopolitical illusions.(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Trump Has No Putin Illusions on Email Hacks" -- WSJ August 2, 2016)

article name: Election 2016: Trump, Once a Fan, Bashes Bloomberg Over Comments
article text: Donald Trump appeared to be a fan of former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, praising him when the billionaire was in office as "brilliant" and a "great mayor."But after Mr. Bloomberg delivered a scathing rebuke of the Republican presidential nominee during a speech on Wednesday at the Democratic National Convention, Mr. Trump took a different approach."'Little' Michael Bloomberg, who never had the guts to run for president, knows nothing about me. His last term as Mayor was a disaster!" Mr. Trump tweeted Friday morning.Mr. Trump later posted that Mr. Bloomberg, who left City Hall in December 2013 after serving 12 years as mayor, wouldn't get 10% of the vote if he ran again."They would run him out of town!" he wrote.Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Trump had been cordial over the years but never close friends, according to people who know them. In his speech Wednesday, Mr. Bloomberg questioned Mr. Trump's sanity and business credentials."Let's elect a sane, competent person," said Mr. Bloomberg, urging voters to elect Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton.Mr. Bloomberg, who successfully ran for mayor three times as the GOP nominee, has been unaffiliated with a political party since 2007. His convention speech was viewed as politically important because Mr. Bloomberg and Mrs. Clinton aren't personally close, and Mr. Bloomberg considered his own run for president.Asked for comment on Mr. Trump's tweets, Mr. Bloomberg's aides pointed to their tweets highlighting the times when Mr. Trump had praised Mr. Bloomberg.In a video posted by Stu Loeser, a spokesman for Mr. Bloomberg, Mr. Trump said: "I have to say you have been a great mayor," while appearing with Mr. Bloomberg in 2013. Mr. Bloomberg's aides also posted a link to a 2013 Fox News appearance during which Mr. Trump called Mr. Bloomberg "brilliant."Hank Sheinkopf, a New York-based political consultant, said Mr. Bloomberg was an effective attack dog for the Clinton campaign because of his business record and reputation for being a moderate."If Bloomberg keeps going after him, Trump's best bet is to attack Bloomberg's positions on gun control as extreme," Mr. Sheinkopf said. "But it's risky going after Mike Bloomberg because he has a lot of money and a lot of friends."New York Mayor Bill de Blasio, a Democrat, also attacked Mr. Trump at the convention, saying he was unfit to lead the country.In an Iowa speech Thursday night, Mr. Trump said Mr. de Blasio was the worst mayor in the U.S.Credit: By Josh Dawsey

article name: Why Donald Trump Is No Gentleman
article text: The most obvious observation about Donald Trump is one rarely made: He is not a gentleman. "Not a gentleman" is a designation and reproach he richly deserves but has not received. And why is that? "Gentleman" is no longer a standard we enforce or even a term we use. The outstanding person in this election is Donald Trump, in that he attracts the most attention, but the outstanding fact is the voters behind him who excuse Mr. Trump for his ungentlemanly behavior.A gentleman -- to define him quickly -- is a man who is gentle by habit and character, and not because he is somehow forced to be. Character is key. The Donald has said in one of his performances on Bill O'Reilly's television show that he "likes to be a gentleman" with women, a generous gesture of his. And one of his girlfriends declared that the New York Times had got her story wrong: She was not demeaned or offended by Mr. Trump; to her he was a "gentleman."This is pretty thin testimony. What would Carly Fiorina and Megyn Kelly say of their experience as Mr. Trump's targets? Also, a gentleman would prefer to be thought of as a gentleman rather than be praised as one, let alone boast of it himself.John McCain would expect, though not require, us to recognize his honorable conduct in a Communist prison camp during the Vietnam War as being beyond just reward. To Mr. Trump, however, Mr. McCain was a loser for having had the bad luck to be captured by the North Vietnamese. ("I like people who weren't captured," Mr. Trump said.) When the Republicans put Mr. McCain up for the presidency, Mr. Trump implied, they were nominating a loser.They compounded their mistake in the next presidential election by nominating Mitt Romney, another gentlemanly loser. Now Republicans have the opportunity to put up a winner, or at least one who believes in winning, namely himself. With his disdain for Mr. McCain, Trump makes it clear that, for him, winning dishonorably is better than losing honorably.This is Machiavelli in a nutshell. But Machiavelli said that one should either caress or eliminate a rival, never merely insult him. With an insult, you leave the rival alive to seek revenge. Yet Mr. Trump does not fear the revenge of John McCain or Mitt Romney or their Republican supporters. He "tells it like it is," meaning that he is bold enough to say what he likes about his rivals and enemies. He is free; the rest of us are afraid, but we have the admiration of the timid for one who is fearless, he believes.We shall see how far this policy takes him. Mr. Trump is not quite a liar, because a liar tries to conceal truths inconvenient to him -- or her. It's more that he doesn't care, or doesn't even know, whether he lies or not.Readers will have noted that my argument suffers from deplorable, out-of-date sexism. Machiavelli was the boldest teacher against the honor of the gentleman, but he too was an old-fashioned sexist. There are several reasons why the gentleman has lost his good repute in addition to the fundamental Machiavellian one, picked up by Mr. Trump, that he is not a winner: The gentleman is also not necessarily a commercial success, nor is he a democratic figure. But today the main objection is that he is not gender-neutral.To make the gentleman gender-neutral, it is necessary to transform him into a sensitive male. He must begin to check his unconscious habits of male superiority, take note of the sensibilities and vulnerabilities of women, and submit to affirmative action. In new programs of retraining, he must learn the prudent ways of women and unlearn the irrational vagaries of men. He probably won't do all this on his own; so he must be required to become politically correct.Is there much doubt that Donald Trump represents resistance to this plan on the part of men and of those women who say they like "real men"? It isn't that he cares about a cause, but as a demagogue he loves to be loved, and as a vulgar man he has an affinity for whatever is vulgar. Incapable as he is of appreciating the gentleman, Mr. Trump earns the disdain of the promoters of gender neutrality. Mr. Trump's resistance to political correctness, however, has the coarseness of a male. Or what used to be the coarseness of a male. Now that women are practicing to swear like sailors, Mr. Trump is a reminder of male superiority in the department of vulgarity. Surely no woman would have run his campaign.Those of us who hanker for the return for some part at least of the gentleman are in a fix. We are caught between distaste for a man who is not a gentleman and dislike of the political correctness that he so energetically attacks -- yet whose effect he illustrates.---Mr. Mansfield, a professor of government at Harvard University, is a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution.(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: 'Lady' and 'Gentleman' Need Not Apply in '16" -- WSJ August 6, 2016)Credit: By Harvey C. Mansfield

article name: Donald Trump Supporter Darrell Issa Faces Tough Re-Election Fight in California; President Obama among Democrats targeting the one-time House Oversight Committee chairman
article text: Rep. Darrell Issa, a Donald Trump supporter and one of President Barack Obama's staunchest congressional critics, is facing his stiffest re-election challenge as national Democrats target one of California's last Republican bastions: Orange County.The Cook Political Report this month declared the race a "toss up" in Mr. Issa's district, which spans southern Orange County and portions of northern San Diego, including Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton--a startling development for the 62-year-old who has won election eight times.His Democratic rival, Doug Applegate, 62, is a former Marine colonel, an Iraq war veteran and a military lawyer now in private practice. He retired from service in 2006 after 32 years, and is running on a platform of job creation, opposition to the Trans Pacific Partnership trade deal and improving health-care and job opportunities for veterans. He described his opponent as a "poster boy for Washington dysfunction [who] always puts his party ahead of our country."Mr. Issa is emphasizing his legislative record, pointing to a report by researchers at the University of Virginia and Vanderbilt University that rated him the second-most effective Republican lawmaker in Congress. He is the wealthiest member of Congress, having run a vehicle antitheft device company before he was elected to Congress in 2000.Democrats would need to win a net of 30 seats to recapture the House majority for the first time since 2010. Mr. Trump's slide in the polls has made Democrats more confident they can winnow the House GOP majority, even if regaining control of the chamber remains something of a long shot."This district is definitely going to become more of a swing seat," said Paul Mitchell, vice president of Political Data Inc., a California research firm that provides data to both parties. "If not in this year, in subsequent years, Darrell Issa is going to start feeling pressure from millennials registering, and other changing demographics."From his perch as chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee from 2011 to 2015, Mr. Issa launched a series of investigations into the Obama administration. They included probes about the deadly attack in 2012 against U.S. personnel in Benghazi, Libya, the failed "Fast and Furious" arms sting by the Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms and the Internal Revenue Service's treatment of nonprofits aligned with conservative causes.Mr. Obama, one of Mrs. Clinton's top surrogates, made clear Mr. Issa's seat is a target . Speaking Sunday at a La Jolla, Calif., fundraiser for congressional Democrats, the president mocked Mr. Issa for featuring him in a recent mail advertisement that said he was "very pleased" the president signed legislation he co-sponsored."This is now a guy who because poll numbers are bad has sent out brochures with my picture on it, touting his cooperation on issues with me," Mr. Obama said. "That is shameless.""I'm disappointed but not surprised that the president, in a political speech, continues to deny accountability for the serious scandals that happened under his watch where Americans died overseas and veterans have died here at home," Mr. Issa said in response to the president's comments.Democrats say Mr. Issa wasn't an original co-sponsor of the bill and had little to do with getting the law passed. A spokesman for Mr. Issa said he advocated for the bill by writing an editorial, and made it a "top priority."In a statement to the Journal, the bill's author, Rep. Mimi Walters, a Republican, praised Mr. Issa's leadership on the matter.Some Democrats believe Hillary Clinton could win Orange County, which would make her the first Democratic presidential candidate to do so since Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1936.If that happens, "it would mean that the Republicans have lost the last stronghold in California," said Henry Vandermeir, chair of the Orange County Democratic Party. "That will start making this county a lot more progressive."The Orange County border has long been dubbed "the Orange Curtain"--a demarcation of conservatism and wealth from traditionally more diverse, liberal Los Angeles. Orange County, the birthplace of former President Richard Nixon , with a large population of military veterans, has voted Republican for decades.But demographic changes have created an opening for Democrats. Latino registration this year ticked up a point to 13% of voters, while millennial registration rose four points to 26% since the 2012 election. About 46% of new registrants this year have been millennials, according to Political Data.In California's June 7th primary, where candidates of all parties face-off, Mr. Applegate won 45.5% of the vote compared with 50.8% by Mr. Issa.The veteran population still figures prominently in the county and the congressional district, and Democrats are going out of their way to feature their candidate's military experience.Still, Mr. Issa enjoys an eight-point advantage in the number of registered Republican voters in the district over Democrats, according to state data.Democrats have sought to make Mr. Issa's continued support of Mr. Trump an issue, gambling that higher-educated, wealthier Republicans will also be turned off by the GOP nominee."Issa has two people to blame for his predicament: Donald Trump and himself," said David Wasserman, an analyst with the nonpartisan Cook Political Report. "It's a Republican-leaning seat, but the Republicans are wealthy and well-educated, and they don't like Trump."Educational attainment is high in the 49th District, with 43.5% having a bachelor's degree or more, compared with a national figure of about 33%. Mr. Trump has struggled to win highly educated voters.The House Majority PAC, a super PAC backing Democratic candidates for Congress, said last week it had begun airing an ad supporting Mr. Applegate, an airtime purchase worth about $660,000. That followed about $2.1 million worth of airtime purchased by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, the official campaign arm for Democrats in Congress.Mr. Issa's campaign has so far spent $2.3 million, according to the Center for Responsive Politics.Carol E. Lee contributed to this article.Write to Alejandro Lazo at alejandro.lazo@wsj.comCredit: By Alejandro Lazo

article name: Election 2016: Pence Says He Stands by Trump, Style Aside
article text: RALEIGH, N.C. -- Republican vice presidential nominee Mike Pence said he may have a "born to be mild" style but he is in lockstep philosophically with GOP presidential nominee Donald Trump.Mr. Pence laughed when an 11-year-old boy at a Thursday town hall here asked whether his role was "softening up Mr. Trump's policies and words.""I couldn't be more proud to stand with Donald Trump, and we are shoulder to shoulder in this campaign," Mr. Pence said. "Sometimes things don't always come out like you mean, right? And Donald Trump and I are absolutely determined to work together."He added: "Differences in style . . . should never be confused with differences in conviction."In the past week, Mr. Pence has endorsed House Speaker Paul Ryan after Mr. Trump declined to do so, and thanked the parents of a Muslim U.S. Army captain who was killed in Iraq, after Mr. Trump had criticized them.Mr. Pence said Thursday that Mr. Trump is plain-spoken, like when he talked about America's economic and international challenges in grim terms at the GOP convention last month in Cleveland."I was told that the strong truth-telling of Donald Trump at our national convention wasn't what the people wanted to hear," he said. "But I was raised to believe that leaders speak the truth."Mr. Pence said he is glad to stand with Mr. Trump, who "doesn't go tiptoeing around" political correctness and controversy."Not since Ronald Reagan in my lifetime has there been a man or a woman at the national level who has understood and heard the frustrations and the aspirations of the American people the way Donald Trump does," he said.Debra Newman, a 61-year-old teacher's assistant from suburban Raleigh, said she is glad that Mr. Pence is on the ticket. "For anybody that says, 'Oooh, Donald,' " said Ms. Newman, with a wince, "Pence brings a good energy."Credit: By Valerie Bauerlein

article name: Clinton Expands Lead Over Trump
article text: Republican Donald Trump showed signs that he is trying to get his campaign back on track amid a series of recent missteps, as a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll found Democrat Hillary Clinton opening a 9-point lead nationally over the New York businessman.Mrs. Clinton's lead, at 47% to 38%, grew from 5 percentage points before the conventions in July. The finding comes as Mr. Trump and anxious Republicans are trying to shift focus away from GOP infighting and personality politics.At a rally in Portland, Maine, on Thursday, a more restrained Mr. Trump read parts of his speech from notes and kept his attention trained on Mrs. Clinton."Hillary Clinton can never be trusted with national security," he said, which elicited cheers of "Lock her up!"The Journal/NBC News poll of 800 registered voters was taken after both parties' national conventions and after Mr. Trump became mired in controversy for criticizing Khizr Khan, the father of a Muslim-American soldier killed in the Iraq war. He stirred additional tensions within his party this week by refusing to endorse the re-election of House Speaker Paul Ryan in next week's primary, capping one of the rockiest stretches of Mr. Trump's campaign.The decline in Mr. Trump's national standing is in keeping with a spate of battleground-state polls that found an erosion of Mr. Trump's support. Those included surveys released Wednesday and Thursday showing Mrs. Clinton with double-digit leads in Pennsylvania and New Hampshire and ahead by 9 points in Michigan.Republicans have been hoping to make those states competitive on the strength of Mr. Trump's support among working-class, white voters. But those surveys and the new Journal/NBC News poll indicate that while Mr. Trump has solidified support among that group, he has been losing support among college-educated and suburban voters, whom he also needs to win the general election.The Journal/NBC News poll found Mrs. Clinton winning among white voters with four-year college degrees by 7 percentage points, 47% to 40%. Mitt Romney, the GOP's nominee in 2012, had won that group by 14 points. Before the conventions, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump were essentially tied among those voters, separated by only 1 percentage point.Similar patterns appeared in the new battleground-state surveys. A Franklin & Marshall poll of Pennsylvania voters, which showed Mrs. Clinton with an 11-point overall lead in the state, found a lopsided, 40-point lead for the Democrat in Southeastern Pennsylvania, including the Philadelphia suburbs, where residents tend to have relatively high incomes and educational attainment.Former Sen. Trent Lott (R., Miss.) is among the many Trump supporters who think Mr. Trump needs to change his tone and stop attacking other Republicans to avoid alienating more voters."The rhetoric has to change, and it has to change soon if he's going to stop the erosion and bring people back who are looking for a way to be for him," said Mr. Lott.There are signs that Mr. Trump is trying to retrain his focus after days in which Republicans inside and outside the campaign implored him to unleash his ire on the Democratic nominee, not Messrs. Khan or Ryan.At the Portland rally, he stayed largely on message and focused on Mrs. Clinton. He spoke at length about a Wall Street Journal report this week that the U.S. had secretly transferred $400 million in cash to Iran just as the country released four detained Americans.Calling the move "just sickening," Mr. Trump said that electing Mrs. Clinton would be akin to "four more years of Obama."The Clinton campaign's press secretary responded on Twitter, saying she had nothing to do with the payment, which occurred several years after she left office.To get others on the same page, the Trump campaign is this week circulating a memo to supporters urging them tofocus on "Clinton's blatant dishonesty to the American public." That is a shift from talking points circulated earlier this week on Capitol Hill, which centered on the dust-up with Mr. Khan and his wife and the "crooked" presidential debate schedule.Susie Wiles, who is helping run Mr. Trump's campaign in Florida, pointed to the large and high-spirited crowds that greeted him in Florida on Wednesday. "I think the ship, which has been listing ever so slightly, seems to be righted," Ms. Wiles said.Allies of Mr. Trump have promised on prior occasions that he would be more "presidential," only to see the candidate stir up another controversy.Penny Nance, chief executive of Concerned Women for America, a group that opposes abortion rights and favors traditional marriage, said she was hoping Mr. Trump would learn from his mistakes. But she cautioned, "I have learned to be really skeptical, because every time I think he's done, he's not."In a two-way race, Mrs. Clinton now leads among male voters 43% to 42%. She leads among women 51%-35%.The poll also found that Mrs. Clinton retained a 9-point lead when third-party candidates are included on the ballot. In a four-way match up, the poll found Mrs. Clinton drew 43%, while Mr. Trump had 34%, Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson had 10% and Green Party candidate Jill Stein drew 5%.The poll found that both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump continued to be viewed more negatively than positively by voters. But it found a small improvement in Mrs. Clinton's image: 37% viewed her positively, while 53% viewed her negatively. Last month, the split was 34% positive, 56% negative.Feelings about Mr. Trump remained almost unchanged from the prior month, with 28% viewing him positively and 61% viewing him negatively.The survey was conducted July 31 to Aug. 3. Its margin of error was plus or minus 3.46 percentage points.---Rebecca Ballhaus and Dante Chinni contributed to this article.Credit: By Janet Hook and Beth Reinhard

article name: USD Gains; Risk of Trump Victory Not Seen Too High
article text: 1006 GMT The U.S. dollar gains, with USD/JPY up 0.2% at 104.93 and EUR/USD down 0.3% at $1.0953, shrugging off news that the FBI is reopening its investigation into presidential candidate Hillary Clinton. Although opinion polls point to increased support for Donald Trump, CIBC currency strategist Jeremy Stretch says the risk is not viewed as sufficiently high to put the dollar under selling pressure. Instead, month-end flows are dollar-supportive, he says. "The markets are increasing the probability of a Trump victory, but are not assuming a high probability." This week's Federal Reserve announcement is also expected to affirm market expectations for a U.S. interest rate increase in December, which should support the dollar.Write to jessica.fleetham@wsj.comCredit: By Jessica Fleetham

article name: Early Voting Bolsters Hillary Clinton in Key States; Democrat sees enthusiasm in Florida and Nevada, while Donald Trump holds his own in Ohio
article text: Democrat Hillary Clinton appears to have a slight edge over Republican rival Donald Trump in a number of battleground states and among important demographic groups based on an analysis of the millions of votes already cast both at polling places and by absentee ballot.Mrs. Clinton is seeing positive signs of enthusiasm in such states as Florida and Nevada. She is also seeing strong turnout rates in the early vote from Latinos and women.But Mr. Trump may have an advantage in the midwestern battlegrounds of Ohio and Iowa, where Democratic voter interest appears to be flagging compared with the 2012 presidential, records show.According to data compiled by the United States Elections Project and the Associated Press, at least 17 million votes had already been cast as of Friday. Early voting is under way in a number of top-tier battlegrounds including Florida, Nevada, Iowa and North Carolina. Absentee voting has been happening in some form in every state, thanks to laws that require military and overseas ballots to be ready by September."Clinton has opened up a national lead in the polling, and there are some states that have been following that lead in the state polling," said Michael McDonald, who runs the United States Elections Project and is one of the foremost experts on early voting. "We can also see similar patterns of movement in the early vote as well."Ballots are secret, but many states release the partisan registration of the voters requesting and returning absentee ballots or voting in-person. While those numbers don't take into account voters who cross over and vote for a candidate of the other party, the early numbers can provide clues into voter enthusiasm and the potential makeup of the electorate.In Florida, Republicans typically have an advantage in early and absentee voting numbers, but this year, the parties are in a virtual dead heat in ballot returns and votes cast. Democrats also cite an increase in female and Latino participation in early voting, with the Clinton campaign using state data to note that 133,000 Latino voters have returned ballots--a 99% increase from this point in 2012. Republicans note that the early-voting sites in some GOP-leaning counties aren't yet open.In Nevada, the first week of early and absentee voting showed Democrats ahead by about 25,000 votes on the strength of returns in Clark County, the state's population center that includes Las Vegas. Democrats attribute their strength among the state's Latino voters for the increase. Republicans are running in closer in Washoe County, home to Reno. The GOP is also ahead in absentee ballots statewide.In North Carolina , the number of early voting sites in the state has been reduced since the last election, but participation is about on par with this point in 2012. As of Friday, Democrats led in early voting and absentee-ballot returns in North Carolina by more than 100,000 votes.Despite a strong early performance in 2012, President Barack Obama lost North Carolina that year, and Mrs. Clinton will need big turnout from black voters, who are down as a share of voters in early returns, according to state data.Only a handful of states release data about the gender of early voters, but the figures that are available shows female ballot returns are outpacing male ones, according to numbers compiled by the United States Elections Project. Mrs. Clinton has built her polling lead on her strength with women.Republican operatives say they aren't alarmed by early voting trends in the battleground states, with one Republican National Committee official saying the states the party hopes to win are still within reach.In Iowa and Ohio, early voting points to lackluster Democratic interest rather than a groundswell of Republican enthusiasm. Key counties around Cleveland and Columbus show lower levels of Democratic early voting, Mr. McDonald said.The story is similar in Iowa, where Republicans are flat in terms of ballots requested, at about 175,000, and the 116,000 ballots that have been already cast is down about 11,000 from four years ago. Democrats, however, are down much more, and Mrs. Clinton on Friday headed to Iowa to try to boost those numbers.Dante Chinni contributed to this article.Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comRelated Coverage* Florida Battle Map: Where Clinton and Trump Must Concentrate Efforts* Voter Guide: Find Answers to Your Election Questions Online* Florida Once Again a Focus in 2016 CampaignCredit: By Byron Tau

article name: Election 2016: Trump Backs Ryan, Senators --- Candidate stresses Republican unity after intraparty tensions were laid bare
article text: After a week in which he exacerbated tension with Republican Party leaders by refusing to endorse House Speaker Paul Ryan and Sens. John McCain and Kelly Ayotte in their 2016 races, presidential nominee Donald Trump backed all three of them during a Friday night campaign stop in Wisconsin, Mr. Ryan's home state."In our shared mission to make America great again, I support and endorse our speaker of the House, Paul Ryan," Mr. Trump in Green Bay. "Working hand in hand, we will work to grow our majority in the House and Senate."Reading from notes, which he rarely does during campaign speeches, Mr. Trump cited the need for Republican unity. It came after all three lawmakers criticized the presidential nominee over his attacks on the parents of a slain U.S. soldier."We will have disagreements, but we will disagree as friends and never stop working together toward victory and importantly, toward real change," he said.Mr. Ryan, who faces a primary challenge in the coming week, wasn't in attendance, nor was Sen. Ron Johnson, who faces a difficult challenge from former Democratic Sen. Russ Feingold. And Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, who delivered a full-throated endorsement of Mr. Trump at the Republican convention last month, was instead attending a spaghetti dinner Friday night in Grand View, a northwestern Wisconsin community.Mr. Trump's nod to Mr. Ryan, Mr. McCain and Ms. Ayotte comes four days after he declined to back the three during an interview with the Washington Post. Mr. Trump had also praised Mr. Ryan's long-shot primary challenger, Paul Nehlen, on Twitter and in interviews. Mr. Nehlen, in a statement released by his campaign, claimed Mr. Trump's delay in backing Mr. Ryan as endorsement enough.Still, Mr. Trump's campaign immediately sought to capitalize on his backing of Mr. Ryan."I have officially endorsed Paul Ryan -- and together, we will fight for YOU, and together we will Make America Great Again!" Mr. Trump wrote to supporters in a fundraising email minutes after he announced his support for the House speaker.Tweaking Mr. Ryan and encouraging his opponent infuriated Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus, who has emerged as Mr. Trump's chief ambassador to fellow Republicans. In Wisconsin, Mr. Priebus, who is from Kenosha in Mr. Ryan's district, had personally vouched for Mr. Trump and had spent weeks assuring Republicans Mr. Trump would be a team player.Mr. McCain faces a primary challenge for his seat, later this month. Ms. Ayotte is trailing in the latest polls in her November race against New Hampshire's Democratic governor, Maggie Hassan.Credit: By Reid J. Epstein

article name: Imagine a Sane GOP United Behind Trump
article text: Peggy Noonan invites us to "Imagine a Sane Donald Trump" (Declarations, Oct. 22). Let's do the same exercise for the Republican Party. Were it sane, the discovery that half of the party's base doesn't share the views of the party's leaders on the big issues would have led to a response other than shock and denial.A sane Republican Party would realize that the greatest danger it faces in the current election cycle isn't the idiosyncrasies of Donald Trump, but the election of Hillary Clinton. Had more in the party followed bold leaders such as Mike Pence and Rudy Giuliani and supported the candidate chosen in the primary process, they might have elected Mr. Trump and the party would then have had the luxury of time to "begin the long process of redefining itself."A sane Republican Party would have insisted that its primary candidates who personally pledged to support the party's eventual nominee honor those pledges. Maybe Mr. Trump would have behaved differently had he not felt the need to defend himself against attacks by so many in his own party who could have better spent their energies attacking Mrs. Clinton and helping defend against attacks by the Democrats.Why do so many of the Republican Party's elite feel the need to help the Democrats by attacking their own candidate? If the Republican elites cannot find it within themselves to make a serious effort to integrate a populist candidate who promises to bring many newcomers to the party this time around, what makes them think they will be presented with the same opportunity next time or at any time in the foreseeable future?Alan StevensonReno, Nev.---Peggy, please write a column entitled "Imagine an Honest Hillary Clinton." Maybe then Donald Trump won't seem so insane.P. KellerMelbourne Beach, Fla.---Unfortunately, a sane Donald Trump would have never won the nomination.Eliyahu KaufmanDallas

article name: Election 2016: Trump Could Slow Tax Audit
article text: Donald Trump says he will release his tax returns when an IRS audit concludes, dangling the possibility of unveiling the documents before the election. The Republican presidential nominee omits one major point: He and his attorneys have substantial knowledge about when the audit will end and some ability to slow the process.The existence of audits going back as far as to 2009 indicates Mr. Trump has given the Internal Revenue Service permission to extend its work beyond a three-year statute of limitations for such inquiries, said lawyers who specialize in tax disputes, who add such extensions are routine. Mr. Trump's lawyers know the IRS's deadlines, and can take their time negotiating settlements and responding to document requests, these lawyers said."He certainly has a lot of influence over the audit ending sooner or later," said Bryan Skarlatos of Kostelanetz & Fink LLP. "It would be relatively easy at this point to extend the audit beyond the elections."Robert McKenzie, a tax lawyer at Arnstein & Lehr LLP, said it was "close to impossible" that the multiyear audit would finish by Election Day. "The complexity -- even if they had a handshake agreement -- of getting it memorialized into a deal could take months," he said.Mr. Trump has said little about his audit's status. In March, his campaign released a letter to Mr. Trump from his lawyers, Sheri Dillon and William Nelson of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius LLP. They wrote that the IRS concluded its audits for 2002 through 2008 and was working on remaining years.Through a spokesman, Ms. Dillon and Mr. Nelson, a former IRS chief counsel, declined to comment. Campaign spokeswoman Hope Hicks said the audit is "routine."The letter from Mr. Trump's lawyers leaves open the possibility the IRS found problems or that he had accumulated tax losses, tax attorneys say.Mr. Trump is likely to become the first major-party presidential candidate since 1976 to release no tax returns. He has said he can't release them during an audit. No law stops him from doing so, though tax lawyers say public comments by tax experts on such released documents could give the IRS new ideas.The IRS typically has three years to finish an audit once a tax return is filed. The agency can ask a taxpayer to extend that period and the taxpayer typically agrees.The alternative is to give the IRS a deadline. That can prompt the agency to issue a "notice of deficiency" that may lead to a "kitchen sink" of potential added taxes, said Joshua Ungerman of Meadows, Collier, Reed, Cousins, Crouch & Ungerman LLP.Forcing the IRS to end an audit also narrows the taxpayer's options, because the only way then to contest the agency is in court, which would make the taxpayer's dispute public.Tax lawyers who reviewed the letter from Mr. Trump's attorneys said their description of the audits for 2002-2008 was phrased in a very specific way. The letter said the audits were "closed administratively by agreement with the IRS without assessment or payment, on a net basis, of any deficiency."The letter indicates Mr. Trump didn't write a check for any taxes owed. It doesn't rule out interest payments on back taxes owed, or the use of accumulated tax losses to cover any deficiency, the attorneys said.The letter seems to suggest the presence of losses, said Juan Vasquez, an attorney at Chamberlain Hrdlicka in Houston. Otherwise, he said, Mr. Trump's lawyers would have written that there was no deficiency without saying "on a net basis."Credit: By Richard Rubin

article name: Trump Tries a Campaign Reboot
article text: Donald Trump is trying to quickly reset his presidential campaign to address worsening poll numbers and growing isolation from influential members of the Republican Party.At weekend rallies, the GOP nominee read from a hand-held script and offered endorsements for the re-elections of a trio of Capitol Hill Republicans whom he had toyed with rebuffing. On Monday, he will head to Detroit to deliver an economic policy address that is expected to draw contrasts with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton.Many in Mr. Trump's party have been clamoring for weeks to see these kinds of adjustments. If he is to persuade Republican skeptics to buy back into his campaign, just weeks before the crucial post-Labor Day stage, the unorthodox, first-time candidate now must show he can make the changes stick.Part of the issue for the New York businessman is that he has run his campaign much like his family business, with his grown children as his top counselors and surrogates. That has meant he hasn't developed a strong connective tissue to party stalwarts and activists that can sustain a candidate through difficult times.Reports of Republicans leaving the party, lining up behind Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson or even backing Mrs. Clinton gained momentum last week, after the nominee' criticized the parents of a U.S. soldier killed in Iraq."The friendly fire within the Republican Party over the last week has been extremely counterproductive," said veteran GOP strategist Dave Carney, who isn't involved in the Trump campaign but says he will vote for him. "In modern presidential politics, this election is an outlier in terms of deterioration of support."Mr. Trump hopes for a reboot with his Detroit speech, which will talk about "the tepid economy under Obama and Clinton, versus the kind of growth economy that Mr. Trump wants to build," campaign chairman Paul Manafort said Sunday on Fox News.Mr. Trump in his speech is expected to give broad strokes about his economic plan, particularly to underscore his support for tax cuts. He is also likely to reiterate his plan to create a single top business tax rate that would apply to corporations and to businesses that pay taxes through their owners' individual returns.The candidate isn't likely to offer a detailed revision of his previously announced plan for big tax cuts. Advisers have been working on an overhaul of that plan to address criticism it would rapidly expand the federal deficit, but that revision isn't yet ready, advisers said.Mrs. Clinton will be in Florida on Monday and in Michigan on Thursday, talking about her economic plans.Mr. Trump has shown an ability to survive rough patches, and he and his running mate, Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, have stressed party unity in recent days. At a rally in New Hampshire Saturday night, Mr. Trump largely stuck to lines of attack against Mrs. Clinton.Still, House Speaker Paul Ryan of Wisconsin and Sen. Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire, both of whom are facing election challenges, didn't appear on stage with their party's nominee during weekend rallies in their respective states. It was at Mr. Trump's appearance in Wisconsin Friday night that he announced his belated support for the re-election of those two lawmakers, and of Arizona Sen. John McCain, who faces a primary challenge this month.Robin Vos, the GOP speaker of the Wisconsin State Assembly, also skipped the Friday event in Green Bay because of Mr. Trump's reluctance to embrace Mr. Ryan's re-election and the positive comments the nominee made about Mr. Ryan's primary opponent."There's this exasperation. We want to all rally; give us a reason," Mr. Vos said.If Mr. Trump continues to slide in national polls and surveys of battleground states -- the latest Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll found Mrs. Clinton leading by 9 points -- more Republicans will be emboldened to declare their independence from the top of the ticket, GOP strategists and party leaders say.A new re-election ad by Rep. Mike Coffman of Colorado vows to "stand up" to Mr. Trump. Scattered resignations from local parties could mean fewer grass-roots activists knocking on doors and working phone banks."People would ask my opinion and they would say, 'How can you support this man?'" said John Fielding, a former chairman of the Berks County, Pa., Republican Party, who recently resigned his post as a local GOP committeeman and switched his registration to independent. "I didn't want to have to defend him."One of the starkest signs of Mr. Trump's weakened support within the party came last week when his campaign circulated an appeal on Capitol Hill for an "urgent pivot" and asked members to write press releases and social media posts defending Mr. Trump's criticism of the parents of Capt. Humayun Khan, the Muslim U.S. soldier killed in Iraq in 2004 while protecting his unit.Only about half a dozen lawmakers publicly vouched for Mr. Trump, while numerous others chided him for questioning the Khan family's motives for appearing at the Democratic convention.Rep. Duncan Hunter of California, the Trump campaign's co-chairman on Capitol Hill, defended Mr. Trump over the Khan episode last week on Fox News. But he has stopped going to the weekly meetings with Trump officials, in part because he has been disappointed by the nominee's lack of personal outreach to his colleagues."There's still a lot of reluctance among members to not just rally behind Trump but to also back up the campaign during moments of controversy," Mr. Hunter said in an email.Credit: By Beth Reinhard and Reid J. Epstein

article name: Trump Gets It Wrong: Trade Is a Winner for Americans
article text: Donald Trump attacks the longstanding Republican promotion of trade as an engine of growth. The Republican presidential nominee asserts that trade produces winners and losers, that a country should always send more value abroad than it imports, and that America is thus a trade "loser." Whether he wins the election or not, Mr. Trump's protectionist views are forcing elected leaders -- especially in the Republican Party -- to decide whether to continue championing free trade or give up on opening markets.Wavering politicians should check their bearings by reviewing what voters think about trade. A July WSJ/NBC poll revealed that 55% of registered voters think free trade is good for America because it opens up markets for U.S. goods, while 38% consider it bad. A September 2015 Gallup poll found that only 18% of Americans said leaving the North American Free Trade Agreement would help the economy. Polls by the Chicago Council on Global Affairs in 2014 and 2015 found that Americans supported the negotiations for trans-Atlantic and trans-Pacific trade by 62%-29% and 64%-29%, respectively. While other polls show more muddled results, at a minimum Republicans would be prudent not to assume voters will join Mr. Trump's retreat on trade.Mr. Trump's complaints are contradicted by the facts. The U.S. has free-trade agreements with 20 countries that account for 10% of the global economy. These deals are the basis for nearly half of America's exports. In the first five years after the U.S. has concluded free-trade agreements, U.S. exports have increased three times as rapidly as overall export growth. Over the past five years the U.S. has, with its free-trade partners, run a trade surplus for manufactured goods of about $230 billion, according to the Commerce Department. America's farmers and ranchers boosted their exports to free-trade partners by 130% between 2003-13, to $56 billion. One of every three acres of crops planted in America is for export.Mr. Trump's concentration on exports alone as "winning" ignores that U.S. businesses import to lower costs for American production. Over 60% of U.S. imports are intermediate goods that go into U.S. products.It would be foolhardy to force American businesses and consumers to pay more and have less freedom to choose. Lower taxes on imports from trade deals save the average U.S. household about $10,000 a year, according to the Peterson Institute for International Economics. Yet Mr. Trump wants to impose steep tariffs to "win" on trade.The presidency of Herbert Hoover, the last Republican in the White House to embrace high taxes on imports, offers a cautionary tale. After the 1930 Smoot-Hawley Act's high tariffs took effect, Hoover achieved the trade surplus that Mr. Trump demands, but also an unemployment rate of 25% -- and the Great Depression.Americans account for only 4% of the world's population. Many potential customers live abroad. American exporters face tariffs that are, on average, four times the U.S. average, plus a host of nontariff barriers. The modern free-trade agreements that Mr. Trump dislikes have eliminated most traditional barriers while setting higher standards to protect U.S. intellectual property. They've also opened doors for U.S. service businesses and small- and medium-size enterprises, established new rules for e-commerce, and promoted anticorruption measures, transparency and environment and labor safeguards.U.S. multinational businesses pay their employees 25%-30% more than average wages, make about 57% of U.S. capital investment, and are the source of 83% of private R&D. At the same time, 98% of the 300,000 U.S. companies that export are small and medium-size enterprises, and they supply about one-third of America's exports.Moreover, those U.S. manufacturing workers whose jobs depend on exports earn on average 18% more than other workers. This wage premium reflects the higher productivity of business and workers who compete around the world. More than 11 million U.S. workers and one million farmers gain from this global competitive edge.Mr. Trump and other antitraders complain that American manufacturing has declined. Yet the U.S. share of global manufacturing has held at around 20% for 40 years. To compete, U.S. companies have had to boost productivity with new supply chains, technologies and products. As a result, workers have lost jobs. Every month, the U.S. economy creates, and loses, about five million jobs because of innovation, competition, changed consumer tastes -- and trade. Republicans should not abandon the world's most successful economic model because, according to Mr. Trump, Americans are "losers."Americans are not losers. But some Americans lose out because economic forces and misfortunes can overwhelm them. Whoever becomes the next president should help people adjust to change, not pretend that change can be prevented. Policy makers should advance ideas to get people back into jobs, assist with their relocation, supplement earned incomes, cut taxes on wages and make useful training and skills upgrades part of ongoing support for economic security.Mr. Trump indulges in the real loser's game: Always find someone else to blame. The U.S. became the most successful country in the world because Americans confronted their challenges. When Republican leaders consider their future agenda, they should reject Donald Trump's losing litany of protectionist ideas and keep opening markets for trade.---Mr. Zoellick is a former World Bank president, U.S. trade representative and deputy secretary of state.(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Promoting Trade Without Competitiveness" -- WSJ Aug. 17, 2016)Credit: By Robert B. Zoellick

article name: Election 2016: Economy Buffets Clinton, Trump Claims -- Mixed reports could undercut arguments by each candidate on state of the rebound
article text: The U.S. economy is flashing mixed signals heading toward November's election, complicating the narrative for both presidential campaigns in a race featuring sharply different views of the vitality of the seven-year expansion.Presidential elections often hinge on popular perceptions of the economy's health, particularly those that solidify in the early summer of an election year. That puts a premium on economic gauges in June and July, be it on overall output, the pace of hiring or measures of consumer sentiment.New figures out Friday showed U.S. gross domestic product, a broad measure of output, averaged a paltry 1% seasonally adjusted annual growth rate through the year's first half, well below historical norms. That has raised fears the economy is slowing heading into the election.That would add a new headwind for Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton as she tries to fend off Republican contender Donald Trump, since her campaign in part is based on praising the success fellow Democrat President Barack Obama has had in rejuvenating the economy since 2009.
