By contrast, the conventions had no measurable impact on either candidate's support among white women without college degrees.As Dale Carnegie famously remarked, you never get a second chance to make a first impression. Mr. Trump's latest campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, who reportedly channels the sentiments of educated Republican women, has her work cut out for her.Credit: By William A. Galston

article name: Trump Turned Down the NAACP's Invitation; Smart Move
article text: Donald Trump is taking lumps for his clumsy and crude "What the hell do you have to lose?" black outreach effort. Black voters, until recently, seem to have been an afterthought for the Republican presidential nominee, who is much more focused on turning out the millions of white voters who supported John McCain in 2008 but stayed home when Mitt Romney ran four years later.If Mr. Trump is serious about increasing his minority support, we'll see him participating in more town halls with large black audiences and campaigning in those blighted neighborhoods that he says he wants to improve. If he really wants his message to reach the black electorate, Trump political ads will air on black websites and be featured during black radio and television programs. Until that happens, expect many blacks, including black Republicans and conservatives, to remain skeptical.Give Mr. Trump credit, however, for not doing something that too many Republican presidential candidates before him have done, only to have it blow up in their face. When the NAACP asked Mr. Trump to address its annual convention last month, he declined. Good for him. Giving speeches to civil-rights groups like the NAACP isn't effective black outreach. It's a setup. Blacks open to Republicanism aren't likely to be found at NAACP gatherings, which are thinly disguised Democratic political rallies. And younger blacks who might be interested in hearing out the GOP have little use for the NAACP. Republicans who try to reach black voters by going through the civil-rights establishment have nothing to gain, unless they like to watch footage of black people booing them on CNN.There was a time when the NAACP was a responsible gatekeeper of black communities, attuned to their needs and looking out for their best interests. Its leadership was comprised of serious people addressing serious concerns. But those days are a distant memory. Today's civil-rights leaders and organizations have their own agenda, and their highest priority by far is to stay relevant by insisting that white racism explains racial disparities -- even if that means turning the actual problems of poor black communities into a secondary concern.There have been many examples over the decades of the growing disconnect between the traditional black leadership's priorities and those of the black underclass, but the latest one is worth examining. Last month the NAACP called for a moratorium on charter schools, even though you would be hard-pressed to find an education model that has done more to narrow the black-white achievement gap over the past quarter century.Charter schools are among the best public schools in the country. It isn't uncommon for a charter located in an inner-city ghetto to outperform affluent white suburban schools on standardized tests. Last year in New York City, the nation's most populous public-school system, the charter schools outperformed all other schools in the state by an average of 18 points in reading, and charters were half of the city's top 10 schools in math proficiency. It's no surprise that the wait list for charter schools in many cities is thousands of children long -- more than 42,000 students are wait-listed in New York City -- and that blacks have the most to lose from the moratorium advocated by the NAACP.The NAACP claims to be acting in the interests of blacks, but its position on school choice couldn't be more at odds with the expressed views of black America. According to the latest Education Next national survey figures from Harvard's Paul Peterson, black support for alternatives to traditional public schools is as robust as it's ever been. Black respondents backed charter schools by two-to-one. Black support for means-tested vouchers was a similarly strong 66%.Civil-rights organizations have also been vocal in support of the Obama administration's efforts to pressure schools into suspending fewer black students regardless of their behavior. Yet the Education Next poll found no groundswell of support for race-based school discipline policies. Less than a third (29%) of all respondents backed the federal effort, including less than half (48%) of all blacks.The NAACP's opposition to charter schools and support for coddling black school bullies has little to do with the merits. The bottom line is that teachers unions fiercely oppose school choice and are major contributors to the NAACP. Blaming racially disparate school suspension rates on white racism comports with the organization's preferred narrative and keeps the NAACP relevant.Should the Trump campaign do a better job of addressing the actual needs of black voters? Sure. But these days, you could fairly say the same thing about groups like the NAACP.---Mr. Riley, a Manhattan Institute senior fellow and Journal contributor, is the author of "Please Stop Helping Us: How Liberals Make It Harder for Blacks to Succeed" (Encounter Books, 2014).Credit: By Jason L. Riley

article name: Election 2016: Trump Says He Isn't Waffling on Immigration
article text: Despite signs that Donald Trump may be softening his rhetoric on the issue that catapulted him to political prominence -- cracking down on illegal immigrants -- the Republican presidential nominee said Monday that he wasn't waffling and reiterated his commitment to strict anti-immigration measures."I'm not flip-flopping," Mr. Trump said Monday in a Fox News interview, one day after his new campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, said that Mr. Trump's stance on deporting the nation's 11 million illegal immigrants, long a central element of his policy platform, was "to be determined."At a rally in Akron, Ohio, on Monday night, Mr. Trump reiterated his pledge to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border to keep illegal immigrants out of the country."We've going to build a wall folks, don't worry, we're going to build a wall," he said. "That wall will go up so fast your head will spin."But he did add a twist that played to recent campaign efforts to reach out to Hispanic and African-American voters: He argued that minority citizens are hardest hit by the influx of illegal workers."Low-income workers are hurt the most by my opponent's policies," he said. "Poor Hispanic and African-American citizens are the first to lose a job, or see a pay cut, when we don't control our borders."Earlier Monday, in a Fox News interview, Mr. Trump seemed to strike a different note. "We want to come up with a fair but firm process," he said. "Fair but firm." He didn't, however, provide any specifics or elaborate further on his position.Mr. Trump had planned to travel to Colorado later this week, and there had been widespread reports that he would give a speech there on immigration. Those plans never came together, but his supporters said they believe such an event will be scheduled at a future date. A Trump campaign official in Colorado didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.The campaign had also planned a Friday rally in Nevada, a state with a large Hispanic population, where Mr. Trump hopes to be competitive. The event no longer appears on the campaign website.The harsh anti-immigration rhetoric that Mr. Trump used from the outset of his presidential campaign, when he accused Mexico of sending "rapists" and "criminals" to the U.S., was one of most prominent elements of his candidacy.Anti-illegal immigration policies remain on his campaign website and are central to the message of the first TV commercial he is airing in the general election campaign."In Hillary Clinton's America, the system stays rigged against Americans," the ad says. "Syrian refugees flood in. Illegal immigrants convicted of committing crimes get to stay."But his rhetoric has risked alienating more-centrist voters and Republicans who have argued the GOP has to do a better job of appealing to Hispanics, who make up a fast-growing part of the electorate."He's finally figured out you can't win a presidential election . . . just with white votes," said Whit Ayres, a GOP pollster who worked with Sen. Marco Rubio's presidential campaign.Javier Palomarez, president of the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, said nuanced changes in rhetoric now won't win more support for Mr. Trump among Hispanic voters who have been offended by months of harsh talk."It is a bit too late; he cannot unring the bell," Mr. Palomarez said.Some Hispanics who have been courted by Mr. Trump welcomed his new language."I think I am starting to see more nuance in his immigration policy, which is a good thing," said state Rep. Jose Felix Diaz of Miami, who was named to Mr. Trump's newly formed National Hispanic Advisory Council.---Rebecca Ballhaus contributed to this article.Credit: By Janet Hook and Beth Reinhard

article name: Election 2016: Voter Influx Appears Missing for Trump --- Registrations in battlegrounds show modest rise; whites make up larger share
article text: This year's presidential primaries produced a slight increase in new voters compared with 2012, but not in numbers that suggest a major influx that might benefit Republican candidate Donald Trump, a new analysis of voter registration data finds.The study by the Democratic firm Catalist, which analyzed records from 10 battleground states this year through June, suggest that the record-breaking turnout seen in the Republican primaries was the result of general election voters becoming motivated to show up for the party's turbulent primary season, rather than a big inflow of new supporters into the Republican Party.But in potential good news for the Trump campaign, Catalist found that white voters accounted for a larger share of the new-voter pool in the first half of this year compared with 2012, and that the number and share of African-Americans was down. Mr. Trump has been trying to capitalize on his strong support among working-class whites, while his hold on African-American voters is weak, polling shows.Mr. Trump has said that his candidacy during the primary season was drawing large numbers of new voters to the GOP, who would carry him to victory in November. The Catalist findings, from a large analysis of registrations, suggest that the pool of new voters in 10 of the most competitive states is so far relatively stable compared with previous election cycles, barring any major new spikes in fall voter registration.Similarly, a Republican firm, Optimus, concluded in a two-state analysis that the GOP primaries were activating general-election voters to participate in primaries rather than adding large numbers of new voters to the rolls. In Ohio, for example, the firm found that 46.4% of primary voters this year had never before voted before in a party primary, but only about 6% had never voted before in any election, its study found."It appears Trump has created new Republican voters, but what remains to be seen is if the modest increase is enough to overcome losses among the longtime Republican voting electorate," said Scott Tranter, a co-founder of Optimus.In its study, Catalist found that about 1.4 million people joined the voter rolls in 10 battleground states this year through June, compared with about 1.3 million in 2012.New registrations compared with 2008 were lower in nine of the 10 states studied. Ohio was the only exception."The data covers the period of the Republican primaries, when Donald Trump was proclaiming that he was going to change the electorate and bring lots of new people in," said Mike Podhorzer, co-chairman of Catalist's board of managers, who also is the AFL-CIO political director.He said the data show that "the Trump effect in the primaries was to energize a lot of people who were Republican voters in the first place" and who voted in general elections but had tended to skip primaries.The share of white voters in the new-voter pool rose by nearly 16% in the first half of this year compared with 2012, Catalist found. The share of African-Americans fell by 12% and also was down from 2008.Ohio, a state that is crucial to Mr. Trump's efforts, is one state that has seen an influx of white voters. About 20,000 more new white voters registered this year than in 2012.Mr. Trump is hoping to maximize his turnout among white voters without a college degree in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, among other states.Historical patterns show that voter registration rises in the weeks leading up to Election Day, and so it remains possible that Mr. Trump could energize new voters before the general election. About 90 million Americans who are eligible voters don't cast ballots at all, in either primary or general election campaigns.Catalist's analysis covers voter registrations in Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Michigan, North Carolina, Nevada, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Virginia, and runs between January through the end of June.The analysis used data on race from states that collect that information; for others, the firm creates models to assess the race of voters based on data taken from other sources.Donald Trump's approximately 13.3 million votes represents the high-water mark of Republican primary votes in any modern campaign. It bests a record set by George W. Bush in 2000 when he captured 12.1 million votes on his way to the GOP nomination and eventually the White House.A spokesperson for the Trump campaign didn't respond to a request for comment.Credit: By Byron Tau

article name: Election 2016: Trump Shifts on Deportation Stance
article text: JACKSON, Miss. -- Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump proposed contradictory immigration policies Wednesday, saying in a broadcast interview that it would be "a very, very hard thing" to deport illegal immigrants who have been in the country for decades.During the primaries, he called for a "deportation force" to remove all 11 million undocumented immigrants, and a campaign aide said Wednesday his position hasn't changed. He also said this to Fox News host Sean Hannity on Tuesday about people who have overstayed their visas: "We have to get them out."In a continuation of the interview broadcast Wednesday, he told Mr. Hannity that he opposed citizenship for those in the country illegally, but added: "Let me go a step further -- they'll pay back taxes, they have to pay taxes, there's no amnesty, as such, there's no amnesty, but we work with them."Mr. Trump said he has been persuaded to take this new position by people who have told him it is "tough" to remove law-abiding undocumented immigrants."Now, everybody agrees we get the bad ones out," he said. "But when I go through and I meet thousands and thousands of people on this subject, and I've had very strong people come up to me, really great, great people come up to me, and they've said, 'Mr. Trump, I love you, but to take a person who's been here for 15 or 20 years and throw them and their family out, it's so tough, Mr. Trump,' I have it all the time!"Aides to his defeated GOP primary opponents pointed out on social media that his comments amount to the "amnesty" that Mr. Trump and others have long accused moderate Republicans of supporting. On Wednesday, Tim Miller, the former spokesman for former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, said Mr. Trump's statements amount to "basically Jeb's position."Before Mr. Trump's Fox interview aired, he spoke at a rally where he condemned other politicians and the media who, he said, pay no attention to illegal immigration. "Why do our leaders spend so much more time talking about how to help people here illegally, than they spend trying to help American citizens?"He also attacked his Democratic rival, saying "Hillary Clinton is a bigot who sees people of color only as votes, not as human beings worthy of a better future." Mrs. Clinton responded in a CNN interview: "He is taking a hate movement mainstream."Separately, Nigel Farage, leader of the populist movement that resulted in Britain voting to withdraw from the European Union in June, encouraged Trump supporters to follow Britain's lead in challenging the status quo. "If I was an American citizen, I wouldn't vote for Hillary Clinton if you paid me," he told the crowd in Jackson.Credit: By Reid J. Epstein and Janet Hook

article name: Old Trump, New Tricks
article text: Donald Trump has used a tactic familiar to football fans: misdirection. You pretend you're headed one way, then go in another. "I am who I am," the GOP nominee insisted last week. "It's me. I don't want to change." This suggested that Mr. Trump would double down on insults, ad libs, exaggerations, vendettas and bouts of political incorrectness. The campaign's newly hired CEO, Steve Bannon of Breitbart News, was seen as exactly the person to unleash Mr. Trump's wild side.Yet the opposite happened. Mr. Trump leashed himself to the teleprompter. He apologized for causing pain to those he had attacked. He met with Hispanics and appealed to African-Americans. He began to soften his harshest positions, like deporting millions of illegal immigrants. He stopped bragging and trashing the press.Skeptics of Mr. Trump's ability to continue in this fashion abound. After all, he has never been disciplined for long. On Monday, he slipped and tweeted several put-downs. These kinds of unforced errors have left Mr. Trump in a deep hole and made him a long shot for the White House.Assuming that he is committed to being serious and amicable, Mr. Trump has a chance to overtake Hillary Clinton and win. But he must tame his ego. His instinct is to dominate the media coverage -- with tweets, interviews, speeches -- and put himself front and center in the minds of voters every day. That worked in the Republican primaries. But now it means allowing Mrs. Clinton to recede into the background. Knowing this, Mrs. Clinton generally keeps a low profile.It might seem counterintuitive, but always being the center of attention doesn't help Mr. Trump. It only makes his style -- especially his temperament and gaffes -- a constant target, putting him invariably on the defensive. Since most of the media are hostile to him, the coverage is routinely unfavorable. The political result: Mrs. Clinton gains and Mr. Trump slumps.What he needs is role reversal, to make Mrs. Clinton into issue No. 1 and force her to play defense. The press assigned to the presidential campaign won't be much help. Their alibi is that they've already vetted Mrs. Clinton. They showed little interest in getting to the bottom of her claim that former Secretary of State Colin Powell had advised her to use a personal email system.It wasn't until People magazine encountered Mr. Powell at a Saturday-night event in East Hampton, N.Y., that his rejection of that story came to light. "Her people have been trying to pin it on me," Mr. Powell said. "The truth is she was using [her private server] for a year before I sent her a memo telling her what I did."Nor is the press eager to dig into the Clinton Foundation, though emails obtained by Judicial Watch documented unethical contacts between it and aides to Mrs. Clinton when she was secretary of state. By and large the media are inclined to treat the foundation as old news. Absent newly released emails, it's up to Mr. Trump to keep the foundation scandal alive.If Mr. Trump can subdue his ego and yield the spotlight to Mrs. Clinton and her agenda, he has an advantage. On most matters of substance, polls show voters prefer his positions to hers.He would repeal ObamaCare. She wouldn't. He would fill Supreme Court vacancies with conservatives. She would choose liberals. He would end President Obama's executive order on illegal immigrants. She would expand it. He would cut taxes. She would raise taxes. He would curtail regulation on energy production. She would increase regulation.To make her agenda into a major topic in the presidential race, Mr. Trump will have to talk about it ceaselessly and allow no antics to avert the media's attention.Finally, there's a cloud over Mr. Trump that will keep him from the presidency if he doesn't dissipate it effectively. It's the question of his temperament. The Clinton campaign has made this the paramount issue. Mrs. Clinton's best speech of the campaign so far argued that Mr. Trump is too unsteady to be president.Worse for Mr. Trump, 50 former national-security advisers and foreign-policy experts in Republican administrations made essentially the same point in a devastating statement in July. They said he lacks "the character, values, and experience to be president" and "has shown no interest in educating himself." All 50 said they wouldn't vote for him.Their statement put the onus squarely on Mr. Trump, though he hasn't got much time remaining to educate himself. He's a smart man and a quick study, but he has to want to learn far more about national security and foreign policy than one can pick up from watching television talk shows.Mr. Trump will never be an expert, but he could learn enough to keep from embarrassing himself this fall in any debate on foreign policy. Mrs. Clinton will have the advantage of knowledge and experience and she's underrated as a debater. Facing her one on one will be the biggest test of Mr. Trump's candidacy. If he backed out of the debate, it would be an admission of inadequacy. And it would leave no room for misdirection.---Mr. Barnes is executive editor of the Weekly Standard.(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Let Trump Be Trump, You Who Have Been So Mistaken" -- WSJ Sept. 7, 2016)Credit: By Fred Barnes
